   LP
OPERATOR: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Amazon.com second quarter 2009 financial results teleconference. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. After the presentation, we will conduct a question-and-answer session. Today's call is being recorded.

For opening remarks, I will be turning the call over to the Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Rob Eldridge. Please go ahead.

   TD
ROB ELDRIDGE, VP OF IR, AMAZON.COM, INC.: Hello, and welcome to our Q2 2009 financial results conference call. Joining us today is Tom Szkutak, our CFO. As Jeff is traveling today, Tom and I will be available for Q&A.

The following discussion and responses to your questions reflect management's views as of today, July 23, 2009 only, will include forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially. Additional information about factors that could potentially impact our financial results is included in today's press release and our filings with the SEC, including our most recent annual report on Form 10-K.

As you listen to today's call, we encourage you to have our press release in front of you, which includes our financial results, as well as metrics and commentary on the quarter.

During the call, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. In our press release, slides accompanying this webcast, and our filings with the SEC, each of which is posted on our IR website, you'll find additional disclosures regarding these non-GAAP measures, including reconciliations of these measures with comparable GAAP measures.

Finally, unless otherwise stated, all comparisons in this call will be against our results from the comparable period of 2008. Now, I'll turn the call over to Tom.

TOM SZKUTAK, SVP AND CFO, AMAZON.COM, INC.: Thanks, Rob. I'll begin with comments on our financial results. Trailing 12-month free cash flow grew 89% to $1.54 billion. Return on invested capital is 42%, up from 29%. ROIC is trailing 12-month free cash flow, divided by average total assets, minus current liabilities, excluding the current portion of long-term debt over five quarter ends. The combination of common stock and stock-based awards outstanding was 451 million shares compared with 446 million.

Worldwide revenue grew 14% to $4.65 billion or 20%, excluding the $227 million unfavorable impact from year-over-year changes in foreign exchange rates. Media revenue increased to $2.44 billion, up 1%, or 7%, excluding foreign exchange rates. EGM revenue increased to $2.07 billion, up 35% or 41%, excluding FX. Worldwide EGM increased to 45% of worldwide sales, up from 38%. Worldwide unit growth was 28%. Active customer accounts exceeded 94 million, up 16%.

Worldwide active seller accounts were more than 1.7 million, up 21%. Seller units were 30% of total units. Worldwide gross profit was $1.13 billion, up 17%.

Now I'll discuss operating expenses, excluding stock-based compensation. Fulfillment, marketing, technology and content, and G&A combined was $829 million or 17.8% of sales, unchanged year-over-year. Fulfillment was (technical difficulty) [$389 million] or 8.4% of revenue, while tech and content was $253 million or 5.5% of revenue. Marketing was $124 million or 2.7% of revenue, up 23 basis points from the prior year.

Now I'll talk about our segment results. Consistent with prior periods, we cannot allocate the segments or stock-based compensation or other operating expense, income net line item.

In the North America segment, revenue grew 13% to $2.45 billion. Media revenue was flat at $1.15 billion, with declines in some categories, particularly video games and video game consoles, offset by growth in books.

EGM revenue grew 29% to $1.19 billion, representing 48% of North America revenues, up from 42%. Kindle sales continued to exceed our expectations, and we reduced the price of Kindle, the number one bestseller in our consumer electronics store to $299.

North American gross profit grew 20% to $672 million, and gross margin increased 161 basis points (technical difficulty) [to 27.4%], driven by increases in third-party product sales, improvement in inventory management, including vendor pricing, partially offset by lower prices for our customers and changes in product mix. North America segment operating income increased 30% to $125 million, a 5.1% operating margin.

In the International segment, revenue grew 16% to $2.2 billion. Revenue growth was 28% adjusted for the $221 million year-over-year unfavorable foreign exchange impact during the quarter.

Media revenue grew 3% to $1.29 billion or 12%, excluding FX. EGM revenue grew 45% to $882 million or 60%, excluding the impact of foreign exchange rates. EGM now represents 40% of International revenues, up from 32%.

International gross profit grew 13% to $461 million or grew 27%, excluding FX. While gross margin decreased 56 basis points to 20.9%, driven by lower prices for our customers and changes in product mix, partially offset by improvements in inventory management, including vendor pricing and increases in 3P product sales.

International segment operating income increased 20% to $179 million, and 8.1% operating margin. Excluding the unfavorable impact from foreign exchange rates, International segment operating income increased 43%.

CSOI grew 24% to $304 million or 6.5% of revenue, up 51 basis points year-over-year. Excluding the $30 million unfavorable impact from foreign exchange rates, CSOI grew 37%.

Unlike CSOI, our GAAP operating income includes stock-based compensation expense and other operating expense income. GAAP operating income fell 27% to $159 million or 3.4% of net sales. Second quarter 2009 operating income including the impact of our settlement with Toys 'R' Us for $51 million, substantially all of which was expensed during the quarter. A one-time payment from Amazon.com will take place in third quarter 2009.

Additionally, included in the second quarter of 2008 GAAP operating income was a $53 million non-cash gain recognized on the sale of our European DVD rental assets.

Our income tax expense was $39 million in Q2 or a 22% rate for the quarter. GAAP net income was $142 million or $0.32 per diluted share compared with $158 million and $0.37 per diluted share.

Turning to the balance sheet -- cash and marketable securities increased $831 million year-over-year to $3.21 billion. Our cash and marketable securities primarily consists of cash, government, and government agencies securities, AAA rated money market funds and other investment-grade securities. Such amounts are recorded at fair value.

Inventory increased 20% to $1.32 billion, and inventory turns decreased to 12.4 from 13.0 a year ago, as we expanded selection, improved in-stock levels, and introduced new product categories.

Accounts payable increased 28% to $2.51 billion, and accounts payable days increased to 65 from 58 in the prior year. Our investment in net fixed assets increased $330 million from a year ago to $981 million. Our Q2 2009 capital expenditures was $78 million.

Yesterday, we announced the acquisition of Zappos. Zappos is a customer-focused company. We see great opportunities for both companies to learn from each other and create even better experiences for our customers.

I'll conclude my portion of today's call with guidance. Incorporated into our guidance are the order trends that we've seen to date and what we believe to date to be appropriately conservative assumptions. Our results are inherently unpredictable and may be materially affected by many factors, including a high level of uncertainty surrounding exchange rate fluctuations, as well as the global economy and consumer spending. It's not possible to accurately predict demand, and therefore, our actual results could differ materially from our guidance.

As we describe in more detail in our public filings, issues such as settling inter-company balances and foreign currencies among subsidiaries, unfavorable resolution of legal matters, and changes to our effective tax rates, can all have a material effect on guidance.

Our guidance excludes Zappos' financial result and assumes that we don't conclude any additional business acquisitions or investments, record any further revisions to stock-based compensation estimates, and that foreign exchange rates remain approximately where they've been recently.

For Q3, we expect net sales of between $4.75 billion and $5.25 billion, a growth of between 11% and 23%. This guidance anticipates approximately 150 basis points of negative impact from foreign exchange rates; GAAP operating income to be between $120 million and $210 million, or between 22% decline and 36% growth. This includes approximately $95 million for stock-based compensation and amortization of intangible assets.

We anticipate consolidated segment operating income, which excludes stock-based compensation and other operating expense to be between [$215 million] and $305 million, or between 7% decline and 32% growth.

We anticipate our free cash flow growth rate to trend similar to our operating profit growth rate over time, with some variability, including from changes in working capital and excess tax benefits from stock-based compensation.

We remain heads-down focused on driving a better customer experience through price, selection, and convenience. We believe putting customers first is the only reliable way to create lasting value for shareholders.

Thanks, and with that, Rob, let's move to questions.

ROB ELDRIDGE: Great. Thanks, Tom. Let's move on to the Q&A portion of the call. Operator, will you please remind our listeners how to initiate a question.

OPERATOR: (Operator Instructions). Mark Mahaney, Citi.

MARK MAHANEY, ANALYST, CITIGROUP: Great. I'd like to ask about the North American trends, particularly gross margins and media sales, and to what extent there's a link there. Last quarter, you had a pretty positive gross margin trend. You repeated it this quarter; but last quarter, it seemed to be because of some access to -- unusual access to inventory.

Was that effect still in place in the second quarter? Or is there something going on in terms of the mix shift within media sales towards digital products, that's really boosting those gross margins? Thank you.

TOM SZKUTAK: Thanks, Mark. I'll start with the gross margin question. We saw, in North America and in International, we saw very solid 3P product sales. So, 3P is certainly impacting margins.

We had very good execution on a lot of other areas, including inventory management. We had very good pricing with our suppliers, which is offset partially, certainly, by lower prices for our customers as well as product mix. So that's really what's driving the gross margins.

In terms of the North America media growth, we saw -- just as a reminder, I mentioned on the last call, we had very strong revenue growth Q2 of last year -- which includes, if you look at it versus really any other quarter, over the past several quarters, it's our strongest quarter -- including the growth that we saw in North American media, which was up 25%.

And we had some declines in some categories, particularly video games and consoles. Video games and consoles are very, very strong last year. And we had both console growth and video games themselves seeing strong growth. Three of our four best releases of last year were released during Q2, including We Fit.

And so, that was included in our Q2 last year, and was driving the growth last year, and we're overlapping that. And so what you're really seeing is an industry slowdown in video games and consoles.

And then we had books growth offsetting that decrease. So, those are the factors that were included in there.

And just another note. On the video games, even though we saw a decline, we're actually very happy with that category. We have added a lot of selection since last year. We've -- our in-stock levels improved dramatically from last year, and there's a number of other things the team has done to make that customer experience even better.

So we're very pleased with the customer experience we're providing there, and what we're seeing is an industry slowdown, which we saw the effect of that in our growth rates.

OPERATOR: Jeetil Patel, Deutsche Bank Securities.

JEETIL PATEL, ANALYST, DEUTSCHE BANK SECURITIES: A couple of questions. As you look at Fulfillment by Amazon, I guess can you talk a little bit more about the impact you're seeing from FBA on the businesses, in the form of just margin contribution? Is it in the form of unit growth? Or just a pickup in customer growth? I guess, a little bit more on how FBA so far is influencing the business or affecting the business.

Second, if you look at Prime internationally, I guess, is Prime internationally helping to drive kind of the same behavior trends by region in the UK, German, and Japanese markets as you rolled it out? And you've been in there for about a year and a half to two years now?

TOM SZKUTAK: Those two programs specifically we're extremely pleased with. Prime, on a global basis, is doing very well. And in International, we're seeing -- we are seeing very similar trends to what we saw when we launched in the US. It's been very successful for us.

When you look at our international growth rate, up 28% year-over-year on a local currency basis, and that's with -- actually, if you look compared to Q2, you saw 20% growth rate as well in Q2, but we had a favorable comparison with the Easter holiday and an unfavorable comparison in 2Q. So, we had very strong growth rate and certainly Prime is helping that growth rate.

In terms of FBA, there's not a lot in terms of specifics from a margin standpoint I can provide today; but Prime is growing very well and it's certainly impacting our third-party growth. And our third-party growth from a units perspective is 30% as a percentage of total units, which was up by year-over-year, again, in Q2. So we're pleased with the growth rate and certainly FBA is [kind of] contributing to that.

JEETIL PATEL: Is the biggest influence on units or customers?

ROB ELDRIDGE: Customer adds.

TOM SZKUTAK: There's not a lot I can add to that. I apologize.

OPERATOR: Mary Meeker, Morgan Stanley.

MARY MEEKER, ANALYST, MORGAN STANLEY: Scott and I had a couple questions. First, to extend on Mark Mahaney's question a little bit -- are you -- you said, in effect, you're not really seeing a slowdown in your media business from any digital transitions that are taking place in music or video. So that's sort of a question.

And another question is, your EGM business is doing extremely well. Can you correlate any of the things that are going on with digital media transitions with upticks in your products that play those products, if you will?

And then on mobile, and a question for Jeff, we are seeing tremendous e-commerce momentum in other parts of the world. And we have -- we're starting to see it in the US, you have a great app for Amazon on the iPhone. You have a great Kindle app, you have a great Stanza app. Is it your view that mobile can be a material portion of Amazon's revenue in the next few years?

TOM SZKUTAK: I'll take the media one first. Certainly, there's industry -- there's some certainly slowness in some of the media categories. And we're seeing some of that slowness reflected in the North America results that you see.

But in terms of what's happened recently, from a trend standpoint, it's clearly the challenging pair that we had versus last year, as well as the video games impact that I mentioned.

In terms of digital, it's still very early. And we're very pleased with what we're seeing in terms of growth of our various digital products that we offer -- text, video, and music. But it's still very early and we're seeing very good unit growth there. And we're very pleased with what we see there.

From an EGM perspective, there's not a lot I can give you in terms of the individual growth rates of some of those items that you mentioned, but we're seeing very good broad-based growth within EGM. We did see some slowness to some of the higher selling priced items, but outside of that, we're very pleased with what we're seeing. Overall unit growth globally remains very strong. So we're very pleased with that.

In terms of mobile, it's a great question. And I apologize, Mary, Jeff is not on the call today. He's traveling and just from a scheduling standpoint, it didn't work. But again, it's -- we certainly think that mobile is an opportunity. As you mentioned, there is a number of applications that we have. We're going to continue to innovate in that space, and it's difficult to say how big that could be over time, but it's certainly something that we're excited about and we're investing in.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: And Tom, this is Scott. I had just one follow up, if I could. The operating margin guidance that you gave, the midpoint was 5.2%. And this quarter, in the second quarter, the midpoint of your guidance was 5.3%; you did 6.5%, which is the highest operating margin since the third quarter of '05.

So I understand there's some one-time dynamics going on in the industry right now, but you didn't have great visibility to that over-performance in Q2, and I was just wondering if you could speak a little bit to the conservativism in the midpoint of your operating income in 3Q. Thanks.

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. Scott, we gave guidance of 215 to 305 from a CSOI perspective, which is implied -- operating margin of 4.5% to 5.8%. So from the upper end of the guidance, at 5.8%, that's about 40 basis points above last year. And so, again, that reflects the right range for the quarter.

One thing to keep in mind, though, is as you look at Q2 to Q3 -- those numbers I was just talking about was the absolute and then comparing them year-over-year -- when you look at sequentially from Q2 to Q3, keep in mind that Q3 historically is a quarter that we're getting ready for our largest seasonal quarter, Q4. And so there's certainly expenses that are included in that quarter to get ready for, for example, adding additional capacity.

And certainly with the growth that we've seen, particularly in international, we are adding capacity to get ready for Q4. So that's reflected in our Q3 guidance. And it's typical at this time [to that] based on getting ready for Q4. So again, that's why you saw -- one of the reasons why you saw a decline last year as well.

OPERATOR: (Operator Instructions). James Mitchell, Goldman Sachs.

JAMES MITCHELL, ANALYST, GOLDMAN SACHS: Great. Thanks for taking the question. It looks like your sales and marketing costs picked up a little bit as a percentage of revenue, both quarter-on-quarter and year-on-year. Could you talk about what's going on behind that? And also if you could just discuss your effective tax rate. Thank you.

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. From a marketing perspective, it was 2.7% of revenue. The range over the past several quarters have been in the low 2's -- 2.2%, I believe, to 2.7%. So it was a little bit on the higher end of the range. But again, I wouldn't read too much into that. It's just based on the opportunities that we saw within the quarter, looking at new customer acquisitions. So again, I don't think there's anything really meaningful to talk about there.

In terms of effective tax rate, the way I'm thinking about it is if you look at the effective tax rate for the half, it's a little bit over 25%. Keep in mind that we had a one-time item, Toys 'R' Us, which was $51 million; substantially all of that would be in that number, which is tax affected at the US tax rate. So that's bringing it down a bit. It's a one-time event. So if you back that out, the tax rate would be a little bit higher than that, which would reflect essentially the projection for the year.

OPERATOR: Imran Khan, JPMorgan.

IMRAN KHAN, ANALYST, JPMORGAN: Thank you for taking my questions. Two questions -- I think in the past, you talked about how you are not seeing cannibalization from Kindle. I think you talked about like how average Kindle owners are buying 1.8 books. Can you give us an update on that number? What kind of trend you're seeing now that you have a larger Kindle owner.

And secondly, I think, Tom, you talked about that you're seeing healthy growth in the third-party international business, but international gross profit margins, I believe, was down on a year-over-year basis, roughly 50 basis points. So could you give us some color to understand that, why? Thank you.

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. I'll take the third-party first, for International.

What you're seeing there is we are actually -- we did actually see very good third-party growth in International. One thing to keep in mind as we look at our overall growth rates in international, we saw extremely strong EGM growth accelerated to 60% year-over-year on a local currency basis.

Many of those categories, if you look back over the past few years, we've launched a number of new categories in EGM and international. And when we launch new categories, oftentimes the gross margins are lower, again, as we're starting out in those categories. So that's reflecting the product mix.

But if you look at our overall International gross margins, we certainly saw strong third-party growth -- very good vendor management, very good inventory management -- but certainly partially offset by the mix that I'm talking about as well as lower prices for customers.

In terms of the Kindle units, we're not doing any updates in terms of the units, in terms of specific numbers today. But we're seeing very, very good growth and we're extremely happy with the growth that we're seeing there, and it's exceeding our expectations.

OPERATOR: Gene Munster, Piper Jaffray.

GENE MUNSTER, ANALYST, PIPER JAFFRAY & CO.: There's been a lot of talk about that tax rate and some third-party affiliates and the impact, and some of the jockeying around where taxes ultimately go in terms of sales tax. Can you give us how just generally you think about the sales tax question over the next several years?

TOM SZKUTAK: It's one of these where we've been working for quite a few years with the states just on the streamlined sales tax act. Beyond that, it's really hard to comment on what will happen going forward.

I think it's important to remember that more than 50% of our business is conducted in areas where consumption tax, the VAT tax through the equivalent of sales tax, are taking place are international geographies. And we now collect sales taxes in five states in the United States. So, we have very strong businesses in our international business, as you can see from today's results.

GENE MUNSTER: Okay. So do you think ultimately that sales tax will be part of -- as a 100% of sales in the next five years, say?

TOM SZKUTAK: Yes -- you can't speculate what will happen going forward.

OPERATOR: Justin Post, Merrill Lynch.

JUSTIN POST, ANALYST, BAS-ML: A couple of things. First, on the media sales decline. When you think longer-term, do you think you might see some pressure on revenues, but the overall gross margins per unit hang in there because of digitization? And could you actually see a margin improvement offset maybe lower prices for in-sales?

And then secondly, tech and content looks like it ticked up $24 million quarter-over-quarter. Wonder if you had any comments you could share with us on maybe where you're allocating that money. Thank you.

TOM SZKUTAK: You know, the way I think about the gross margins for our digital businesses, if you look at our overall digital business, it's very early. Think of it that we're investing, in the investing mode. And over time, we think that we can get very good returns for shareholders. And we think that there's a lot of room for us and content owners and publishers to do well there. We think that those are -- that we'll get good returns over time.

In terms of tech and content, there's a number of things that are going in there. You can see from our employment numbers that the growth is approximately 14% year-over-year. It slowed from past quarters, but we did still see a sequential increase of about 400 people. Some of those people are certainly going to tech and content, investing in areas like digital and Web services and other areas, which is certainly -- are reflected in the tech and content costs.

OPERATOR: Doug Anmuth, Barclays.

DOUG ANMUTH, ANALYST, BARCLAYS CAPITAL: Thanks for taking my question. Tom, can you comment on the unearned revenues line? And in particular, it looks like you've had a very good, consistent trend there over the last several quarters, which I believe is probably fueled by Prime and the Kindle. And you said that you're pretty comfortable with where both of those products are; but basically, we're seeing from 1Q to 2Q, a flat number in unearned revenue. So if you could provide some clarity on that, I'd appreciate it. Thanks.

TOM SZKUTAK: Yes, there is a number of things that go in there, including the items that you mentioned. We do amortize the sale of Kindles over two years in the month following the sale.

We are amortizing the Prime subscriptions. There's also other partner relationships, revenues that go into that line -- some amortization. And beyond that, it does bounce around a bit, as you see from the trend. But beyond that, there's not a lot I can add from a [call-up] perspective.

DOUG ANMUTH: But you mentioned earlier just that you were -- that Prime growth was pretty good. I mean, is there any reason to think that there's any slowdown here in terms of new members coming onboard?

TOM SZKUTAK: No. No, in fact, Prime growth is very strong. And obviously, from our other discussions, Kindle growth is very strong. So, no, we're seeing strong growth in both areas.

OPERATOR: Youssef Squali, Jefferies & Company.

YOUSSEF SQUALI, ANALYST, JEFFERIES & COMPANY: Two quick questions, Tom. You've lowered prices on Kindle, on Kindle 2. How should we be thinking about the driving force there? Did you get enough cost scale to still keep margins relatively unchanged? Or did you lower price really to just increase penetration?

And secondarily, on the affiliate question, as you pulled back out of certain states -- so, I think North Carolina, Rhode Island, and a few others -- are you using other affiliates in other states? Or are you moving some of that money to other ROI channels, like Search, et cetera? And which one has better ROI? Thanks.

TOM SZKUTAK: Yes, we use a number of different channels on the marketing side. And we're just looking at what's the most effective way to make that spend and where do we think it drives incremental value to shareholders over time. And so that's not something new.

There's no change there from that perspective. And we use a number of different channels. From a pay channel perspective, we also have our Associates channel as well. So there's not a lot new there from that perspective.

And then your other question -- in terms of Kindle (multiple speakers) -- price change, we certainly are getting better economies, and given the growth in Kindle devices, and we think that that's an appropriate price for customers. And we think that it's certainly helpful, given the growth that we're seeing.

OPERATOR: Jeffrey Lindsay, Sanford Bernstein.

JEFFREY LINDSAY, ANALYST, SANFORD C. BERNSTEIN & COMPANY, INC.: Thanks for taking my question. Two things -- could we ask -- could you give us any sense of whether Zappos is going to be dilutive or accretive to earnings? And could you give us a sense of the post-merger integration planning for that acquisition? And how we should think about it going forward, particularly if it is going to be dilutive to earnings?

And then second, could you tell us have you any plans to take Kindle overseas? Thank you.

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. In terms of Zappos, we're extremely pleased with the announcement that we made yesterday. And we're not discussing the dilutive or accretive nature of Zappos.

I guess the way you should think about it is this -- they had approximately $635 million worth of revenue last year. They had a small profit. And that would certainly be before any of the acquisition costs, which include intangible amortization as well as stock-based compensation, which would be post-acquisition.

But we're -- in terms of integration, the way you should think about it is it's going to be a standalone business. We're very, very excited about the value that they bring to customers. It's very unique. We're very excited about helping that team build brand. And we think it's a unique brand and culture, and this will be a great fit with Amazon.

We think that we can grow -- it's a great way to grow our overall shoe and apparel business. So we're very excited about it. And we've got a great team there -- overall team; a great leadership team. And we're extremely happy to be able to make the announcement yesterday.

JEFFREY LINDSAY: And then in terms of (multiple speakers) -- are you taking it overseas?

TOM SZKUTAK: The last part? (multiple speakers) International. In terms of Kindle International, it's certainly an opportunity. Our customers have certainly expressed it's an interest. And we have a long-standing practice of not talking about what we might do, but certainly, it's clearly an opportunity.

OPERATOR: Spencer Wang, Credit Suisse.

SPENCER WANG, ANALYST, CREDIT SUISSE: Just have a follow up question regarding Zappos. Tom, could you just talk a little bit more about just the strategic rationale behind Zappos? Leaving it as an independent brand and company, it's a little bit of a departure, I think, in terms of how you've historically grown your business under the Amazon brand.

And then secondarily, as part of that, even though it's going to be an independent unit within Amazon, are there any cost savings that we should be expecting from a -- maybe a Fulfillment perspective? Any clarity on that would be great. Thank you.

TOM SZKUTAK: It's -- actually, the way we're thinking about it is this -- we have Zappos and 6pm, which will join us. We have shopbop; we have Endless; and we certainly have Amazon.com -- all selling in softlines, in shoes and apparel. So we're very, very excited to have all those websites with -- if you take a look at those websites, they have many different brands. They have different customers. They have a different customer experience associated with each of them.

So we're very excited to have all those. And from our standpoint, we're looking to learn from each other. And we think that those categories are very interesting. And we think there's a lot of growth opportunity, and that's why we're doing that.

So this is not an acquisition that we're talking about -- you mentioned synergies; certainly, we'll be smart about it. If there's fulfillment centers that -- a fulfillment center that they have, if they have additional space, we'll certainly look to use that. Or if we have additional space that Zappos can use, we certainly will look at those opportunities.

But this is not about synergies. This is about growing in categories that we think are very interesting. And so we're very excited about it.

I'd also add that this really isn't that much of a departure at all -- or is not a departure at all. We've done a number of acquisitions over time -- shopbop, as I mentioned, is one of those; is an acquisition we did about three years ago, in the same similar categories, certainly in the softlines. It's more of an apparel -- fashion for women's apparel and shoes website and accessories.

And so we've also done a number of acquisitions; as we look at some of our country launches -- the last one was joyo.com, was our launch in China. So again, we've done a number of these. Our strategy, as it relates to acquisitions, hasn't changed; it's the same it's been for several years now. And again, we saw it was a great fit and we're really pleased to be able to make the announcement yesterday.

OPERATOR: Sandeep Aggarwal, Collins Stewart.

SANDEEP AGGARWAL, ANALYST, COLLINS STEWART: Thanks for taking my question. Tom, as eBay continues to transform its marketplace, what does that mean for Amazon?

I know you already talked about Prime membership doing very well, but, I guess, are you seeing any signs of weakness in the new enrollment of Prime membership or any visible changes in the growth of third-party merchant enrollment?

TOM SZKUTAK: We have a long-standing practice of not talking about other companies; but in terms of our seller business, we had our -- as I mentioned, third-party units were 30% -- percentage of total units, which is up over last year.

Our sellers grew 21%, which is the fastest growth rate we've seen. In Q2, it's the fastest growth rate we've seen in many quarters. And our seller team has continued to focus on how to make it, that customer experience for our sellers, as good as it possibly can be.

FBA is an example of that. It's a great example where we provide services for sellers. It's great for customers, because they get to get sellers the use of our multi-node fulfillment network, which allows them to get shipments using our Super-Saver Shipping and Prime programs.

And so, again, our seller team is continuously focused on trying to make that experience better. And that's reflected in the metrics that you saw today that I mentioned, as well as the gross profit growth that we mentioned earlier as well.

OPERATOR: Ben Schachter, Broadpoint AmTech.

BEN SCHACHTER, ANALYST, BROADPOINT AMTECH: I was wondering if you could discuss the private label that you're creating for some products and just discuss the strategic value there, and any issues that that may bring up with some of the 3P partners. And then also any update you may have on your used videogame efforts. Thanks.

TOM SZKUTAK: You know, we experiment in a number of different areas. And we do have a small amount of private label product. I don't think there's a lot to talk to, but again, there's -- we're certainly doing some. And we'll see what traction we get there.

In the used videogame, that's something -- certainly it's one of the things -- when you look at our total customer experience for video games, the team, again, as I mentioned, has done a great job of improving the customer experience over the past few years. And that's just another example of one of the things that they've done.

OPERATOR: Jim Friedland, Cowen and Company.

JIM FRIEDLAND, ANALYST, COWEN AND COMPANY: Looking at the other line in North America sequentially, it showed some pretty good growth. And I was wondering, did that come from any of the cloud computing services? Are you seeing momentum there? Or is that driven by marketing fees or something in that area?

TOM SZKUTAK: There's a number of things that are going on there, but certainly, our Web services business is growing very nicely for us. And that's reflected in those numbers.

OPERATOR: Heath Terry, FBR Capital Markets.

HEATH TERRY, ANALYST, FRIEDMAN, BILLINGS, RAMSEY GROUP, INC.: You just mentioned that the Web services business is growing nicely. Can you give us an idea of which, if any, if there are any specific segments of the Web services business that are performing particularly well? And when -- looking at those on a standalone basis, where would you suggest we focus in terms of which ones you feel like have the most potential long-term to really contribute?

ROB ELDRIDGE: It's Rob here, Heath. How are you doing? (multiple speakers) We don't go down into specific service-related financials in this market, as you well know. But we're very, very happy with EC2, S3, Simple Database, the entire suite of services. And we've been in the market now for three-plus years with our paying customers, trying to deliver reliable, scalable, fast, flexible, responsive solutions to our developer base. And we're going to continue to go do that.

ROB ELDRIDGE: Great. Well, thank you very much for joining us on the call today and for your questions. A replay will be available on our Investor Relations website at least through the end of the quarter. We appreciate your interest and look forward to talking with you again next quarter. Thank you.

 Q1  2009  Amazon .com, Inc. Earnings Conference Call - Final

   LP
OPERATOR: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Amazon.com first-quarter 2009 financial results teleconference. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. After the presentation, we will conduct a question-and-answer session. Today's call is being recorded.

For opening remarks, I will now be turning the conference over to the Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Rob Eldridge. Please go ahead, sir.

   TD
ROB ELDRIDGE, VP OF IR, AMAZON.COM, INC.: Hello and welcome to our Q1 '09 financial results conference call. Joining us today is Tom Szkutak, our CFO. Jeff Bezos, our Founder and CEO, and Tom will both be available for Q&A.

The following discussion and responses to your questions reflect management's views as of today, April 23, 2009, only, and will include forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially. Additional information about factors that could potentially impact our financial results is included in today's press release and our filings with the SEC, including our most recent Annual Report on Form 10-K.

As you listen to today's call, we encourage you to have our press release in front of you, which includes our financial results, as well as metrics and commentary on the quarter.

During this call, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. In our press release, slides accompanying this webcast and our filings with the SEC, each of which is posted on our IR website, you will find additional disclosures regarding these non-GAAP measures, including reconciliations of these measures with comparable GAAP measures.

Finally, unless otherwise stated, all comparisons in this call will be against our results for the comparable period of 2008.

Now I will turn the call over to Tom.

TOM SZKUTAK, SVP AND CFO, AMAZON.COM, INC.: Thanks, Rob. I will begin with comments on our financial results. Trailing 12-month free cash flow grew 82% to $1.43 billion. Return on invested capital was 41%, up from 32%. ROIC is trailing 12-month free cash flow divided by average total assets, minus current liabilities, excluding the current portion of long-term debt over five quarter ends.

The combination of common stock and stock-based awards outstanding was 447 million shares compared with 435 million.

Worldwide revenue grew 18% to $4.89 billion or 25% excluding the $268 million unfavorable impact from year-over-year changes in foreign exchange rates.

Media revenue increased to $2.72 billion, up 7%, or 13% excluding foreign exchange. EGM revenue increased to $2.05 billion, up 38%, or 46% excluding FX. Worldwide EGM increased to 42% of worldwide sales, up from 36%. Worldwide unit growth was 30%. Active customer accounts exceeded 91 million, up 16%. Worldwide active seller accounts were more than $1.6 million, up 19%. Seller units were 32% of total units versus 30%.

Worldwide gross profit was $1.15 billion, up 20%.

Now we will discuss operating expenses excluding stock-based compensation. Fulfillment, marketing, technology and content and G&A combined was $826 million or 16.9% of sales, unchanged year over year. Fulfillment was $407 million or 8.3% of revenue, while tech and content was $239 million or 4.9% of revenue. Both were unchanged from the prior year. Marketing was $124 million or 2.5% of revenue, up 11 basis points from the prior year.

Now I will talk about our segment results. And consistent with prior periods, we do not allocate to segments our stock-based compensation or the other operating expense (income), net line item.

In the North America segment, revenue grew 21% to $2.58 billion. Media revenue grew 8% to $1.31 billion. EGM grew 42% to $1.17 billion, representing 45% of North America revenues, up from 39%. North America gross profit grew 22% to $694 million, and gross margin increased 18 basis points to 26.9%, driven by improvements in inventory management, including vendor pricing and the increase in the 3P product sales, partially offset by lower prices for our customers and changes in product mix.

North America segment operating income increased 15% to $150 million, a 5.8% operating margin.

In the international segment, revenue grew 15% to $2.31 billion. Revenue growth was 28%, adjusting for the $258 million year-over-year unfavorable impact from foreign exchange rates during the quarter. Media revenue grew 6% to $1.42 billion or 17% excluding FX. And EGM revenue grew 34% to $874 million or 50% excluding the impact of foreign exchange rates.

EGM now represents 38% of international revenues, up from 33%.

International gross profit grew 17% to $454 million or grew 33% excluding foreign exchange rates, while gross margin increased 36 basis points to 19.6%, driven by improvements in inventory management, including vendor pricing, and increases in 3P product sales, partially offset by lower prices for our customers and changes in product mix.

International segment operating income increased 34% to $172 million, a 7.4% operating margin. Excluding the unfavorable impact from FX, international segment operating income increased 63%. CSOI grew 25% to $322 million or 6.6% of revenue, up 33 basis points year over year. Excluding the $32 million unfavorable impact from foreign exchange rates, CSOI grew 37%.

Unlike CSOI, our GAAP operating income includes stock-based compensation expense and other operating expense/income. GAAP operating income grew 23% to $244 million or 5% of net sales.

Our income tax expense was $69 million in Q1 or a 28% rate for the quarter. GAAP net income was $177 million or $0.41 per diluted share compared with $143 million and $0.34 per diluted share.

Turning to the balance sheet, cash and marketable securities increased $579 million year over year to $2.73 billion. Our cash and marketable securities primarily consist of cash, government and government agency securities, AAA-rated money market funds and other investment-grade securities. Such amounts are recorded at fair value.

During the quarter, we redeemed the remaining EUR240 million, $319 million based on the euro to US dollar exchange rate at the date of redemption and principal, of our 6.875% peaks.

Inventory increased 18% to $1.27 billion and inventory turns were 12.5, down 0.5 turns from the prior year, as we expanded selection, improved in-stock levels and introduced new product categories.

Accounts payable increased 28% to $2.38 billion, and accounts payable days increased to 57 from 53 in the prior year. Our investment in net fixed assets increased $295 million from a year ago to $889 million. Our Q1 2009 capital expenditures were $55 million.

I will conclude my portion of today's call with guidance. Incorporated into our guidance are the order trends that we have seen to date and what we believe today to be appropriately conservative assumptions. Our results are inherently unpredictable and may be materially affected by many factors, including a high level of uncertainties surrounding exchange rate fluctuations, as well as the global economy and consumer spending.

It is not possible to accurately predict demand, and therefore our actual results could differ materially from our guidance. As we describe in more detail in our public filings, issues such as settling intercompany balances in foreign currencies among our subsidiaries, unfavorable resolution of legal matters, and changes to our effective tax rates can all have a material effect on guidance.

Our guidance assumes that we don't conclude any additional business acquisitions or investments, record any further revisions to stock-based compensation estimates, and that foreign exchange rates remain approximately where they have been recently.

For Q2, we expect net sales of between $4.3 billion and $4.75 billion, or growth between 6% and 17%. This guidance anticipates approximately 700 basis points of negative impact from foreign exchange.

GAAP operating income to be between $110 million and $190 million or a decline between 49% and 12%. The second-quarter 2008 results include the $53 million noncash gain recognized on the sale of the Company's European DVD rental assets. This includes approximately $90 million for stock-based compensation and amortization of intangible assets.

We anticipate consolidated segment operating income, which excludes stock-based compensation and other operating expense, to be between $200 million and $280 million or between 18% decline and 14% growth. We anticipate our free cash flow growth rate to trend similar to our operating profit growth rate over time, with some variability, including some changes in working capital and excess tax benefits from stock-based compensation.

We remain heads-down focused on driving a better customer experience through price, selection and convenience. We believe putting customers first is the only reliable way to create lasting value for shareholders.

Thanks, and with that, Rob, let's move to questions.

ROB ELDRIDGE: Great. Thanks, Tom. Let's move on to the Q&A portion of the call with Jeff and Tom. Operator, will you please remind our listeners how to initiate a question?

OPERATOR: (Operator Instructions). Doug Anmuth, Barclays Capital.

DOUG ANMUTH, ANALYST, BARCLAYS CAPITAL: Great quarter. Can you talk a little bit more about the 2Q guidance? And in particular, is there something that you're seeing early in the quarter that is making the outlook look a little bit lower than we would have expected versus the 1Q numbers, particularly on the margin side? Thank you.

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. Our guidance from a revenue standpoint is growth of 6% to 17%. That's on a dollar basis. On a local currency basis, that works out to be 13% to 24%. A few things to keep in mind. One, last year, Q2 was our strongest growth quarter. So if you take a look at the splits by quarter, last year we had 41% growth rate in Q2, or 35% growth rate on a local currency basis, or overlapping that growth rate, again, the strongest quarter.

A couple other things to keep in mind on the top line as well, smaller impacts, but certainly Easter was in Q1 last year. It was in Q2 this year. So we had that benefit in Q1, and we will be overlapping that in Q2. Also, as I mentioned, from an exchange standpoint, the 700 basis points is more than we saw in Q1. So again, those are the impacts from the top line.

So that is why the high end of the range, if you will, works out to be 24%, which is a little bit lower than we came in for Q1. So that translates down into, obviously, a lower operating income. The other thing to keep in mind, too, is as you look at our Q2, seasonally Q2 is our lowest quarter from a revenue perspective, which means with that top line, you get a little bit less leverage in particularly the fixed operating costs. So that is reflected in the guidance.

OPERATOR: James Mitchell, Goldman Sachs.

JAMES MITCHELL, ANALYST, GOLDMAN SACHS: Great. Thank you for taking the question, which is about the improvement in gross margin year on year in the first quarter. Were there any unusual gross margin influences other than our old friends, inventory management and third-party mix, EGM mix and lower prices?

TOM SZKUTAK: No. Those are the big pieces. Certainly inventory management, we worked well with vendors in terms of getting vendor savings. An example would be something we have been working on for a number of quarters, but certainly working with them to ship when they have shipments to ship in bulk to the nearest fulfillment center. The benefit of that is they get -- this is a way to share some of those savings of them shipping to the closest facility, and then we get to optimize taking that larger bulk shipment and optimizing that in our network. So things like that, but certainly inventory management, vendor savings and also third-party growth were certainly key factors. And those were partially offset by lower prices to customers.

JAMES MITCHELL: Are digital sales an impact or not?

TOM SZKUTAK: Well, digital sales, as you can -- you are referring to Kindle sales or all digital or--? I mean, digital is certainly part of the numbers. Keep in mind as you think about Kindle specifically from a device standpoint, we recognize that in the month following shipment over a two-year period. We amortize that over a two-year period.

OPERATOR: Jeetil Patel, Deutsche Bank.

JEETIL PATEL, ANALYST, DEUTSCHE BANK: Two questions. First of all, it's probably hard to break out, but I guess maybe a qualitative view. But I'm just curious how much of your core infrastructure that you have been building over the last couple years is being redeployed in other business initiatives, such as FBA and AWS, that are maybe contributing to the operating profit line. I guess is there any way to quantify that, what the contribution looks like to CSOI, at the end of the day, some of your newer initiatives in terms of leveraging the fixed assets and costs that you've built out over the years?

Second question is, I guess, can you characterize how much downsizing and retrenching that online and offline retailers are doing out there in the landscape is impacting your business positively or in general as it relates to as you kind of go after customers or consumers, as well as just talking to your suppliers? Thank you.

TOM SZKUTAK: The first part of your question, just to maybe talk to how we think about the overall infrastructure, both from an operations as well as infrastructure capacity standpoint, the retail part of our business, you know, we plan for peak. And so when you think about, say, fulfillment capacity, we are certainly planning for peak, which, again, is in December. Our infrastructure capacity that supports our retail business, we also plan for peak as well.

And so some of the things that you are seeing with FBA, as well as Web Services, we are not looking at it as a way to use our existing infrastructure. We are looking at them as separate, separately standing businesses, if you will. And we look at the economics that way as well.

So I don't know if that is helpful. So it is hard to tease apart -- to answer your question. And then the second part, could you repeat the second part of the question, Jeetil? Sorry.

JEETIL PATEL: (technical difficulty) is having for you guys in terms of talking to consumers and talking to your suppliers?

TOM SZKUTAK: Could you repeat that? I apologize. I couldn't hear you.

JEETIL PATEL: Yes, just trying to understand whether online and offline retailers, as they shrink their business, kind of grow spending out there, how much of an impact is that having or opportunity is that as you go after customers, as well as go after better supplier terms out there?

TOM SZKUTAK: Yes, I apologize. I don't think I can help you much with that one. I would just add to the first one that we use the same -- so, for example, with Fulfillment by Amazon, the Fulfillment by Amazon inventory is commingled with our Amazon-owned inventory in the same fulfillment centers. So in that respect, we're leveraging those fixed investments. But we are not -- there's not excess capacity that we can -- we are building new capacity, both for Amazon-owned inventory and new capacity for FBA. But it is commingled inventory.

Same thing for Web Services. When you look at our data centers, the Amazon Retail Services and the Web Services that we offer through infrastructure computing like EC2 and S3, those are commingled in the same data centers as well. So there you go.

OPERATOR: Mark Mahaney, Citi.

MARK MAHANEY, ANALYST, CITIGROUP: Jeff, in your shareholder letter you refer to muda, or waste, a Japanese word for waste. And you talk about being able to -- seeing it in a lot of different places and a lot of potential. Could you maybe bring it down to financial terms for us? And where do you think you have your best opportunity to get at that waste and where we would see it maybe show up, or are we already seeing it in terms of some of those CapEx efficiencies? CapEx spending seems to be nicely contained.

And then secondly, just on marketing spend, is there any particular reason why you're not seeing a little bit more efficiency in marketing spend, given what seems to be pretty clear deflationary trends in online display or search advertising? Thank you very much.

JEFF BEZOS, PRESIDENT, CEO AND CHAIRMAN, AMAZON.COM, INC.: Well, on the muda point, this is very encouraging for me and very energizing for me that everywhere we look, and every team here looks, when we look we find that we are doing every operation that we do in suboptimal ways. We have gotten better every year, but we still have a lot of progress that we can make. And that is encouraging, because it means we can get variable, we believe, we can get variable and fixed productivity for a long time to come.

So that is the opportunity. I don't know how to quantify that for you. We do have, every time we go through our planning process, we do set top-down targets for variable and fixed productivity, and we try to work towards those, make sure that we're being frugal and efficient so that we can have a cost structure that supports the customer experience we want to have, which is to have the lowest prices. So that is something we take very seriously, and as I said, very, very energizing for me to see how much opportunity there is there.

OPERATOR: Justin Post, Merrill Lynch.

JUSTIN POST, ANALYST, MERRILL LYNCH: A couple. Some people measure Google's paid clicks versus revenues as a measure of the recession impact. If I look at your revenues versus your units, 30% units, 25% revenues, is that 5% related to maybe ASPs, or is there a mix issue or shift going on?

And then two quick ones. Your shipping revenue was down 1% year over year. Does that have any indication on Prime adoption? And then the other revenue in the US, the growth slowed there. Were there some interesting things going on last year that maybe have stopped, and can we read anything into your Web Services adoption based on that number? Thank you.

TOM SZKUTAK: From a mix standpoint, the one thing that we are seeing certainly is higher-priced items are still growing, but certainly not growing as much as they were a few quarters ago. So that is really one of the impacts that you are seeing. Keep in mind when you look at our -- our business, given the selection that we have and the categories that we are in, you do see certainly some variation by quarter in terms of mix, just because the sheer amount of the selection that we have.

In terms of the shipping revenue, there is no question that we are seeing a good adoption in Prime, and it certainly -- and free shipping, and that is certainly impacting that revenue line item. That is a trend that you have been seeing, if you look back to prior quarters, that's something you have been seeing for awhile.

In terms of your last portion of the revenues, there is a number of things that goes in that line item, and as we have talked about in previous calls, that can tend to be a little lumpy from quarter to quarter. But again, there's a large number of things that go in there, as we've described in other quarters.

OPERATOR: (Operator Instructions). Scott Devitt, Morgan Stanley.

SCOTT DEVITT, ANALYST, MORGAN STANLEY: I just wanted to touch on vendor pricing again, if I could, and ask it a different way. I was wondering if you were seeing any significant differences by category possibly in areas where there's more significant retail disruption. And then also, if you could just comment on the sustainability of these vendor pricing improvements in all economic environments. I think, Tom, you mentioned getting product to different fulfillment centers. Does that seem sustainable? And I'm interested if, as well, if there's vendor pricing that is just driven by the general disruption in the channel and whether the relevance of the business model can sustain that as the economy improves. Thanks.

TOM SZKUTAK: I apologize. There's not a lot of help I can give you on the vendor pricing side. We continue to work with our partners in all of the categories that we are in geographically. Certainly the way you should think about it is, we think that there is room over time to work with our partners to get better prices over the long term. Certainly the categories that we have been in the longest, there's still opportunities. But when you think about magnitude in terms of basis points, I would think that there would be more opportunity in the categories that we have been in the shortest amount of time. That is the way I would think about it.

In terms of what it could look like going forward, we certainly had a healthy amount of savings in Q1, as reflected in the gross margins that you see. And what we believe is certainly reflected in our Q2 guidance. But we will continue to work over certainly a long period of time to continue to try to get better, work better with suppliers to get better savings.

OPERATOR: Jeffrey Lindsay, Sanford Bernstein.

JEFFREY LINDSAY, ANALYST, SANFORD BERNSTEIN: Could I ask two questions? First, did you have a specific push on Fulfillment by Amazon, or was that demand-driven? And then could you give us just an indication on margins on that business and where you are booking it exactly? Is it all going into other, or is it spread across the product categories?

TOM SZKUTAK: In terms of FBA, this is something that we have been doing for not long. But it's, again, over the last several quarters, and it has continued to build. I wouldn't call it any specific push. It's certainly something that we are offering to sellers. We think it is a very good experience for sellers so that they can take advantage of our multinode fulfillment network in the US and our fulfillment networks outside of the US.

So we think that that is a great opportunity. It comes in a number of different forms in terms of the revenue. Certainly the third-party revenue that you're seeing would come in the individual categories, which is certainly the largest piece. And obviously, we are recording the operating expense associated with those fulfillment services in our fulfillment line item.

JEFF BEZOS: I think I will add to that just to say that one of the things that is driving the uptake of Fulfillment by Amazon is that sellers have the opportunity to drive up their sales when they switch to Fulfillment by Amazon, in large part because of the interaction between Fulfillment by Amazon and Amazon Prime. So as soon as a seller switches to using Fulfillment by Amazon, all of their products become eligible for Amazon Prime just as if they were Amazon-owned items. So the interaction between those two programs is driving sales for sellers. And that is something, of course, that sellers want. I think that is, in large part, what is driving the uptake of Fulfillment by Amazon.

OPERATOR: Spencer Wang, Credit Suisse.

SPENCER WANG, ANALYST, CREDUT SUISSE: Wondering about the media line. That has been decelerating. Is there anything -- I know FX has impacted the international part. Is there anything going on there beyond just the maturation of the category?

Then on a related matter, as media as a category transitions to digital, could you, Jeff, maybe talk about Amazon VOD and how you plan on differentiating that going forward? Thanks.

JEFF BEZOS: If you take a look at our -- you mentioned the international media, I think was the first part. (multiple speakers) growth in general. We saw -- in North America, we saw an 8% growth, which is consistent with what we saw in Q4. Q4 was just slightly less than that, plus 7%. And then in international, on a local currency basis, it was up 17%, which was down a little bit from Q3. It was 22%.

And again, you saw our total revenue. If you go back to Q4 for international, it was 31% on a local currency basis. And so it was really consistent with what we saw in the first -- really the first three quarters of the year. We saw that dip a little bit, and we believe that is economic-related in Q1, to 28%, but still very solid growth. 28% in total for our international businesses on a local currency basis. So we did see a little bit of decline in international media, but we saw a corresponding increase in EGM also, growing 50% on a local currency basis.

JEFF BEZOS: The Amazon Video On Demand team is doing a terrific job. The strategy is very simple, which is to keep improving the customer experience of Video On Demand relentlessly as we go forward, and at the same time, to make it very, very easy for partners to integrate the Video On Demand service into their set-top box or video display device.

So, today, you can use Video On Demand, very -- Amazon Video On Demand very seamlessly on TiVo and also on the Roku box. So continuing to do those kinds of integrations is an important part of the strategy in making those integrations easy for our partners.

OPERATOR: Sandeep Aggarwal, Collins Stewart.

SANDEEP AGGARWAL, ANALYST, COLLINS STEWART: Jeff, one question on -- obviously, Kindle -- both generation one and generation two of Kindle did very well. Any plan to unleash the computing power of Kindle and let it compete with form factors like netbook, which are obviously gaining better traction now?

JEFF BEZOS: We are really focused on purpose-built reading devices. And so we wouldn't talk anyway about what we might do in the future. But I can tell you that we're really focused on devices with electronic ink displays that are purpose-built for reading. Kindle 2 really is a terrific long-form reading device. And we think reading is an important enough activity that it deserves a purpose-built device, and that is really a sweet spot for us.

OPERATOR: Marianne Wolk, Susquehanna.

MARIANNE WOLK, ANALYST, SUSQUEHANNA FINANCIAL GROUP: I had a couple of quick questions. First, can you update us on your cloud computing business and any initiatives with larger corporate accounts you've been successful with? Also, in the past you disclosed the number of web developers in your solution as nearly 400,000. Can you provide any update to that figure?

And then finally, you reduced capacity earlier this quarter, which appeared minor, and headcount fell by about 100 sequentially. Can you comment whether these are cost control efforts and describe any other specific cost reduction initiatives in place that are helping margins? Thanks a lot.

JEFF BEZOS: I will take the first one. Examples of enterprise customers using our infrastructure Web services today, there are many, but I will name a few -- Eli Lilly doing basic research, clinical trial analysis using EC2. ESPN is another user of EC2. Autodesk is a user of EC2. There are many more. Some of them prefer not to be identified for competitive reasons. There are a number of hedge funds using EC2 for compute. So I will just leave it at that. But there is good traction in the enterprise customer set, as well, of course, there is with startups, small business and medium business.

TOM SZKUTAK: In terms of your other question related to headcount, it was pretty flat. Q1 headcount was pretty flat with year end. We did continue to hire, but we also had attrition as well. So it just remained pretty flat.

In terms of other productivity, we have a large number of things that we are working on from a productivity standpoint. I talked about some of them earlier. We continue to work with suppliers to find ways where we can make them more successful, as well as us more successful.

One of the ways that we -- like Jeff talked about some of the efforts we have earlier, in Mark's question. And one of the ways that we spent a lot of time on is -- to get productivity is by becoming more efficient for customers. And we find that the many, many programs that we have to become more efficient for customers translates into a better experience for customers, but it also results in productivity. So we have many, many different programs across the Company. This is not something new. This is something that we've been working on for quite a few years. And as Jeff described earlier, we have a lot of opportunities to continue to work on those going forward as well.

OPERATOR: Youssef Squali, Jefferies & Co.

YOUSSEF SQUALI, ANALYST, JEFFERIES & CO.: Two quick ones. First, starting with Tom, if I look at the segment breakouts and I look at your electronics and other in the US, there was a noticeable reacceleration in that business. Growth was at 42%. Can you just help us understand why the acceleration? Were there any subcategories that performed exceptionally well or better than your expectations?

And then, Jeff, back to the Amazon VOD, a question -- what would be the hurdles to maybe allowing Amazon to move into a subscription model and in addition to the a la carte offering that you already have? Thank you.

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. In terms of electronics and other general merchandise, we did see strong growth in North America. We also saw strong growth in international. And it was -- we continue to add selection in those categories. We continue to improve our in-stock levels, so that when customers came to our detail pages to order it was available right away for shipment. So a lot of -- and pricing was very, very competitive. So we think the combination of certainly prices, adding additional selection, in-stocks and certainly fast delivery with Prime helping those numbers as well.

JEFF BEZOS: In answer to the Video On Demand subscription model, there is nothing structural that would prohibit that. The amount of selection that you have available in a subscription model today is much less than what you can get with the a la carte model. So that is the beginnings of an answer to your question, I think.

OPERATOR: Colin Sebastian, Lazard.

COLIN SEBASTIAN, ANALYST, LAZARD CAPITAL MARKETS: Thanks for taking my question. I was hoping to get your perspective on some of the regional and national initiatives to impose sales taxation on the Internet, for example what you might expect to see in terms of any impact on demand perhaps from an historical perspective.

TOM SZKUTAK: You know, it's hard to say. There's not a lot I can help you with there.

OPERATOR: Imran Khan, JPMorgan.

IMRAN KHAN, ANALYST, JPMORGAN: Thank you for taking my questions. Two questions. First, I think some of the retail companies and some online retailers also talked about business condition stabilization or improving. Now, your business was not impacted that much by the economy, but can you give us some sense -- have you seen some sign of improvement or growth rate acceleration as we progress towards the end of the quarter?

And second question is for Jeff. Jeff, third-party business is growing at a faster pace and becoming a bigger part of the business. The challenge is, I think you are very extremely focused on improving user experience. As third-party becomes a bigger part of the business, how closely are you monitoring the user -- consumer satisfaction, and how do you guarantee that the consumer gets the same satisfaction when they buy from Amazon when Amazon is the principal? Thank you.

TOM SZKUTAK: Well, in terms of growth rate, it is obviously difficult to say what the economic impact is. But we certainly, starting in Q4, looking at our overall growth rates, we saw solid growth rates, but certainly not as strong as we saw for the several quarters previous to that. And you saw the same thing again in Q1. So our Q1 revenue growth was 25% on a local currency basis. But last year, in the first three quarters, it was well into the 30s.

And so we did see some slowdown both in Q4 and Q1. But we continue -- we are not doing anything different than we have done in the past. We're continuing to focus on what we think are the right things for customers. And that's what we are doing. So it's hard to say what the economic impact is.

JEFF BEZOS: On the third-party sales business question, how do we guarantee the customer experience in a third-party model, there are a couple of ways. One, we maintain scorecards on the sellers. And the sellers are very interested in self-improvement. The fact of the matter is that the vast majority of sellers do a very good job fulfilling for customers. And the small fraction that do not, we can provide them feedback and we can ultimately ask them not to sell on Amazon.

The second thing we do is we have the A-to-z Guarantee. So ultimately, we can take care of customers if the seller cannot.

And then third, we have Fulfillment by Amazon. So Fulfillment by Amazon really levels the experience and makes it so that those third-party-sold items have exactly the same fulfillment and customer service experience as Amazon-owned inventory.

OPERATOR: Heath Terry, FBR Capital Markets.

HEATH TERRY, ANALYST, FBR CAPITAL MARKETS: You mentioned that third-party this quarter was 32%. That is a number that has been surprisingly stable for awhile, and particularly surprising, given the growth that you are obviously seeing to some degree in third-party in Europe. Can you give us a sense of where you feel like the right balance for that is? And I guess to the extent that you are willing to talk about the difference in where you are with third-party as a percent of your units in the US or as a percentage of quarters in the US versus Europe, at what level do you see that balancing out?

JEFF BEZOS: You know, ultimately the customer is going to decide what that mix ends up being. And what we are trying to do is trying to make sure that we have a great customer experience certainly for our consumers. We continue to work as well on our sellers, which is another customer set that we have.

And so the way you should think about it is we're trying to make those two experiences -- as well as our third customer set, which is developers -- but in terms of mix, the customer is going to ultimately decide. And what we're trying to do is just make that experience as good as we can make it so that the customers will ultimately decide who they buy from.

In terms of the -- we haven't disclosed what the numbers are for each of the two segments. But looking at Q1, both segments are growing nicely.

OPERATOR: Jim Friedland, Cowen and Company.

JIM FRIEDLAND, ANALYST, COWEN AND COMPANY: I was wondering if you could give us any color on what is going on with the asset in China in terms of how big is it at this point, or if you can give us some sort of comparison as to what it would look like compared to when Amazon was young. When did it become a material part of the business? Thanks.

JEFF BEZOS: We haven't split out the specific geography numbers. But we are very pleased with the business we have in China. It is growing nicely, and we think that's an interesting long-term opportunity for us.

OPERATOR: Gene Munster, Piper Jaffray.

GENE MUNSTER, ANALYST, PIPER JAFFRAY: If you can talk a little bit about Prime and just the overall percentage of products on Prime right now. I know you talked about Fulfillment by Amazon. And how do you basically fulfill and promote more products being offered by Prime?

And the second is, can you talk a little bit about just behavior when people actually do sign up for Prime, just general differences in how people's buying behavior changes once they become Prime?

TOM SZKUTAK: In terms of selection, we have very vast selection in Prime. And so it is just a very good experience for customers, and we continue to add to that selection. We continued to add selection to that in Q1; we will continue to add selection in the coming quarters for our Prime customers.

In terms of the experience, what we are seeing, we are seeing customers are doing a lot more cross-shopping than they have previously. And so it is a very good experience for customers. It's certainly impacting the growth rates that you're seeing, not only this quarter, but the last several quarters. So it is a very good experience for customers.

JEFF BEZOS: I would just add, when Tom talks about Prime selection growing, it is millions of different items, and it is across all categories. So you can use your Prime membership to buy shoes, to buy food, to buy diapers, to buy obviously media products and electronics and so on. But it's across a wide array of categories and growing every day.

TOM SZKUTAK: Thank you for joining us on the call today and for your questions. A replay will be available on our Investor Relations website at least through the end of the quarter. We appreciate your interest in Amazon.com and look forward to talking with you again next quarter.

OPERATOR: That concludes today's conference. Please disconnect at this time.
