   LP
OPERATOR: Thank you for standing by. Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Amazon.com fourth-quarter 2005 financial results conference. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the conference over to the Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Tim Stone. Please go ahead, sir.  

TIM STONE, VP, IR, AMAZON.COM: Welcome to our Q4 '05 financial results conference call. Joining us today is Tom Szkutak, our CFO. Jeff Bezos, our Founder and CEO, and Tom will both be available for Q&A. In the following discussion, responses to your questions reflect management's views as of today February 2, 2006 only and will include forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially. Additional information about factors that could potentially impact our financial results is included in today's press release and our filings with the SEC, included our 2004 annual report on Form 10-K.  

   TD
As you are listening to today's call, we encourage you to have our press release in front of you, which includes our financial results as well as metrics and commentary on the quarter.  

During this call we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. In our press release, slides accompanying this webcast and our filings with the SEC, each of which is posted on our IR website, you will find additional disclosures regarding these non-GAAP measures, including the reconciliation of these measures with comparable GAAP measures. Finally, unless otherwise stated, all comparisons in this call will be against our results for the comparable period of 2004.  

Now I will turn the call over to Tom.  

TOM SZKUTAK, CFO, AMAZON.COM: Thanks, Tim. This was another successful year for Amazon.com. We significantly expanded our value proposition for customers, and we are grateful to our customers, our global teams and our partners for helping deliver these results.  

Let me start by reviewing 2005 in full. Trailing 12-month free cash flow grew 11% to a record $529 million. Trailing 12-month free cash flow includes a onetime payment of $40 million in connection with the patent lawsuit settlement in Q3 of '05. Excluding this settlement, 2005 free cash flow grew 19% to $569 million. Free cash flow is operating cash flow minus capital expenditures.  

As a reminder, the financial measure we are working to maximize over the long-term is free cash flow per share. The combination of common stock and stock-based awards outstanding was 438 million shares compared with 434 million shares, up 1%. Stock-based towards outstanding were 22 million or 5.2% of shares outstanding, down from 25 or 6% of shares outstanding. Return on invested capital was 34%, ROIC is TTM free cash flow divided by average total assets minus average current liabilities. Revenue grew 23% to $8.49 billion or 24%, excluding the $73 million unfavorable impact from year-over-year changes in foreign exchange rates. North America grew 22% to 4.7 billion, and international grew 23% to 3.8 billion, 25% year-over-year growth excluding year-over-year changes in foreign exchange rates.  

Gross profit grew 27% to 2.04 billion, and gross margin increased 87 basis points to 24%. Consolidated segment operating income grew 16% to $566 million or 17%, excluding $8 million of unfavorable year-over-year impact from foreign exchange, and operating margin decreased 41 basis points to 6.7%.  

Turning to the balance sheet, cash from marketable securities increased $221 million to $2.0 billion. In Q1 of '05 we repurchased EUR200 million of our convertible debt. And as separately announced today, we will be redeeming EUR250 million or approximately $300 million at recent Eurodollar exchange rates in the principal amount of our 6 7/8 Euro denominated convertible debt notes due 2010 at par plus accrued and unpaid interest. This redemption mitigates potential dilution of over 2.9 million shares and reduces our annual cash interest expense by approximately $21 million. Inventory increased 18% to $566 million, and inventory turns decreased from 16 to 14 as we bolstered inventory levels for customers by optimizing in stock levels across product categories and expanding the breadth of product category selection in our fulfillment centers. We will continue to increase our direct buying efforts in existing and new product categories, enabling us to extend even lower prices to customers. Our investment in fixed assets, which includes net capitalized software development costs, increased $101 million from a year ago to 348 million, of which $87 million is capitalized software development costs. Our 2005 capital expenditures were $204 million, of which $79 million was software development costs.  

Now I will discuss the fourth quarter. Revenue grew 17% to $2.98 billion or 22% excluding $121 million of unfavorable year-over-year impact from foreign exchange. Worldwide unit growth for the quarter was also 22%. Third-party units representing marketplace and merchant stat units sold on Amazon sites were 28% of total units, up from 26%. For the first time, North America media surpassed $1 billion, and North America electronics and general merchandise exceeded $500 million. And worldwide electronics and other general merchandise increased 31% to $901 million or 36% excluding FX, representing 30% of worldwide sales, up from 27%. Active customer accounts representing customers who have ordered in the past year surpassed 55 million, up 19%. Gross profit grew 23% to $667 million, and gross margin increased 98 basis points to 22.4%, primarily due to increased third-party sales, changes in the geographic mix of business and a $19 million increase in other revenue primarily from Amazon Enterprise Solutions, formerly known as merchant.com, partially offset by a greater shipping loss driven by free shipping in Amazon Prime, our lower product prices and continued mix shift to EGM. In Q4 we offered free short-term membership trials for Amazon Prime, and although they are expensive, we expect to continue offering these trials for our customer base in the future.  

Now I will discuss operating expenses excluding stock-based compensation expense under FAS 123R, which we adopted early in Q1 of '05. Fulfillment, marketing, technical content and G&A combined was $482 million or 16.2% of sales, up 175 basis points. Fulfillment was $246 million or 8.3% of sales, up 26 basis points. In 2005 we expanded our fulfillment capacity through efficiency gains, as well as increases in leased warehouse space in order to accommodate greater selection in these anticipated shipment volumes from ourselves, as well as third-parties for whom we provide the fulfillment.  

In 2006 we expect to increase our fulfillment space, less than in 2005, to expand our capacity to satisfy peak demand. For example, we intend to expand our warehouse space in Germany. Marketing was $67 million or 2.2% of sales, roughly flat as a percentage of sales year-over-year. Technology and content was $123 million or 4.1% of sales, up 127 basis points as we continue to hire top computer scientists and software engineers to further innovate for customers in areas such as our (inaudible) platforms, search, Web Services and digital. Q4 '05 represents an annual run-rate of approximately $500 million as we enter 2006. In 2006 we will continue investing in our long-term opportunities, innovating on behalf of customers. We expect technology and content costs to continue to grow in absolute dollars and our 2006 year-over-year percentage growth rate to be lower than 2005.  

G&A was $46 million or 1.5% of sales, up 27 basis points. G&A costs increased primarily due to payroll and related expenses, professional fees and legal costs.  

Now I will talk about our segment results. Consistent with prior periods, we don't allocate stock-based compensation or other operating expense to our segments. In the North America segment, revenue grew 21% to $1.7 billion. Media grew 16% to $1 billion. And EGM grew 29% to $580 million, representing 34% of North American revenues, up from 32%. Apparel, jewelry and sporting goods revenue all more than doubled year-over-year. Other revenue was up 25% primarily from Amazon Enterprise solutions. Gross profit grew 18% to 418 million, and gross margin decreased 64 basis points to 24.8%, largely due to Amazon Prime and free shipping, products and service mix and our price reduction across product categories, partially offset by third-party sales. North America segment operating income decreased $30 million and $92 million or 5.5% operating margin.  

In the international segment, revenue grew 13% to $1.3 billion. Revenue growth was 23% adjusting for the $122 million unfavorable impact from foreign exchange during the quarter. Media revenue grew 6% to $968 million or 16% excluding foreign exchange rates. EGM grew 36% to $321 million or 49% excluding FX, representing 25% of international revenues, up from 21%. Gross profit grew 31% to $249 million, while gross margin increased 273 basis points to 19.3%, primarily from increase in third-party sales and from vendor management, including discounts from suppliers partially offset by increased free shipping, product price reductions and product mix shift.  

International segment operating income increased $37 million and $93 million, and operating margin increased 233 basis points to 7.1%. It is important to remember that a significant majority of technology and content costs are incurred in the U.S. with most of them allocated to the North America segment.  

The combination of operating income in our North American and international segments is our consolidated segment operating income or CSOI. Our segment information financial statement in our press release reconciles CSOI to GAAP operating income. CSOI grew 4% to $185 million or 11%, excluding the $12 million unfavorable year-over-year impacts from foreign exchange rates. Unlike CSOI, our GAAP operating income includes stock-based compensation expense and other operating expense. GAAP operating income increased 1% to $165 million. Excluding the $12 million impact from year-over-year changes in foreign exchange rates, operating income increased 9% to $176 million. Our provision for income taxes includes a tax benefit of $90 million in Q4 of '05 or $0.21 per diluted share related to our determination that certain of our deferred tax assets are realizable. Without the benefit of this change, our effective tax rate was 43% in 2005, higher than the 35% statutory rate resulting from the transfer of certain operating assets from the U.S. to international locations in connection with establishing our EU headquarters in Luxembourg.  

We will transfer additional assets in 2006 to finalize the European headquarters transition, and we will expect this will result in an effective tax rate significantly higher than the statutory rate for 2006. Since we have deferred tax assets related to our NOLs, these asset transfers will not have a significant impact on our cash taxes paid in 2006, which we expect to be approximately $25 million compared with $12 million in 2005. We are endeavoring to optimize our global taxes on a cash paid basis, not for tax expense on a financial reporting basis.  

GAAP net income was $199 million or $0.47 per diluted share compared with $347 million or $0.82 per diluted share. Excluding the $90 million tax benefit in 2005 and the $244 million tax benefit in 2004, GAAP net income would have been $110 million or $0.26 per diluted share in Q4 of' 05 and $102 million or $0.24 per diluted share in Q4 of '04.  

Our growth continues to be fueled by our relentless focus on the primary inputs to customer experience -- convenience, selection and price. Some recent examples of our progress include Amazon Prime. We continue to be pleased with Amazon Prime results. Subscriptions to Amazon Prime more than doubled from November to December. We have seen increased purchases by Amazon Prime customers across more categories with especially heavy purchases in electronics, kitchen and health and personal care. For $79 a year Amazon Prime members get "all-you-can-eat" free two-day shipping.  

Our "Search Inside the Book" technology is now available in six geographies, most recently in Japan, where customers can preview the text inside over 160,000 books. Building on our successful "Search Inside the Book" technology, the digital team also announced it is currently developing two innovative programs, Amazon Pages and Amazon Upgrade, to benefit readers, authors and publishers that will enable customers to purchase online access to any page, section or chapter of a book, as well as the book in its entirety.  

Our German site, Amazon.de, launched Express Delivery in Q4, giving customers the ability to order eligible products by 7:30 PM for guaranteed delivery by noon the next day. Worldwide active seller accounts, merchants with an order from a customer during the preceding 12 months, exceeded 1.05 million, up 24% year-over-year.  

Amazon's China site, Joyo.com, in a long-term test lowered the order site threshold for customers to qualify for free shipping from 99 to 200 RMB and offers more than 300,000 books, music, video and DVD titles, making it the largest Chinese bookstore in the world.  

Amazon Japan's site, Amazon.co.jp, launched a sports store with over 100,000 items and more than 600 brands across 17 categories, including baseball, golf and soccer. Some price highlights include the average customer discount across books, music and video products purchased on  www.Amazon.com  increased by over 175 basis points year-over-year. The average customer discount for electronics products on  www.Amazon.com , increased over 50 basis points year-over-year. Customers saved over $475 million on shipping through our worldwide free shipping offers in Amazon Prime in 2005.  

I will conclude my portion of today's call with guidance. Incorporated into our guidance are the order trends that we are seen to date and what we believe to date to be appropriately conservative assumptions. However, there is a high level of uncertainty surrounding fluctuation in the Euro, Pound, Yen, Canadian dollar and Yuan exchange rates, as well as the global economy and consumer spending and the impact on both of world events. While we are cautiously optimistic, it is not possible to accurately predict demand, and therefore, our actual results could differ materially from our guidance.  

Let me also remind everyone that we mark our Euro denominated debt to market at the end of each quarter, which results in a gain or loss for any movement in the Euro between reporting dates. We also have Euro exposure related to our interest expense on this Euro denominated debt. We incur a foreign currency gain or loss corresponding with intercompany balances denominated in foreign currencies which are settled among subsidiaries.  

Depending on the amount and timing, an unfavorable resolution of outstanding legal matters could materially affect our business, results of operations, financial position and our cash flows in a particular period. Our effective tax rate in 2006 is subject to significant variations based on changes in our corporate structure and business operations, the amount of expenses incurred that are permanently nondeductible for U.S. tax purposes such as stock-based compensation paid to foreign employees, the tax characterization of income earned and changes in current tax laws and estimates, including variability in predicting our taxable income and the taxable jurisdictions to which it relates.  

Our guidance assumes that we don't report any additional intangible assets or any further revisions to stock-based compensation or restructuring-related estimates and that FX rates remain approximately where they have been recently. For Q1 we expect net sales of between 2.14 billion and 2.29 billion or growth of between 13 and 20%. This guidance anticipates more than 75 million or over 400 basis points of negative impact to foreign exchange due to the dollar's continued strength. GAAP operating income could be between 70 and 105 million or between a negative 35% and a negative 3% decline. This includes stock-based compensation and amortization of intangible assets of approximately $30 million. We anticipate consolidated segment operating income, which includes a negative impact from foreign exchange and excludes stock-based compensation and other operating expense to be between 100 and $135 million or between a negative 22% decline and 5% growth.  

For calendar year 2006, we expect net sales of between $9.85 billion and $10.45 billion on growth of between 16 and 23%. This guidance anticipates approximately $100 million or over 100 basis points of negative impact from foreign exchange rates. GAAP operating income to be between $370 million and $510 million or between a 14% decline and an 18% growth. This includes approximate $135 million for stock-based compensation and amortization of intangible assets. We anticipate consolidated segment operating income, which includes the negative impact from foreign exchange and excludes stock-based compensation and other operating expense, to be between $505 million and $645 million or 11% decline and 14% growth.  

Operating leverage should accelerate in the second half of the year compared with the first half of the year. We expect our 2006 free cash flow growth rate to trend similar to the operating profit growth rate year-over-year. This excludes the impact of FAS 123R, which may result in up to $100 million of tax benefits from stock-based compensation to be classified as positive financing cash flows net of operating cash flows, up from $7 million in 2005. We expect capital expenditures, including capitalized software development costs, to be approximately $225 million. Our strategy is to remain relentlessly focused on customer experience with our financial focus on long-term growth and free cash flow per share. We believe the investments we have made and will make in 2006 in the form of lower prices and free shipping, as well as investments in further technology innovation, are the right investments for future free cash flow.  

In the last four years, we have generated nearly $1.5 billion in free cash flow, while investing $1.1 billion in technology and content, and customers saved over $1.25 billion on shipping since we have made free shipping a permanent offer and introduced Amazon Prime for customers on top of our prices which continue to lower. We will continue to strive for year-over-year annual growth of free cash flow and free cash flow per share while investing in our long-term opportunities. We are confident that if we continue to improve customer experience and execute efficiently, our value proposition, as well as our free cash flow, will further expand.  

Thanks, and with that, Tim, let's move to questions.  

TIM STONE: Great. Thanks, Tom. Let's move onto the Q&A portion of the call with Jeff and Tom. Operator, will you please remind everyone of the Q&A process?  

OPERATOR: (OPERATOR INSTRUCTIONS). Anthony Noto, Goldman Sachs.  

ANTHONY NOTO, ANALYST, GOLDMAN SACHS: Jeff, in the past you and I have talked about some of the -- I have asked you questions about the structural challenges outside of the books, music and video that I thought were apparent. I was wondering today if we could focus on the books, music and video business. This has clearly been a business that has really benefited from competitive advantages and you being a low-cost operator being able to give consumers lower prices than anyone else and better selection.  

As you think about that business in the next five to 10 years and the impact digital may have on the profitability, do you worry about the profitability of that business eroding given the visual margins are much lower than the physical margins?  

And then secondly, in 2006 it looks like it is going to be the third year in which your incremental margins have trended below the prior year, which means you continue to invest. At what point does that investment end, and we start to see a rise in your incremental margins and return on that investment? Thank you.  

JEFF BEZOS, FOUNDER & CEO, AMAZON.COM: Sure. Thanks, Anthony, and by the way, I think you had twins yesterday. Congratulations on that. If you look at our digital investment, we are excited about the opportunity there going forward. In the physical world, that is where the vast majority of media products are sold today in physical stores. And as we move forward with digital, we think Amazon is especially well-positioned to capture a bigger part of that business. While media products are physical, it makes a lot of sense for a big faction of them to be sold in physical stores, and I think that there will be sustainable margins there for those players who can create a very good customer experience. And that is what we're working on doing.  

And the second part of the question, I forgot.  

ANTHONY NOTO: It was just that 2006 looks like it will be the third year in which your incremental profitability is lower than the prior year, which implies you are investing again for the future. I am just wondering at what point do we see that investment tail off and a return on the investment hit the P&L, which we would measure as an improvement in incremental margins?  

JEFF BEZOS: Well, if you look at 2005, it was definitely a year where we increased our cost structure significantly. We did that very deliberately, and we did it because we see a lot of opportunity going forward. I do think that we will see over the next couple of years that we will be able to -- we will start to see the utilization of that cost structure over the next couple of years.  

OPERATOR: Robert Peck, Bear Stearns.  

ROBERT PECK, ANALYST, BEAR STEARNS: Following on Anthony's question, could you maybe quantify or shape for us with the investments you are making what portions are going to newer initiatives like A9, Alexa? What portion is going for Amazon Prime? Could you maybe quantify how many current subs you have for Amazon Prime?  

JEFF BEZOS: In terms of the investments we are making, we are making a number of investments that are short-term, intermediate and longer-term, and we have not quantified the pieces, but certainly you should look at the investment we are making in A9.com as being longer-term. Digital Web Services is certainly longer-term initiatives for us.  

But again, we are making a number of different initiatives. Amazon Prime certainly is one that we are investing in today. It is expensive. That being said, the early results that we see we like. We are seeing the customers that are Amazon Prime members are shopping more, they are doing more cross shopping. We saw a nice increase in subscriptions in Q4 with subscriptions doubling from November to December. So we're seeing some positive signs. It is still very early, but we see positive signs, and so we like what we see there.  

TOM SZKUTAK: And I will just add that Amazon Prime while very expensive, we see in it the same potential that we had with the FREE Super Saver Shipping. That was very expensive, and yet it really improved the customer experience, and we think drove very good business results over the medium-term. And that is exactly what we would expect to have happened with Amazon Prime.  

ROBERT PECK: And a quick follow-up. Could you maybe give us your thoughts on competition from eBay Express, Google Base and [Freemont] and what that could mean to your future growth?  

JEFF BEZOS: Well, we have a long-standing practice of not talking about other companies. But more generally what I can tell you is that we believe and have believed for a long time that the Internet is driving better and better consumer information. And as a result, we believe that companies that deliver sincerely better customer experiences, which includes competitive pricing, it includes reliable fast delivery, it includes having the right selection and the inventory in stock and available, that those important customer experience drivers will shine through in a world that has increasingly better consumer information. And I think many of the things that we see happening on the Internet fit into that trend of better and better information, more empowerment for consumers. From where we sit because of the way we have operated the business, we like that trend.  

OPERATOR: Heath Terry, Credit Suisse Asset Management.  

HEATH TERRY, ANALYST, CREDIT SUISSE ASSET MANAGEMENT: Can you talk just a little bit about products, your international product strategy? I know I have asked this question before, but as you continue to see success in areas outside of the -- or in areas that you don't currently offer in other markets, what is the thought process behind expanding your product portfolio internationally to mirror the one that you have got in the U.S.?  

JEFF BEZOS: Sure. We in terms of additional selection you should expect going forward that we are going to add additional selection in the categories that we are in. You should expect that we are going to launch new categories certainly over time in international as well. When we launch new categories, we are always trying to learn how to give the best possible customer experience that we can. We learn from that, and then we expand to other geographies. And so that is how we think about it traditionally. That has happened first starting with the U.S., but certainly over the past few years, we have also done that in all the geographies we are in.  

HEATH TERRY: So there are certain limitations in the international markets that have kept you from entering categories there that have been successful here?  

JEFF BEZOS: No, I would not say there are structural limitations. As we build up categories, we need to build supply chain vendor relationships and so on. So there is a deliberate effort that takes time that we go through in opening those categories. We used the data from whatever market we first opened in. We used that data to help prioritize which categories we do next in other geographies. But our selection goals -- well, first of all, in terms of category expansion, our long-term vision is to have all the geographies be the same. So any store you see in any category you see in any geography, you will see in all the geographies. So that is a long-term vision.  

And then within each category, we also continue to add selection. So even in categories -- even in U.S. books, the category that we have been working on the longest -- even in that category over this past year, we added significant selection.  

OPERATOR: Paul Keung, CIBC World Markets.  

PAUL KEUNG, ANALYST, CIBC WORLD MARKETS: With your free cash flow growth that has (inaudible) somewhat in the midteens in the back half of this year, and then based on your guidance, it looks like you are looking for free cash flow growth next year in a midpoint somewhere plus or minus 10%. So the basis of that question is I guess very similar to that of Anthony. I mean, as you plan your business out and if you look at the range of guidance for next year, is it possible to manage your business from a point your actual free cash flow may not grow next year, or do you actually manage actively to try to sustain a growth comparable to your top-line?  

JEFF BEZOS: Well, certainly we have a focus of trying to make sure that we grow free cash flow and free cash flow per share over time. It is certainly a key element that we look at, and it is certainly the most important measure.  

That being said, we're going to make sure we do the right thing for long-term investors as well. And as you look at 2006 specifically, we think that free cash flow will trend largely with operating income. And as you look at the guidance, you can see that based on the Q1 guidance that we have given and the total year guidance that we have given that we expect that the leverage is likely to be better in the second half versus the first half. So again, as you look at free cash flow, we think it will trend in line with how I described.  

PAUL KEUNG: Is that more specific to your OpEx, or is it that the capital spending that is causing that?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Yes, if you look at the operating expense for 2005 and the buildup that we have had through the course of the year, you have seen that very specifically our total operating expenses are up 127 basis points. Our technology and content is 115 basis points of that increase. And, as Jeff described earlier, that is because of the opportunities that we see.  

We are going to still increase technology and content next year. We are going to hire more software development engineers and computer scientists. But I would not expect that the increase in technology and content in 2006 to be as great as 2005. So again, you have the base that we have that you can see as of Q4 and then the elements that I described, which would mean that as you get closer to the back half of the year, we will be lapping some of the big increases that you saw in 2005.  

PAUL KEUNG: Got it. I see. And then one real quick one. I have seen some interesting things you have done on Alexa, IMBd and on the Search, and I was curious is there any modernization of those assets in your '06 forecast?  

JEFF BEZOS: Sure, yes. Certainly the IMBd, certainly we would monetize that today. It is an interesting business for us, and certainly it is incorporated into the guidance for 2006.  

OPERATOR: Jeetil Patel, Deutsche Bank.  

JEETIL PATEL, ANALYST, DEUTSCHE BANK: Two questions. First of all, can you talk about just overall market-wise the UK e-commerce market? Is there any interesting nuances, challenges, changes in that market dynamic there from an economy standpoint, just maybe a slowdown as you went throughout the quarter?  

Second, can you talk about I guess the third-party business in Europe? And are you getting enough selection in broadly in the international markets to drive relevance and drive transactions, or do you think there is still opportunity to build out selection through a third-party platform there?  

JEFF BEZOS: In terms of the -- you know, we have a long-standing practice of not talking about individual countries. But if you look at certainly our international growth, we saw we had a very solid performance in our international segment in Q4. We grew revenue 13% on a dollar basis, but 23% on a local currency basis, which was consistent with what we saw in Q1. A little bit below what we saw in Q3. Excuse me, Q2 and Q3 with Q3 had Harry Potter 6 in it. But our operating performance in total was very strong with gross margins being at the highest level that they have been in some time, gross profit being up 44% and CSOI growing 89%. So strong overall operating performance in international.  

And then in terms of the third-party, it continues to be a big part of our overall mix globally in both segments. As I have mentioned in the opening comments, the third-party mix is 28% of our total units globally. That is up from 26% in Q4 2004, and we still see a lot of opportunities to add selection as a seller, as well as third-party selection.  

OPERATOR: Safa Rashtchy, Piper Jaffray.  

SAFA RASHTCHY, ANALYST, PIPER JAFFRAY: Could you talk about the investments that you are making in the digital area? What is needed to get that operation going, assuming the next few years you will have a sizable part of your media available in digital format in addition to obviously securing those titles from the content providers and having some basic technology which I assume is already available? What else do you need to do to get there, and can you give us some color on these investments you are making? Thanks.  

TOM SZKUTAK: It is a good question, but it is premature for me to talk in any detail about those initiatives. We will -- you will just have to stay tuned on what we are doing there.  

SAFA RASHTCHY: Okay. Then if I could do a follow-up on a different topic. Tom, could you talk about your expectations on return on equity? Do you expect it to continue to increase, or given the investment mode that you are in and the decrease in operating income in '06, what should we expect on ROE?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. We are not giving guidance on ROE specifically, but certainly our return on invested capital, if you will, was 32% for the year. And again we still think it is something that we utilize capital very efficiently, and we think that there is a lot of opportunity over time to improve that.  

OPERATOR: Jim Friedland, SG Cowen.  

JIM FRIEDLAND, ANALYST, SG COWEN: Can you give an update on a regulatory front if there's any visibility when you might need to select sales tax beyond the states where you have physical operations?  

TOM SZKUTAK: No, there is not a lot new there. We collect sales tax in a few states today, and we continue to work to try to help legislators come up with something that is simple.  

JIM FRIEDLAND: And in the states where you do collect sales tax, is there any kind of meaningful difference in the dynamic between the way your customers purchase versus other states, like maybe not buying as many big-ticket items, things like that?  

TOM SZKUTAK: No, in fact, it is not just the individual states. You should also need to be aware that we collect value-added tax in countries that require it and have been doing so since inception. So again, we have a lot of other data points beyond the states that we collect in.  

OPERATOR: Imran Khan, J.P. Morgan.  

IMRAN KHAN, ANALYST, J.P. MORGAN: Hi, Jeff and Tom. In terms of you are investing a lot of money in interesting the customer's experience, if I look at the revenue growth rate, your U.S. and international business is growing at the same rate. So two questions. In terms of international, what can you do to accelerate the growth rate because I assuming the market share is probably bigger than U.S.?  

And secondly if you look at the U.S. numbers, I know you don't report gross margin as volume, but how do you think about the market share? Because if I look at the e-commerce market as probably growing like 24, 25%, you are reporting 21% revenue growth. So do you think you are losing market share, or the growth is coming from other categories, and if so, if you see an opportunity to expand into those categories? Thank you.  

JEFF BEZOS: Sure. I will take the North America piece first. I think we have made good progress. If we look at our share, we think on a product category by product category basis, we think we are doing pretty well there. If you look at the results that we have had, our North America revenue grew 22% in 2005. That is actually an acceleration up from 400 basis points, up 400 basis points from 2004. If you just look at the history, 2005 was 22% growth; 2004 was 18; 2003, 18; 2002, 12 and 2001, 3%. So again you have seen some very nice progress over the past five years in terms of growth. And so the challenge going forward is, how do we continue -- how can we continue to accelerate that growth?  

In terms of international, we still think there is a lot of opportunity as you mentioned. We are going to, as I mentioned earlier, going to continue to expand selection in the categories we are in. We are going to expand into new categories over time. Certainly over time you should expect us also to launch new countries. Certainly we're going to invest more in pricing as well and continue to focus our resources on improving the customer experience. So those are things that we think we can do to improve our growth there and will certainly get a lot of our attention.  

OPERATOR: Mark Rowen, Prudential.  

MARK ROWEN, ANALYST, PRUDENTIAL: If I could ask two questions actually. The first if I could just follow-up on Imran's question. So when you look at the international growth in media products and also consumer electronics, they tend to be trending about the same now as North America. Would you say that as you go country by country in Germany and the UK and Japan and France, are you at similar levels of penetration in those product categories as you are in the U.S. and North America, and is that why the growth is sort of trending at the same level, or is there something specific going on internationally that is causing the growth to decelerate towards that trendline? And then I have another question if I could.  

JEFF BEZOS: Sure. I think if you look at the categories that we are in outside of the U.S., we are actually in each of the countries in less categories outside of the U.S. than inside the U.S. So it is certainly an opportunity for us to grow. Again, I think if you look at the deceleration that you just described in Q4 specifically, again if you look at our total performance, you see that the performance and certainly the revenue is strong at 23% excluding exchange, which is higher than our North America growth. But on top of that, our gross profit is up 44%. Our gross margins are up 273 basis points. Our CSOI, excluding exchange, is up 89%.  

So again, we have a strong overall performance. But we need to make sure going forward that we have a good balance between growth and profitability and driving free cash flow off our international. So that is how we are thinking about it. You said you had another follow-up question?  

MARK ROWEN: Yes, just on that one also. So would you say that you are at similar levels of market share in, say, the media products category in places like the UK and Germany as you are in the U.S.?  

JEFF BEZOS: Yes, we have not disclosed our market segment share results by country or anything. But I would certainly say there is certainly very sizable opportunities both inside the U.S. and outside the U.S. and even outside of the categories that we are in. Again, we are just in less categories today outside the U.S. than in the U.S. And so there is certainly a lot of opportunity so globally.  

MARK ROWEN: Okay. My other question is for Jeff. Jeff, you have said for a long-time that your model is more efficient than the traditional retail model because you don't have to invest in real estate, which always goes up. Instead you can invest in technology, which goes down. But if I add up all of your expenses as a percent of revenue and add in free shipping, which you sort of view as a marketing expense, I think in 2005 it was a little over 20% and in the fourth quarter a little over 19, which is 200 or 300 basis points higher than a company like Wal-Mart. So could you sort of just give us an idea why that is such a paradox? Why is it that we are not seeing more efficiency if, in fact, the model is more efficient?  

JEFF BEZOS: Well, I think one thing to keep in mind is that if we were not investing in some of these new initiatives such as digital and Web Services, our cost structure would be different today. So if we were totally optimizing our cost structure for a kind of a steady-state business, you would see a different cost structure. Other things that we talk about that you may remember are, if you look at the return on invested capital, the dynamics between our business and traditional retail are very different in large part because of the efficiency of our capital model, high inventory turns, low PP&E.  

OPERATOR: Justin Post, Merrill Lynch.  

JUSTIN POST, ANALYST, MERRILL LYNCH: A couple of things about gross profit which actually surprised me upside versus our forecast. It looks like gross profit in Europe was really strong. Was there a product mix? I think you mentioned some vendor improvement. Is that sustainable?  

And then on the other revenue growth, has the credit card growth kind of flattened out a little bit here, and can you give us any outlook on what you think for other revenues going forward?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. In international we did see very positive vendor management. We did see positive from third-parties. We also saw you mentioned mix. Actually the product mix, we had EGM, which at a lower margin actually grew at a faster rate. So that actually was -- hurt gross margin, if you will.  

But then also partially offsetting the expansion that we saw was certainly lower prices to customers. So that is kind of the picture on the international side.  

On the other in North America, yes, we saw very good growth in our merchant.com business, if you will, our third-party business growth, and we have two big pieces that roll through that for North America. The other pieces are cobranded credit card. We did have a very large 2004 Q4 as we have mentioned before, and we are lapping that. So that was essentially flat. So the third-party business, our merchant.com business was very strong.  

JUSTIN POST: Great. And just a follow-up. Is the improvement in Europe sustainable, or were there some one-time buys that really helped you out in the fourth quarter?  

TOM SZKUTAK: As I talked about earlier, the challenge was -- you described it is Europe; it is actually international, which includes our Asian business as well. But the challenge with our international segment is to make sure that we have a good balance between growth and profitability. And so what you saw is certainly growth in international that was stronger, excluding exchange, than we saw in North America. But again, we had expansions in gross margins and operating margins there. So the challenge going forward is we need to make sure that that is balanced and that we get both strong growth and profitability and free cash flow there.  

TIM STONE: Thanks, Justin. Thank you for joining us on the call today and for your questions. A replay will be available on our Investor Relations website at least through the end of the quarter. We appreciate your interest in Amazon.com and look forward to talking to you again next quarter. Thank you.  

OPERATOR: Again, that does conclude today's Amazon.com fourth-quarter 2005 financial results conference. We thank you all for joining us.

 Q3  2005  Amazon .com, Inc. Earnings Conference Call - Final
