IMRAN KHAN: The second question is, what is the operating margins on that other revenue segment? And the third question was, give us an update on the digital media? Like you're getting into the DVD rental business in Europe. Any plans to get into the U.S. business, or are you thinking about the music business?  

JEFF BEZOS: In terms of the margin question, we don't break out any of the margins except for the segments that we provide. So we don't break it out on any particular categories or line items.  

DVD rental we have launched in the UK, and then in this quarter we launched in Germany as well. Both of those businesses are going extremely well. As far as what we might do in the future in that regard or with music, we have a practice of not preannouncing things, and we will stick with that; so you will just have to stay tuned.  

OPERATOR: Paul Keung, CIBC World Markets.  

PAUL KEUNG, ANALYST, CIBC WORLD MARKETS: A couple of questions. I think first, not to beat the bush on Harry Potter launch, but there are some leading questions here, somewhat misleading questions I should say. I was wondering if you are seeing a similar halo effect on Harry Potter as the customer (inaudible) to relatively earlier Harry Potter book launches?  

And remind us again sort of what type of benefits you will see in Harry Potter results and whether it is preorder and post-order, typically as you launched a book, and then another question on that?  

JEFF BEZOS: Again, it is difficult to say. As I mentioned before, we think the impact on Q2 growth is less than 100 basis points. We think the impact on Q3 will be less than 300 basis points. It is difficult to compare it to other releases at this stage of where we are.  

PAUL KEUNG: But then again, it does not necessarily accrete (inaudible). For you it's more the lifetime value of the customer. And what percent of those customers buying Harry Potter now are new customers versus old; and how does that compare versus, let's say, book two, book three, book four?  

JEFF BEZOS: We don't break that out, but I will tell you that anecdotally we love the opportunity to reach out and interact with customers of that age group. Those are customers that we hope and expect to be, if we give them a good experience now, we hope and expect that they will be customers of ours for many decades to come.  

And this is a fantastic opportunity for us to show off our very best for both kids and parents. And the team here works incredibly hard on it. The logistical exercise involved in laying down over a million copies of Harry Potter on a single day is truly phenomenal, and there is just a lot of work that goes into it, and it also happens to be a very fun exercise, especially when it is over.  

PAUL KEUNG: Okay. And then you mentioned earlier about a commitment to hire a new software developer. I was curious given we're hearing the same thing from Google and a lot of others out there, how has the environment changed in terms of attracting and retaining and compensating developers as you move your platform into more advanced innovation?  

JEFF BEZOS: I think we're doing very very well. I think in general the market for top talent is competitive. I think it will continue to be competitive. I think that is a worldwide phenomenon, and I think we're in a very fortunate position because we are doing some very exciting things. And so we're able to attract top talent. I think if you were not doing very exciting things, it would be a very tough world out there.  

PAUL KEUNG: But would you say it costs more to hire a developer today than what you thought it would cost six to nine months ago?  

JEFF BEZOS: No.  

OPERATOR: Bob Peck, Bear Stearns.  

BOB PECK, ANALYST, BEAR STEARNS: Just a couple of quick questions here. First of all, could you comment on pricing of keyword search and how you have seen that over the last quarter? We have had some competitors of yours say they are seeing somewhat of a bubble in the middle area of the bell curve of keywords, and I wanted to get your thoughts on that.  

Two is, we're also hearing that there is pretty strong success over at Joyo.com, so could you update us on China? And lastly (technical difficulty)-- integration and what (technical difficulty)-- going from here?  

JEFF BEZOS: Could you just repeat the last part of the question? I'm sorry you were breaking up a little bit.  

BOB PECK: It is just on A9 integration and where you see A9 going from here?  

JEFF BEZOS: Well, I will take the A9 one. There are two pieces of what A9 does. They do the Amazon product search for us and for our partners, our Merchant.com partners, where we provide the plumbing for other people to operate their websites in a private-label fashion.  

And then they have a consumer facing piece Web search called A9.com. A9.com has in this quarter redesigned their user interface. I think the team did an amazingly good job on that, and it is definitely worth checking out. So they moved the buttons on the right hand side to become tick boxes at the top, and there was a lot of work that went into that change in terms of testing it and making sure it was a significant improvement. I think it is and you should check that out and judge it for yourself.  

Basically what they do is they take some of the server side technologies that Amazon.com has innovated over the years like greeting the searcher by name and then remembering the history of searches. This is a particularly valuable service for people who are heavy searchers who may want to remember what searches they did three months ago, six months ago. As well as deploying for A9 toolbar users server side bookmarks so that as you go around and bookmark things, you can find the things you bookmarked from your office or from your home, from any computer that you have access to.  

So there are a number of things like that, people who visited this website also visited this website. It is the analog to the Amazon.com customers who bought this, also bought that. Those are the kinds of innovation that A9 is layering into Web search. And their strategy is just to keep inventing and innovating relentlessly for years to come.  

BOB PECK: And the other question was on how Joyo is doing in China and keyword pricing?  

JEFF BEZOS: In terms of Joyo, we are certainly very pleased with the investment we made there. Keep in mind that it is a very long-term investment for us. You know it is very early, and so we're pleased with what we see. But again, we are going to continue to work to make the experience better for customers over time at Joyo.  

In terms of pricing on keywords, I don't think it is necessarily appropriate for us to comment on that. It is certainly part -- you know, we have a number of different online marketing that we do. When you look at our expenses so far for the quarter, it was flat from a percentage of revenue year-over-year. And again, also keep in mind that a majority of customers come to us free. They come to us because we continue to work on the customer experience, making sure we have the right pricing, the right selection and continue to try to make it more convenient for customers.  

TOM SZKUTAK: We don't break down any of our marketing channels and talk about the performance of this channel or that channel. But I can tell you that our most important marketing is lowering prices, offering FREE Super Saver Shipping. It does not show up in the marketing line, but we do consider it a kind of marketing. And improving the customer experience in terms of availability, how rapidly you can get the products, whether they are in stock, lowering prices, increasing selection, those are the things.  

So when you see that our marketing line has stayed roughly flat as a percentage of sales, what you should -- the way we're able to do that and still grow the business and grow free cash flow is by improving the customer experience, lower prices, bigger selection, better availability.  

OPERATOR: Mark Mahaney, Citigroup Smith Barney.  

MARK MAHANEY, ANALYST, CITIGROUP SMITH BARNEY: Two real quick ones. The other income line internationally has stayed fairly small. It looks like you have really tapped into an opportunity in the North American market. What is the timing like for tapping into that in international markets?  

And then secondly, Jeff, you had talked about the tech development spending. One of the benefits has been to improve the ability of third-party sellers to sell on Amazon. We had picked up in the past that that seemed to have been harder than third-party sellers would have liked. Can you talk about one or two things specifically that you have done to improve the process for third-party sellers on Amazon?  

JEFF BEZOS: Sure. One of the things that we have done is improve the rating system for sellers. We still have a tremendous amount of work to do there. We're integrating, improving the customer service side of that so that we will be able to treat change of address and things like that more consistently with the way it is done when it is an Amazon owned inventory sale.  

So those kinds of things, basically what we're doing is slowly and systematically step by step driving parity between the third-party seller and the Amazon owned inventory business. So those two experience from a customer point of view are as similar as we can make them.  

So we want to be at parity with these third-party sellers on our own website, open it up to them. If they can offer a better bargain to our customers or better availability, we want to cannibalize ourselves in that way. At the same time, we're driving very hard in our owned inventory business so that we can be effective competitors by driving productivity and fulfillment operations in relationship with vendors and so on and so on. So there is a tremendous opportunity on both sides of that business. We will work to push hard on both of them.  

We have also -- another example would be making it easier for people to give us the feeds of their inventory, so that feed processing has gotten much better over the years. We will continue to make those things better just as we have over the last 10 years worked hard at making fulfillment and customer service and all the other things we work on better.  

In terms of the first part of your question, you mentioned other income. I think you were referring to actually other revenue the way you described it in terms of the service business in international, and we certainly don't have any announcements to make related to that. But certainly it is an opportunity for us over time.  

The only thing we have announced is certainly the work that we're doing, working with Marks & Spencer that we announced in the first half of this year. Again, we will be a developing a website with them, a private-label website with them, servicing them. So again that is something that we announced earlier this year.  

TIM STONE: Thank you for joining us on the call today and for your questions. A replay will be available on our Investor Relations website at least through the end of the quarter. We appreciate your interest in Amazon.com and look forward to talking to you again next quarter.  

OPERATOR: That does conclude today's conference call. Thank you for your participation. You may now disconnect.

 Q1  2005  Amazon .com, Inc. Earnings Conference Call - Final

   LP
OPERATOR: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Amazon.com first-quarter 2005 financial results teleconference. (OPERATOR INSTRUCTIONS). For opening remarks, I will now be turning the call over to the Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Tim Stone. Please go ahead, sir.  

TIM STONE, VP, IR, AMAZON.COM, INC.: Hello and welcome to our Q1 '05 financial results conference call. Joining us today is Tom Szkutak, our CFO. Jeff Bezos, our Founder and CEO, and Tom will both be available for Q&A.  

   TD
The following discussion and responses to your questions reflect management's views as of today April 26, 2005 only and will include forward-looking statements. Action results may differ materially. Additional information about factors that could potentially impact our financial results is included in today's press release and our filings with the SEC, including our 2004 annual report on Form 10-K.  

As you listen to today's call, we encourage you to have our press release in front of you, which includes our financial results, as well as metrics and commentary on the quarter. During this call, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. In our press release, slides accompanying this webcast and our filings with the SEC, each of which is posted on on our IR website, you will find additional disclosures regarding these non-GAAP measures, including reconciliation to these measures with comparable GAAP measures. Finally, unless otherwise stated, all comparisons in this call will be against our results for the comparable period of 2004.  

Now I will turn the call over to Tom.  

TOM SZKUTAK, SVP & CFO, AMAZON.COM, INC.: Thanks, Tim. This was another successful quarter for Amazon.com. I will start with comments on our financial results. Our ultimate financial measure and the one we most want to drive over the long-term is free cash flow per share. Trailing 12 months or TTM free cash flow grew 21% to $417 million driven by improvements in operating profit. As a reminder, free cash flow excludes stock-based compensation and includes cash taxes paid which is well below our booked tax provision due to our tax NOL.  

A combination of common stock and stock-based awards outstanding was 434 million shares compared with 432 million shares. Stock-based awards outstanding were 24 million or 5.7% of shares outstanding, down from 27 million or 6.8% of shares outstanding. We strive to efficiently manage share count to create more cash flow per share and long-term value for owners.  

Return on invested capital was 35% down from 38%. We calculate ROIC as TTM free cash flow divided by average total assets minus the average current liabilities. We now have $307 million of net deferred tax assets on our balance sheet, up from $9 million a year ago. For ease of comparability, excluding deferred tax assets from this calculation, ROIC would have been 40%. Our long-term expectation remains achieving triple digit returns on invested capital.  

Revenue grew 24% to $1.9 billion or 22% excluding the $30 million benefit from year-over-year changes in the foreign exchange rate throughout the quarter. Unit growth was 26%, and third-party units as a percentage of total units were 27%, up from 23%. Active customer accounts representing customers who ordered in the past year were nearly 49 million, up 18%. Electronics and other general merchandise or EGM increased to 25% of worldwide sales in Q1 of '05 up from 22%. And on a trailing 12 months basis, we surpassed $7 billion in sales, 45% of which came from our international segment, up from 40%, and for the first time, EGM sales exceeded $1.8 billion representing one quarter of our trailing 12 month sales.  

Gross profit grew 27% to $458 million in Q1, and gross margin increased 53 basis points to 24.1% primarily due to increased third-party sales and a $23 million increase in other revenue, including amounts earned from our cobranded credit card agreement and our Merchants.com program offset by lower product prices, a $12 million greater shipping loss driven by increased adoption of free shipping and Amazon Prime and continued mixed shift to international and EGM. Although gross margins increased this quarter, I would like to take the opportunity to reiterate that we are optimizing for profit dollars not percentage margins.  

Before moving to operating expense line items, a few words about stock-based compensation. Previously we classified stock-based compensation expense in a separate line item on our income statement. In accordance with SAB-107, we're now classifying stock-based compensation within the fulfillment, marketing, technology and content and G&A line item as we do for cash compensation. In our earnings release, we've included a reconciliation of these line items from what we reported to an amount net of stock-based compensation.  

Now I will discuss operating expenses net of stock-based compensation expense as we have in the past. Fulfillment, marketing, technology and content and G&A combined was $330 million or 17.4% of sales, up 142 basis points. Fulfillment was $163 million or 8.6% of sales, up 22 basis points. To support our growth and that of our Amazon service partners, we extended our worldwide fulfillment capacity in 2004, including in Scotland and expect to further extend our capacity in 2005. For example, we plan to open unautomated lower capital fulfillment centers this quarter in Pennsylvania and Kentucky, each of which will primarily handle nonsortable product. Fulfillment also includes a $5 million charge from our Q1 '05 removal of certain North American fulfillment equipment from service.  

Excluding this $5 million charge, fulfillment would have been 8.3% of sales consistent with Q1 of '04. Marketing was $43 million or 2.3% of sales, up 7 basis points. Our marketing across targeted online marketing channels is largely variable based on growth in sales and changes in rates. Technology and content was $82 million or 4.3% of sales, up 72 basis points. We anticipate continuing to hire computer scientists and software engineers throughout 2005 to invest in further innovation for customers. We expect annual technology and content cost devoted to our solid platform, search, Web services, digital and other initiatives to increase in absolute dollars in 2005.  

G&A was $42 million or 2.2% of sales, up 41 basis points. The increase was due to an $8 million charge for possible settlement of outstanding litigation, as well as increases in employment cost, professional fees and legal cost. Excluding the litigation charge, G&A would have been 1.8% of sales consistent with Q1 of '04. We don't allocate stock-based compensation or other operating expenses to our segment, which is consistent with prior periods.  

Now I will talk more about our segment results. In the North America segment, revenue grew 21% to $1 billion. The last two quarters are the two fastest growth rate quarters in four years. Media revenue grew 17% to $699 million, and the last two quarters are also the two fastest growth rate quarters in four years.  

EGM revenue grew 25% to $282 million and in North America surpassed $4 billion in TTM sales for the first time. Gross profit grew 23% to $279 million, and gross margin increased 49 basis points to 27.2%, primarily due to a $23 million increase in high margin, other revenues and third-party sales substantially offset by our price reductions across product categories, product mix shift, Amazon Prime and free shipping. Free shipping and Amazon Prime savings drove an incremental $3 million of net shipping loss compared with Q1 of '04, effectively a $3 million price reduction for customers.  

North America's segment operating income decreased $10 million to $66 million, and operating margin declined from 8.9% to 6.4%. As a reminder, we had a $5 million charge for North America fulfillment equipment in Q1, and the majority of our technology and content costs are incurred in the U.S. with most of them allocated to our North American segment. Additionally much of the $8 million litigation charge was allocated to the North America segment.  

In the international segment, revenue grew 28% of $875 million, ahead of where North America was a year ago. Revenue growth was 24% adjusting for the $29 million year-over-year benefit from foreign exchange rates during the quarter. Media revenue grew 17% to $675 million. In EGM revenue grew 86% to $199 million increasing to 23% of total segment revenues, up from 16%.  

Gross profit grew 33% to $179 million, while gross margin increased 79 basis points to 20.5%, partially from greater third-party sales offset by increased free shipping, product price reductions and mixed shift. Increased customer adoption and savings from our free shipping offers contribute to an incremental $9 million of net shipping loss compared with Q1 of '04.  

International segment operating income increased $21 million or 51% to $62 million, and operating margin increased 108 basis points to 7.2%. The combination of operating income in our North America and international segment is our consolidated segment operating income or CSOI. Our segment information financial statement in our press release reconciles CSOI to GAAP operating income.  

CSOI grew 10% to $128 million or 8% excluding $3 million favorable year-over-year impact from foreign exchange rates. Consolidated segment operating margin declined 89 basis point to 6.8%. Excluding the $8 million charge for litigation and the $5 million charge for fulfillment equipment, CSOI would have grown 21% to $141 million.  

Unlike CSOI, our GAAP operating income includes stock-based compensation expense and other operating expense. GAAP operating income declined $3 million to $108 million, and GAAP operating margin declined 155 basis points to 5.7%.  

As previously announced, we choose to adopt FAS 123R, the new accounting rules on stock-based compensation effective January 1st, 2005 earlier than required. Stock-based compensation increased $12 million to $19 million, including the $14 million impact from our early adoption of FAS 123R. Other operating expense includes amortization of intangibles of $1 million.  

Last quarter we said GAAP net income for 2005 would decline because we expected a tax provision in 2005 rather than the large tax benefit we had in 2004. Our provision for income taxes increased $58 million to $56 million in Q1, a 52% effective tax rate higher than the 35% statutory tax rate primarily due to taxable income associated with the Q1 '05 transfer of certain assets from the U.S. to the international locations. We expect these asset transfers to result in tax expense for financial reporting above the statutory rate throughout 2005 and beneficially impact our effective tax rate over time.  

On a cash basis, since we have tax net operating losses, these asset transfers will not have a significant effect on cash taxes paid. We expect cash taxes paid to be approximately $25 million in 2005 compared with $4 million in 2004. We are endeavoring to optimize our global taxes on a cash basis rather than a financial reporting basis.  

GAAP net income was $78 million or $0.18 per diluted share compared with $111 million and $0.26 per diluted share. Excluding the impact of foreign exchange rates of $12 million, GAAP EPS would have been $0.16 per diluted share. The $33 million decline in GAAP net income is primarily due to the $58 million increase in income taxes and a $12 million net benefit from our early adoption of FAS 123R. Because although FAS 123R decreased operating income by $14 million, it created a $26 million onetime benefit from the cumulative effect of accounting change, which is classified below operating income on our income statement.  

Turning to the balance sheet, cash and marketable securities increased to $1.15 billion. In Q1 '05 we repaid EUR200 million or $265 million of our 6 7/8 Euro denominated convertible notes due 2010 at par. Over the past 18 months we have repaid over $600 million of our convertible debt, mitigating potential dilution of over 6 million shares and reducing annual cash interest expense by over $30 million. Inventory increased 43% to $403 million, and turns decreased 17% to 15.5 as we took advantage of buying opportunities from vendors, bolstered inventory levels to optimize in stock levels across product categories and expanded the breadth of product category selection in our fulfillment centers. We will continue to increase our mix of direct buying and existing and new product categories enabling us to offer even lower prices to customers.  

Our investment in fixed assets which includes net capitalized software development costs increased 13% from a year ago to $245 million. Our capital expenditures were $26 million, over half of which was software development cost.  

Our growth continues to be fueled by our relentless focus on the primary inputs of customer experience, convenience, selection and price. I will now share some of our recent progress for each of these inputs.  

We continue to innovate on behalf of customers to improve convenience. Recent examples include Amazon Prime. We're seeing especially heavy use of Amazon Prime in electronics, tools, kitchen and health and personal care. For $79 a year, Amazon Prime members get all you can eat free express shipping. Getting your items right away changes the way you use and think about Amazon.com.  

Amazon Prime members get unlimited express two-day shipping for free with no minimum purchase required on over a million eligible items sold by Amazon.com. Members can order as late as 6:30 PM Eastern time and still get their order the next day for only $3.99 per item and can share the benefits of Amazon Prime with up to four family members living in their household.  

With less than 90 days to go before its scheduled release, customers worldwide had already placed 700,000 pre-orders for Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, the sixth book in this epic series. On www Amazon.com, HP6 has been the top-selling book for 18 consecutive weeks and is priced at 17.99, a 40% discount. And we are offering our U.S. customers guaranteed delivery of the book on its release date Saturday, July 16, 2005 for the same price as standard shipping, and the service is free for Amazon Prime members. Customer self-service, content and defect reduction initiatives across the organization and more robust order and product information on our website helped our worldwide customer service team again achieve an over 20% year-over-year reduction in content per unit.  

A9.com launched A9.com Yellow Pages helping users find and discover local businesses in a completely new way, including block view which shows street view photos of millions of businesses and their surroundings. A9.com Yellow Pages now has over 26 million photographs of 15 cities including five new cities this month -- Fargo, Houston, Miami, Phoenix and Washington D.C..  

A9.com also launched A9 OpenSearch, a collection of technologies built on top of popular open standards to allow content providers to publish their search results in a format suitable for syndication. OpenSearch enables content providers' results to be displayed anywhere, anytime.  

Any site that has content and a search box can choose to return results on A9.com using OpenSearch RSFs. Customers can now view search results from the New York Times, Flickr, Wikpedia and over 150 content providers at  www.A9.com .  

We have recently introduced some interesting fonts and useful new book features available on hundreds of thousands of titles. First sentences are included on the top of product detail pages. For example, at the top of the detail page of The Kite Runner, just below the title it says, "I became what I am today at the age of 12 on a frigid overcast day in the winner of 1975."  

Statistically improbable phrases are also on the top of product detail pages. On the detail page of the top seller Blink: The Power of Thinking Without Thinking" underneath the first sentence content are the phrases rapid cognition, intuitive repulsion, sip test, adaptive unconscious and red decks. If you click on one of these words, we show you other books that also use these phrases.  

Also in the pop-up box on the cover images are books on related topics, concordance and text depth. Concordance is an alphabetized list of the most frequently occurring words in a book excluding common words. The font size of a word in the list is proportional to the number of times it occurs in the book, and you can hover your mouse over a word to see how many times it occurs or click on the word to see a list of book excerpts containing that word.  

For example, in the book Blink, the word man is mentioned 47 times and woman is mentioned 51 times. With text depths, we provide the number of characters, number of words and sentences, readability, index measures. We provide an educational level, reading ease scale and school grade appropriateness for the book and complexity measures such as syllables per word, percentage of complex words, those with over three syllables and words per sentence.  

For example, a (inaudible) has 6% complex words and a Flesch Kincaid Readability Index of 4.8, meaning it is appropriate for people with a fourth grade or higher reading level. In pioneering portfolio management, an unconventional approach to institutional investment has 31% complex words and a Flesch Kincaid Index of 16.2, meaning it may not be suitable for people without a college education.  

Our selection continues to increase worldwide. In April we acquired BookSurge, a global reader and inventory free book printing and fulfillment. BookSurge's catalog has thousands of titles that can be printed on demand and are available for sale on Amazon.com. BookSurge offers its inventory free book fulfillment network to publishers through BookSurge publishers services and to authors through BookSurge publishing.  

In addition retailers, wholesalers and distributors can leverage the BookSurge direct wholesale platform. The $1495 Philips HeartStart Home Defibrillator is a bestseller and the most wished for item in our health and personal care store. Content on the product detail page include a video customers can watch of the product in action and over 50 customer reviews, including thorough passionate reviews from paramedics, cardiologists and others with personal stories.  

Macy's joined our Merchants program and now offers its wide selection on Amazon.com, everything from exclusive Macy's brands like Inc. International Concepts Apparel and Hotel Collection Bedding to Macy's wide selection of jewelry, apparel, beauty, bedding, tableware and home furnishings products are now available to Amazon customers.  

Third-party sellers remain a key part of our selection expansion and active seller accounts. Merchants with an order from a customer during the preceding 12 months exceeded 925,000, up by a third year-over-year.  

We plan to continue expanding selection in existing categories and opening new categories worldwide in 2005 and thereafter. In addition, we will continue to explore opportunities for geographic expansion in the years to come.  

Finally, we continued with our strategy to continually lower prices for our worldwide customers. Our objective remains offering low prices every day and applying them broadly across our entire product range rather than discounting a small number of products for a limited period of time. We again lowered product prices on tens of thousands of media products worldwide in Q1 and on  www.Amazon.com . The average customer discount across both music video products purchase increased over 375 basis points year-over-year, including over 300 basis points on both books and DVDs.  

We also lowered product prices on thousands of EGM products in Q1, and the average customer discount electronics at Amazon.com increased by 40 basis points year-over-year.  

Worldwide adoption of free shipping increased again in Q1 when customers saved over $100 million in shipping through our free shipping offers and Amazon Prime. Continuing to lower product and shipping prices is an ongoing way of doing business. We look forward to working relentlessly further to lower prices throughout 2005.  

Additionally, we have made good progress with Merchants.com partners. We launched Diane Von Furstenberg's site, DVF.com. Next year we will be providing the technology behind a private-label branded website for leading UK retailer Marks & Spencer and its in store and telephone ordering and customer service systems. Oshkosh B'Gosh, a premier marketer of children's apparel and accessories and existing Merchants@ partner will use the Amazon services Enterprise solution for its online offering.  

Yesterday specialty apparel retailer, bebe and Amazon services announced it will be building a new private-label bebe.com website using our technology to provide bebe with tools to manage the content of the site to offer their online customers an experience that combines the distinct bebe brand with Amazon's shopping features.  

I will conclude my portion of today's call with guidance. Incorporated into our Q2 '05 guidance and the 2005 baseline expectations are the order trends that we have seen to date and what we believe today to be appropriately conservative assumptions. However, there is a high level of uncertainty surrounding fluctuations in the Euro/pound, Yen, Canadian and Yuan exchange rates, as well as the global economy and consumer spending and the impacts on both world events.  

While we're cautiously optimistic, it is not possible to accurately predict demand, and therefore, our actual results could differ materially from our guidance.  

Let me also remind everyone that we mark our Euro denominated debt to market at the end of each quarter, which results in a non-cash gain or loss for any movement in the Euro between reporting dates. We also have exposure to the Euro related to our interest expense on this Euro denominated debt. We incur a non-cash foreign currency gain or loss corresponding with intercompany balances denominated in foreign currencies, which are to be repaid among subsidiaries.  

Depending on the amount and timing, an unfavorable resolution of outstanding legal matters could materially affect our business, results of operations, financial positions or cash flows in a particular period.  

Our effective tax rate in 2005 and beyond is subject to significant variations based on our corporate structure, timing differences and current tax laws. And our current guidance assumes FX rates remain approximate where they have been recently compared with the prior year period and that we don't regard any additional intangible assets or any further revisions to our restructuring-related estimates.  

For Q2 we expect net sales of between $1.675 billion and $1.825 billion or growth between 21 and 32%. GAAP operating net income to be between $50 million and $80 million or a decline between 42% and 7%. This includes stock-based compensation of approximately $35 million. Keep in mind that in Q2 '04 stock-based compensation under our prior accounting method and other operating income were a combined $15 million.  

Excluding stock-based compensation and other operating income, we would anticipate operating income to be between $85 million and $115 million or between -16% and 14% growth. For calendar year 2005, we expect net sales of between $8.175 billion and $8.675 billion or growth of between 18 and 25%. GAAP operating income to be between $395 million and $510 million or between a 10% decline and 16% growth. This includes stock-based compensation of approximately $115 million.  

In 2004 stock-based compensation under our prior accounting method and other operating income combined was $50 million. Excluding stock-based compensation and other operating income, we anticipate operating income to be between 510 and $625 million or growth of between 4% and 28%. And we expect free cash flow to grow year-over-year with capital expenditures including capitalized software development costs for approximately $175 million.  

Our financial focus is on long-term growth and free cash flow per share. We're confident that if we continue to improve the customer experience, including increasing selection and lowering prices and execute efficiently, our value proposition as well as our free cash flow will further expand.  

Thanks and with that, Tim, let's move to questions.  

TIM STONE: Thanks, Tom. Let's move onto the Q&A portion of the call with Jeff and Tom. Operator, please remind our listeners how to ask a question.  

OPERATOR: (OPERATOR INSTRUCTIONS). Safa Rashtchy, Piper Jaffray.  

SAFA RASHTCHY, ANALYST, PIPER JAFFRAY: Thank you. Could you comment on the expectation that you have for growth of free cash flow? I believe this was the first quarter that you had a sequential decline in the trailing 12 months free cash flow. And also in terms of the international growth you have been reporting, it appears to me, and I may be wrong on this as we had a quick look at the filing, but it appears to me that there was a noticeable drop in the growth rate in Q1. Were there any one-time factors, especially on the media side, that might have contributed to that, or is this related (inaudible) we should expect for national growth?  

TOM SZKUTAK: In terms of the first part of your question, free cash flow grew 21% to $417 million on a trailing 12 month basis. And what you are seeing is we certainly saw higher inventories year-over-year as I mentioned in the opening remarks, you know, as we expanded existing and new categories, as we got our in stock levels up and we took advantage of buying opportunities.  

In addition to that, you are seeing capital expenditures increase year-over-year. You know we spent $26 million in CapEx in Q1. That is up from $9 million last year in Q1. And again, a big piece of that is more than half of the CapEx is actually capitalized software as we have talked about for the technology initiatives that we have underway. So that handles the free cash flow.  

You mentioned something about guidance going forward. The only thing we have said related to free cash flow for the year is that it would be up year-over-year.  

In terms of international, you know we saw international growth of 28%, up 24% year-over-year. Certainly our international segment has become more meaningful. Our revenue was $875 million, which is higher than our North America segment revenues were in Q1 of '04. And it is growing at a faster rate. So again, we're certainly pleased with what we see there.  

Obviously keep in mind from our overall growth standpoint we are overlapping to a smaller extent -- we had the benefit of a leap year last year. We had Easter falling into a different quarter, you know, year-over-year. So those are some of the impacts. But again, we are very pleased with what we're seeing in our international segment.  

Beyond the growth part that we saw I mean up 28% year-over-year, we saw segment operating income growth of 51% as well. So again, we're very pleased with our international segment.  

OPERATOR: Mark Mahaney, American Technology Research.  

MARK MAHANEY, ANALYST, AMERICAN TECHNOLOGY RESEARCH: Two questions. The first is you have announced a couple of new merchant relationships recently. What is the status of expanding your merchant networks, Merchants@Amazon internationally?  

And secondly, when can you -- do you want to draw a line in the sand in terms of when the pro forma operating income margins can stabilize and then start to grow again there? Do you want to say it is the fourth quarter or the first quarter of next year?  

TOM SZKUTAK: In terms of -- I will take the second part first -- you know again our goal is to maximize free cash flow per share over time. And as part of that, we want to maximize operating profit dollars to help grow free cash flow over time. So as we have said in the past, that is really our goal, and that is how we think about it.  

JEFF BEZOS, PRESIDENT, CEO & CHAIRMAN, AMAZON.COM, INC.: I will add on the Merchants.com piece, we're seeing as you can see from the recent announcements that we have been making, very strong interest in building private-label e-commerce websites for other merchants who want to have an Amazon.com like experience for their customers. We are offering not only the website, but we are also finding the people are interested in having fulfillment and customer service applications, too.  

OPERATOR: Jeetil Patel, Deutsche Bank Securities.  

JEETIL PATEL, ANALYST, DEUTSCHE BANK SECURITIES: A couple of questions. Can you in just looking at the Merchants.com strategy with announcements like Marks & Spencer and bebe and others, can you just characterize I guess it seems like a bit of an extension of the strategy you had on leveraging the platform from a technology and distribution standpoint, but somewhat nascent in terms of doing this over the past couple of years, why the need to kind of go expand from a Merchants.com standpoint now? Has there been a change in the marketplace among the retail partners you are working with in terms of amortization of e-commerce cost finally runout, off their P&Ls or something that has changed for them to look at outsourcing their platforms to you.  

And second, as it relates to international, obviously Safa pointed out the growth rate. But can you characterize how Germany is performing? Can you see anything unique or interesting about that market or changes in the economies that are influencing e-commerce growth rates as a whole in that marketplace?  

JEFF BEZOS: I will take the first part of the question on Merchants.com. Certainly from some of the recent announcements you are seeing we're getting some good traction in launching new partners. I don't think there is anything new there. Again, it is just a way that we can leverage our platform with these partners you know in a variety of different ways.  

TOM SZKUTAK: The only thing I would add to that is that we are seeing -- one of the things that you see is as people start to build e-commerce businesses of any scale, they find that scaling those businesses and making them operate at scale is much harder than when it is being done at very small scale. And so that is one of the -- that may be one of the structural things that you're seeing in the recent announcements.  

JEFF BEZOS: And in terms of the second part of your question, we have not broken out any of the individual countries within international. So I cannot speak much to Germany, except to say that we're certainly pleased with our total overall international results with revenues being up 28% year-over-year.  

JEETIL PATEL: From a cost standpoint and timed resources standpoint, what do you think it takes -- is it a significant investment on your part to launch incremental Merchants.com partners, or is it a leverage the tools that you have already built-up over the past several years?  

JEFF BEZOS: One of the things that you see in our technology and content line is us hiring more software engineers and computer scientists. One of the things that is happening there is we are investing substantially in our seller platform and the different pieces of that. But that is -- it is a single platform, so there is not an undue amount of custom software and development for these particular Merchants.com private-label solutions. So we are able to use the platform that we have been investing in over the years to service their needs.  

OPERATOR: Anthony Noto, Goldman Sachs.  

ANTHONY NOTO, ANALYST, GOLDMAN SACHS: Tom, I was wondering if you could talk about the other domestic or other North American revenue of $46 million? What is in that line item specifically that is causing the growth on a year-over-year basis, and do you see that staying at that level? And how should we think about the operating margin related to that?  

The second thing, I want to go back to international. What do you think your plan was implied in your guidance for the first quarter? It grew 28%, which obviously is a big deceleration. It has been talked about on the call. I'm just trying to understand where was it relative to what you thought? And the one thing that would have been a driver of it being below your expectations if that was the case.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. In terms of your first question, other revenue within North America, there are a number of drivers. The two principle ones are revenue from our credit card, cobranded credit card. The second is Merchants.com.  

In terms of international, you know we don't breakout our guidance between the segments. But as you can tell from the results that we had, our revenue guidance for Q1 was 1.8 billion to 1.95 billion. We came in at 1.9 billion, well within our guidance and certainly in the upper half of guidance. And again, we are not breaking out any individual segments or countries or categories within that.  

ANTHONY NOTO: Sure, no, I completely understand. I'm just trying to get a sense for did we forecasting 30% international media growth relative to 33% year-over-year in the December quarter, did we completely miss some year-over-year comparison, or did something fundamentally change your international media business just so as we can think about the business going forward we could better assess it. I'm just trying to focus on the difference between those two. Thanks.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Right. I think -- again, I don't think it is appropriate to comment on any specific categories or geographies as it relates to guidance. But keep in mind as you think about international and our total, first of all, we are overlapping a leap year, which again is a small impact.  

Also, the Easter and within Europe it is the Easter holiday period is in different quarters this year versus last. These are certainly known items to us when we put together our guidance.  

OPERATOR: Douglas Anmuth, Lehman Brothers.  

DOUGLAS ANMUTH, ANALYST, LEHMAN BROTHERS: I just had a couple of questions around Amazon Prime. I was just curious what kind of traction you are seeing versus your expectations when you first launched the program? And you mentioned a few categories that are having better adoption there. Are you really seeing a difference in the type of products that members are ordering, and also how it is impacting your average order value?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Yes, we are. We are seeing a disproportionate use in those categories that we listed. The program is off to a very good start, and it appeals to active customers, people who buy from Amazon.com multiple times a year. Convenience-oriented customers who don't want to take on the mental task of waiting to find a $25 order. Want to be able to adjust get things done off the top of their list and get the items fast. And it does change the user perception of Amazon.com. As you use it for awhile, you start to realize that you can use Amazon.com for a much larger fraction of your purchases than you thought you could when items were taking longer to arrive.  

OPERATOR: Mark Rowen, Prudential.  

MARK ROWEN, ANALYST, PRUDENTIAL: A couple of questions. First, in U.S. media the 17% growth and the 18% last quarter, which was an acceleration as you mentioned from the last four years, was there any mix shift from third-party to first-party sales that helped accelerate that, or was unit volume also up in those same levels? And I don't know if I missed it, but did you give out third-party sales as a percentage of units for the quarter?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. I will take the second half of the question first. Our third-party units as a percentage of the total was 27%. That is up from 23% last year.  

Mark, we don't give the split-out between third-party and retail units. But again, you characterized the growth correctly. The North America media growth, both this quarter and last quarter, were our two fastest quarters that we have had in the past four years. We're very pleased with it both from a retail and a third-party standpoint.  

MARK ROWEN: I'm not asking for the breakout of it. I'm just asking if there was a mix shift, and if that helped accelerate the revenue growth in the last couple of quarters?  

TOM SZKUTAK: I would say that we are -- the way I would characterize it is we're happy with -- we're pleased with the performance of both.  

MARK ROWEN: Okay. And could you give us an update on the Toys "R" Us lawsuit and what your plans are for this holiday season for toys?  

JEFF BEZOS: We're pleased with the way that is going. Beyond what we say in our official filings, we don't comment on active litigation. Certainly we will stick to that policy here. But we are -- we're in the process of and we will continue to supplement our U.S. toy selection with merchandise from other sellers.  

OPERATOR: Justin Post, Merrill Lynch.  

JUSTIN POST, ANALYST, MERRILL LYNCH: Can you talk a little bit about your sources of traffic, where most of your traffic comes from, and how that has changed over time? Also, can you talk about the growing use of search comparison sites for shopping? Has that had any impact on your business?  

TOM SZKUTAK: The majority of our traffic has been and continues to come from people coming directly to Amazon.com. We also do a variety of online marketing to get people to come to the site. Our best marketing dollars we believe are first spent on customer experience which includes lowering prices for customers and the free shipping initiatives, Amazon Prime, etc.  

So we look first to spend dollars on customer experience and then on measurable marketing activities, and continue to see very strong what we call direct traffic, people coming straight to Amazon.com.  

JUSTIN POST: And do you think growing use of search has made people more price conscious over the last few quarters?  

JEFF BEZOS: No, I would not say that. I think that there is a long-term trend that has been going on for a much longer period than that and will continue over the next number of decades where customers have better and better information. And that is basically we optimize our business based on that belief, that customers will continue to be empowered with better information, and that will happen online and off. We're organizing our business over time to do well in that kind of scenario.  

OPERATOR: Bridget Niget, Lazard.  

BRIDGET NIGET, ANALYST, LAZARD: Hello. Hey, guys. I just had a question. I am trying to compare apples-to-apples, and maybe, Tim, this is better served off-line. But what is going on in the operating expense line, like, for example, (inaudible) intangible amortization, we had a North American asset litigation settlement. But apples-to-apples Q1 '04 and Q1 '03, if you want me to call you back off-line, that is fine, too.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Why don't I --  

BRIDGET NIGET: I don't know what is the cleanest way to handle that?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. If you're trying to get our operating income, probably the best thing to do, if I understand your question correctly, is if you look at our segment information and our press release on page 6, you will see the individual segments and you will also see the consolidated segment, and the consolidated segment operating income was $128 million, which we mentioned was up 10% year-over-year.  

Included in that 128 was the $8 million increase for possible settlements of litigation, as well as the write-down of the assets to remove from service of $5 million. If you take the 128 and you add the 13, you get 141 or a year-over-year increase of 21%. So that gives you a pretty good I think apples-to-apples comparison of consolidated segment results.  

BRIDGET NIGET: And in 2004, were there any similar adds or minuses?  

TOM SZKUTAK: No.  

BRIDGET NIGET: Okay, and then 2003 similarly as well, that is pretty clean?  

TOM SZKUTAK: I would have to go back to --  

BRIDGET NIGET: Okay. But that would at least put it out apples-to-apples to 2004?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Correct.  

OPERATOR: Heath Terry, CS First Boston.  

HEATH TERRY, ANALYST, CS FIRST BOSTON: Great. Can you talk a little bit more about the additional third-parties, the deals that you are signing, particularly the Marks & Spencer deal in Europe? Is there a potential for this deal to evolve over time to more of the third-party relationships that you have in the U.S. where you're able to include that inventory with your own? Can you also give us an idea of how the finances behind those kind of deals are going to work where we will see the income impact on the income statement as well as the segment breakdown?  

TOM SZKUTAK: In terms of the Marks & Spencer partnership, all of our arrangements are multi-year arrangements. We don't disclose specific details of any particular one, and I'm not sure to say much more beyond that.  

Again, we are excited about the relationship. It is certainly a very good one as it relates to a very (inaudible) reseller within Europe and in the UK. So we are excited about it.  

HEATH TERRY: You know, I'm not looking for really any specifics, but if you can just kind of talk about generally the structure of those kind of relationships, particularly obviously Marks & Spencer's covers a lot of waterfront in terms of product availability, to the extent that that would give you an advantage in expanding your product line outside of the U.S. where you still have a much broader product line in the U.S. relative to the bigger market share in Europe.  

TOM SZKUTAK: The arrangement does contemplate having that selection available on Amazon.co.uk as part of our Merchants@ program at some point in the future. And the Marks & Spencer partnership is a big win for Amazon services in Europe, and we are super excited about it.  

OPERATOR: Paul Keyung (ph), CIBC.  

PAUL KEYUNG, ANALYST, CIBC: Looking at -- I see some decent growth in your third-party business this year and this quarter. I'm just curious as to if you have been able to maintain your gross profit per transaction metrics for third-party versus your sort of traditional retail sales?  

TOM SZKUTAK: You know, we're certainly pleased with our third-party business and our retail business. We have not disclosed historical results or individual quarter results on third-party versus retail.  

What we have said in the past, though, is as we try to price these third-party relationships from a Merchants@ standpoint, we try to price them such that our contribution profit dollars per unit are approximately the same, and that is something that we continue to try to do.  

PAUL KEYUNG: And has it stayed the same over the last couple of quarters or so?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Yes, again we have not disclosed any historical results on that. But it is certainly something on an ongoing basis that we try to do.  

OPERATOR: Robert Peck, Bear Stearns.  

ROBERT PECK, ANALYST, BEAR STEARNS: I just had a couple of quick questions here. One is, could you comment on any potential DVD partnerships in the U.S.?  

Number two is, could you comment on your fulfillment and what you're doing there, taking initiatives to maybe lower that as a percent of revenues? Does it make sense to use PayPal? Maybe your own PayPal service?  

And lastly, how should we think about investments from Amazon? You think about 43 Things, the funding of Delicious, BookSurge, Moby Pocket. Could you give us an idea of how we should be thinking about that on a dollar basis as well as strategically?  

TOM SZKUTAK: In terms of DVD, I'm assuming you are referring to our rental business. We have a DVD rental business in the UK. Beyond that, we will have a long-standing practice of not talking about what we will do in other geographies. But certainly it is very early in the UK, but we are pleased with what we see there.  

In terms of fulfillment, our team globally continues to try to make sure that we optimize for customers, as well as get efficiencies over time. So we will continue to do that. That includes everything certainly from our traditional CS and fulfillment costs, as well as our credit card fees as well.  

You mentioned PayPal. Certainly I would not comment on that, but we're certainly always trying to do the right thing in terms of having the right payment methods for customers.  

And then the last part of your question, I'm sorry was what again?  

ROBERT PECK: On your investment strategy going forward, you know with the funding of Delicious, 43 Things, Moby Pocket, BookSurge, how should we in the investment community think about the dollar amount going forward as far as investments, as well as probably more importantly the strategic direction for the Company?  

JEFF BEZOS: Well, we have always said that we are -- certainly we have used a lot of dollars to develop technology internally to make sure we do the right things for customers over the long-term where we see opportunities as well to supplement that externally. These are some examples of that. We will certainly do that.  

Some of the things that we are able to invest in dollarwise can be quite small. In terms of executive bandwidth or distractions, it can also be quite small as long as they are separable and not conflated with other things that we are doing. So that is certainly a factor that we take into consideration.  

When you look at where we are investing more significantly, we're looking at areas like our seller platform, like our digital initiatives, and there are a number of things where other customer experience initiatives on the website that where we continue to increase the amount of spending, and you can see that in our technology and content line.  

TIM STONE: Thank you for joining us on the call today and for your questions. A replay will be available on our IR website at least through the end of the quarter, and we appreciate your interest in Amazon.com. We will look forward to talking to you again next quarter.  

OPERATOR: That does conclude today's conference call. I would like to thank everyone for their participation.

 Q4  2004  Amazon .com, Inc. Earnings Conference Call - Final
