   LP
OPERATOR: Thank you for standing by and good day, everyone. Welcome to the Amazon.com fourth quarter 2004 financial results conference call. Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to the Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Tim Stone. Please go ahead, sir.  

TIM STONE, VP OF IR, AMAZON.COM, INC.: Hello. Welcome to our Q4 '04 financial results conference call. Joining us today is Jeff Bezos, our founder and CEO, who will begin the call by discussing Amazon's first ever membership service; and Tom Szkutak, our CFO. Both Jeff and Tom will be available for Q&A.  

   TD
The following discussion and responses to your questions reflect managements views as of today, February 2, 2005 only. It will include forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially. Additional information about factors that could potentially impact our financial results is included in today's press release and our filings with the SEC including our 2003 annual report on Form 10-K.  

As you listen to today's call, we encourage you to have our press release in front of you, which includes our financial results as well as metrics and commentary on the quarter. During this call we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. In our press release, slides accompanying this webcast, and our filings with the SEC, each of which is posted on our IR website, you will find additional disclosures regarding these non-GAAP measures, including reconciliations of these measures with comparable GAAP measures. Finally, unless otherwise stated, all comparisons in this call will be against results for the comparable period of 2003.  

Before Tom reviews the results, let me now turn the call over to Jeff.  

JEFF BEZOS, CHAIRMAN, PRESIDENT, CEO, AMAZON.COM, INC.: Thanks, Tim. During the 2000 and 2001 holiday seasons, Amazon.com tested free shipping on our U.S. website with orders over $99 qualifying for free shipping. 6 months later, in June of 2002 we tested a lower minimum order of $49. 2 months after that we tested a lower threshold of $25, and in January of 2003 we announced our discussion to make free Super Saver Shipping on orders of over $25, a full time year-round offer. We plan to keep free Super Saver Shipping in place indefinitely and each of our international sites now offers free shipping.  

We knew our customers would benefit from free shipping, but we tested it carefully because we also knew it would be expensive for the Company. And it has been. In 1999 we generated a worldwide profit on shipping of $12 million, while in 2004 we generated a loss on shipping of $197 million. This is a direct give back to customers. As you know, free, Super Saver Shipping requires a $25 minimum order size. And customers who use Super Saver Shipping accept an additional 3 to 5 business day delay relative to our standard shipping, which means the customers receive their orders in approximately 8 to 10 business days.  

Today, I'm very excited to announce a new shipping innovation for our customers, Amazon Prime, our first ever membership program offering all you can eat express shipping. The program is simple. For a flat membership fee of $79 per year, Amazon Prime members get unlimited express 2-day shipping for free with no minimum purchase requirements. Amazon Prime members also can choose overnight shipping for only $3.99 per item. Keep in mind that customers normally pay $9.48 for 2-day shipping on a single book and $16.48 for overnight shipping. In addition, Amazon Prime members can place their orders as late as 6:30 p.m. Eastern time and still receive their item overnight for only $3.99 or receive the item the day after that for free. With these cut off times, members can make their purchase decisions late in the day and still get their items quickly.  

With Amazon Prime membership, there's no minimum purchase to think about, no need to combine items into a single order and with Amazon Prime there's no fretting over whether to indulge in express shipping. After paying a fixed annual fee, members have peace of mind throughout the year to buy as many items as they like, pay no additional shipping charge and get the orders sent quickly to the their door. It's easy to become an Amazon Prime member, if you are already an Amazon customer you can sign up for membership with 1 click.  

At no additional cost, Amazon Prime members can share the membership with up to 4 family members living in their household. So for example, a husband and wife can pay a single $79 membership fee, but still shop separately using their only Amazon accounts and getting their own separate personalized recommendations. When you become a member, our product detail pages will appear differently for you. There will be a special horizontal buy box at the top of each detail page with a drop down list of shipping addresses and special Amazon Prime buy buttons to order items overnight for $3.99 or express 2-day for free.  

We expect Amazon Prime to be expensive for the Company in the short term, perhaps the most expensive thing we've done since free Super Saver Shipping. However, over the long term, we believe it will drive incremental demand just as Super Saver Shipping has done. Super Saver Shipping is one of the factors driving free cash flow and North American growth, including North America media, in Q4, both of which grew at their fastest rate in 16 quarters.  

Amazon Prime improves the customer experience and simplifies the decision process for customers. One of the great things about Amazon Prime is it applies broadly across our many categories, including books, music, DVDs, consumer electronics, tools, kitchen, house wares, apparel, jewelry, watches, health and personal care and more. For a single annual fee, members can get expedited shipping for free on over 1 million in-stock products across our dozens of categories.  

We will be closely monitoring Amazon Prime on metrics, such as shopping frequency and conversion. As with lower product prices, expanded selection, improved convenience, continued technology innovations and free Super Saver Shipping, Amazon Prime is good for customers. And over the long term, the interest of customers and shareholders are aligned.  

Now I will turn the call over to Tom.  

TOM SZKUTAK, CFO, SVP, AMAZON.COM, INC.: Thanks, Jeff. This was another successful year and quarter for Amazon.com and we are grateful to our customers, our global teams and our partners for helping deliver these results.  

Let me start by reviewing 2004 in full. Free cash flow grew 38 percent to $477 million, driven by improvements in revenue and operating profit. The combination of common stock and stock-base awards outstanding was 434 million shares compared with 433 million a year ago. Return on invested capital increased to 44 percent, up from 38 percent, calculated at trailing 12-month free cash flow divided by average total assets minus average current liabilities. Our long-term expectation remains achieving triple-digit returns on invested capital.  

Revenue grew 31 percent to $6.92 billion or 26 percent excluding $276 million of favorable year-over-year impact from foreign exchange. And our international segment reached sales of over $3 billion. Gross profit grew $345 million to $1.6 billion and gross margin declined 73 basis points to 23.1 percent driven by lower prices, increased adoption of free shipping and continued mix shift from North America to international and from media to electronics and other general merchandise. Offset partially by an increase in other revenues and third-party sales.  

Consolidated segment operating income grew 36 percent to $490 million or 30 percent excluding the $20 million of favorable year-over-year impact from foreign exchange. Operating margin improved 22 basis points to 7.1 percent. North America segment operating income grew $38 million to $321 million while segment-operating margin decreased 35 basis points to 8.3 percent. International segment operating income more than doubled to $169 million and segment-operating margin improved 161 bases points to 5.5 percent.  

It remains our long-term expectation that worldwide operating margins will reach the low double digits. That said, the Company's goal is to maximize profit dollars not percentages, ultimately maximizing free cash flow and free cash flow per share.  

Turning to the balance sheet, inventory increased 63 percent to $480 million, an average 5 percent of revenues. Inventory turns decreased from 18 to 16 as we took advantage of buying opportunities from vendors, bolstered inventory levels to optimize in-stock levels across product categories and expanded the breath of product category selection in our fulfillment centers. We will continue to increase our direct buying efforts in existing and new product categories, enabling us to extend even lower prices to customers. We again had an operating cycle of greater than negative 20 days, which we believe to be sustainable over the long-term.  

Our investment in fixed assets, which includes net capitalized software development costs, increased 10 percent from a year ago to $246 million. Our capital expenditures were $89 million, of which half was software development cost. Cash and marketable securities increased to $1.78 billion, including $55 million from favorable movements in foreign exchange rates, which benefited our cash balances held in foreign currencies. During the year we repaid $150 million of our 4 and 3/4 convertible subordinated notes and have separately announced today we will be redeeming 200 million Euros or approximately $260 million at recent Euro dollar exchange rates. And of our 6 and 7/8 Euro denominated convertible subordinated notes due 2010 at par, plus accrued and unpaid interest. These 2 redemptions combined to mitigate potential dilution of over 4 million shares and reduce our annual cash interest expense by approximately $25 million.  

Now, a few comments on the fourth quarter. On the income statement, revenue grew 31 percent to $2.54 billion or 26 percent excluding $85 million of favorable year-over-year impact from foreign exchange. Unit growth for the quarter was also 26 percent and third-party units as a percentage of total units were 26 percent, up from 24 percent in Q4 of '03. Gross profit grew 28 percent to $544 million and gross margin decreased 51 basis points to 21.4 percent driven by continued product price reductions, product and geographic mix shifts and a $22 million greater shipping loss offset partially by increases in other revenue and third party sales.  

Marketing expense rose 44 percent year-over-year to $58 million. We expect absolute amounts spent in marketing to increase over time. G&A costs increased 38 percent year-over-year primarily due to increases in professional and litigation costs. We expect absolute amounts spent in G&A to increase over time. Consolidated segment operating income grew 16 percent to $177 million or 13 percent excluding $5 million of favorable year-over-year impact from foreign exchange. Operating margin decreased 88 basis points to 7 percent.  

In the North America segment, revenue grew 22 percent to $1.39 billion, the fastest growth in 16 quarters. Media revenue grew 18 percent to $885 million; also the fastest rate of growth in 16 quarters, while EGM, or electronics and other general merchandise revenue grew 27 percent to $449 million, representing a record 32 percent of total segment revenues. And for the 4-day Thanksgiving weekend consumer electronic sales on  www.amazon.com  surpassed book sales for the first time.  

Gross profit grew 23 percent to $355 million, and gross margin increased 19 basis points to 25.5 percent. Primarily due to a $20 million increase in high margin, other revenues, and third party sales, partially offset by our price reduction of the cross product categories, product mix shift and free shipping. Free shipping drove an incremental $6 million of net shipping loss compared with fourth quarter 2003.  

In North America segment-operating income increased $8 million to $122 million, and operating margin declined from 10 percent to 8.8 percent due to higher operating expenses, including increased technology and content expenses. As a reminder, the majority of our technology and content costs are incurred in the U.S. and most of them are allocated to the North America segment.  

In the international segment, revenue grew 43 percent to $1.15 billion, accounting for 45 percent of worldwide sales. Revenue growth was 33 percent adjusting for the $83 million year-over-year benefit from foreign exchange rates. Media revenue grew 33 percent to $911 million, and for the first time was higher than North America media revenue. EGM revenue grew 96 percent to $237 million, representing 21 percent of total segment revenues up over 550 basis points. And for the weekend before Christmas in Germany, electronics and photo sales surpassed book sales for the first time.  

Gross profit grew 37 percent to $190 million, while gross margin decreased 66 basis points to 16.5 percent driven by increased free shipping, product price reductions and mix shift, partially offset by third-party sales. Increased adoption of our free shipping offers contributed to an incremental $16 million of net shipping loss compared with fourth quarter of 2003.  

International segment operating income increased $17 million or 43 percent to $55 million and the operating margin was flat at 4.8 percent. Pro forma net income increased to $394 million or $0.93 per diluted share compared with $125 million and $0.29 per diluted share for fourth quarter 2003.  

GAAP net income was $347 million, or $0.82 per diluted share compared with $73 million and $0.17 per diluted share for fourth quarter 2003. The $47 million difference between pro forma and GAAP net income was due largely to a $77 million loss on re-measurement of our Euro denominated debt and $20 million in stock-based compensation offset partially by a $44 million gain related to the impact of FX on inter-company balances.  

In Q4, based on our evaluation of the likelihood of realization of deferred tax assets, we determined that $363 million of our deferred tax asset is realizable through future operations and recorded a benefit of $244 million to our provision for income taxes and a direct credit to stockholders equity for $106 million. Excluding the $244 million benefit for income taxes, fourth quarter pro forma net income would have been $149 million or $0.35 per diluted share and GAAP net income would have been $103 million or $0.24 per diluted share.  

We expect net income for 2005 to decline because we expect a tax provision in 2005 rather than the large tax benefit we received in 2004. From a cash perspective we expect our taxes paid in 2005 to be approximately $25 million compared with $4 million in 2004. Our growth continues to be fueled by our relentless focus on the primary inputs of customer experience, convenience, selection and price.  

I will now share some of our recent progress for each of these inputs. We continue to innovate on behalf of customers to improve convenience. In addition to our new Amazon Prime membership program, which Jeff mentioned at the outset of the call, recent examples include, approved efficiency allowed our U.S. fulfillment centers to extend the standard shipping holiday deadline by an additional 2 days to December 20. While again shipping more than 99 percent of all orders in time to meet holiday deadlines. Demonstrated peak holiday unit capacity across our worldwide network increased 25 percent. On our peak day we received orders for a record 2.8 million units worldwide, or 32 items per second, a 33 percent increase over the peak unit day in holiday 2003.  

Our U.K. site introduced a DVD rental service featuring tens of thousands of DVD titles for next-day rental with plans that start from just 7 pounds 99 per month. In addition, rental members received an extra 10 percent discount off Amazon's already low prices on all of their DVD purchases from Amazon.co.uk. Results to date have exceeded our expectations and we remain well-positioned to offer this service in other geographies.  

Our Japanese site introduced Amazon's scan search, enabling Japanese cell phone users to scan bar codes at their local stores and retrieve a real-time Amazon detail page for the item scanned, complete with pricing information, customer reviews, and an ability to purchase the item with just 1 click. We believe over time pricing information in all markets will only become more transparent, on-line and off, which we view as a positive development relative to our model and strategy.  

We launched several new discovery features to help products find customers, including most wished for items, those recently added most often to wish lists. Top rated items, those rated highest by customers who recently wrote reviews. Popular gifts, items most often given as gifts by customers. And a self-explanatory, what similar items do customers ultimately buy after viewing this item. Customers across worldwide sites have already placed hundreds of thousands of pre-orders for Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, the sixth installments in the popular book series due to be released on July 16, 2005.  

Our A9.com subsidiary launched A9.com yellow pages helping users find and discover local businesses in a completely new way, including Block View a powerful technology which brings the Yellow Pages to life by showing a street view of millions of businesses and their surroundings. Block View allows its users to see storefronts and virtually walk up and down the streets of currently more than 10 U.S. cities using over 20 million photographs. In addition, A9.com Yellow Pages uses features on Amazon.com that allow users to review, rate, provide more information, create lists and get recommendations on over 14 million businesses across the U.S. A9.com Yellow Pages are available now on the A9.com home page at  www.A9.com .  

2004 was another year of innovation as we substantially increased our technology teams. And in 2005 we anticipate continuing to hire computer scientists and software engineers to invest in further innovation for customers. We expect annual technology and content costs devoted to our stellar platform, search, Web services, digital and other initiatives to increase again in absolute dollars in 2005.  

In addition to our geographic expansion into China, we also expanded product selection across sites worldwide. We introduced 9 new categories worldwide in 2004, including new toy stores in Germany and Japan, these stores featuring over 20,000 toys, games and hobby products from Amazon with additional marketplace selection that were popular with customers during the holidays becoming the second biggest category launch in those countries behind books own a unit sold basis for the categories first 90 days.  

We officially launched our jewelry and watches store in the U.S. and introduced Beta version of beauty and musical instruments. These 3 categories combined have increased product selection by over 150,000 unique items. From November 25 to December 23, our jewelry and watches store sold more than 1 watch per minute.  

Our consumer electronic store is now directly sourcing extensive product selection from Panasonic and Sony and we have been named a strategic growth account by Sony Corporation. And in the December issue of Consumer Reports, Amazon.com was named the best place to shop for electronics for price and selection on-line and off.  

Third-party sellers are a key part of our selection expansion, and active seller accounts, merchants with an order from a customer during the preceding 12 months, reached over 850,000 in 2004, up 35 percent year-over-year. We plan to continue expanding selection in existing categories and opening new categories worldwide in 2005 and thereafter. In addition, we will continue to explore opportunities for geographic expansion in the years to come.  

Finally, in Q4 in 2004 we continue with our strategy to continually lower prices for our worldwide customers. Our objective is not to discount a small number of products for a limited period of time, but rather to offer low prices every day and apply them broadly across our entire product range. We continue to lower prices on hundreds of thousands of media products for sale at Amazon.com.  

The average customer discount across books, music and video products purchased increased over 200 basis points in Q4. Examples of price reductions include increased discounts on books over $15 from 30 percent to 32 percent. And we are experimenting with even greater discounts for different price points in book to genre, including 34 percent off books over $25, selected DVD top sellers are discounted 35 percent and every day mid-list title discounts have increased 1,000 basis points during 2004.  

Our German site introduced free shipping for all book orders with no minimum order amount and a DVD price guarantee. Customers finding DVD prices lower off-line or on-line receive gift certificates for future purchase equal to the difference in price. For the second time in 15 months, our UK site reduced the threshold for free shipping, dropping the minimum required order from 25 pounds to be 19 pounds in September 2004. Customers embraced the reduction this holiday period increasing their free shipping adoption substantially.  

Worldwide adoption of free shipping increased in Q4 and 2004, and customers again saved hundreds of millions of dollars with free shipping in 2004. Continuing to lower product and shipping prices is an ongoing way of doing business, and we look forward to working relentlessly to lower prices in 2005.  

I'll conclude my portion of today's call with guidance. Incorporated into our Q1 '05 guidance in 2005 baseline expectations are the order trends that we've seen to date and what we believe today to be appropriately conservative assumptions. However, there is a high level of uncertainty surrounding the fluctuation in the Euro, pound, yen, Canadian dollar and Juan [ph] exchange rates, as well as the global economy, consumer spending and the impact on both of world events. While we are cautiously optimistic, it is not possible to accurately predict demands and therefore our actual result could differ materially from our guidance.  

Our operating results could change substantially if FX moved where they have been recently and we will not give intra quarter adjustments to guidance based on FX movements. Let me also remind everyone that we mark our Euro denominated debt to market at the end of each quarter, which results in a non-cash gain or loss for any movement in the Euro between reporting dates. We also have exposure to the Euro related to our unhedged interest expense on this Euro denominated debt.  

We incur a non-cash foreign currency gain or loss corresponding with intra company balances denominated in foreign currencies, which have been paid among subsidiaries. And our effective tax rates in 2005 and beyond are subject to significant variation base on our planned tax structure, timing differences and current tax laws. Given the inherent uncertainty in these non-operating items, it is not possible to accurately predict net income and net income per share, nor do we optimize for these 2 measures internally. Therefore, we do not provide guidance beyond operating income, which could roughly trend with free cash flow on a trailing 12-month basis. We encourage investors to consider focusing their forecasting efforts for our business on free cash flow, free cash flow per share and the primary drivers of each, operating income and shares rather than net income and net income per share.  

Beginning with Q1 we don't intend to report or provide guidance on pro forma operating income or net income measures. However, we plan to continue disclosing stock-based compensation, other operating expense, re-measurements in other line items and our results of operations.  

For the March quarter, we expect net sales of between $1.8 billion and $1.95 billion, or growth of between 18 and 27 percent, assuming FX rates remain approximately where they've been recently compared with the prior-year period. Operating income to be between $80 million and $110 million. This assumes, among other things, that we early adopt FAS 123R on January 1, 2005, with resulting stock-based compensation of approximately $25 million, that we do not record any further revisions to our restructuring related estimates.  

Also as Jeff mentioned, we expect Amazon Prime to be an expensive investment in customer experience and our expectations do reflect estimated expenses associated with Amazon Prime. For the calendar year 2005, we expect net sales of between $8.05 billion, and $8.65 billion, a growth of between 16 and 25 percent, assuming FX rates remain approximately where they've been recently compared with the prior year.  

Operating income to be between $385 million and $510 million, this assumes among other things that we early adopt FAS 123R on January 1, 2005, with resulting stock-based compensation of approximately $115 million, and that we do not record any further revisions to our restructuring related estimates. Our full-year expectations also reflect estimated expenses associated with Amazon Prime. Capital expenditures, including capitalized software development costs to be approximately $175 million. We expect free cash flow to continue to grow year-over-year.  

Before turning to questions, I want to take a moment to reflect back to our April, 2002, shareholder letter in which we talked about generating meaningful sustained free cash flow, while limiting share count growth by targeting net dilution stock-based awards on average of 3 percent. I'm pleased to report that in the 3 years since 2001, the Company has generated over $950 million in free cash flow while actually decreasing shares plus equity awards outstanding.  

While driving that free cash flow, we invested over $650 million in technology and content, innovating on behalf of customers. We drove higher adoption of free shipping and we continued to lower product prices, laying the foundation for future free cash flow generation. We remain committed to annual year-over-year growth and operating profit, free cash flow, and free cash flow per share while investing in long-term opportunities.  

Thanks. With that, Tim, let's move to questions.  

TIM STONE: Great. Thanks, Tom. Let's move on to the Q&A portion of the call with Jeff and Tom. Operator, will you please remind our listeners how to ask a question?  

OPERATOR: Thank you. (Operator Instructions). Our first question today is from Jeetil Patel from Deutsche Bank Securities. Please go ahead.  

JEETIL PATEL, ANALYST, DEUTSCHE BANK SECURITIES: Hi, guys. I had a couple of questions. The technology or product development investment continues at Amazon, and really try to want to understand as you look at investing in that area of the business, can you talk about when we should start to see the fruits of the labor? Is it something that is an ongoing process and we might start to see it as early as mid-year this year or do you think it's more of a second half event in 2006?  

Second question, you talked -- with the Prime service out there today and continued expansion that you are going to go after, it seems like you are balancing both frequency in terms of purchases and units relative to user growth. Can you talk about the ongoing effort of continuing to lower the pricing hurdle? Do you think that has a bigger impact on frequency or user growth in your business as you look forward now? And then just on your top-line guidance, increasing relative to the prior quarter, can you give us as of whether that's more of a function of the weaker dollar or is that a change in the unit growth assumptions as you look forward now?  

JEFF BEZOS: This is Jeff. I'll take a couple of those and maybe Tom wants to add on. First of all with Amazon Prime, the primary effect that we hope to see there in terms of incremental demand generation is with more frequency across more categories and increased conversion rates with existing customers. So while there may be some new customer generation as a result of that program, that's not the primary thing that we would anticipate. So it really is about getting customer -- earning more of the business from current customers.  

As far as investments go, whether they be in pricing things like Super Saver Shipping, Amazon Prime, technology, they tend to be -- to take -- if we look at the things we are benefiting today, things like international or category expansion or electronics business and so on, those are seeds that really got planted a few years ago and that's the kind of time scale -- the scale of the Company at this point when we start something completely new it has to grow for awhile before it has a meaningful impact on the Company's overall financials. So that's certainly the kind of time horizons that we look at when we are thinking about investments.  

The other thing I would say with respect to investments in general and our technology investments in particular, is that we don't expect our rate of investment to be constant quarter by quarter or year by year. There will be natural investment rates which correspond to what we see in the external marketplace, what's sort of going on in the world, and we feel if we were to level that out artificially we would miss opportunities in some years and probably over invest in certain other years. So you should expect that to not be constant.  

TOM SZKUTAK: In terms of your guidance question was that Q1 you're referring to, Jeetil?  

JEETIL PATEL: Just '05, relative to the prior quarter, what you talked about for '05.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. Again, we increased guidance from what we gave 90 days ago, and revenue for the total year is going to guidance of 16 percent to 25 percent. Again, we are cautiously optimistic. We think the guidance is appropriately conservative. And that's where we see it.  

JEETIL PATEL: Just, how much of that change versus the prior quarter is more of a function of the weaker dollar relative to -- as opposed to unit growth?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Yes, the way I would think about it is the exchange rates that we've assumed is where they've been recently. So that's all that we are providing.  

JEFF BEZOS: Thanks, Jeetil.  

OPERATOR: Our next question will be from Anthony Noto from Goldman Sachs.  

ANTHONY NOTO, ANALYST, GOLDMAN SACHS: Thank you very much. A couple of questions. When you guys have given fourth quarter guidance in revenue and operating income there's always a match between the different ends of the ranges in terms of revenue and the appropriate operating income that would go with that. While you hit the high-end of revenue, which actually accelerated on a year-over-year basis of a growth rate which was positive, the operating income was not commensurate with the revenue performance. I was just wondering, was there some type of competitive factor that caused the cost of doing business to be higher than your guidance sort of implied in terms of the revenue and the corresponding operating income that would have generated before the fourth quarter?  

And also when I look at the incremental operating margin it continues to deteriorate down to about 4.1 percent to 6.5 last quarter, 11.7 the quarter before that and mid-teens a year ago. So I was just wondering if you can comment on both of those things as it relates to your investment versus competition and what you are seeing. And I have one follow up. Thanks.  

JEFF BEZOS: Anthony, one of the things that I think the right light to view this in is we actually see this as, I was talking before, about investment periods not being constant or sort of smooth. We see this as an important time to be investing. We think that there are a lot of opportunities. And so when you look at software engineers that we are hiring, computer scientists and so on, that is basically because we really do believe that this is a great time to be investing in this business.  

ANTHONY NOTO: Great. So I definitely understand that lumpiness, but is there any change in the competitive environment either from the incumbent traditional brick and mortar guys that are maybe becoming more aggressive, the up-start shop and comparison sites or maybe even other electronic retailers? And then as we talked in the fall, your approach to potentially taking more inventory in non-books music and video category have primarily been third-party businesses, can you focus a little bit on that as you go into 2005 in terms of how aggressive you will be there and what benefits you think you may have gotten from lessons learned in the fourth quarter? Thanks.  

JEFF BEZOS: Well, one of the things -- the basic answer to your question is no. But I will -- on the inventory piece it is -- it is the case that we have taken more in-stock inventory. One of the things that has driven the success, for example, of our electronics business over the last few years, that business has operated better, the pricing is sharper, the inventory levels are better so that there's in-stock availability across a very wide selection of things.  

And in fact, it's the broad in-stock inventory that makes -- across many different categories, that makes the Amazon Prime program doable at this point. So it really is that having that inventory on hand available for overnight shipping, which people can now get for $3.99 an item once they've paid for a $79 a year membership. So for a certain group of customers, this is a very important benefit and it comes from having this very sophisticated fulfillment network that has very high inventory turns across a very, very large number of different products across different categories.  

TIM STONE: Thanks, Anthony.  

ANTHONY NOTO: Great.  

OPERATOR: We have a question from Mary Meeker from Morgan Stanley.  

MARY MEEKER, ANALYST, MORGAN STANLEY: And we have a few questions. To Jeetils question earlier, you talked about increase in frequency. I think you talked about an increase in cross shopping that might imply that conversion rates also rose in the fourth quarter. A bull could argue that what you are doing is offensive and long-term in nature and a bear could argue that what you are doing is defensive. Could you give us a sense, and I say that as it relates to Prime and the probable reduction in operating margins in fiscal '05.  

Could you talk about what you saw in the fourth quarter vis-a-vis conversion rates, frequency and cross shopping with more specificity and give us a sense if that's something that gave you more confidence that the Prime effort would be a successful effort. From the guidance that you gave previously, it appears as though the Prime concept in rolling it out, and the expenses associated with it, was something that evolved in the fourth quarter. So I assume there's some data that gave you the confidence to go forward with that. And in spite of that being a very long-winded question, I have a couple more if you will allow me.  

JEFF BEZOS: Well, in Q4 we have seen very good cross shopping as you suspected in your question. One of the pieces of evidence that we shared with folks of that being the case is the Thanksgiving holiday weekend where electronics surpassed our book business for the first time ever, even though our book business set a new record that weekend. You can also see that in the accelerated growth rates in our North America business. And so Amazon Prime is certainly what we see is this is a way for to us generate a very compelling customer benefit in a way that we are uniquely positioned to do well.  

To do something like Amazon Prime well, you have to have large in-stock selection. You have to have a fulfillment center network with multiple nodes so that you can have attractive shipping cost structure, and you also have to operate multi-category. Because it's probably not as worth it for a customer to pay an annual membership fee if they can only purchase in 1 product category. So there are a unique set of factors which really make Amazon.com ideally positioned to offer this kind of customer benefit. And that's really what's driving this.  

We see an opportunity to take our best customers, who are purchasing from us frequently and there are a lot of those, and offer them a new way of shopping at Amazon.com, which gets them to really experience this very differently. It's one thing to order something and get it a week later or 10 business days later in the case of Super Saver Shipping. It's quite another to all of a sudden start using this service in a different way so that as you order the things come very, very quickly. It just feels differently. And even for people who can afford second-day shipping, it feels sort of like an indulgent luxury. But turning it into a fixed cost makes it possible for people to do that without any guilt.  

MARY MEEKER: If I go to shopping.com, for example, and find a book that I'm interested in and Amazon has a good price -- a price that's compelling, what's the probability that I will see a price that also says, for Prime members, price would be X?  

JEFF BEZOS: I don't know, but certainly if you are paying $79 a year for a membership fee, you yourself are going to think about that price.  

MARY MEEKER: Yes. Can I ask 2 more questions, Jeff?  

JEFF BEZOS: Sure.  

MARY MEEKER: How will you recognize the $79 Prime revenue that you receive? And for the '05 range of operating margin guidance, what percent of that change versus the prior guidance is related to Prime-related expenses versus research R&D-related expenses, versus search R&D-related expenses for the A9 stuff, versus search's sales and marketing expenses? And that's my last -- those are my last questions. Thanks.  

JEFF BEZOS: Sure, the first part of your question, Mary, in terms of the recognition, it will be amortized over the course of the year. So, again, it will be a straight line over the year. In terms of the other piece, could you just repeat the last part of it?  

MARY MEEKER: It's your operating margin range for '05 is wide and it's also, I think, somewhat lower than people were expecting. What is the change there? How long is that going to persist?

So it's certainly a significant portion of the 175.  

In addition to that, we are -- certainly with the growth that we are seeing in international, you can assume that we may have to add capacity in international during 2005. So those are the key pieces, but certainly software development will be the most significant pieces.

OPERATOR: We have a question from Heath Terry from CS First Boston.  

HEATH TERRY, ANALYST, CREDIT SUISSE FIRST BOSTON: Great. I was wondering if you could kind of give us a bit of a drill down in terms of the way that you go through the thought process on price reductions. We saw pretty significant revenue growth on a year-over-year basis. But free cash flow growth lagged significantly. Can you walk us through how you evaluate those and do you have maybe some examples you can give about, in terms of where the leverage really is in a price reduction actually driving higher free cash flow either during the quarter or just in kind of a theory example?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Just to correct something you said, our revenue growth for the year was 31 percent. Our free cash flow grew 38 percent. So we are getting leverage while again, as Jeff mentioned earlier, a lot of these things, price reductions and the technology initiatives that we have in place do take time, but again, you are seeing good leverage free cash flow.  

HEATH TERRY: And can you talk about maybe in a product category where you've done these price reductions where you've seen that kind of leverage?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Well, I think if you look at kind of what I said before, but electronics, consumer electronics is a good example of something that we have been investing in for approximately 4 years now, the business from a customer experience point of view and from an operating efficiency point of view has gotten better every year and we expect that to continue. And that is what's driving the -- that's an example of an investment that we started making many years ago. It's now large enough to actually influence the overall financials of the Company.  

HEATH TERRY: Great. Thank you.  

TIM STONE: Thanks.  

OPERATOR: We have a question from Safa Rashtchy from Piper Jaffray.  

SAFA RASHTCHY, ANALYST, PIPER JAFFRAY: Thank you. A question on the growth rate of electronics and other, as I understand your electronics and other categories has basically been stagnant at about 27 percent year-over-year growth for the past 3 quarters, while the media segment, as you noted, actually accelerated growth. Given the announcements you had about improvements in more electronic sales, I would have expected an accelerate of that. I know that the strategy for Amazon has been to kind of portray the Company more as a general merchandise store rather than just books, music and video. Is there any other initiatives that you have to take to accelerate the growth in electronics?

OPERATOR: We have a question from Aram Rubinson from Banc of America.  

ARAM RUBINSON, ANALYST, BANC OF AMERICA SECURITIES: Thanks. A couple questions. On the site I noticed that in the apparel section, as an example, you changed the way you merchandise it from being kind of a top-seller approach to being an editors picks. I'm curious if there are other areas around the site that you merchandised differently that I might not yet have picked up on? And then I have a quick follow up.  

JEFF BEZOS: Well, a lot of our merchandising is done by basically by algorithms and some of the merchandising that we have been very successful with is things like customers who bought this also bought this and so on and so on. There are a number of such things, personalized merchandising. We're very fortunate because we operate in an environment where those things are very measurable and so we can usually do very straight-forward tests where we don't have to guess about what works better. Does A work better than B? We can actually try both things. And no, the answer instead of trying to guess at it.  

The cost of doing such experiments in our environment is much lower than it is in the more traditional retailing environment. At the same time, the inputs that we put into those algorithms, I think we are starting to over time be better merchants. So I think that that's still one of those things where we will be improving for years and years and years and we look forward to that.  

ARAM RUBINSON: The second question and it will be brief, is I'm trying to understand what behavior you are trying to drive with the Amazon Prime. It sounds to me as if the behavior you are encouraging is more frequent, but smaller value orders, and I'm curious if that's correct and if that's a behavior you prefer, or if you prefer fewer but larger orders.  

JEFF BEZOS: Well, I think if we got to choose, we would prefer more frequent larger orders. But really what we are -- our economics more followed the units rather than the order size, and so what we are really trying to drive is more units whether they come in in big orders or smaller orders. So there is some fraction of our economics which follow order size and some fraction of it that follows unit size -- I'm sorry, follows the units. But we really, in this case, what we are trying to do is create a better experience for the large fraction of our customers that already shop with us frequently and hopefully they shop with us even more frequently. That's what will over time make this program work for Amazon's shareholders. It works very well today for the customers who use it.  

ARAM RUBINSON: Just tell us the number of customers that you've added? It's something you've talked to in the past and then I will leave you be.  

TOM SZKUTAK: It's 47 million, it's up 19 percent.  

ARAM RUBINSON: Thank you.  

OPERATOR: We have a question from Robert Peck from Bear Stearns.  

ROBERT PECK, ANALYST, BEAR STEARNS: Jeff, I know in the past you've mentioned the idea of Amazon expanding into services and a lot of people have taken that to mean Netflix or DVD type services. Can you talk a little bit more about what other services you see as potential products for Amazon going forward?  

JEFF BEZOS: One of the things that we have been very successful with is providing third-party services for other companies that want to participate in e-commerce, both in terms of making our Web services to them and you can learn more about that by going to Amazon.com/webservices. And also through our programs where we help merchants acquire on-line customers through merchant sat [ph] and then where we also operate both the website and the fulfillment infrastructure for other merchants as we do for Target, for example, if you go to target.com, that's operated on top of Amazon.com technology.  

ROBERT PECK: And, Tom, could you maybe talk about any sort of impact from EBAY increasing its prices? Have you seen any pick up at all from third party?  

TOM SZKUTAK: We have a longstanding policy of not talking about other companies. Our marketplace business has been doing extraordinarily well and it continues to do very, very well.  

ROBERT PECK: As you look at on-line search, some of it consider it sort of a distribution method for you, advertising, marketing, others sort of consider it more of competitors. What's your view of on-line search and how it's changing and shaping the landscape of e-commerce?  

JEFF BEZOS: Our view of on-line search is it is a piece of a very large trend that is -- that will go on for a long time, which is the consumers more and more every passing day, every passing year and decade have more perfect information and more transparency. So consumers are becoming more and more empowered. They are able to quickly find exactly -- they will be able to find out the correctness about things. We operate our entire business based on the believe that customers are smart and that they are going to be empowered with perfect information.  

ROBERT PECK: And as we try and gauge longer term here in margins, it looks like your guidance for '05 is for margins to come down a little bit. Does there come a level where you think the margins sort of flatten out and you can get some of the other operating components in your model?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Again, as Jeff had mentioned earlier, we expect it not necessarily it to be smooth. We've made good progress in operating margins over the last few years. Back in 2001 our operating margins were negative. 2004 our operating margins were 7 percent. As we see investment opportunities, we're clearly -- that we think are right for the long-term, we are clearly going to make sure that we invest in those. So you will see some years where our expenses will grow at faster rates than others. I think at the end of the day though we're all about how do we maximize for free cash flow for our shareholders and that's what we are going to focus on. And so we think that's the right thing and that's what we are going to optimize for.  

ROBERT PECK: Thanks, guys.  

OPERATOR: And we will take our final question today from Bridget Niget from Lazard Asset Management.  

BRIDGET NIGET, ANALYST, LAZARD ASSET MANAGEMENT: My question has been answered. Thanks.  

TIM STONE: Great. Thank you.  

JEFF BEZOS: Thank you, everybody.  

OPERATOR: That does conclude today's conference call. Thank you for your participation. You may now disconnect.

 Q3  2004  Amazon .com, Inc. Earnings Conference Call - Final
