   LP
OPERATOR: Good day everyone and welcome to the Amazon.com third-quarter 2004 financial results teleconference. Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks I will be turning the call over to the Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Tim Stone. Please go ahead.  

TIM STONE, VP IR, AMAZON.COM: Welcome to our Q3 '04 financial results conference call. Joining us today is Tom Szkutak, our CFO, Jeff Bezos, our Founder and CEO, will be available for Q&A. The following discussion and responses to your questions reflect management's views as of today, October 21, 2004 only, and will include forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially.  

   TD
Additional information about factors that could potentially impact our financial results is included in today's press release and our filings with the SEC, including our 2003 annual report on Form 10-K. As you listen to today's call, we encourage you to have our press release in front of you, which includes our financial results, as well as metrics and commentary on the quarter.  

During this call we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. In our press release slides accompanying this webcast and our filings with the SEC, each of which is posted on our IR website, you'll find additional disclosures regarding these non-GAAP measures, including reconciliations of these measures with comparable GAAP measures.  

Finally, unless otherwise stated, all comparisons on this call will be against our results for the comparable period of 2003. With that, I will turn the call over to Tom.  

TOM SZKUTAK, CFO, AMAZON.COM: This was another solid quarter for Amazon.com as we continued to improve our worldwide customer experience through broad product selections, low prices and shopping convenience. Let me start with a few comments on our financial and operating results.  

Free cash flow on a trailing twelve-month basis grew 76 percent to $420 million, driven by organic growth in revenues and operating profit, and improvements in our operating cycle. The combination of common stock and stock based awards outstanding was 434 million shares, essentially flat with a year ago.  

On the income statement revenue grew 29 percent, gross profit grew 24 percent, while gross margin decreased 87 basis points. Consolidated segment operating profit grew 29 percent. Operating margin was flat, and pro forma net income grew 52 percent.  

Revenue grew 29 percent to $1.46 billion or 24 percent after the $57 million favorable year-over-year impact from foreign exchange. Unit growth was 30 percent. Consolidated segment operating expenses, which declined 88 basis points as a percentage of sales, were up $48 million year-over-year, or $41 million adjusted for foreign exchange rates.  

Fulfillment increased $28 million due to variable cost corresponding with sales volume, our mix of product sales, credit card fees and bad debt costs, including processes associated with our guarantee for certain third party seller transactions.  

Additionally, our second UK fulfillment center in Scotland is now shipping orders and fully operational. We expect the absolute amount spent to fulfillment to increase over time. Technology and content grew $11 million as we were adding top computer scientists and software engineers to enhance the customer experience on our website and websites powered by us, and to improve our process efficiency.  

Additionally, we continue to invest in several areas of technology, including seller platform, A9.com, Web services, and additional development centers. We intend to continue investing in these and other initiatives. And we expect absolute dollars spent in technology and content to increase over time as we continue to add computer scientists and software engineers to our staff.  

Marketing costs grew $5 million. We expect absolute amounts spent in marketing to increase over time as our marketing expenses are largely variable. We use a number of targeted online marketing channels to direct customers to our website. To the extent there's increased or decreased competition for these traffic sources, or to the extent our mix of these channels shift, we would expect to see a corresponding change in our marketing expense.  

G&A increased $4 million primarily due to higher professional fees. We expect absolute dollars spent in G&A to increase over time. Consolidated segment operating income grew 29 percent to $95 million, and operating margin was flat at 6.5 percent. Adjusting for the $4 million benefit for foreign exchange rates operating income grew 23 percent.  

Trailing twelve-month consolidated segment operating income was $466 million, up $156 million year-over-year, including $21 million of benefit due to FX. Trailing twelve-month consolidated segment operating margin increased 82 basis points to 7.4 percent.  

In the North American segment, revenue grew 15 percent to $816 million. Media revenue grew 12 percent to $564 million. Top sellers in media this quarter included the Star Wars Trilogy DVD, and Jimmy Buffett's latest CD, License to Chill. EGM, or electronics and other general merchandise, revenue grew 27 percent to $229 million, and represented 28 percent of North America revenue, up from 25 percent.  

For the first time EGM revenue for the trailing twelve-month period was over $1 billion. EGM top sellers for the quarter include Apple iPods, Similac baby formula, the Sims II video game and Sony Ericsson mobile phones.  

Gross profit grew 11 percent while gross margin decreased from 28.4 percent to 27.4 percent as a result of free shipping, product mix shifts, continued price reductions and lower other revenue related to marking revenue, offset partially by increased sales volume from third party sellers.  

North America operating profit declined $5 million or 8 percent to $57 million. And operating margin declined from 8.8 percent to 7 percent due to lower gross margins and higher operating expenses. The majority of our technology and content costs are incurred in the U.S., and most of them are allocated to the North American segment, including expenses related to our seller platform search and Web services initiatives.  

Increased adoption of free shipping contributed to an increase of $7 million in net shipping loss compared with third quarter of 2003. In the international segment revenue grew 52 percent to $646 million, representing 44 percent of worldwide sales. Revenue growth was 39 percent adjusting for the $56 million benefit from foreign exchange rates.  

Media revenue grew 41 percent to $530 million. As in the U.S., Star Wars Trilogy DVD was the best-selling international DVD title, setting a record for pre-orders in the UK with 85,000. EGM revenue grew 132 percent to $116 million and represented 18 percent of international revenues, up from 12 percent.  

Gross profit grew 56 percent, while gross margin increased from 19.9 to 20.5 percent, primarily due to more third party sellers, offset by changes in product mix, price reductions and free shipping.  

International operating income grew $38 million, and operating margin expanded from 2.6 percent to 5.8 percent. Pro forma net income increased 52 percent to $73 million or 17 cents per diluted share compared with 11 cents per diluted share. On a trailing twelve-month basis pro forma net income, a component of free cash flow, was $370 million or 87 cents per diluted share. Our GAAP net income was $54 million or 13 cents per share, compared with net income of $16 million or 4 cents per diluted share.  

On a trailing twelve-month basis, GAAP net income was $315 million or 74 cents per diluted share. Inventory was $357 million, up $73 million sequentially as we began preparation for the seasonal holiday period. Trailing twelve-month inventory turns were 17, down from 19 a year ago as we optimized in-stock levels and improved availability times by increasing the breadth and depth of our direct vendor relationships. We also added inventory in our new product categories.  

Our negative offerings cycle was over 20 days, and average inventory was 4.6 percent of trailing twelve-month sales. Our investment in fixed assets, which includes capitalized software development costs, increased to $227 million. Capital expenditures were $29 million for the quarter, and $70 million on a trailing twelve-month basis.  

Cash from marketable securities increased from 1.06 billion to 1.18 billion, including approximately $41 million from favorable movements in foreign exchange rates. During the prior twelve months we have redeemed $350 million in convertible debt that was otherwise due in 2009, mitigating over 4 million shares of potential dilution in addition to reducing our cash interest expense.  

In Q3 we used $72 million in cash to acquire Joyo.com Limited. Return on invested capital increased from 27 percent to 44 percent, calculated using what we believe is a conservative approach to both return and invested capital, trailing twelve-month free cash flow divided by average total assets minus average current liabilities. Our long-term expectation is to achieve triple digit returns on invested capital.  

Our growth continues to be fueled by our persistent focus on the primary inputs of customer experience, selection, convenience and price. We expanded selection across our sites worldwide and increased our geographic footprint. We introduced toy stores in Germany and Japan. Customers now have their choice of over 20,000 toys, games and hobby products, and enjoy discounts up to 30 percent on many products.  

Inventory in both countries is anchored by Amazon with additional selection from marketplace sellers. Our newest U.S. stores have added over 1 million items for purchase since the introduction of apparel in November 2002. Our apparel store now features over 250,000 items in 2 million color and size combinations from over 400 merchants.  

Sports and outdoors offers over 300,000 items from more than 600 merchants. Health and personal care offers over 200,000 products from Amazon and third party merchants. Jewelry currently features over 100,000 items from Amazon and third parties, including diamonds jewelry from Amazon at industry low markups of less than 15 percent and significantly less for more expensive diamonds.  

Amazon Services has over 800,000 active seller accounts worldwide, including over 6,000 launched Merchants@ platform sellers ranging from well-known branded merchants like Liz Claiborne to smaller specialty retailers such as Cheerleading Company. Units sold from third parties now represent 28 percent of worldwide unit sales, up from 22 percent a year ago.  

We established our seventh global Web site by acquiring 100 percent of Joyo.com Limited, a British Virgin Islands company which operates the Joyo.com Website in cooperation with Chinese subsidiaries and affiliates. The Joyo.com Website is the largest online retailer of books, music and videos in China. Results from Joyo were not significant in Q3 and are not expected to be significant in Q4.  

We plan to continue expanding selection in existing categories and opening new categories worldwide. In addition, we will continue to explore opportunities for geographic expansion in the years to come.  

We continue to innovate on behalf of customers to improve customer experience. Customer self-service, contact and (indiscernible) reduction initiatives across all areas of the organization and more robust order and product information on our Website help our worldwide customer service team achieve a 32 percent year-over-year reduction in contacts per unit.  

Our A9.com subsidiary, in addition to improving search for Amazon.com and our merchants, unveiled a new stand-alone search engine,  www.A9.com to make search more effective. A9 helps users discover information from several powerful sources, including Web and image search from Google, text from hundreds of thousands of book titles from Amazon Search Inside the Book, movie information from the Internet movie database, and site information from Alexa Internet, both of which are owned by Amazon.com.  

We think of A9 as a search engine with a memory. With the A9 toolbar installed, your Web browsing history is saved so you can search through your entire history. A9.com uses your history to recommend new sites, to alert you to new search results, and to let you know the last time you visited a page.  

And A9.com is about more than just search. It helps you organize what you find. The toolbar diary lets you take notes on any web page, and reference these notes whenever you visit the page. Easy to use bookmarks allow you to drag and drop any search results directly to the bookmark area. And all your information is always searchable directly on the A9 search page.  

Lastly, because A9 stores all information on its servers, you can utilize the features I mentioned from any computer you use.  

Finally, we continue with our strategy to continually lower prices for our customers. Customer adoption of worldwide free shipping offers reached another high point this quarter, saving customers tens of millions of dollars. In the UK for example we continue to see increased adoption of free shipping as customers embrace the new 19 pound threshold, which was reduced from 25 pounds at the beginning of September.  

We continue to lower product prices on thousands of media and hard-line products. Books over $15 at Amazon.com are discounted by 30 percent. We're currently testing even greater reductions for books that meet certain price points and elasticity criteria. And in DVDs we have increased discounts for our mid sales range titles.  

Free shipping, increased product discounts, and Amazon-owned inventory in newer product categories are part of Amazon's ongoing everyday effort to lower prices. And we intend to further lower prices for customers during the holidays and thereafter. Our goal is to maximize gross profit dollars, not percentages, ultimately maximizing free cash flow and free cash flow per share for our shareholders.  

Before moving onto guidance, let me just say a few words about the upcoming holiday season (indiscernible) at Amazon.com. Preparations are underway at our customer service and fulfillment centers, including the hiring and training of seasonal employees. The receive and stocking process is well under way for toys, housewares, consumer electronics, and other popular holiday gift items.  

We are pleased to offer customers even more selection at lower prices during holiday 2004 than in years past. These great offers include a 1/4 carat princess cut diamond earring for just $79, eligible for free super saver shipping. Starting with Black Friday, the day after Thanksgiving, our buyers anticipate that mall jewelers will be marking down similar items to $99 to a $129 range, but Amazon.com customers can enjoy these items at everyday low prices in our jewelry store right now.  

And Creative Labs' full line of Zen Micro MP3 players are available for pre-order exclusively at Amazon.com for $249.99, also eligible for free super saver shipping. The Zen Micro comes in ten different colors, and should be a favorite for holidays with 2 -- 2,500 song capacity, 12 hour battery life, FM radio and other exciting features.  

I will now conclude my portion of today's call with guidance. Incorporated into our Q4 '04 guidance and the 2005 baseline expectations are the order of trends that we have seen to date, and what we believe to date to be appropriately conservative assumptions.  

However, there's a high level of uncertainty surrounding fluctuations in the euro, pound, yen, and Canadian dollar foreign exchange rates, as well as the global economy and consumer spending, and the impact on both of world events. While we're cautiously optimistic, it is not possible to accurately predict demand; and therefore our actual results could differ materially from our guidance.  

Let me also remind everyone that certain stock awards are subject to variable accounting. We incur a non-cash charge or gain for any movement in our share price between reporting dates. We mark our euro denominated debt to market at the end of each quarter, which results in a non-cash gain or loss for any movement in the euro between reporting dates. We also have exposure to the euro related to our unhedged interest expense on this euro denominated debt. We incur a non-cash foreign currency gain or loss corresponding with intercompany balances denominated in foreign currencies which are to be repaid among subsidiaries.  

And we cannot forecast these items, yet they could have a significant positive or negative impact on our results. For the December quarter we expect net sales of between $2.295 billion and $2.545 billion, or growth of between 18 percent and 31 percent.  

Consolidated segment operating income to be between $162 million and $222 million, or growth between 6 and 45 percent. We expect capital expenditures, including capitalized software development costs, to be $85 million or loss for the full year. For calendar 2005 we expect net sales of between $7.4 billion and $8.15 billion. Consolidated segment operating income to be between $500 million and $625 million. We expect capital expenditures, including capitalized software development costs, to be $150 million or less. Q4 and 2005 guidance assumes foreign exchange currency rates stay approximately where they have been recently.  

Amazon.com will continue to focus on relentlessly improving customer experience for our buying customers, our selling customers, and Web site developers, ultimately maximizing free cash flow for our shareholders. Thanks. And with that, Tim, let's move to questions.  

TIM STONE: Let's move on to the Q&A portion of the call with Jeff and Tom. Operator, will you please remind our listeners how to ask a question?  

OPERATOR: (OPERATOR INSTRUCTIONS). Brian Pitts with Morgan Stanley.  

BRIAN PITTS, ANALYST, MORGAN STANLEY: A couple of things here. Obviously there is so many new things going on in online search. Can you talk about what you see yourself sitting in the game long-term, and what the potential impact on your expenses and CapEx are looking out? And then I've got a follow-up.  

JEFF BEZOS, FOUNDER, CEO, AMAZON.COM: If you look at A9.com they are really doing two things. The first is they have -- Amazon has been investing in search since the beginning 9 years ago, focused on e-commerce search. And A9.com continues with that work for both Amazon.com and our partner websites.  

And the second thing they're doing is they have the consumer facing Web site that Tom talked about in his remarks at A9.com that uses a lot of the kind of server side mentality that Amazon.com has built up over the years. So things like discovery features, recommendations based on your past history with A9.com. If you used A9.com toolbar it tracks which websites you been to, remembers those websites. It greets you by name. You can see which websites you been to, so that if you visit the Web site -- want to find a Web site you visited six months ago, you can easily do that. You can search on the websites you've already visited and so on.  

So it is -- it is a different strategy. And I think what you're going to find is that there will be a lot of different search engines taking different tactics, different strategies, different customer experiences, creating unique differentiation.  

BRIAN PITTS: Can you talk about the overall impact of the additional 1.57 percent discount from A9? What has been the take rate on that? And how has this cost been offset by revenue generated from sponsored links?  

TOM SZKUTAK: We're not breaking that out at this point. And we will continue -- it is obvious a great deal for customers. If you used the A9.com search engine, then automatically without any work on your part as a user, you get a pi over 2 or 1.57 percent discount on all Amazon.com purchases. And that is -- it is something we're not advertising and people are slowly discovering it.  

OPERATOR: Anthony Noto.  

ANTHONY NOTO, ANALYST: Jeff and Tom, I have a couple of questions about what is changing your business. If I look at the marginal profitability of the business in the quarter, the year-over-year incremental operating margin is down to 6.5 percent. Well down from a year ago in the teens, and low double digits in March and June. And when I look your guidance at the midpoint it is calling for about a 6 percent incremental operating margin in 2005.  

The question is what is changing your business that is costing so much more to drive growth? Is it the relative value proposition outside of books, music and video? Is that not as appealing? Is it competition? Is there some other factors? And then I have a follow-up.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. If you look at our total operating expenses, we are actually up by 23 percent this year -- excuse me, this quarter -- versus last year. There's two big pieces of that. One is fulfillment and the other is technology and content. Our technology and content expenses grew $11 million year-over-year. And again that is -- again, to continue to invest in the business and some of the things I talked about in my opening remarks. So we're certainly investing in search. We are investing in a solid platform. We continue to invest in customer experience, Web services.  

Again these are things that we think can really help our future. And we are going to continue to invest in those. So that is the piece that you're seeing. Also, clearly you're seeing gross margins are down year-over-year. That is not a new trend, but again we continue to invest in low prices, making sure that we have the best possible value proposition for customers. We also had our super saver shipping adoption rate reach its highest point this quarter. Again, those are things that we think are beneficial to us in the long term as well as our customers. So we're going to continue to do those things. And we think it it will be good for our shareholders and customers over time.  

ANTHONY NOTO: How long do you think that level of investment will be until you get back to incremental margin that is in the double digits? Or do you think that you're long-term margins won't get back to the double digits? And then is the reason your operating income in the third quarter in the North American business -- is the reason that is down on an absolute basis year-over-year and sequentially due to the investments that you made, or is there some other trend there on your third party business that you have cut rates or changed rates?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. I will take the second part of the question first, the North America operating profit. Our gross margins are down year-over-year. There are a couple of reasons for that. One is we had some other historical marketing revenue that you'll see -- it is about $3 million -- that ran off last year Q3. The other piece is if you look at our shipping profit for North America that loss actually increased year-over-year, because again -- because of our super saver shipping adoption.  

And then our operating expenses were up. When I talked earlier about our technology and content being up $11 million year over year, and the things that we're doing with that, a very significant portion of that is in our North America segment. So again that is what is driving the operating expenses, again, to invest in our business.  

And then the first part of the question. We don't -- certainly from an operating margin standpoint we have said historically that our operating margin over the long-term, our goal was to either reach double digits or high single digit. But again our goal always has been, we want to maximize free cash flow for our shareholders. And that is what we're going to do. So we're going to optimize for free cash flow. We had we think very strong results in Q3. And over the past 12 months our free cash flow reached $420 million. Significant growth, up 76 percent year-over-year. That is what we're optimizing for. So we're making investments. We're making those great trade-offs we believe to optimize free cash flow over the long term.  

OPERATOR: Shawn Milne with Friedman, Billings, Ramsey.  

SHAWN MILNE, ANALYST, FRIEDMAN, BILLINGS, RAMSEY: Tom, just a quick couple of questions on the operating cycle. Free cash flow numbers were pretty strong in the quarter. Just looking at some of the numbers here, the payable days went up. Was there something going on there? And we saw the inventory turns actually dip a little bit. Isn't that surprising given that the third party unit number continues to go up? If you could just add a little bit more around that?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. The first part of your question on payable days. Yes, sequentially our payable days went from 51 days to 57 days. If you look at last year you saw a similar increase. Not quite to the extent, because we had Harry Potter 5 and was launched in Q2 of last year. We didn't make the majority of the payments until Q3. But you saw an increase of 6 days sequentially this year. We saw an increase of approximately 5 days last year sequentially. Again, that is getting ready for the holiday season.  

In terms of the inventory in the existing categories we continue to add selection. We continue to make sure that we get our in-stock levels where we want them to be. Obviously we have launched quite a few new categories over the past 12 months. And we have -- with those we have also made sure that we had the right inventory on hand as well. So those are what is driving the two measurements. But as you had mentioned, our operating cycle is still very strong, still greater than 20 days. And again, you should expect that to be -- still continue to be part of our model.  

SHAWN MILNE: I'm not sure if I got the right number. Can you just repeat the third part of unit number?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Yes, third-party units as a percentage of the total was 28 percent this quarter. That was a high for us. That is up from 22 percent in the third quarter of last year.  

OPERATOR: Heath Terry with Credit Suisse First Boston.  

HEATH TERRY, ANALYST, CREDIT SUISSE FIRST BOSTON: You just mentioned that third-party has hit a record level. I'm curious if you could just kind of walk us through the strategy for third-party outside the U.S.? I am kind of surprised that we haven't seen more news around that. Obviously we saw that you have expanded into the toy category in Germany and Japan. Can you give us an idea of what the time frame and the roll out is going to look like as you get the international sites to look more like the U.S.?  

JEFF BEZOS: Third-party sales, of course internationally are already fairly strong in most of -- with the marketplace business. With Merchants@, that is something that is rolling out as we roll out the technology to do that around the world. So there is -- that is an opportunity that we will be pursuing. As far as the timing of that, I can't share that with you.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Just to add on to that, as the Jeff had mentioned, our third-party sales in international are very strong. We also reached a record high in international as well.  

OPERATOR: Jeetil Patel with Deutsche Bank Securities.  

JEETIL PATEL, ANALYST, DEUTSCHE BANK SECURITIES: I had a couple of questions. I don't know if you talked about unit growth or not, but can you -- can you give us a sense of the unit growth looks like in the quarter?  

Secondly, and I am just trying to think about the search business in general. And do you think that there any -- what is the impact on your business should some of the search engines out there, like Yahoo and Google, change some of their algorithms around and continue to optimize, does that have any sort of impact on your business, especially when you consider, I guess, on the algorithmic search site and your ability to serve pages into the engines and being relevant out there? And also within your affiliate network?  

JEFF BEZOS: I'm not completely sure I understand the question. We do -- to the degree that the algorithms change we might get less traffic from algorithmic search, less or more. Amazon is well-positioned because such a large fraction of our traffic comes directly to Amazon.com. The associates program that we started 9 years ago has a very large number of associates in the program pointing to Amazon.com. Those associates are independent of search.  

TOM SZKUTAK: The other part of your question, unit growth was 30 percent for the quarter year-over-year.  

OPERATOR: Imran Khan with J.P. Morgan.  

DANA GREY, ANALYST, J.P. MORGAN: This is Dana Grey in for Imran. I'm just wondering if you can comment going into the holiday season on your inventory levels in the toys category? I know with the lawsuit with ToysRUs I'm not sure what the inventory levels are like, and how you're planning to compensate with any of your other vendors?  

JEFF BEZOS: The receiving and storage of inventory for the holiday, including toys is proceeding on schedule. And we're also in the process of supplementing our toy selection with merchandise from other sellers.  

OPERATOR: Paul Keung with CIBC.  

PAUL KEUNG, ANALYST, CIBC: Help me out here. Your CapEx went from 85 million, I believe you said, this year to 150. Can you explain again the reason for the increase? And is it a signal of a longer-term trend in terms of your CapEx spending?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Our CapEx in general is going to be very low for our business. We're not a capital intensive business. What you're seeing is for next year you'll continue to see more software engineers and computer scientists hired. So you should expect to see more capitalized software. With all the initiatives that we have going on from a technology standpoint, you should expect that storage capacity will be increasing. We will be using some of the CapEx for that.  

And then lastly, we will be, as always, trying to make sure that we have the best productivity in our fulfillment centers, so we will be using some of the CapEx for that as well.  

PAUL KEUNG: So the absolute level will stay at those -- I'm sorry the numbers will continue to increase on an absolute level, is that correct?  

TOM SZKUTAK: No, you shouldn't expect -- you should expect that over time our investment intensity to be low. You will have years that we will have a reinvestment ratio that will be above 1. You will have years that will be below 1. Where it settles in is difficult to say. But again, based on our model, we're not a heavy capital intensive business.  

PAUL KEUNG: And then I'm trying to reconcile some of the assumptions in my model here. When you talked about maximizing free cash flow, can you talk about when you go next year, as the levels we have seen sort of have indications of the type of hurdles you like to meet in terms of maximizing free cash flow growth on a LTM basis?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Good you repeat the last part of the question?  

PAUL KEUNG: Yes, we saw LTM free cash flow go up this quarter 76 percent. Correct?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Yes.  

PAUL KEUNG: Is that a --?  

TOM SZKUTAK: That is a trailing 12 --.  

PAUL KEUNG: It is trailing twelve-month level. If we looked at that number and the last couple of numbers, maybe the numbers implied the next couple of quarters. Is that a sort of a good indication of where you think the health of your business is?  

TOM SZKUTAK: I'm not sure I understand the question, but I will take a pass at it. I think certainly pro forma net increase is one driver of our cash flow, as well as our operating cycles kind of continue to be similar to what it is. As I mentioned earlier, we're going to do the right things to make sure that we do the right long-term things for our shareholders, which is continue to focus on adding selection on the categories that we in, continue to focus on adding new categories.  

We think there is opportunity to improve our seller platform, improve the customer experience. We think there's an opportunity in search, Web services. Those are things that we certainly have our top computer scientists and engineers on today. And we expect and hope to deliver free cash flow -- high levels of free cash flow over time with those investments.  

PAUL KEUNG: So essentially high double digits for the long-term?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Our stated goal is to reach triple digit returns on invested capital over time. And we're certainly making progress towards that goal.  

OPERATOR: Dan Geiman with McAdams Wright Ragen.  

DAN GEIMAN, ANALYST, MCADAMS WRIGHT RAGEN: With respect to Joyo.com what is your strategy, and what are your opportunities with respect to this business? Are you going to be rolling out new products and services? And are there going to be any costs related to the operations?  

JEFF BEZOS: Over time we will roll out more categories, just as you have seen us do in other places in the world. It is a long-term strategy. It is still very early days for e-commerce in China. And there is a tremendous amount of long-term opportunity. And we're excited about being there in these early days.  

DAN GEIMAN: Any costs related to operations, say, in '05?  

TOM SZKUTAK: We're not giving out specific guidance on Joyo.com for 2005, but it is certainly incorporated in our guidance.  

OPERATOR: Bob Peck with Bear Stearns.  

VICTOR ANTHONY, ANALYST, BEAR STEARNS: This is Victor Anthony sitting in for Bob Peck. I just had a quick follow-up with regard to China. I just wanted to talk about your long-term strategies within that country. Do you plan to, I guess, implement the same sort of strategies you have in the U.S., in the European countries, such as free shipping, lower prices, developing a third party business over there over time in China? And could you talk about some of the challenges you would face implementing those strategies if you choose to do so?  

JEFF BEZOS: First of all, I believe they already have free shipping at Joyo.com. But basically the answer to your question is we will employ the same customer centric strategy in China that we employ everywhere in the world. And the three main drivers of that are selection, low prices, and convenience. So you can expect to see us pursue exactly that same set of important customer experience drivers in China over time.  

OPERATOR: Lanny Baker, Citigroup Smith Barney.  

LANNY BAKER, ANALYST, CITIGROUP SMITH BARNEY: Looking at the guidance that you have given out for next year, it strikes me that you have given revenue and operating income numbers, but not free cash. And yet it seems like in listening to you guys, you're trying to maximize around optimizing long-term free cash flow or current free cash flow, but free cash flow really seems to be the thing you have a penchant for.  

Is there a reason why you don't think it would be useful to sort of highlight free cash flow expectations that you hold for yourselves in '05? And sort of along those lines can you're help us just sort of tick off what the checklist of differences would be between, as you look right now -- look at your free cash flow relative to your operating income this year? And then sort of tick off what will be the differences that might affect that relationship between free cash flow and operating income in '05? I guess higher CapEx is one of them.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Yes, we haven't given -- we haven't given guidance on free cash flow for 2005. But certainly we have given you guidance on operating profit. We have given you guidance on capital expenditures. You can assume that certainly our operating cycle will remain similar over the years to come. So I think you have enough certainly to work with on that. Did that answer your question?  

LANNY BAKER: Yes, I guess so. So the relationship seems pretty constant, and you didn't guide to it just because you didn't guide to it. Is that fair enough?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Yes.  

OPERATOR: We will take our final question from Safa Rashtchy.  

SAFA RASHTCHY, ANALYST: Just trying to understand your cost structure next year, and to what degree these investments will pay off in the future year. You obviously have established a premier position in e-commerce worldwide, and very solid infrastructure. And you have been investing this year already heavily, which is why the operating margin margins have been taking a hit.  

I'm a little puzzled that next year the operating margins will further come down. I understand your comments in general, Jeff, that you're building more with computer scientists and infrastructure and so forth. But it if your goal is still to maintain -- to reach double-digit operating margin, certainly you're not going in the right direction by next year. And my question is when would we see a reversal of this decline? To what degree this is onetime buildup, or is it just much more expensive to sell online than you had originally assumed?  

JEFF BEZOS: I think it is really a -- what we're trying to do, and what we have been doing for the last few years is over time developing a better understanding of elasticity with respect to things like lower product prices. We're developing a better understanding of -- even inside product categories which subcategories respond more to price than others. It gives us the ability to get smarter on pricing.  

As we get smarter on pricing, able to -- and if we get more operational efficient so that we can afford to lower prices for customers -- both in the form of lower product prices and free shipping programs -- that allows us to maximize dollar operating income and dollar free cash flows, as opposed to optimizing percentage operating margins.  

And I think that is really the top-level point that we're trying to emphasize, is as we get smarter about our business, we going to try to do the right thing for driving absolute dollar numbers rather than percentage numbers. And the beneficiaries of that strategy are going to be our customers because it turns out that the best way in our business to maximize dollar numbers, absolute dollar numbers, is by lowering prices and offering free shipping, and basically taking our efficiencies as we can afford to do so and giving them back to customers. We are well positioned to do that.  

Many of our costs are relatively fixed. And because of the scale that we have in our business we are able to amortize those portions of our costs which are fixed across a very large customer base. So there's a big structural advantage for us there.  

TIM STONE: With that I want to thank everyone for joining us on the call today, as well as for your questions. Somebody will be available on our Investor Relations Website, at least through the end of the quarter. We look forward to talking to you again next quarter, and appreciate your interest in Amazon.com. Thank you.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Thank you.  

JEFF BEZOS: Thank you.  

OPERATOR: Ladies and gentlemen, this does conclude today's teleconference. We appreciate your participation. You may disconnect at this time.

 HD
 Q2  2004  Amazon .com, Inc. Earnings Conference Call - Final

   LP
OPERATOR: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Amazon.com second-quarter 2004 financial results conference call. Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to the Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Tim Stone. Mr. Stone, please go ahead.  

   TD
TIM STONE, VP OF IR, AMAZON.COM: Good afternoon. Welcome to the Amazon.com second-quarter 2004 conference call. Joining us on today's call is Tom Szkutak, our CFO. Jeff Bezos, our Founder and CEO, will be available for Q&A. The following discussion and responses to your questions reflect management's views as of today, July 22, 2004 only and will include forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially. Additional information about factors that could potentially impact our financial results is included in today's press release and our filings with the SEC, including our 2003 annual report on Form 10-K. As you listen today's call, I encourage you to have our press release in front of you which includes our financial results as well metrics and commentary on the quarter.  

During this call, we also discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. In the release, slides accompanying this webcast and our filings with the SEC, each of which is posted on our IR Web site, you'll find additional disclosures regarding these non-GAAP measures, including reconciliations of these measures to certain comparable GAAP measures. Finally, unless otherwise stated, all comparisons in this call will be against our results for the comparable period of 2003.  

With that, I will turn the call over to Tom.  

TOM SZKUTAK, CFO, AMAZON.COM: Thanks, Tim. Today I will discuss our financial and operating results and our future expectations. This was another successful quarter for Amazon.com as we continued to execute on our strategy of low prices, broad selection and convenience to our customers.  

Let me start with a few comments on our financial results. Free cash flow on a trailing 12-month basis grew 45 percent to $354 million driven by organic growth in revenues and operating profit. The combination of common stock and stock-based awards outstanding was 434 million shares, essentially flat with a year ago.  

On the income statement, revenue grew 26 percent, gross profit grew 25 percent, while gross margin decreased 32 basis points. Consolidated segment operating profit grew 50 percent, operating margin increased 116 basis points, and pro forma net income grew 77 percent. Revenue grew 26 percent to $1.39 billion or 22 percent after the $47 million favorable year-over-year impact from foreign exchange.  

We're pleased with this growth in the context of a very tough comparison with Q2 '03 when Harry Potter 5 was released. Our best estimate is that Harry Potter 5 and the accompanying purchases accounted for 5 points of incremental growth or more.  

Consolidated segment operating expenses as a percentage of sales declined 148 basis points. G&A increased primarily due to higher legal fees as we continued to vigorously defend legal matters. We expect absolute dollar spend and G&A to increase in Q3 and over time. We also expect technology and content costs to continue to grow in absolute dollars in Q3 and over time.  

We continue to be successful in hiring top computer scientists and software engineers on an accelerated basis. We believe this is the right thing to do for the customer experience and long-term shareholder value.  

In addition, we have started recruiting for our Development Centre in Scotland, which will open later this year. We have also chosen Scotland as the location for our second UK fulfillment center to meet growing demand in the UK. The leased facility is already occupied by some of our staff who are planning for shipments before the holidays and will employ approximately 300 over time. Consolidated segment operating income grew 50 percent to $101 million, and operating margin increased from 6.1 percent to 7.3 percent. Adjusting for the $4 million benefit from foreign exchange rates, operating income grew 44 percent. Trailing 12 month consolidating segment operating income, a component of free cash flow, was $444 million, up $180 million year-over-year including $18 million due to foreign exchange.  

In the North America segment, revenue grew 13 percent to $792 million. Media grew 9 percent and would have been substantially higher without the year-over-year compare of Harry Potter 5. EGM or electronics and other general merchandise revenue grew 27 percent to $226 million and represented 29 percent of North America revenue, up from 25 percent. Gross profit grew 16 percent, while gross margin increased from 27.1 percent to 27.7 percent. Operating income grew 21 percent, and operating margin expanded from 7.8 percent to 8.3 percent.  

In the international segment, revenue grew 50 percent to $595 million, representing 43 percent of worldwide sales. Revenue growth was 38 percent adjusting for the $46 million benefit from foreign exchange rates. Media revenue grew 35 percent and would have been substantially higher without the year ago compare of Harry Potter 5. EGM revenue grew 218 percent to $99 million and represented 17 percent of international revenue, up from 8 percent. Gross profit grew 45 percent, while gross margin was down from 21.1 percent to 20.4 percent as a result of our free shipping, product mix shift and price reductions.  

Operating income grew $22 million, reaching $35 million, and operating margin expanded from 3.2 percent to 5.9 percent. Pro forma net income increased to $75 million or 18 cents per diluted share compared with 10 cents per share. Our GAAP net income was $76 million or 18 cents per diluted share compared with a loss of $43 million or 11 cents per share.  

The net change of $120 million was primarily the result of the following. First, a $46 million improvement in the mark-to-market effect of remeasuring our Euro based debt to dollars, and a $44 million increase in operating income, 7 million of which was due to a gain recorded on previously vacated office space in conjunction with our 2001 restructuring which we determined during the quarter was necessary for our future needs. Though GAAP net income of $76 million is again higher than pro forma net income of 75, we still believe the pro forma number is an important and useful way to look at our business.  

Inventory was $284 million including the foreign exchange lift from inventories held outside the U.S.. Trailing 12 month inventory turns were 18 down from 20 as we bolstered our inventory to optimize in stock levels across our product categories, including newer categories such as jewelry. Our negative operating cycle was again over 20 days. Inventory again averaged 4 percent of annual sales.  

Our investment in fixed assets, which includes capitalized software development costs, declined 3 percent to $216 million. Capital expenditures were $14 million. Fixed assets plus inventory were $500 million, which accounts for nearly 70 percent of our total assets excluding cash and marketable securities. Cash and marketable securities increased from $989 million to $1.15 billion, including $46 million from favorable movements in foreign exchange rates.  

During the prior 12 months, we have redeemed $350 million in convertible debt that was otherwise due in 2009 mitigating nearly 4.5 million shares of potential dilution in addition to reducing our cash interest expense. Return on invested capital increased from 28 percent to 39 percent calculated using what we believe is a conservative approach to both return and invested capital, trailing 12 month free cash flow divided by average total assets minus current liabilities. Our long-term expectation is to deliver triple-digit returns on invested capital.  

Our growth continues to be fueled our persistent focus on the total customer experience -- selection, price and convenience. We expanded selection across our sites worldwide. We launched beta versions of our beauty and musical instrument stores in the U.S. further leveraging our merchants at platform and building on the success of recent new product categories such as gourmet food, health and personal care and jewelry.  

Customer shopping at our beauty start can now find, discover and buy more than 20,000 products, such as lush bath bombs and (inaudible) from over 40 merchants including Avon, L'Occitane, N.V. Perricone and Sephora.  

Our musical instruments stores offers customers with more than 30,000 products, including popular and exotic instruments, sound and recording equipment, DJ gear and accessories from leading industry merchants such as Musicians Friend, Woodwinds & Brasswinds, and Music123.  

In stores and outdoors, we now have over 400 merchants, as well as unique product content selection available online only at Amazon.com, including Cal Ripken Jr.'s essay on the importance of practice, and the a Flybar 1200, a revolutionary new pogo stick stunt bar enables riders to clear over 5 feet. The Flybar is now available for pretty order exclusively at Amazon.com.  

In apparel we continue to add new merchants to our growing selection, including Boot Barn, Cutter & Buck, Elizabeth, G&L Clothing, J.C. Penney and Liz Claiborne. The apparel store now features over 300 merchants and 3000 brands. We have now launched over 4000 merchants at business sellers offering primarily new merchandise, up from over 350 less than a year ago.  

Units sold from third-parties represented 24 percent of worldwide unit sales, up from 19 percent. We plan to continue to expand selection in existing categories and opening and promoting new categories worldwide over the next year.  

We continue to lower prices for customers. Customer adoption of our worldwide free shipping offers reached another high point this quarter, saving customers tens of millions of dollars more this quarter. In the UK, for example, we continue to see increased adoption of free shipping as customers embrace the 25 pound threshold which was 39 pounds this time last year. And Japanese customers continue to enjoy free shipping on a very high percentage of their orders due to the low 1500 Yen purchase threshold or less than $15.  

Our Jewelry Store continues to attract customer interest featuring high-quality items at low prices, including margins targeted at about 13 percent on diamond jewelry. Our number one bestseller is a $29 potato pearl necklace and earrings set, which has received great customer reviews and is eligible for free Super Saver Shipping.  

Our worldwide customer service team achieved a greater than 20 percent year-to-year reduction in contacts per unit, enabling us to share the savings from self-service and more efficient customer contacts with customers in the form of lower prices.  

We continue to lower prices on thousands of media and EGM products this quarter, and we have improved selection of value-priced, closeout and refurbished products, especially in our electronics and home and garden stores. Free shipping offers, low prices in jewelry and closeout products are part of Amazon's everyday effort to lower prices, and we intend to further lower prices for customers in the second half of this year and thereafter. Our goal is to maximize gross profit dollars not percentages, ultimately maximizing free cash flow and free cash flow per share for our shareholders.  

I will conclude my portion of today's call with guidance. Incorporated into our Q3 '04 guidance and 2004 baseline expectations are the order trends that we have seen to date and what we believe to date to be appropriately conservative assumptions. However, there is a high level of uncertainty surrounding fluctuations in the Euro pound, Yen and Canadian dollar foreign exchange rate, as well as the global economy and consumer spending and the impact on both of world events.  

While we are cautiously optimistic, it is not possible to accurately predict demand, and therefore, our actual results could differ materially from our guidance. Let me also remind everyone that since certain stock awards are subject to variable accounting, we incur a non-cash charge or gain for any movement in our share price between reporting dates. We mark our year denominated debt to market at the end of each quarter, which results in a non-cash gain or loss for any movement in the Euro between reporting dates. We also have exposure to the Euro related to our unhedged interest expense on this Euro-denominated debt.  

We incur a non-cash foreign currency gain or loss corresponding with intercompany balances denominated in foreign currencies which are to be repaid among subsidiaries. We cannot forecast these items, yet they could have a significant positive or negative impact on our results.  

For the September quarter, we expect net sales between 1.425 billion and 1.525 billion or growth of between 26 and 34 percent compared with Q3 of '03. Consolidated segment operating income to be between $80 million and $100 million or grow between 9 and 36 percent. For the calendar year 2004, we expect net sales of between 6.625 billion and 6.925 billion or growth between 26 and 32 percent. Consolidated segment operating income to be between $475 million and $535 million or growth of between 31 and 48 percent. We expect capital expenditures, including capitalized software development costs, to be $80 million or less. When we think about growth, we're focused on long-term growth from free cash flow per share; that is ultimately how we will measure our success.  

Finally, we cannot predict fluctuations in foreign exchange rates. This guidance assumes foreign exchange rates to stay approximately where they have been recently. We're confident that if we continue to drive customer experience, execute efficiently against our many challenges and opportunities, and earn customer trust, our value proposition as well as our free cash flow will further expand.  

Thanks and with that, Tim, let's move to questions.  

TIM STONE: Thanks, Tom. Let us move on to the Q&A portion of the call with Jeff and Tom. Operator, would you please remind our listeners how to ask a question?  

OPERATOR: (OPERATOR INSTRUCTIONS). Mark Mahaney, American Technology Research.  

MARK MAHANEY, ANALYST, AMERICAN TECHNOLOGY RESEARCH: Here is the question. In terms of your September quarter guidance, the midpoint of your pro forma operating margin is about 6.1 percent, which is down 120 basis points quarter to quarter. What is the major driver there of that sequential decline given the gross margin trends of the quarter, given they are sequentially down sales and marketing numbers in the June quarter?  

The second question just really briefly, are you seeing any general trends in terms of consumer spending, and particularly a pullback in consumer spending either in the U.S. or internationally? Thank you.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. In terms of our guidance, there is three key reasons for our Q3 bottom guidance, things that we are going to be doing differently than we have. First of all, one thing that is a constant is we are going to continue to lower prices for customers in the Q3 in the second half.  

Second, as I mentioned in my comments, we expect that technology and content costs are going to continue to grow in absolute dollars. We will continue to be successful in recruiting top computer scientists and software engineers, and we think that is the right thing for our customers and for our shareholders over the long-term.  

And third, we've actually seen very strong growth in the UK, and we have announced that we're actually adding a second UK fulfillment center in Scotland. And we actually are leasing a facility today in Scotland. We have some staff in Scotland already preparing for the holidays. We will continue to staff that facility over the course of the quarter. Of course, with that, we will have the cost of that facility and the people in that facility, but we won't have a lot of throughput to that facility until either later in the quarter or into the fourth quarter. So that will certainly be a lag versus what we saw in second quarter. So again that is what is reflected certainly in our guidance, and we think it positions us very well for the future, and we are excited with the things that we're doing.  

OPERATOR: Anthony Noto, Goldman Sachs.  

ANTHONY NOTO, ANALYST, GOLDMAN SACHS: Thank you very much. As we think about value in the Company and think about the long-term growth and profitability of the Company, we often look to incremental operating margin as the best leading indicator of that. And when the Company was going through its march to profitability, the incremental profitability of the Company on an operating income basis was in the midteens, and it was still in that level in 2003 until we got to the fourth quarter drop-down sub 10 percent. And since then, we have continued to see the deterioration and it has stayed in the 11 percent range through this quarter. And as we look at the third quarter, it is going to be in the single digits.  

And I just wonder if you think you're going to have to respend the amount of money and technology and marketing and R&D to stay competitive, that the incremental margin will not be in that range for the foreseeable future? And is that the key driver behind the spending?  

Secondly, could you give us some sense of the progress that you're making in your new categories? It seems that you have offered several new categories just domestically that we would see in the EGM line since the October time period, but we are not really seeing a pickup in growth. Thank you.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Thanks. Our goal always is to maximize free cash flow over time, and to step back from that, in addition to that we are trying to maximize operating profit dollars over time. And what you're seeing clearly in Q3 as I mentioned to Mark in the previous question, is we're making sure we're doing the right things going forward. Again, continuing to lower prices, continuing to make sure we have the best talent from a software engineering computer science standpoint, and again we accelerated hiring, which is impacting Q2 -- excuse me, Q3 guidance. And again, those are things that we certainly want -- they are the seeds we are planning for the future and we think will help improve the overall customer experience going forward.  

And then lastly again, I mentioned Scotland as well. That is one that's more of a temporary drag on Q3, and again once that is operational, you will see a lot of throughput to it.  

So again looking forward you know we're very optimistic about the model that we have and the opportunities we have in front of us. And when we see good opportunities to invest like we're doing, we are going to continue to do the right thing for our long-term shareholders.  

And the second part of your question, Anthony, I am sorry?  

ANTHONY NOTO: I was just wondering if you would give us some type of granularity on the progress of all the new stores that you have launched since October. You know obviously that is reported in a lot of different lines. We sort of look to the North American EGM line as a potential proxy for that, and the growth is there slowing. And you did not have those businesses a year ago in the convertible second quarter, and they been open for three-quarters. I was just wondering is there some slower traction in those businesses, less awareness, less supply that or selection that is appealing to drop conversion rates? What is the underlying trend in the business, and how should we think about it? Thanks.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Anthony, the new categories are growing very rapidly. Their impact on the growth rate of the company as a whole is small because the baseline off of which they are growing is still small, although getting larger all the time.  

OPERATOR: Heath Terry, Credit Suisse First Boston.  

HEATH TERRY, ANALYST, CREDIT SUISSE FIRST BOSTON: I was wondering if you could give us an idea abut the planned rollout for the third-party business in Europe, particularly how you plan to approach signing partners there, like the partners here that you have got with Circuit and Target and the rest? And to the extent that you have started this process, what kind of a reaction you're getting in Europe and how it might be different from the reaction that you got from partners here in the U.S.?  

TOM SZKUTAK: We don't see any structural differences or any substantial differences between the United States and Europe in that regard, and we think we will have over time the same kind of success, at least we hope we will, in Europe that we have had in the U.S..  

HEATH TERRY: And is there any timeline that you can put around that for when we should start seeing that develop?  

TOM SZKUTAK: No, I would not want to speculate on specific timeline, but it is something we are working toward.  

OPERATOR: Imran Khan, J.P. Morgan.  

IMRAN KHAN, ANALYST, J.P. MORGAN: As electronic products became a bigger portion of your total revenue and it seems like those products have lower gross margin, how are you going to manage your gross margin as those products become a bigger portion of your revenue?  

TOM SZKUTAK: I'm wanting to keep in mind, you would certainly add to this, is that the gross -- what we are really focused on is the gross profit dollars in those items. And in many cases, the gross profit dollars are actually much higher than we're accustomed to dealing with. So you take a $300 digital camera with a 13 percent gross margin, and it still has a very healthy number of gross profit dollars in it, and that's what really matters to us.  

IMRAN KHAN: Thanks.  

OPERATOR: Safa Rashtchy, Piper Jaffray.  

SAFA RASHTCHY, ANALYST, PIPER JAFFRAY: Thank you, Tom Jeff. The growth in the U.S. media segment slowed down significantly to 9 percent from 16 percent last quarter, and it has been pretty much around 14 to 16 percent up until last quarter. That is the single biggest segment of your revenues. Could you talk about what factors contributed to that pretty significant decline in growth, and what makes you optimistic about continuing growth given that the bulk of the revenues are actually declining?  

TOM SZKUTAK: In terms of media in North America, as you know, we had Harry Potter 5 release last year, and so it was certainly significant for us.  

SAFA RASHTCHY: But even if you said it was 5 percentage points, even without that, it was a noticeable sequential decline.  

TOM SZKUTAK: I said it was -- I had mentioned in my comments it was 5 incremental points or more globally, so on our total company.  

SAFA RASHTCHY: Okay, and may I have a follow-up on that please?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure.  

SAFA RASHTCHY: Actually not on the revenue line, but I wanted to just make sure I understood your comments about the reason for increased spending in R&D in particular. I'm not sure if I am understanding what is the use of the increased resources. You mentioned that you have access to very good talent, and I'm sure that's not the only reason to hire them. Could you talk about given that you have pretty substantial operating expenses already and very good infrastructure how would you be deploying these new resources and why are you hiring them?  

TOM SZKUTAK: It is a good question. There are a number of things that we are working on that you will see deployed over time. I don't want to talk about the things we will do in the future, but if you look in the recent past, the kinds of things that you see are things like "Search Inside the Book," which has been very successful for books category. And there are a number of very complicated but effective software projects that can be done on both the front-end and the back-end to make our business better for customers and shareholders.  

SAFA RASHTCHY: Thank you.  

OPERATOR: Lanny Baker, Smith Barney.  

LANNY BAKER, ANALYST, SMITH BARNEY: Thanks a lot. A pretty simple question. On the revenue in North America and the investments that you're making, it looks like they are against the margins right now. How long is the cycle of hiring people and working on the product technology? How long do you make the investment stock price margin before it slingshots back the other way potentially?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Most of the technology projects that have fairly short timelines or a least we get incremental results fairly quickly so we don't work on things for a long time before launching anything. If they are customer facing things, then once you do launch it, then it generally takes quite a bit of time for something to build into a substantial business, sort of like a new category. You launched it. The customers who use it like it. It grows very rapidly, but it grows off of a small initial base. So it takes time before these things effect the performance of the company as a whole.  

LANNY BAKER: Okay. So is it -- I guess in some total then on the investments that you're making right now, are we talking about is it a six-month period that the Company is in of heavier investments and heavier spending or is it 12?  

TOM SZKUTAK: I think it's very difficult to say in the abstract without talking about the specific investment because there are a variety of investments, some of which have very short payback horizons and some of which have somewhat longer payback horizons. But certainly a number of the things -- most of the things that we do today affect our results a couple of years from now. I am speaking in general.  

OPERATOR: Jeetil Patel, Deutsche Bank Securities.  

JEETIL PATEL, ANALYST, DEUTSCHE BANK SECURITIES: A couple of questions. Can you talk a little more about I guess the search market and related products that you have in that kind of segment of the market? And does it allow you to basically rev the model faster in terms of understanding what the consumer buying behavior looks like, where maybe demand is shifting towards? Is it allowing you to roll out categories even faster because of what you're learning in the search industry with the products that you have out there today like A9?  

And second, can you just talk about what you see in Germany in particular given the weak economy out there? Are you kind of seeing a little bit more of a seasonal trend in that marketplace today given a lot of the talk about Germany?  

JEFF BEZOS, FOUNDER & CEO, AMAZON.COM: On the first question -- I will let Tom answer the second piece -- but on the first question, certainly all of the activities that we do we learn from. A9.com in particular is focused on two things. One is improving e-commerce search for Amazon.com and our partners. That is something we have been working on for nine years, and we are just going to keep working on it.  

The second thing that that team does is have a consumer facing Web site at A9.com, which you could certainly go and check. And yes, there may be interesting data that comes out of that, although that is not the primary motivation for doing it. And then Tom?  

TOM SZKUTAK: In terms of individual countries, we have not in the past given any specific results. We certainly have a very strong business in Germany. We have built a very strong business in Germany. And in terms of the total segment, international segment is up 50 percent. (inaudible) exchange is up 38, and certainly was impacted year-over-year with the difficult compare with Harry Potter 5. But again beyond that, we are not giving you any specific country results.  

JEETIL PATEL: Can you just talk about what your (inaudible) looked like in the quarter?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. Globally it was 26 percent.  

OPERATOR: Mark Rowen, Prudential.  

MARK ROWEN, ANALYST, PRUDENTIAL: Good afternoon. A couple of questions. First, if I look at your international media products, I am estimating that in local currency that grew at about 25 percent give or take, and that is a pretty steep deceleration of growth from the last three quarters. I might be wrong, but I don't think you could explain all of it with Harry Potter. So could you explain what is going on in international media products?  

And then second, there was a question earlier which I don't think you asked on the consumer pullback, we have seen consumers pulling back in a lot of sectors of retail, home furnishings, office supplies even. Are you seeing that on your site in June or in July?  

TOM SZKUTAK: In terms of international media, we do certainly have a sizable impact from the year-over-year comparison of Harry Potter 5. It certainly impacted not only our North America segment, but our international segment. And then in terms of your question based on the economy, I don't think we are necessarily a bellwether for the economy. So in terms of the online penetration for retail sales, it is very small, and we are just not a bellwether for the economy.  

MARK ROWEN: So, Tom, are you saying the entire deceleration in international media products is due to Harry Potter? Did I understand that right?  

TOM SZKUTAK: It is actually hard to know. We certainly know what our sales were of Harry Potter 5 last year in the accompanying attachments, but certainly we had very positive traffic. So it's hard to tell.  

OPERATOR: Bob Peck, Bear Stearns.  

BOB PECK, ANALYST, BEAR STEARNS: I have two larger picture questions. One is I guess as far as expansion, further international expansion. Could you talk about maybe some timing, when we could see new countries rolled out, and what the impact of that would be?  

Number two is, could you give a little more color around the competitive landscape? One particular example that comes to mind would be jewelry versus something like Blue Nile. Is competition intensifying? Is that why prices are coming down? Do you see barriers to entry? Can you just give us more comments on the competitive landscape that would be great. Thanks.  

TOM SZKUTAK: In terms of international expansion, we like the countries and the Web sites we are in today. Certainly you should expect that we will expand into new countries over time In terms of timing of that, we certainly would not disclose that until we were ready to do so. But again you should expect that we will expand into new countries over time.  

In terms of competition, we don't really like to talk about any specific competitors. That being said, we certainly look on a category by category basis how our pricing is compared to our various competitors to make sure that we have very competitive prices in all the categories that we are in.  

OPERATOR: Sean Young, Friedman, Billings, Ramsey.  

SEAN YOUNG, ANALYST, FRIEDMAN, BILLINGS, RAMSEY: Thank you, Tom and Jeff. I wondered if you could just talk a little bit about your marketing going forward and in the quarter and specifically online advertising costs? You knew going into the quarter what your Harry Potter 5 units were, but it still seems like the revenue was at the low end of the range. Is there something that you saw in the marketing channel that caused you to dial back marketing during the quarter? Because the dollar number was a little bit below what I was expecting. Maybe, Jeff, if you have any thoughts on how you see that market developing in the next 6 to 12 months? Thank you.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Just briefly I think our marketing as a percentage of sales has stayed relatively flat. We are pretty happy with where it is. Our best use of marketing dollars we believe, given what we know about price elasticities, is to first we look to reduce product prices, do things like free Super Saver Shipping. Basically take the dollars that would have been spent on advertising and put those instead into improving the customer experience.  

Then second, we have certain kinds of advertising that we can do that are measurable. A large component of that is our associates program. That is a very effective program for us. We continue to do that. But I think our marketing dollars are pretty flat as a percentage of sales, and I think they are about where we want them.  

OPERATOR: Douglas Anmuth, Lehman Brothers.  

DOUGLAS ANMUTH, ANALYST, LEHMAN BROTHERS: Thank you. You reiterated today your commitment to free shipping. I am curious how you view free shipping? You have obviously stated in the past that it takes time for new initiatives to be absorbed throughout the customer base. So as a result, perhaps it takes longer really more than a year for free shipping to be absorbed and utilized. Even though we've already cycled through more than a year of free shipping obviously here in the United States, I'm wondering if you believe the Company is still benefiting from this initial adoption within the customer base, where do you think the user base is in the process in the U.S. and both internationally, and do you think it is continuing to help drive results the same way it was a few years ago or few quarters ago I am sorry, and whether you think that this is going to be an impact on North America media results in the coming quarters as you are looking to reaccelerate that growth level? Thank you.  

TOM SZKUTAK: I think there is still benefit to come from the free Super Saver Shipping offer. It takes a long time for a message to become really internalized in the minds of millions of consumers. And some evidence for that is the fact that we set another record this quarter for adoption of Super Saver Shipping. We expect customers to continue to learn about that and utilize it.  

TIM STONE: With that, I want to thank everyone for joining us on the call today. A replay will be available on Investor Relations Web site at least through the end of the quarter. I look forward to talking with you again next quarter, and thank you for your interest in Amazon.com. Good-bye.  

OPERATOR: This will conclude today's conference call. We do thank you for your participation, and you may disconnect at this time.

 Q1  2004  Amazon .com, Inc. Earnings Conference Call - Final
