   LP
OPERATOR: Good day, everyone and welcome to the Amazon.com first quarter 2004 financial results conference call. Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks and introductions I would like to turn the call over to the Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Tim Stone. Please go ahead, sir.  

TIM STONE, VP IR, AMZN: Thank you. Good afternoon. Welcome to the Amazon.com first quarter 2004 conference call. Joining me on today's call is Tom Szkutak, our CFO. Jeff Bezos, our Founder and CEO, will be available for the question and answer portion of the call.  

   TD
Please keep in mind, the following discussion and responses of your questions reflect management's views as of today, April 22, 2004 only and will include forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially. Additional information about factors that could potentially affect Amazon.com's financial results is included in today's press release and our filings with the SEC, including our annual report on form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2003 and all subsequent filings.  

As you listen to today's call, I encourage you to have our press release in front of you, which includes all of our financial results, as well as metrics and commentary on the quarter. It will correspond with much of the discussion that follows. During this call we also present certain non-GAAP financial measures. In the release, slides accompanying this webcast and our filings with the SEC, each of which is posted on our website, you'll find additional disclosures regarding these non-GAAP measures, including reconciliations of these measures with comparable GAAP measures.  

Finally, unless otherwise stated, all comparisons in this call will be against the results for the comparable period of 2003. With that I'll turn the call over to Tom.  

TOM SZKUTAK, CFO, AMZN: Thanks Tim. Today I'll discuss our financial and operating results and our future expectations. This was a great quarter for Amazon.com thanks to customers who continue to take advantage of our lower prices, free shipping and expanded selection.  

Let me start with a few comments on our financial results. Free cash flow on a trailing 12-month basis grew $221m, or 180%, to $344m, driven by improvements in top line growth and operating profit. The combination of common stock outstanding and stock-base awards was 432m shares, flat with a year ago.  

On the income statement, revenue grew 41%, gross profit grew 33%, while gross margin declined 139 basis points. Consolidated segment operating profit grew 73%, operating margin increased 142 basis points and pro forma net income grew $57m, or 141%.  

Revenue grew to $1.53b and for the first time, half of our revenue was from shipment to customers in over 200 countries outside the US. Adjusting for the $87m favorable year over year impact from foreign exchange rates, revenue growth was 33%.  

Consolidated segment operating expenses as a percentage of sales, declined 282 basis points. G&A increased primarily due to higher legal fees. We continue to vigorously defend legal matters and accordingly, this year we expect G&A costs to increase in absolute dollars, but not as a percentage of sales.  

Consolidated segment operating income grew 73% to $117m and the operating margin increased 142 basis points to 7.6%. Adjusting for the $7m benefit from foreign exchange rates, our operating income grew 64%. Trailing 12-month operating income of $411m, a component of free cash flow, benefited by $17m from foreign exchange rates.  

In the North America segment, revenue grew 20%, to $847m. Media revenue grew 16%. EGM, or electronics and other general merchandise revenue grew 33% and represented 27% of North America revenue.  

Gross profit grew 21%, while gross margins increased slightly to 26.7%, and operating income grew 46% as margin expanded 159 basis points to 8.9%.  

In the international segment, revenue grew 80%, to $684m. Revenue growth was 58%, adjusting for the $85m benefit from foreign exchange rate. Media revenue grew 62%. EGM revenue increased more than four times, from $23m to $107m. Gross profit grew 61%, while gross margin was 19.7%, down 236 basis points as a result of our free shipping, product mix shift and price reductions.  

In the UK for example, in addition to lowering book prices in the first quarter, we continue to see increased adoption of free shipping. We offered free shipping on orders over 39 pounds for roughly two-thirds of the first quarter of 2003 and since July of 2003 have offered free shipping on orders over 25 pounds. Additionally, the mix of EGM grew to 16% of international revenue, up from 6% of revenue, as we're offering low prices across our expanding selection as we grow these stores similar to our US approach. Over time we expect to increase selection in these stores with more third party sellers as well.  

International operating income grew over $25m, reaching $41m as margin expanded 190 basis points to 6.1%. Pro forma net income more than doubled, to $97m, or $0.23 per diluted share, compared with $0.10 per diluted share.  

Our GAAP net income was $111m, or $0.26 per diluted share, compared with a loss of $10m, or $0.03 per share. The net change was primarily the result of the following; the $71m increase in operating income, 20m of which was associated with the decline in stock-based compensation and a $46m improvement in the mark to market effect of re-measuring our Euro-based debt to dollars. Though it was lower than the $111m GAAP net income number, we believe the $97m pro forma net income number is an important and useful way to look at our business.  

Inventory was $282m, including the foreign exchange impact from inventories held from outside the US. Inventory, again, averaged 4% of annual sales as we continue to bolster our inventory levels to optimize 2004 worldwide in stock levels across our product categories, including our newer ones, such as jewelry.  

The trailing 12-month inventory churns were 19, down from 20, and our negative operating cycle was again over 20-days. Our investment in fixed assets, which includes net capitalized software development costs, declined 5% from a year ago, to $217m. Capital expenditures were $10m.  

Cash and marketable securities decreased to $998m, including $68m from favorable movement in foreign exchange rates. During the quarter we repaid $150m of US dollar convertible debt that was otherwise due in 2009, eliminating some potential share dilution, in addition to reducing our future net cash interest expense.  

Return on invested capital increased to 38%, up from 15%, calculating using what we believe is a conservative approach to both return and invested capital, trailing 12-month free cash flow divided by average total assets, minus current liabilities.  

Our growth continues to be fueled by our focus on every customer facing aspect of our business, from our product prices to our selection, from our Webster's user interface to how we package and ship items. The customer experience we create is by far the most important driver of our business.  

I'll now share some of our recent progress for each of the primary inputs into customer experience, selection, convenience and price. We expanded selection across product categories worldwide. As we enter the peak season for sports and outdoors, we now offer more than 200,000 items from over 250 Amazon services merchants. Since we introduced the store, over 350,000 customers have purchased products from our merchants. We've added over 125 merchants, including And 1 basketball gear, Bike Nashpar, Curly's Fishing Lures, The Official NHL Store, Paintball Stuff For Less, and many more across 50 sports and outdoor activities.  

In keeping with our customers' New Year's resolutions during Q1, we sold over 14,000 Bowflexes, treadmills, ab trainers, stop watches, pedometers and other exercise equipment and accessories.  

In apparel, we added several leading retailers and brands, including JLo by Jennifer Lopez, Lucky Brand Jeans, mahanuala, by Puma and Christy Turlington Burns, Samsonite and Teva Sport sandals. We now have over 200 Amazon services merchants in our apparel store, offering more than 2,000 brands, featuring over 150,000 clothing styles, with more than 1m color and size combinations. Since launch, more than 1m customer accounts have ordered an apparel item.  

We launched four new international stores; home and garden stores in Germany, do it yourself in tools in the UK, garden and outdoors stores in the UK and PCs in Japan. Active seller accounts, those with an order from one of our customers in the last 12-months, increased over 50%, to more than 700,000, including more than 2,000 merchant [at] business sellers offering primarily new merchandise.  

We plan to expand selection in existing categories and open and promote new categories worldwide over the next year. We constantly strive to make our stores more convenient for customers. We introduced guaranteed accelerated delivery, offering our US customers guaranteed next business day delivery on hundreds of thousands of products ordered from Monday through Thursday morning. Now customers who just can't wait for that new book, DVD, digital camera or other product can have it on their doorsteps the next day. And this service is guaranteed we'll get it to you the next business day or the shipping is on us. To see if your item is eligible, just look below the availability information on a product detail page.  

This morning, for example, when I went on the site at 8:14 a.m., the product detail page for the Six Sigma Way indicated, Want it delivered Friday, April 23rd? Order it in the next three hours and 16 minutes and choose one-day shipping at checkout.  

Again this year the widely followed American Customer Satisfaction Index gave Amazon.com a score of 88, the highest customer satisfaction score ever recorded in any service industry online or off.  

We'll grow our technology teams again in 2004 as we hire computer scientists and software engineers to invest in long-term innovation for customers. For the first time since 2000, annual technology and content costs are expected to grow in absolute dollars this year, although remain flat or decline as a percentage of revenue.  

And we strive to offer the lowest prices. Our pricing objective is not to discount a small number of products for a limited period of time, but to offer low prices everyday and apply them broadly across our entire product range. Recent examples include customer adoption of our worldwide free shipping offers reached the highpoint this quarter, saving customers tens of millions of dollars and bolstering our result to keep our free shipping offers in place indefinitely.  

We offered low prices in Canada. We lowered book prices in Canada by offering 30% off books over $25. Previously we offered 30% off books over $30. In both media and EGM we lowered prices on thousands of products again last quarter. In the UK we further reduced book prices by offering 30% off books over 10 pounds. Previously we offered 30% off books over 15 pounds.  

Our pricing strategy does not attempt to maximize margin percentages, but instead seeks to drive maximum value for customers and thereby create a much larger bottom line in the long-term. For example, as we discuss in more detail in a letter from Jeff on our homepage today, we're targeting gross margins on our jewelry sales to be substantially lower than industry norms, because we believe over time customers figure these things out. This approach will produce more value to shareholders.  

I'll conclude my portion of today's call with guidance. Incorporated into our Q2 '04 guidance and 2004 baseline expectations, are the order trends that we've seen to date and what we believe today to be appropriately conservative assumptions. However, there is a high level of uncertainty surrounding fluctuations in the Euro pound, yen and Canadian dollar foreign exchange rates, as well as the global economy and consumer spending and the impact on both of world events.  

While we are cautiously optimistic, it's not possible to accurately predict demand and therefore, our actual results could differ materially from our guidance. Let me also remind everyone that since certain stock awards are subject to variable accounting, we incur non-cash charge or gain for any movement in our share price between reporting dates. We mark our Euro denominated debt to market at the end of each quarter, which results in a non-cash gain or loss for any movement in the Euro between reporting dates. We also have exposure to the Euro related to our un-hedged interest expense on this Euro denominated debt.  

We incur non-cash foreign currency gain or loss corresponding with inter-company balances denominated in foreign currencies, which are to be repaid amongst subsidiaries. We cannot forecast these items, yet they could have a significant impact, either positively or negatively on our results. For the June quarter we expect net sales of between $1.34b and $1.44b, or growth of between 22 and 31%, compared with Q2 of '03, when we shipped over 1.4m copies of Harry Potter V worldwide. Consolidated segment operating income to be between $85m and $105m, or growth between 27 and 56%.  

For the calendar year 2004 our expectations are net sales of between $6.45b and $6.85b, or growth of between 23 and 30%. Consolidated segment operating income to be between $455m and $535m, a growth of between 26 and 48%. While we expect to generate year over year growth, we will also continue to invest in our long-term opportunities. When thinking about growth we're focused on long-term growth and free cash flow. That's ultimately how we'll measure our success.  

We expect capital expenditures, including capitalized software development costs, to be approximately $80m or less. And finally, we cannot predict fluctuations in foreign exchange rates. This guidance assumes foreign currency rates stay approximately where they've been recently.  

We are confident that if we continue to drive customer experience, execute efficiently against our many challenges and opportunities and earn customer trust, our value proposition as well as our free cash flow will further expand, leading to triple-digit returns on invested capital.  

Thanks and with that, Tim, let's move to questions.  

TIM STONE: Great. Thanks Tom. Let's move on to the Q&A portion of the call with Jeff and Tom. Operator, will you please remind our listeners how to ask a question?  

OPERATOR: If you would like to ask a question at this time, please signal us by pressing the star key, followed by the digit one on your touch-tone telephone. If you are using a speakerphone, please be sure your mute function is turned off to allow your signal to reach our equipment. As a reminder, in the interest of time, we ask that you please limit yourself to asking one question. Once again, please press star one to ask a question at this time.  

And we'll take our first question from Jeetil Patel, with Deutsche Bank Securities.  

JEETIL PATEL, ANALYST, DEUTSCHE BANK SECURITIES: Hey guys. I have a couple of housekeeping questions. Can you talk about user and unit growth and how that trended in the quarter? Second, can you just talk about North America EGM? Growth actually accelerated. How much of an impact did some of your newer categories have in that line item? And then if you look at the calculation, it was something like $1.40 in operating profit, I believe, per unit. Where do you think that is going to settle out longer-term, as you scale up the business from a volume standpoint and among some of these newer categories?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure, thanks Jeetil. In terms of unit growth, our unit growth for the quarter was greater than 36%. In terms of our growth in North America EGM, it was certainly driven by a number of things that we've done from a customer experience standpoint. Certainly lower prices - we lowered prices across many items during the quarter, excuse me, across many products during the quarter. We also improved in stock levels significantly as well. So those are certainly the key drivers that led to that growth as well as obviously the new categories that we've launched recently.  

OPERATOR: And we'll take our next question from Brian Pitz, with Morgan Stanley.  

BRIAN PITZ, ANALYST, MORGAN STANLEY: Hey guys. A quick question on your A9 business. Obviously you rolled it out recently. Can you talk about what type of expense that's impacting in the expense line? And also your longer term plans for that? Because it does look like a great product. Thanks.  

JEFF BEZOS, FOUNDER, CEO, AMZN: This is Jeff. The expense there is very much related to the number of people that are working on it. And there are a couple of different things going on there. They're working on eCommerce search, which is the eCommerce search engine that Amazon uses and that we offer to our partners. They've launched a consumer website, A9.com that has a few unique features. It integrates the search inside the book results. It has a personalized search history, so in the Amazon.com sort of way, it greets you by name, remembers your search history. And then there's a tool bar that has a persistent server side diary feature. So that's what A9 is working on.  

BRIAN PITZ: Okay. And just a follow-up on another topic regarding the foreign exchange. What have you guys been assuming for the Euro currency and some of the other currencies? And how much above your expectation was this quarter, versus what you were estimating? Thanks.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Your question was related to Q1?  

BRIAN PITZ: Yes.  

TOM SZKUTAK: It certainly exceeded our expectations. We haven't disclosed the exact rate from an assumption standpoint, that we used, but it certainly exceeded our expectations.  

BRIAN PITZ: Okay, thank you.  

OPERATOR: And we'll take our next question from Anthony Noto, with Goldman Sachs.  

ANTHONY NOTO, ANALYST, GOLDMAN SACHS: Thank you very much. Jeff, in the past you've talked about your strategy of driving down cost to lower prices and that this would create demand. And that's been very successful in the categories where you've owned inventory, such as books, music and video. And then your announcement today with jewelry is very much aligned with that.  

Could you talk about how you can apply that strategy to sporting goods and apparel where I believe Amazon owns very little inventory, and how do you really differentiate that versus your competitive set? And if you do start to take inventory, what's the implications for fulfillment capacity? And are these categories where you're going to have to do more broad scale marketing? Thanks.  

JEFF BEZOS: Most of the categories that we're in are hybrid categories in one way or another. And of course, even if you took a category like books, where we own a lot of inventory, the third parties who also sell books on our website are often able to offer a lot of value with respect to price. So I wouldn't characterize it as that the owned inventory is required to drive a low price strategy. We have several excellent partners in various categories, including electronics and so on and so on, who are often able to offer excellent value to customers. And we value those partner relationships.  

At the same time, we are, in our owned inventory business, going to be relentlessly focused on lowering prices, giving back value to customers and driving growth in our business that way. That's something we've been doing for several years now and we believe that strategy is working.  

ANTHONY NOTO: If I could just follow-up with one additional question on that. If you look at the marginal profitability on a year over year basis, the incremental operating margin, which we think is the best proxy for long-term margins, is around 11%, versus 18% last year. And I know that you've been giving back value to the consumer through free shipping and lower prices. But this is the first time in addition to that, that we've seen marketing up double-digits in 13 quarters. Do you think you have to continue to drive that marketing line going forward? Thanks.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. We're going to continue to do the things that we think are right to help drive growth in the business. As you mentioned, our marketing spend was up. And again, that was online marketing that we're doing to drive traffic to our website, which we thought was pretty effective and we're going to continue trying to do more of the same.  

OPERATOR: And we'll take our next question from Lanny Baker, with Citigroup Smith Barney.  

LANNY BAKER, ANALYST, CITIGROUP SMITH BARNEY: Thanks a lot. I have two questions. One's just a definition. Tom, could you go over again how you're calculating the return on invested capital number that you come up with? And then the second question is, of the 2,000 merchants I think that you said were merchants at Amazon.com. how many of those are selling on non-US Amazon sites? I imagine it's a pretty small number. What's the timeframe or what's the plan, what are the impediments at the moment from not making that a bigger number of third parties selling overseas?  

TOM SZKUTAK: The first part of your question, return on invested capital, we're using trailing 12-month free cash flow divided by average total assets, minus current liabilities. And can you just repeat the second half of the question related to third parties? I didn't get the full--.  

LANNY BAKER: Sure. I think that you had said that there were about 2,000 merchants at Amazon. Is that about right? And I was wondering if you could tell us how many of those are selling on Amazon's overseas properties and is there a plan to make that a - my sense is that it's a relatively small portion of them and is there a plan to make the third party selling bigger and what might be the timing of that and what are the challenges or the impediments to getting that done?  

TOM SZKUTAK: The way we are thinking about it is certainly as we enter new categories in all of our geographies, in many cases we start off with Amazon owned inventory first, in the case of EGM within international. And then over time as we increase our volume in those particular categories, we'll continue to attract more third party sellers. So again, it's part of everything that we do. So again, we expect that we'll continue to grow those as we go.  

OPERATOR: And we'll take our next question from Heath Terry, with Credit Suisse First Boston.  

HEATH TERRY, ANALYST, CREDIT SUISSE FIRST BOSTON: Great, thanks for that. I was wondering if you could just talk a little bit about strategy - and this may follow-up a little bit on the last question, but strategy as it goes towards signing up new third party partners outside of the US, particularly in Europe? And more specifically, realizing it's something that you do want to do, what barriers you expect to run into as you start to sign up those partners?  

JEFF BEZOS: What we've found so far is that there have not been substantial differences in the way we operate as we do things in different countries. So I would expect that we would find that that will be a very similar situation to what we found here.  

HEATH TERRY: Okay, thanks.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Jeetil, I think we missed the first part or one of the parts of your question. You had asked about active customer accounts. That was 41m, up 26%.  

OPERATOR: And we'll move next to Robert Peck, with Bear Stearns.  

ROBERT PECK, ANALYST, BEAR STEARNS: Yes, I have a quick three questions. Could you give us any thoughts on your plans for paying down more debt during the year? Could you also talk to us a little bit about where you are seeing increased competition coming from at the other online sites, who more particularly may be giving you more pressure than the others? And lastly, could you also comment on Amazon France and what exactly happened there with the local authorities in terms of the current situation over there?  

JEFF BEZOS: The first one on the debt, we did announce at the last call that we're retiring 150m of debt, which we did. We also announced that we'd be retiring up to $500m over time. And so that's all that we've announced to date. From a competitive environment standpoint, certainly we spend a lot of time focused on the customer and trying to improve the customer experience and that's where we spend our time. We certainly do look at individual competitors or other companies that are out there and trying to see what they do well and trying to learn from that. But again, we're a very customer focused company.  

The last question I think was on France, if I heard that correctly. Certainly we don't make it a practice to comment on any regulatory matters outside of our public filings.  

OPERATOR: And we'll take our next question from Mark Rowen, with Prudential.  

MARK ROWEN, ANALYST, PRUDENTIAL EQUITY GROUP: Thanks. Two quick questions. One, I didn't notice in the release, can you tell us what percentage of units came from third party sales in the quarter? I think you've disclosed that in the past. And then second, as I look at your international media product sales, that business is almost as big as your North American media business, granted with some currency benefit. But it's growing at a significantly faster rate than the North American business and has been for a while now. Can that continue through the rest of the year and into next year? And if so, given the fact that it's about the same size now, why is it growing so much faster? Thanks.  

JEFF BEZOS: In terms of third party units, our third party units as a percentage of the total was 23%, which is up from 19% from Q1 of last year. And in terms of media growth, we certainly have seen very strong growth in both international as well as North America media growth. And we're certainly not giving guidance for the year in those particular categories, but again, we're focused on the inputs that help us drive growth in both of those geographies, meaning in our international segment as well as North America. And we're continuously looking at ways to improve the total customer experience to do that.  

MARK ROWEN: But do you think that the market opportunity for the international media business is significantly bigger than the US?  

JEFF BEZOS: It's very difficult to know in advance. There certainly are some very nice things about some of the geographies in which we operate in, very rapid delivery times in some cases, for example. Sometimes there are reasons why big box stores don't work especially well in certain geographies due to zoning restrictions, et cetera, et cetera. So, there are some very nice characteristics and I think we'll just have to wait and see.  

MARK ROWEN: Okay great, thank you.  

OPERATOR: And we'll take our next question from Doug Anmuth, with Lehman Brothers.  

DOUG ANMUTH, ANALYST, LEHMAN BROTHERS: Thank you. If I look at the guidance that you put out and compare it to what we saw at the last quarter, it looks like you raised the top line and the consolidated operating income both by about 3.1%, which kind of gets us to a 7.44% margin, which would be just about the same as it was last quarter. I'm just wondering if there's any particular reason why we might not see more operating leverage in that number?  

And then also, just speaking about the North America media business, which also came in very strong again for the quarter, I'm just wondering how you see that playing out against some tougher comparisons over the next couple of quarters and how recent strength in music sales might also be impacting the business? Thank you.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. In terms of guidance for the total year, we did raise guidance. Last quarter we had said that guidance for the year, for the top line would be between $6.2b and $6.7b and we raised that to 64.5 to 68.50. Again, I'm reflecting the optimism that we have for the year. Certainly in terms of your question on operating leverage, we continue to focus on the right things, which are again, how do we make the improvements in customer experience to drive growth?  

From an operating leverage standpoint, what that means is that we're going to continue to make sure that we continue to hire software development engineers. So you should expect that technology and content, for example, will continue to grow through the course of the year. But again, we're focused on balancing that with maximizing operating profit dollars and free cash flow over the course of the year.  

And I'm sorry, the other part of the question related to media?  

DOUG ANMUTH: The North America media business, which was obviously very strong, how it might stack up going forward against some tougher comparisons? And then also how much music contributed, given that it's been stronger the last several months, a few months at least?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Again, we've certainly seen very solid growth in media. We're not giving guidance specifically on media. Certainly for Q2 as you look at our guidance, just keep in mind that that has a tough compare to last year with us selling over 1.4m copies of Harry Potter V.  

DOUG ANMUTH: And on the music, or you have no comment on that? I mean if you've seen a boost there kind of commensurate with the overall market?  

TOM SZKUTAK: We actually have not broken individual subcategories out.  

DOUG ANMUTH: Okay great. Thank you.  

OPERATOR: And we'll take our final question from Mark Mahaney, with American Technology Research.  

MARK MAHANEY, ANALYST, AMERICAN TECHNOLOGY RESEARCH: Great thank you. Two quick questions. One on the guidance for the June quarter. The midpoint of your guidance implies 9% sequential decline. That seems greater than the seasonality you've seen not last year, but two years ago. So just any more color on why your guidance is like that?  

And secondly, I know you don't run the business off of gross margins, but there is this significant gap between US and international gross margins. It's approximately 690 basis points in this last quarter. Could you talk about two or three levers you have that could reduce those margins and specifically bring up the international gross margins to US levels? Thank you.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. First in terms of the sequential decline from a revenue standpoint from Q1 to Q2, first a couple of reminders. The first one is in Q1 we had a significant benefit from foreign exchange rates in Q1. Q1 revenue was helped by $87m from foreign exchange rates. And certainly the dollar has strengthened in the recent months, so you should assume that there's certainly a meaningful benefit in Q2 guidance, but not as significant. And obviously the second major driver would be, obviously, with comparing Q2 we have a tough compare, as I mentioned before, because of Harry Potter V last year selling over 1.4m copies, and obviously the associated traffic with that as well.  

MARK MAHANEY: And on the gross margin opportunity?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. On the gross margin opportunity I think we're certainly at two different stages between North America and international. Some of our categories are certainly just much newer. For example, you can see within international, our EGM growth was very significant during the quarter, roughly four times the absolute amount in terms of growth during the quarter. So again, we just have very different stages.  

And so as we grow we'll continue to do the right thing to make sure the customers have the best possible pricing. But we'll also be able to get better scale, which means we'll be able to get better prices with suppliers. In turn we'll also be able to attract more third party sellers. So all of those things will help that over time.  

MARK MAHANEY: Thank you.  

TIM STONE: Okay, thanks Mark. With that I'd like to thank everyone for joining us on our call today. A replay will be available on our investor relations website at least through the end of the quarter. We look forward to talking with you again next quarter and thank you again for your interest in Amazon.com.  

OPERATOR: This does conclude today's conference. We thank you for your participation. You may now disconnect.

OPERATOR: Thank you for standing by. Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Amazon.com Fourth Quarter 2003 Financial Results conference call. Todayâ€™s call is being recorded.  

For opening remarks and introductions Iâ€™d like to turn the call over to the Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Tim Stone. Please go ahead, sir.  

   TD
TIM STONE, VP OF IR, AMZN: Thank you. Good afternoon, and welcome to the Amazon.com Fourth Quarter 2003 conference call. Joining on todayâ€™s call will be Tom Szkutak, our Chief Financial Officer. Jeff Bezos, our CEO, will be available for the question and answer portion of the call.  

Please keep in mind that the following discussion and responses to your questions reflect managementâ€™s views as of today, January 27th, 2004 only and will include forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially.  

Additional information about factors that could potentially affect Amazon.com's financial results is included in today's press release and our filings with the Securities & Exchange Commission including our annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2002, and also the SEC filings.  

As you listen to todayâ€™s call I encourage you to have our press release in front of you since all of our financial results as well as the metrics and commentary on the quarter are included and will correspond to much of the discussion that follows.  

During this call we will also present certain non-GAAP financial measures. In the release, slides accompanying this webcast and our filings with the SEC each of which is posted on our IR web site, you will find additional disclosures regarding these non-GAAP measures, including reconciliations of these measures with comparable GAAP measures. And finally, unless otherwise stated all comparisons used in this call will be against our results for the comparable period of 2002.  

With that, Iâ€™ll turn the call over to Tom.  

TOM SZKUTAK, CFO, AMZN: Thanks, Tim.  

Today Iâ€™ll discuss our financial and operating results, and our future expectations. This was another great year and quarter for Amazon.com, thanks to the efforts of our global teams and partners and our returning and new customers who continued to take advantage of our lower prices, free shipping, and expanded selection.  

Let me start by reviewing 2003. Free cash flow grew 156 percent to $346m driven by improvements in top line growth and operating profit. The combination of common stock outstanding and employee stock based awards was 433m shares, flat with a year ago. Revenues grew 34 percent to $5.26b, adjusting for the $232m of favorable year-over-year impact from foreign exchange rates revenue growth was 28 percent.  

Our international segment, the U.K., Germany, France, and Japan, reached combined sales of over $2b for the first time. Active customer accounts representing customer accounts with purchases in 2003 increased 26 percent to over 39m.  

Consolidated segment operating income doubled to $361m and margin improved 228 basis points to 6.9 percent. North America segment operating margin reached nine percent while international achieved a four percent margin. But more importantly, from our perspective, operating profit dollars for each grew substantially.  

Inventory turns were 18, and inventory was $294m including the foreign exchange impact from inventories held outside the U.S. Inventory again averaged four percent of annual sales while we took advantage of buying opportunities from vendors and bolstered our inventory levels to optimize 2004 worldwide in stock levels across our product categories, including our newer ones.  

Our investment in fixed assets, which includes net capitalized software development costs, declined six percent from a year ago to $224m. Our capital expenditures were $46m less than depreciation, for the third consecutive year.  

Cash and marketable securities increased to $1.39b including $72m from favorable movement in foreign exchange rates. During the year we repaid $464m of long-term debt, consisting of the remainder of our 10 percent senior discount notes in May and $200m of our U.S. dollar convertible debt in November.  

Today we announced that in February we will redeem an additional $150m of our U.S. dollar convertible debt for face value plus a 2.375 percent premium, which will result in a $6m charge to re-measurement in other in our first quarter GAAP results.  

The combined $350m early repayment of our convertible debt that was otherwise due in 2009 eliminates potential dilution of over 4m shares in addition to reducing our future net cash interest expense. We also announced the program to repurchase or redeem up to an additional $500m of our remaining outstanding convertible debt over time.  

Return on invested capital increased to 38 percent, up from 15 percent calculated using what we believe is a conservative approach to both return in invested capital, free cash flow divided by total assets minus current liabilities.  

Now for a few comments in the quarter. Revenues grew 36 percent to $1.95b, 46 percent of which was shipped to over 200 countries outside the U.S. Adjusting for the $98m favorable year-over-year impact from foreign exchange rates revenue growth was 29 percent.  

Third party units representing the units sold by our partners on our web site grew to 24 percent of total units.  

North America segment revenues grew 18 percent to $1.14b. North American media grew 16 percent, and electronics and other general merchandise revenue grew 22 percent. Electronics and other general merchandise revenue grew 30 percent excluding the toy and baby product categories.  

International segment revenues were $804m, a 74 percent increase. Adjusting for the favorable year-over-year impact from foreign exchange rates international revenue growth was 54 percent. International gross margin declined 17 percent driven by lower prices, free shipping, and product mix shift. For example, the electronics and other general merchandise grew to 15 percent of our international sales, up from seven percent of our sales as we invested in low prices in selection in our Japan, Germany, and U.K. stores.  

Consolidated segment operating income grew 50 percent to $153m including a $6m benefit from foreign exchange rates. Consolidated segment operating margin increased to 7.9 percent.  

Pro forma net income grew 66 percent to $125m or 29 cents per diluted share, compared with 19 cents per diluted share. Our GAAP net income was $73m or 17 cents per diluted share, compared with $3m or one cent per share. The net change was primarily the result of the following. First, a $67m increase in operating income. Second, a $36m re-measurement gain corresponding with intercompany balances denominated foreign currencies which are to be repaid among subsidiaries. Third, a $27m increase in the mark-to-market charge from remeasuring our Euro based [debt] [ph] to dollars. And fourth, a $9m charge we incurred in connection with our November 24th early redemption of $200m of our 4-3/4 U.S. dollar convertible debt.  

Our growth continues to be fueled by our relentless focus on the primary inputs into customer experience. Selection, convenience, and price. Iâ€™ll share some of our recent progress for each of these.  

Weâ€™ve expanded selections across our product categories worldwide. In our electronics last year we increased U.S. selection by over 40 percent, significantly increased U.K. and Germany selection, and introduced a new store in Japan. Electronic unit sales increased nearly 50 percent in the U.S. and over 80 percent worldwide.  

Unique items ordered from our U.S. home category more than tripled in the fourth quarter, fueled by greater selection including additions from our newer merchants, The Container Store, Plough & Hearth, and Smith & Hawken.  

Last year we added tens of thousands of titles to our U.K. DVD catalog last year, and the number of unique items ordered more than doubled in Q4. We launched a new home and kitchen store in Japan, and introduced marketplace in France and Canada. Last quarter we also introduced three new stores in the U.S.: Gourmet Food with over 40,000 unique items, Health & Personal Care with over 70,000 unique items, and Jewelry & Watches which now offers over 60,000 unique items.  

Selling alongside Amazon.com in these new stores are great merchants like Dean & DeLuca, Godiva, Harry and David, Omaha Steaks, and Câ€™s Candies, Vitamin Shop, Fossil, fortune off, Mandera, Ross-Simons, and Watchzone.  

In 2003 active seller accounts, those with an order from one of our customers in the last 12 months increased over 70 percent to more than 600,000, including more than 1,000 branded merchants offering new merchandise.  

Expanding Amazon.com and third party selection worldwide in existing and new product categories is a constant focus. While we made great progress in 2003 thereâ€™s more to come. Including new stores weâ€™re currently building that we plan to open and promote over the next year.  

We constantly strive to make our stores more convenient for customers. Last quarter, for example, we introduced Search Inside the Book, facilitating customer discover by allowing text from books from hundreds of participating publishers to be searched and previewed.  

Our global fulfillment centerâ€™s controllable free replacements, an important quality measure, improved over 40 percent, while throughput per hour increased 39 percent. Demonstrated peak holiday unit capacity across our fulfillment centers increased 24 percent. Improved efficiency allowed our fulfillment centers to accommodate our growth without any new automated fulfillment centers again last year, and enabled our U.S. fulfillment centers to extend the holiday free shipping deadline for customers by four additional days to December 16th. While again shipping more than 99 percent of all of our orders in time to meet holiday deadlines.  

In 2003 we substantially increased our technology teams, and in 2004 weâ€™ll continue hiring computer scientists and software engineers to invest in the future innovation for our customers. For the first time since 2000 annual technology and content costs are expected to grow in absolute dollars next year.  

We continue to lower prices to create the best possible value proposition for our customers. As weâ€™ve said before, â€˜at Amazon.com lowering prices worldwide is not an event, itâ€™s the way we run our business.â€™ Our objective is not to discount a small number of products for a limited period of time but to offer low prices every day and apply them broadly across our entire product range.  

Recent examples include free shipping offers around the world to save customers tens of millions of dollars more this fourth quarter. In the U.K., for example, where we tested free shipping on orders over 39 pounds for the first time in holiday 2002 and lowered the threshold to 25 pounds in July 2003 the percentage of units shipped free increased over 1,300 basis points.  

In both media, and electronics, and other general merchandise we lowered prices on thousands of products again last quarter. We heavily promoted our newer stores with discounts off future Amazon.com purchases when customers ordered over $50 of apparel, sporting goods, gourmet food, and jewelry. As a reminder, these offers are recorded against current revenues.  

And today in the U.K. we announced a further reduction in book prices by offering 30 percent off books over 10 pounds. Previously, we offered 30 percent off books over 15 pounds. In 2004 weâ€™ll maintain our relentless focus on finding ways to afford even lower prices. And for years to come weâ€™ll continue assessing the elasticity of demand as we lower prices even further.  

Iâ€™ll conclude my portion of todayâ€™s call with guidance. Incorporated in our Q1 â€™04 guidance in the 2004 baseline expectations are the order trends that weâ€™ve seen to date and what we believe today to be appropriately conservative assumptions. However, thereâ€™s a high level of uncertainty surrounding fluctuations in the Euro, pound, yen, and Canadian dollar foreign exchange rates, as well as the global economy and consumer spending, and the impact on both of world events. While we are cautiously optimistic it is not possible to accurately predict demand and, therefore, our actual results could differ materially from our guidance.  

Let me also remind everyone that since certain stock awards are subject to variable accounting we incur a non-cash charge or gain for any movement in our share price between reporting dates. And we mark our Euro denominated debt to market at the end of each quarter which results in non-cash gain or loss for any movement in the Euro between reporting dates. We also have exposure to the Euro related to our unhedged interest expense on this Euro denominated debt, and we incur a non-cash foreign currency gain or loss corresponding with intercompany balances denominated in foreign currencies which are to be repaid among subsidiaries. We cannot forecast these items, yet they could have a significant impact either positively or negatively on our results.  

For the March quarter we expect net sales of between $1.39b and $1.49b, or a growth of between 28 and 38 percent. Consolidated segment operating income is to be between $95m and $150m, or grow between 41 and 70 percent.  

For calendar 2004 our expectations are that net sales of between $6.2b and $6.7b or growth of between 18 and 27 percent. Consolidated segment operating income could be between $430m and $530m, or growth of between 19 and 47 percent. While we expect to generate year-over-year growth we will also continue to invest in our long-term opportunities.  

We expect capital expenditures including capitalized software development costs to be less than $100m. This guidance assumes foreign currency rates stay approximately where theyâ€™ve been recently. We cannot predict fluctuations in foreign exchange rates. Finally, when we think about growth weâ€™re concerned with long-term growth of free cash flow. Thatâ€™s ultimately how weâ€™ll measure our success.  

Before opening up to questions let me close by looking forward for the next several years. We will be on the leading edge of technology and innovation, weâ€™ll continue investing over $200m a year in technology and content because we believe thereâ€™s a lot more innovation ahead of us than behind us. Weâ€™ll continually challenge ourselves on whether weâ€™re delivering the best possible customer experience in the lowest possible prices. In addition to the inherent benefits of shopping online weâ€™re determined to create a unique experience for customers globally.  

Our growth in existing countries and as we expand to additional countries will continue to be driven by increased selection and new and existing categories, including more third party sellers, greater convenience, and progressively lower prices. We believe that these initiatives combined with the advantages of our model, and strong execution against our many challenges will meet the high returns on invested capital and sustainable growth in free cash flow. Customer experience comes first at Amazon.com, and we believe that that approach drives the best long-term returns for our shareholders.  

Thanks, and with that, Tim, letâ€™s move to questions.  

TIM STONE: Great, thanks, Tom. Letâ€™s move onto the q and a portion of the call with Jeff and Tom. In the interest of allowing as many people as possible to ask a question please limit yourself to one question.  

Operator, if you could remind our listeners how to ask a question, weâ€™ll proceed.  

OPERATOR: Yes, sir. (Caller Instructions.)  

Weâ€™ll take our first question from Heath Terry with CS First Boston.  

HEATH TERRY, ANALYST, CS FIRST BOSTON: Great, thanks. I was wondering if you could talk to us a little bit about, I mean it looks like this quarter we saw unit growth and revenue growth near each other a little more than weâ€™ve seen in the last few quarters. Is it fair to say that maybe weâ€™re seeing the third party business reach a little bit more of a steady state here as a percentage of revenue? And if that is or isnâ€™t the case what would you suggest we expect going forward in terms of the growth of the third party business relative to what youâ€™re doing first party?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Certainly from a third party perspective what weâ€™re trying to do is offer great selection of prices, and our customers are going to ultimately decide what that mix is going to be. You know, you should expect us to continue to add selection to the seller, as well as all of our third parties.  

As it relates to the compression question that you had specifically, what youâ€™re seeing is certainly the mix within our business of [EGM] [ph] being a higher percentage of the total during Q4 is making that compression narrower. Thatâ€™s being offset by clearly we continue to lower prices for our customers, so our prices on all of our products continue to go down, as well as with third party mix. And so our third party business is doing very, very well. Itâ€™s still growing, you know, very dramatically as you can see by the percentage of our total units.  

HEATH TERRY: And in terms of what we should expect for â€™04?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Yeah, weâ€™re not giving any, you know, specific guidance going forward on third party units, but again, ultimately our customers will decide what that mix is. But, again, we plan on offering great selection and continuing to add more selection from third parties as well as Amazon as a seller.  

HEATH TERRY: Great, thanks.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Thanks.  

OPERATOR: Weâ€™ll take our next question from Jeetil Patil with Deustche Bank Securities.  

JEETIL PATIL, ANALYST, DEUSTCHE BANK SECURITIES: Hey, guys. A couple of questions. First of all, on the capex I think you said $100m, can you clarify that? And I guess how many DCs that youâ€™re kind of planning on for this year in that number, or any new countries or markets that you may be looking at in general embedded in that assumption?  

And then, secondly, as you look at the â€“t looked like you got to about 35 percent unit growth for 2003 overall. But you know, if you look at the drivers of selection versus pricing or prices what do you think is going to be the bigger driver? It looks like itâ€™s more prices in 2004, do you think it would be a little more balanced between selection and prices, kind of this year? And, you know, would move over to pricing as being the bigger driver of the business over the next several years? Can you kind of clarify kind of where did the growth come from, which element of the business?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Thanks, Jeetil. To answer the first part of your question, yeah, we said that capex would be less than $100m in 2004. Weâ€™ve certainly challenged the team. We donâ€™t anticipate a new automated fulfillment center in the U.S. in 2004 based on the guidance that weâ€™ve given.  

As it relates to your question about â€˜which is going to have the bigger impact, selection or pricing,â€™ the reality is we donâ€™t know, weâ€™re working on both. Weâ€™re going to continue to make sure that we expand selection in all of the existing categories that we have today. Obviously, offering new categories going forward, and make sure that we have the best possible prices. And so you should expect to see lower prices in all of our categories. It will come in a number of different forms. Weâ€™ll continue to obviously get greater adoption, we think, in supersaver shipping globally, as well as just lower prices across-the-board. So you should expect more selection and lower prices going forward.  

JEETIL PATIL: Tom, are you putting any more emphasis on selection in the near term relative to pricing, or pricing relative to selection?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Yeah, we donâ€™t look at them separately. We, again, our goal is to offer the best possible prices. And so we will be lowering prices more in 2004 and will be expanding selection.  

OPERATOR: Weâ€™ll take our next question from [Mary Meeker] [ph] with Morgan Stanley.  

MARY MEEKER, ANALYST, MORGAN STANLEY: Yes, thanks, Tom. Brian and I have a couple of questions, and you may have â€“an you hear us?  

JEFFREY BEZOS, CEO, AMZN: Hey, Mary, can you hold on one sec, I just wanted to add to that previous answer.  

MARY MEEKER: Oh, yeah, go ahead.  

JEFFREY BEZOS: Just to say the two things are not linked and theyâ€™re not tradeoffs, and so there are, you know, we can proceed on lowering prices quite independently from the efforts that we undertake to increase selection. And, in fact, weâ€™ll be able to increase selection in terms of breadth of selection across new categories but also continue the efforts that weâ€™ve been making all along within existing categories continuing to increase selection.  

So I just wanted to kind of emphasize the point that Tom already made, that thereâ€™s really no tradeoff in our model between increasing selection and lowering prices. And you should expect to see us very strongly do both in the coming years.  

So, go ahead, Mary.  

MARY MEEKER: Great, thanks, Jeff. Do we get two questions here? Specifically, on the gross margin outlook, youâ€™ve kind of in the last, in the answer to Heathâ€™s question and Jeetilâ€™s question youâ€™ve talked around pricing and shipping, the tradeoff, third party, et cetera. But your gross margin in the December quarter was the lowest itâ€™s been in a long time. Should we expect, Tom, that 21.9 percent give or take 100 or so basis points on either side is kind of the range we should see on a go-forward basis?  

And then a second question would be, Tom, you talked about electronic selection rising about 40 percent, and selection rising across the site generally, do you have a number for the aggregate increase in selections either for full year â€™03 or for the fourth quarter, specifically? Thanks.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure, just taking the first part of your question, we certainly are not giving guidance on gross margin going forward. But Iâ€™ll tell you how weâ€™re certainly thinking about it internally. And which, and related back to Q4. Hereâ€™s what youâ€™re seeing. You should expect to see, you know, again, looking at it from a year-over-year perspective in any given quarter you should expect to see pressure on gross margins. And, again, thatâ€™s something that weâ€™ve been talking about for a long time because weâ€™re going to continue to invest in lower prices, weâ€™re going to continue to invest in new categories.  

And so what youâ€™re seeing in Q4 specifically is we invested very, very heavily in all of the new categories within electronics and general merchandise. You can see that, you know, clearly in our international results. We lowered prices substantially in all of our categories. We had great, an example of the U.K., we had great adoption and supersaver delivery in the U.K. in Q4. And so, again, thatâ€™s what youâ€™re seeing in terms of pressure on gross margins. We view that as a great investment in the business and a great investment, you know, that youâ€™ll see benefits from going forward.  

Combined with that what youâ€™re seeing is our model is working. Weâ€™re seeing, you know, great growth in our total business, and youâ€™re seeing operating margins expanding even though gross margins are coming down. So, again, we have for fourth quarter we had North America operating margins of 10 percent, so highest ever. Fourth quarter we also had international operating margins of just under five percent, again our best ever, you know, with significant increases year-over-year.  

So, again, pressure on gross margins driving the top line, but seeing expanding operating margins. So thatâ€™s something weâ€™ve been talking about for quite some time, and we think itâ€™s exactly what you want to see going forward.  

In terms of selection, again, we havenâ€™t disclosed our total selection increases in terms of the [indications] [ph] across all of Amazon, but again, thatâ€™s something that we focus on every day. Itâ€™s a constant focus for our business, and you know, we definitely increased selection dramatically, and youâ€™ll definitely see more of that going forward.  

MARY MEEKER: Thanks, Jeff. Thanks, Tom.  

JEFFREY BEZOS: Iâ€™ll just add to the gross margin answer. The, what youâ€™re seeing there is very consistent with our strategy in that weâ€™re making a choice to return, as we have success in the business to return some of the operating efficiencies and so on that we are getting to customers in the form of significantly lower prices, through supersaver shipping, and so on. And so these are conscious choices that weâ€™re making, and weâ€™re not trying to optimize the company for gross margins, weâ€™re trying to optimize the company for aggregate free cash flow in absolute dollar terms.  

And so, you know, weâ€™ll try to, as we know more about the elasticity and how we can drive demand with lower prices, and so on, weâ€™ll try to do the right thing with respect to margins. So, you know, but we can be quite analytical about that, and it is our, you know, we will for years, and years, and years consistently give back the gains that we get to customers in the form of lower prices. We think thatâ€™s the right way to operate this business.  

OPERATOR: Weâ€™ll take our next question from Anthony Noto with Goldman Sachs.  

ANTHONY NOTO, ANALYST, GOLDMAN SACHS: Thank you, very much, Jeff and Tom. A couple of questions. And so I was wondering what was going on with the gross profit â€“â€™m sorry, cost of goods sold dollars that are non-shipping related?  

And then, lastly, your incremental margins in the quarter were 9.8 percent, and thatâ€™s the first time we havenâ€™t seen a double-digit incremental operating margin since back in the beginning of 2002. Thanks.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Great. Just to take the first piece, if you look at the North America, basically the EGM growth that you mentioned of 22 percent. Just for looking at the total year for a second, our total year growth in EGM was 29 percent in 2003. If you look at Q4 our growth was 22 percent. If you back-out our toy and baby business that growth was actually 30 percent. And if youâ€™ll recall, we sold our toy catalog business back in Q3, and thatâ€™s a significant portion of that delta that I described. So thatâ€™s the EGM piece.  

You also asked about apparel specifically, weâ€™re actually very pleased with our apparel business. We actually had substantial unit growth during Q4 year-over-year even though we were lapping some very large promotions that we did last Q4. And so, again, weâ€™re very pleased with our performance in our apparel category.  

From a cost of goods sold you are certainly seeing a significant increase, but, again, the way weâ€™re looking at it internally is itâ€™s really around again how are we going to invest within the business to make sure we have the best, lowest possible prices, again, so youâ€™re seeing lower prices impacting gross margin. Youâ€™re seeing supersaver delivery doing that, as well, and the mix of EGM driving that, as well. And so itâ€™s difficult to isolate just the cost of goods piece, okay, without looking at the other pieces of the equation.  

And Iâ€™m sorry, the last question I think related to, you said the 9.8 percent which was really the incremental operating margin or the incremental operating leverage. If you take a look at it in pieces youâ€™ll see that the North America incremental operating margin was consistent with where its been over the previous several quarters. When you look at the international segment youâ€™ll see that itâ€™s a little bit less than that, at least on a, you know, when you compare it to the trailing 12-month basis. And thatâ€™s exactly the way I described it earlier.  

Again, weâ€™re very pleased with our international business. What we did in Q4 specifically was we invested very heavily in our electronics and general merchandise in terms of, in the form of lower prices and increased selection. EGM mix as a percentage of our total revenue international was 15 percent. If you compare that to Q4 of â€™02 it was less than seven percent. We had great success in adoption rates within the U.K. of our supersaver delivery, again, reducing that threshold back in Q3.  

So, again, all of those things contributed to the numbers that you just referred to. But, again, our international business in total weâ€™re extremely pleased with. Up, you know, we exceeded $2b in revenue for the first time, up 52 percent year-over-year excluding exchange. We had zero operating margin in 2002. We had four percent operating margin in 2003. We generated $78m worth of operating profit in our international segment. And weâ€™re going to do more of it. We announced today that weâ€™re going to lower prices even further in the U.K. by going to 30 percent off books over 10 pounds.  

So, again, if you look at the total picture for our international segment weâ€™re extremely pleased. Itâ€™s consistent with the message weâ€™ve been sending to all of our investors, and weâ€™re going to do more of the same.  

ANTHONY NOTO: Tom, you didnâ€™t mention the fourth quarter or what unit girth number, did you? I didnâ€™t catch that on the call.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure, our fourth quarter unit growth number was 33 percent.

SAFA RASHTCHY, ANALYST, PIPER JAFFREY: Good afternoon, Tom, Jeff. A question for you first, Tom. And a follow-up for you, Jeff, if I may. Thereâ€™s still increased adoption after youâ€™re online for convenience and selection, and so could you maybe talk about that a little bit, please. Thank you.  

TOM SZKUTAK: The first part of it on gross margins, you know, we certainly donâ€™t give guidance going forward. But, again, from a gross margin standpoint, again, in international you did see reductions in gross margins year-over-year. We saw expansions in operating margins also year-over-year, both Q4 and the total year.  

And so, again, thatâ€™s something when weâ€™re investing in new categories, as you can imagine with EGM being 15 percent of our total revenue, and international up from, you know, Q4 of â€™02 what was less than seven percent, you can imagine that weâ€™re being very aggressive on pricing, make sure that we have the best possible pricing. We have, you should expect that our gross margins are lower in that category, in our international business versus the rest of our international business. But, again, thatâ€™s something that we want to do to make sure that we, you know, grow that business. And so, again, you should expect to see continued pressure on gross margin and expansion in operating profit dollars.  

JEFFREY BEZOS: And in answer to the, you know, â€˜why pursue a strategy of relentlessly lowering prices year in and year out?â€™ The answer is that it is one of the important customer experience drivers. And so we know that the things that matter to customers are convenience, selection, lower prices. And that is a very stable set of desires. Those things are not going to change. Customers are always going to want those things.  

You may recall that a couple of years ago we did a one-year long test of television advertising, and very controlled tests. We did it in two markets. And we were able to measure with some significant, some statistical significance the lift of our sales in those two markets as a result of doing that television test. While there was a lift, that lift was not great enough for our business to justify that television advertising. In other words, we could demonstrate to ourselves that through things like free supersaver shipping and lower product prices that the combination of those things would actually be better for our business than spending an equivalent amount of money on television advertising.  

So, in effect, what weâ€™re doing is weâ€™ve made a deliberate decision to go down a particular path, and that path is instead of, you know, giving the money to the television networks give the money back to our customers.  

SAFA RASHTCHY: Thanks, thatâ€™s helpful.  

OPERATOR: Weâ€™ll take our next question from Lanny Baker with Smith Barney.  

LANNY BAKER, ANALYST, SMITH BARNEY: Thanks a lot. Thereâ€™s been a lot of discussion of the gross margin, and so to try to move it beyond that, you all talk about driving your business from a free cash flow maximization or optimization standpoint. And I was wondering if you could do two things? One, is there a roadmap you can provide that links the segment income to free cash flow? What portion of it, what portion of segment operating income you think the model will convert into free cash flow sustainably? I mean itâ€™s improved pretty nicely year-to-year, does it continue to improve the conversion of segment income?  

And then, secondly, maybe a simple question, but can you talk a little bit about how the levers of new categories, lower prices, free shipping, third party feed free cash flow in sort of bright line terms to kind of simplify it so that I guess you could draw more clearly the line between the levers that youâ€™re using to drive the business, and the outcome that youâ€™re trying to generate for shareholders?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. As far as the question on segments and how they trend to free cash flow, certainly over time they should trend together. Thatâ€™s what our expectation will be. We certainly donâ€™t, you know, break those out separately for you, you know, externally today. But, again, they should trend together over time.  

Iâ€™m sorry, the second part of the question, Lanny, was, again?  

LANNY BAKER: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about how your categories or lower prices, or free shipping, sort of what are the simple ways to think about how those things have impacted the sustainable free cash flow levels that youâ€™re generating? And how, you know, adding the new categories that youâ€™ve added, or lowering prices another round in Europe? What are sort of the mechanics of how that powers free cash?  

JEFFREY BEZOS: The simplest way to think about that is that the better you can make your customer experience, and lower prices are a version of better customer experience, the more customers youâ€™ll attract, the larger share of that householdâ€™s purchases you will attract, and so on and so on. So you can become a more, a bigger, you know, a bigger part of a customerâ€™s life by just simply doing a better job for them.  

Itâ€™s a very, very simple minded approach. And one that I think is, you know, the results over the last couple of years since we started taking this approach, I think to a degree speak for themselves. You know, this kind of focus on the customer experience including low prices, weâ€™d always been very customer experienced focused from the very beginning but we had focused primarily on selection and convenience. Starting a few years ago we layered on top of that this focus on low prices, as well. And those three drivers are really important to customers, and so they drive the amount of business that we do with each individual customer simply because weâ€™re doing a better job with them.  

And as that happens, you know, if you operate the business efficiently, thatâ€™s the other side, you canâ€™t, lowering prices is easy, itâ€™s being able to afford to do so thatâ€™s difficult. And so lowering prices and having that be the companyâ€™s strategy or big portion of our strategy is difficult in as much as it forces us to take on the job of being very operationally efficient, very productive, trying to do things in smarter ways, trying to reduce defects because defects are so expensive. But this is all goodness, and that is, you know, thatâ€™s really what weâ€™re trying to do is put these, we have the company on that path and weâ€™re going to stay on it.  

OPERATOR: And weâ€™ll take our last question from [Daryl Smith] [ph] with JP Morgan.  

DARYL SMITH, ANALYST, JP MORGAN: Great, first question, what do you believe is the penetration of your active user base that is taking advantage of your free shipping? And what is the longer term opportunity to convert those users who are not aware of it? TOM SZKUTAK: Certainly, we have a very, you know, our adoption rates as it relates to free shipping has been, you know, increasing over time. And what weâ€™re trying to do is try to find the right thresholds and in many cases, you know, we think we have. And so weâ€™re going to continue to test to make sure that we have the right levels, and if we think thereâ€™s an opportunity to change that, you know, weâ€™ll certainly consider doing that.  

What was the other part of your question, Daryl? Iâ€™m sorry.  

DARYL SMITH: I asked about your, you know, given that youâ€™ve anniversaried the free shipping offers in all of the quarters as you have in the Q1 through Q3 of this year what do you see is driving your growth in 2004?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Again, itâ€™s more of the same as we talked about earlier in the call. Weâ€™re going to make sure that we have the best possible prices, and so weâ€™re going to be lowering prices more during 2004, and weâ€™re going to expand selection. Thatâ€™s going to be in existing categories, as well as new categories going forward. And so thatâ€™s the plan, and you know, we think that our customers are responding nicely to that. And weâ€™re going to continue to do more of the same.

And we will continue to do both, and you know, thereâ€™s some things that we can do very efficiently and thereâ€™s some things that some of our partners can do very efficiently, and working together we can do a better job for the customers than any of us alone can do.

 Q3  2003  Amazon .com, Inc. Earnings Conference Call - Final
