   LP
OPERATOR: Good day everyone, and welcome to the Amazon.com Third Quarter Financial Results Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to the director of investor relations, Mr. Tim Stone. Please go ahead, sir.  

TIM STONE, DIRECTOR OF INVESTOR RELATIONS, AMAZON.COM: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Amazon.com Third Quarter 2003 Conference Call. Joining me on today's call will be Tom Szkutak, our CFO. Jeff Bezos, our CEO will be available for the question and answer portion of the call.  

   TD
Please keep in mind that the following discussion and responses to your questions reflect management's views as of today, October 21st, 2003 only and will include forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially. Additional information on factors that could potentially affect Amazon.com's financial results is included in today's press release and our filings with the SEC, including our annual report on form 10K for the year ended December 31, 2002 and all subsequent filings.  

As you listen to today's call, I encourage you to have our press release in front of you since all of our financial results, as well as commentary on the quarter are included and will correspond to much of the discussion that follows. During this call we will also present certain non-GAAP financial measures. In the release slides accompanying this webcast and our filings with the SEC, each of which is posted on our IR website, you will find additional disclosures regarding these non-GAAP measures, including reconciliations of these measures with comparable GAAP measures.  

Finally, unless otherwise stated, all comparisons used in this call will be against the results for the comparable period of 2002. With that, I will turn the call over to Tom.  

TOM SZKUTAK, SVP, CFO, AMAZON.COM: Thanks, Tim. Good afternoon, everyone. Today I will discuss our financial and operating results and our future expectations. This was another great quarter for Amazon.com, driven by our customers who continue to take advantage of our lower prices, free shipping and expanded selection.  

A few highlights for the quarter. Free cash flow on a trailing 12 month basis grew 100 percent to $239m, driven by improvements in operating profit. The combination of common stock outstanding and employee-based stock awards increased 1 percent to 433m shares.  

Worldwide unit growth was 36 percent, and total units served increased sequentially. Over the trailing 12 months, units grew 37 percent. Third party units representing units sold by our partners on our websites grew to 22 percent of total units.  

Revenue grew 33 percent to $1.13b, adjusting for the $29m favorable year-over-year impact from foreign exchange rates, and for the $170m impact over the trailing 12 months, revenue growth was 30 percent again this quarter and 26 percent over the trailing 12 months.  

Active customer accounts representing customers with purchases in the last 12 months increased 27 percent to 37m. North America segment revenues grew 21 percent to $709m. North America electronics and other general merchandise revenue grew 35 percent and even though Q2 included Harry Potter 5, our North American media growth rate accelerated sequentially to 15 percent.  

International segment revenues were $425m, a 61 percent increase. Adjusting for the favorable impact from foreign exchange rates compared with Q3 of 2002, international revenue growth was 50 percent.  

Consolidated segment operating expenses increased 12 percent and segment operating income was $74m, including a $1m benefit from foreign exchange rates. Consolidated segment operating margin increased over 300 basis points to 6.5 percent. Pro forma net income was $48m, or 11 cents per diluted share compared with zero cents per share.  

Our GAAP net income was $16m, or 4 cents per diluted share, compared with a net loss of $35m, or 9 cents per share. This net change was primarily the result of the following. First, a $62m increase in operating income. Second, a $12m increase in the market to market charge related to our Euro based debt. Third, a $2m gain on the sale of our toy catalog business, which in its seasonally peak fourth quarter last year had sales of $13m and a few million of contribution profit.  

Finally, on our balance sheet inventory was $242m and trailing 12 month inventory returns were 19 as we made substantial progress towards our inventory build for the holidays and took advantage of various buying opportunities from our vendors. Compared with a year ago, we took receipt of more holiday inventory including pre-release titles and expect record in-stock levels this holiday season.  

Correspondingly, AP days increased to 54 for the quarter and 47 days over the trailing 12 months. Our investment in fixed assets, which includes net capitalized software development costs declined 7 percent from a year ago to $221m while revenues grew 31 percent over the trailing 12 months.  

For the third consecutive year, we expect our reinvestment ratio, or capital expenditures divided by depreciation to be less than one. Cash and marketable securities increased to $1.6b. As a reminder, in May we paid $277m to redeem our 10 percent senior discount notes.  

Our growth continues to be fueled by a relentless focus on the primary inputs into customer experience; selection, convenience and price. I will share our recent progress for each of these.  

We've expanded selection in new categories as well as in existing countries and product categories. We've launched a sporting goods store, which has over 125 merchants offering their selection of 3,000 brands in 50 sports. We've launched the consumer electronics store in Japan.  

Many new merchants including Bombay, Cooking.com, Kitchen Etc., Lance Plus, Northern Tools, True Value and Wine Enthusiasts began offering their selection to their customers on our Amazon.com home and garden stores.  

And nearly a year after launching our apparel store, over 600,000 customers have ordered an apparel item. The number of apparel brands has more than tripled to over 1,500. There are over 100,000 unique items and the number of apparel merchants has increased fivefold to over 150, including recently Jay Jill, K Swiss and Pacific Sunwear.  

And there is more selection to come. We are currently building a number of new stores that we plan to open and promote over the next year, and will continue to add third-party sellers worldwide who will join our more than 550,000 active seller accounts, those with an order from one of our customers in the last 12 months, including over 350 branded sellers offering front line new merchandise.  

We constantly strive to make our stores more convenient for customers. For example, our cycle time, the amount of time taken by our global fulfillment centers to process a customer order, was 10 percent faster than Q3 of 2002. Customer contacts per order, one of our most important measures of satisfaction, decreased by 17 percent.  

We introduced, "Look Inside the Manual", giving our customers easy access to over 15,000 electronic product manuals, and we are working on several new features we plan to introduce to customers this holiday season.  

We continue to lower prices to create the best possible value proposition for our customers. As we said before, at Amazon.com lowering prices worldwide is not an event, it's the way we run our business. Our objective is not to discount a small number of products for a limited period of time, but to offer low prices every day and apply them broadly across our entire product range.  

Recent examples include free shipping offers around the world have saved customers tens of millions of dollars so far this year. We lowered our top hundred DVDs to 30 percent off or more, and electronics and other general merchandise we've lowered prices on thousands of products again last quarter and we are heavily promoting our newest stores with discounts off future Amazon.com purchases when customers make a purchase over $50 off sporting goods, apparel and shoes.  

In Q4 in 2004 [SI1]we'll maintain our relentless focus on finding ways to afford even lower prices, and for years to come we will continue assessing the elasticity of demand over time as we lower prices even further.  

I will conclude my portion of today's call with guidance for Q4 of 2003 and our baseline expectations for next year. Incorporated into our Q403 guidance and the 2004 expectations are the order trends that we have seen to-date and what we believe today to be appropriately conservative assumptions.  

However, we also recognize we are lapsing our prior year price reductions, particularly $25 free shipping in the U.S., and there is a high level of uncertainty surrounding fluctuation in foreign exchange rates as well as the global economy and consumer spending and the impact on both of world events.  

While we are cautiously optimistic, it is not possible to accurately predict demand and therefore our actual results could differ materially from our guidance. Let me also remind everyone that since certain stock awards are subject to variable accounting, we incur non-cash charge or gain for any movement in our share price between reporting dates, and we mark our Euro-denominated debt to market at the end of each quarter, which results in a non-cash gain or loss for any movement in the Euro between reporting dates.  

We also have exposure to the Euro related to our unhedged interest expense on this Euro-denominated debt. We cannot forecast these items, yet they could have a significant impact either positively or negatively on our results.  

For the December quarter, we expect net sales of between $1.76b and $1.91b, a growth of between 23 percent and 34 percent. Consolidated segment operating profit to be between $125m and $155. For the calendar year of 2004, our expectations are net sales of between $5.75b and $6.25b, or based on our fourth quarter guidance, growth of between 13 percent and 20 percent.  

Consolidated segment operating profit to be between $375m and $475m. While we expect to generate year-over-year growth, we also intend to continue to invest in our long-term opportunities. We expect capital expenditures, including capitalized software development costs to be less than $100m. This guidance assumes foreign currency rates stay approximately where they've been recently. We cannot predict fluctuations in the Euro, Pound, Yen, Canadian Dollar or other foreign exchange rates.  

Also when you think about growth we are concerned with long-term growth for free cash flow. That is ultimately how we will measure our success. Before opening up to questions, let me close by looking forward to the next several years.  

We will be on the leading edge of technology and innovation. We will continue investing over $200m a year in technology and content, including hiring more software engineers and computer scientists next year, because we believe there is a lot more innovation ahead of us than behind us.  

In addition to the inherent benefits of shopping online, we are creating unique customer experience for customers globally. We are determined to offer both world-class customer experience and the lowest possible prices. We will focus on further improving our customer experience, continually challenging ourselves on whether we are delivering the best possible customer experience worldwide.  

Our growth in existing countries, and as we expand to additional countries, will continue to be driven by increase selection in new and existing categories, including more third-party sellers, greater convenience and progressively lower prices.  

We believe that these initiatives, combined with the advantages of our model and strong execution against our many challenges will lead to high returns on invested capital and sustainable growth and free cash flow.  

Finally, customer experience comes first at Amazon.com and we believe that that approach drives the best long-term results for our shareholders. Thanks, and with that Tim, let's move to questions.  

TIM STONE: Great. Thanks, Tom. Let's move onto the Q&A portion of the call with Jeff and Tom. In the interest of allowing as many people as possible to ask a question, please limit yourself to one question. Operator, if you could remind our listeners how to ask a question we will proceed.  

OPERATOR: Thank you. (Operator instructions) Our first question today is from Lanny Baker from Solomon Smith Barney.  

LANNY BAKER, ANALYST, SOLOMON SMITH BARNEY: Thanks a lot. You know, Tom, after making something, 250 basis points of improvement in your consolidated segment operating margins over the last 12 months, it looks like the guidance from here to next year is not much improvement in profitability, maybe up to 100 basis points more if I am doing the math right. What is the change, what changes between the last year and the next year that would shift the profitability improvement?  

In addition to that, I was wondering if you could talk about, you know, over the last year the free shipping seems to really have helped unit volume and stimulated revenue growth. Can you talk about the velocity of your pricing on merchandise in the next 12 months given that in the last 12 months you benefited from free shipping on top of the list price reductions that you were making. Should we think that the list prices come down faster, or they come down at the same rate over the next 12 months as you cycle now past the free shipping benefit?  

TOM SZKUTAK: In terms of the first part of your question related to the expectations for 2004, it is obviously very difficult to get visibility out that far and so we think that certainly the guidance is appropriately conservative. We think we are focused on the right inputs to drive growth, to get cost out. We are going to continue, obviously, to make sure that we continue to add selection, have great pricing.  

So again, I think the guidance is appropriate but again, it is appropriately conservative given the time that is out there.  

In terms of the second part of your question, if you could just repeat that, I am not sure I understood the question as it related to pricing.  

LANNY BAKER: Well I guess in the last year you had the twin drivers from a volume perspective; price reductions on merchandise and also free shipping. Now going forward, free shipping sort of incrementally wouldn't be as much of a stimulant to unit volume.  

I was wondering whether you then turn back and spin the dial a little bit more aggressively on pricing to drive unit volume, or not.  

JEFF BEZOS, PRESIDENT, CEO AND CHAIRMAN OF THE BOARD, AMAZON.COM: I'll take a pass at that. This is Jeff, and Tom can add to it if he likes. I think the most important thing to keep in mind is that when you do something like free supersaver shipping, it actually takes multiple years for a customer base the size of ours to really internalize that and to change their behavior.  

So even though we have rolled over the anniversary of free supersaver shipping, it's not like we've gotten the full benefit from that. In fact, we think that it will take a long time for all of our customers to realize that particular feature of the way we do business and to fully take advantage of it.  

TOM SZKUTAK: I think just to add to that also, we are continually lowering prices. As I mentioned in the script, in electronics and general merchandise we lowered prices on over 1,000 different items. We did a similar thing last quarter.  

Also, you know, outside of the U.S. we are continually focusing on lowering prices as well. We lowered the threshold in the U.K. for the supersaver delivery to 25 pounds three months ago, and again you are seeing that reflected in the Q3 results.  

So again, it's a continuous focus and I absolutely agree with Jeff - it certainly takes a long time for customers to see it and realize that.  

LANNY BAKER: Okay, thanks.  

JEFF BEZOS: Lowering prices will go on for years and years and years. I mean, that is just the way we are going to do business. What we are doing is trying to focus on cost structure and be as lean as we can so we can continue to pass on those savings to customers, and we'll figure out significant ways to do that over the coming years.  

OPERATOR: We will go next to Mary Meeker from Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead.  

MARY MEEKER, ANALYST, MORGAN STANLEY: Thanks. A couple of questions. You indicated that third party sales were 22 percent of units in the quarter, that momentum continues to build. Jeff, I think in the past you've thrown out some numbers that were very early stage estimates that you might get up to a third of your units coming from third-party sales. If I am misquoting you, I apologize and stand to be corrected shortly. But where do you think that may go given that you've gotten more insight into how that builds?  

The second question is, you are clearly embracing a lot of the retailers, the momentum seems to be pretty strong, can you give us some thoughts on how confident you are and they are that that is going to be a key driver of an ongoing ramp in the third party sales as the net in effect is back with strong momentum and those companies are finding that you are really providing a valuable service to them, if that's the case?  

JEFF BEZOS: Mary, on the first part, we don't take a position on what fraction of our unit sales will be third party versus our own owned-inventory business. For the simple reason that what we try to do is provide the best possible customer experience in both of those buckets, and then let customers decide over time what that ratio should be.  

It's hard to know what the right - I'm not sure there is any right ratio, and so we are not targeting any specific ratio. With respect to the third party business in general, we continue to see as you can tell from the unit numbers, very strong adoption. We are driving a lot of demand for third party sellers. We have a very good e-commerce platform which the new Amazon Services unit is basically making available for any e-commerce company that wants to have a best-of-breed e-commerce website for its customers.  

So there is genuine value there for both consumers and for the third parties, and we are just going to keep our heads down, focused on trying to drive that value more every year.  

TIM STONE: Great, thanks Mary. Operator, next question.  

OPERATOR: We have a question from Heath Terry from CSFB. Please go ahead.  

HEATH TERRY, ANALYST, CS FIRST BOSTON: Great. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about, we saw gross margins in the international business come down this quarter, and I understand new free shipping and that kind of thing. Is there anything beyond the free shipping promotion that we should be thinking about in terms of margins in the international business, and is there any reason that over time we shouldn't expect that the international segment can get to the same kinds of margins that the U.S. segment is seeing now?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. In terms of Q3 specifically, the free shipping is one aspect. We've also dramatically lowered prices in parts of our international segment. The third aspect is, we have a very heavy consumer electronics and general merchandise mix as you can see from our results, so those are the three drivers for the lower margins during Q3. But again, we are very optimistic, we've made a lot of progress in our international segment and we think over time that that will certainly grow over time from an operating margin standpoint. And again, we've made a lot of progress there.  

HEATH TERRY: Thanks.  

OPERATOR: We have a question from Anthony Noto from Goldman Sachs.  

ANTHONY NOTO, ANALYST, GOLDMAN SACHS: Thank you very much. Looking at the quarter, Tom, it looks like operating expenses on a year-over-year basis grew for the first time double digits, as far back as I can remember. I was wondering, especially in the context of your comment about continuing to invest in technology, will you continue to make incremental investments at a double digit year over year growth rate in 2004? Especially given it looks like you are sort of guiding to a 7 percent operating margin at the midpoint of your range.  

And then secondly, if I look at the growth rate in revenue on a year-over-year basis, relative to unit growth on a quarterly basis, the delta or gap between the two has started to converge. As we think about 2004 revenue growth of 16 percent, would unit growth be greater or less than that growth rate? Thanks.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure, to answer the first part of your question, operating expenses were up 12 percent, and again, it is the first time we've seen double digit. I think the two things that you should be aware of is certainly as our third party business continues to grow, there is an element of that, credit card bad debt, obviously that grows more on a GMS basis as opposed to a net revenue basis.  

The other part that's impacting this also within our expenses is certainly foreign currency. So again, if you back out the two of those for the quarter you get down to a much smaller single digit growth relative to a 30 percent revenue growth, excluding exchange rate.  

So again, revenue is growing about 30 percent ex-exchange; operating expenses are growing a small single digit number when you back out credit card bad debt in both periods and the effect of foreign exchange.  

So again, what is that going to look like going forward? We are still going to continue to invest heavily in technology and content. We think that is obviously the right thing to do and we are going to invest heavily on everything surrounding our inputs that help us drive growth within our business.  

So we are not specifying any specific absolute value. We haven't disclosed any of that yet. Again, what you will see is you will see productivity over time. You will see our expense to revenue over the long term continue to decline.  

And the second part of your question, related to again units and revenue? Could you repeat that part again?  

ANTHONY NOTO: Yes, the mid-point of your guidance range I think is about 16 percent, correct me if I'm wrong. I was just wondering, is that based on a unit growth rate that is greater than or less than the growth rate implied by absolute revenue of 16 percent?  

TOM SZKUTAK: It's hard to say at this point. We're obviously not giving guidance today surrounding units, and again it is difficult to say what our competitor is going to do in this environment in 2004. So it is difficult to say.  

ANTHONY NOTO: Thank you.  

OPERATOR: Our next question is from Jeetil Patel of Deutsche Bank Securities. Please go ahead.  

JEETIL PATEL, ANALYST, DEUTSCHE BANK SECURITIES: Hey guys, a couple of questions. You have 37m active customers today. Kind of by our estimates you have maybe total, that have transacted with Amazon about 65m to 70m. I know you've talked about just in general about free shipping having not really hit the entire customer base.  

What do you think as you look at the next 30m to 35m customers that you can go after, what really drives them to cross the chasm and transact with Amazon and become happy customers? Are there different demographics that this customer is, or is it more of a pricing issue, diversity of retail partners, what do you think are the key elements to drive your penetration of that audience?  

And then secondly, as you look at the third party business, can you comment on how integration is going and interest level from partners both on the retail front as well as the vendor community out there? Do you see any particular trends within those particular segments of the market?  

JEFF BEZOS: I'll take a pass at this. As far as you know, sort of the next tens of millions of customers and what will drive their adopting our service, I believe it is many of the same things we've been working on for the last eight years.  

One of them that I think is particularly relevant to this particular question is selection. So as we continue to expand selection, we become relevant to a wider set of customers. So there are a lot of people who buy media products, but there are people who don't buy a lot of media products.  

So we need to continue expanding into new product categories and increasing the depth of selection in the categories we are already in. That's one of the ways that we will make ourselves more relevant to a wider group.  

At the same time, focusing on lower cost structure and therefore being able to return lower prices to customers, continue on that strategy, that's going to be equally important as we go forward. So those are the two big drivers. Increasing selection across categories and driving even lower prices. So you can count on us to keep working on both of those things just as hard as we can.  

With respect to integration, we have several different ways that third parties can integrate with us. Some of them are very lightweight, some of them are for a more sophisticated solution, larger integration costs, heavier weight solutions that give better control and better customer experience. So these third parties can choose depending on their level of sophistication, the size of the partner and so on.  

What we're doing is we are working to always enhance our toolset so that even the higher end integration efforts can be done with less friction. You can count on us to continue to work on that too.  

OPERATOR: Our next question is from GeraldSmith of J.P. Morgan.  

GERALDSMITH, ANALYST, J.P. MORGAN: We've seen your third party contribution to total unit sales increase dramatically, they are now comprising roughly 22 percent of worldwide unit sales. As a follow up to Mary Meeker's question, can you comment on the long-term target for mix between internally fulfilled products and your third party sales and the potential impact to your projected sales growth, given that while you generate higher margins on these sales, you're recognizing the sales on a net basis.  

JEFF BEZOS: We really don't have a particular target level for what that mix should be. Our point of view on that is that we should simply try to make both of those offerings the very, very best they can be for consumers, and then let customers decide what that mix should be.  

GERALDSMITH: And secondly, if you look at your domestic gross margins, they increase roughly 1 percent. Is that primarily driven by your third party sales? Finally, do you see the potential for your electronics and other categories seeing profitability by Q403, is that really a realistic objective still, and where do you stand there?  

JEFF BEZOS: North American margins, the increase in North American margins were driven by our strong media growth, our North American media was up 15 percent, which is certainly very strong compared to previous quarters, and that was driven by two things. Again, it was both our retail business, meaning Amazon as a seller, and third party. So we had great growth in both aspects and that is really what drove the operating margin growth within North America.  

In terms of your question around electronics and general merchandise, that's not really the way we look at our business. We look at our segments certainly our North American segment and international segment, we look at individual products within there but we don't really focus on individual categories. Again, we're trying to improve the profitability and the cash flow of all of our individual products that we offer.  

GERALDSMITH: Thank you.  

OPERATOR: We will take a question from Shawn Milne from SoundView.  

SHAWN MILNE, ANALYST, SOUNDVIEW TECHNOLOGY CORP.: Thank you very much. Just a quick question on rolling out new categories. Jeff, I wondered if you could talk a little about the experience now that you've got the sporting goods category up and running, and how it looks relative to the launch of apparel last year. Any learnings from the company, anything you can take forward to new categories? Thanks.  

JEFF BEZOS: It's certainly too early to report back on sporting goods. The basic learning is that we are trying to focus on having the right set of merchant partners so that we have a complete selection for customers and attractive prices for customers. One of the things that is very interesting about sporting goods in particular is that in the physical world, a sporting goods store that has breadth of selection, sort of a superstore concept, tends to have very shallow selection in any particular category. So that if you get into fly fishing or archery or badminton you don't have very good selection.  

So what we are trying to do is build a sporting goods store that has that breadth, but within each category has the depth that you might find in a specialist enthusiast store. So we are very excited about the customer experience that we think is possible in sporting goods at Amazon.com, but it's too early to report back on that.  

SHAWN MILNE: And just a quick follow-up on geographical growth. There's been some pretty positive data points coming out of Japan in terms of online growth. Can you give us an update there, and maybe dovetail that in with an overall Asian strategy in the next couple of years? Thanks, Jeff.  

JEFF BEZOS: I can't give you numbers on, specific numbers, on Japan since we don't break it out that way. I can tell you that we are very pleased with the Japanese business and the way that is going. That team is doing a great job. They are serving our Japanese customers at an extraordinarily high level and the business is growing very nicely. I really can't go beyond that.  

As for what we might do in the future in terms of new geographies, that is also something that we would like to continue with our practice of not preempting those kinds of things.  

SHAWN MILNE: Thank you.  

OPERATOR: We will take our final question today from Mark Rowen of Prudential. Please go ahead.  

MARK ROWEN, ANALYST, PRUDENTIAL EQUITY GROUP, INC.: Thank you. A couple of quick questions. Tom, number 1, on North American media the acceleration to 15 percent, could you be a little bit more specific about what caused that growth? Was it a specific product category? Books, music, movies, video games.  

And, can you give us a sense of how much of that was same-store sales versus taking over new stores for other companies?  

Related to that, international media products seemed to slow fairly significantly this quarter, even with the benefit of currency. Could you give us a sense of what is going on there?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. As it relates to the North American media, what is driving that is a lot of the things we've been talking about. It's again, lower prices, free shipping. We just had great growth again from Amazon as a seller and third parties. Again, our growth was 15 percent, it's the strongest growth we've had in North American media in several quarters and so again, you can see the acceleration there.  

In terms of international media growth, one thing that you are seeing there is clearly, particularly in the U.K. we've lowered prices and with the supersaver delivery certainly you are seeing the impact of that in the top line, so again we've aggressively lowered prices during the quarter as well as supersaver delivery, we are giving more to customers. That is showing up in the top line and the bottom line. We certainly think it's the right thing to do, but again, that's what you are seeing there.  

MARK ROWEN: Okay. And then finally, since third party is so important to you, I wonder if you could give us gross merchandise sales and revenue from third party sales?  

JEFF BEZOS: No, we haven't disclosed that, Mark, and we don't think it's appropriate to do so at this time.  

MARK ROWEN: Okay. Thanks very much.  

TIM STONE: Thanks, Mark. With that I want to thank everyone for joining us on our call today. As a reminder, a replay will be available on our investor relations website at least through the end of the quarter. We look forward to talking to you again next quarter, and thanks for your interest in Amazon.com.  

OPERATOR: That does conclude today's conference call. We appreciate your participation. You may now disconnect. [SI1]He did say 2004, I think he meant 2003

 Q2  2003  Amazon .com, Inc. Earnings Conference Call - Final

   LP
OPERATOR: Good afternoon. My name is Matthew and I will be your conference facilitator today. At this time I would like to welcome everyone to Amazon.com's second quarter 2003 financial results conference call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise. After the speakers' remarks, there will be a question and answer period. If you would like to ask a question during this time simply press star, then the number 1 on your telephone keypad. If you would like to withdraw your question, press the pound key. Thank you. I would like to now turn the call over to Mr. Tim Stone, director of investor relations. Mr. Stone, you may begin.  

   TD
TIM STONE, DIRECTOR INVESTOR RELATIONS, AMAZON.COM: Thank you. Good afternoon and welcome to the Amazon.com second quarter 2003 conference call. Joining me on today's call will be Tom Szkutak, our CFO. Additionally, Jeff Bezos, our CEO, will be available for the question and answer portion of the call. Please keep in mind that the following discussion and the responses to your questions reflect management's views as of today, July 22, 2003 only and will include forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially. Additional information about factors that could potentially affect Amazon.com's financial results is included in today's press release and our filings with the SEC, including our annual report on form 10K for the year ended December 31, 2002 and all subsequent filings.  

As you listen to today's call, I encourage you to have our press release in front of you since all of our financial results, as well as commentary on the quarter are included and will correspond to much of the discussion that follows. During this call, we will also present certain non-GAAP financial measures. In the release and slides accompanying this webcast and our filings with the SEC, each of which is posted on our IR website, you will find additional disclosures regarding these non-GAAP measures, including reconciliations of these measures with the comparable GAAP measures.  

Additionally, unless otherwise stated, all comparisons used in this call will be against our results for the comparable period of 2002. With that introduction, I will turn the call over to Tom.  

TOM SZKUTAK, SVP AND CFO, AMAZON.COM: Thanks, Tim. Good afternoon, everyone. Today I will discuss our financial and operating results and our outlook for Q3 in the remainder of the year. This was another great quarter for Amazon.com, as our customers continued to take advantage of our low prices and free shipping offers.  

First, a few highlights for the quarter. Free cash flow on a trailing 12 month basis was $245m. The combination of common stock outstanding and employee stock-based awards increased 1 percent to 433m shares. Worldwide unit growth accelerated to 42 percent, providing meaningful benefit to our bottom line results.  

Third party units as a percentage of total units were 20 percent for the quarter, an increase from 14 percent. Units served excludes products sold by our partners on their websites. Revenues driven by free shipping offers and lower prices grew to a non-holiday quarter record of $1.1b, representing growth of 37 percent. Adjusting for the $55m favorable year-over-year impact from foreign exchange rates, revenue growth accelerated to 30 percent.  

Our North America segment revenues grew 20 percent to $703m, our North American electronics and other general merchandise growth rate increased to 36 percent and our media category revenue grew 14 percent.  

International segment revenues were $397m, an 81 percent increase. Adjusting for the favorable impact of foreign exchange rates, international revenue growth accelerated to 57 percent.  

Active customer accounts, those with purchases in the last 12 months, totalled $35m worldwide, a 27 percent increase. Consolidated segment operating income, which is consistent with pro forma operating income was $67m or 6 percent of sales, including a $3m benefit from foreign exchange rates. Our operating leverage was 14 percent, representing year-over-year incremental segment operating profit divided by incremental revenue.  

Pro forma net income, which includes interest expense, was $42m, or 10 cents per diluted share, compared to a loss of a penny per diluted share a year ago. Our GAAP net loss improved by $50m to $43m, or 11 cents per share, compared with a net loss of $94m, or 25 cents per share. The improvement was largely the result of a $40m increase in GAAP operating income.  

Three primary factors contributed to the remaining $10m net improvement in our GAAP net loss. First, the market-to-market related to our Euro-based debt was $33m lower. We had a $38m charge in the current quarter, compared with a $71m charge in the prior year.  

Second, in connection with our May 28th early redemption of our 10 percent senior discount notes, we incurred a $15m charge, consisting of a $13m redemption premium and $2m of unamortized debt issuance costs.  

Third, we incurred a $6m non-cash charge to terminate our swap agreement that hedged the foreign exchange rate risk on a portion of our Euro-based debt.  

Moving to our balance sheet, inventory was $178m at June 30, 2003, up from $127m and trailing 12 month inventory trends were 20, up from 19. We encourage you to compare these metrics to other world-class retailers.  

Our investment of fixed assets declined 11 percent from a year ago to $222m, while revenue units have grown substantially. This is difficult for a normal retailer to do, but we have the advantage of trading real estate for technology.  

Cash and marketable securities at the end of June increased $165m to $989m after paying $277m to redeem our 10 percent senior discount notes this quarter.  

Now I will discuss our operating results in more detail. Our primary long-term goal has been and continues to be to drive sustainable and significant amount of free cash flow. On a trailing 12 month basis, free cash flow reached $245m, an improvement of over $225m, driven by improvements in operating cash flow.  

When thinking about cash flows, let me remind you that operating cash flows and free cash flows can be volatile and are sensitive to many factors, including changes in working capital. Working capital at any specific point in time is subject to many variables including world events, seasonality, the timing of expense payments, discounts offered by vendors, and vendor payment terms. You should expect that we may take advantage of offers from vendors when it's the right economic trade, such as discounts offered by vendors in exchange for early payment, but over time, fluctuations in working capital will even out.  

For example, our second quarter 2003 trailing 12-month operating cash flow and free cash flow were positively impacted by approximately $20m because, as reported last year, a credit card service provider unintentionally failed to make a scheduled quarter-end payment to us until the third quarter of 2002.  

And in the second quarter of 2003, we purchased and received customer payment for over $1.4m units of Harry Potter 5, for which payment was generally not due to our vendors until after second quarter of 2003.  

Trailing 12 month unit growth was up 38 percent, while consolidated segment operating expenses increased only 5 percent, resulting in an increase of over 350 basis points and consolidated segment operating margin.  

Every part of the company contributed to these results. In Japan, for example, which we opened two-and-a-half years ago, our sales have grown to the point where over the trailing 12 months we achieved a small operating profit. Our growth is being fuelled by the relentless focus on the primary inputs into customer experience; selection, convenience and price. I will briefly touch on each aspect.  

We continue to expand selection inside of existing countries and product categories. We launch consumer electronics in Japan earlier this month. We introduced kitchen and home stores in the U.K. and Germany. We launched software and video game stores in Canada. [Rico Camera] is offering their selection in the Amazon.com camera and photo store, and we expanded to over 1,000 brands in our apparel and accessory stores, more than double the more than 450 brands that launched last November.  

And there is more to come. We are currently building a number of new stores that we plan to open and promote later this year, and we expect to continue to add third party sellers to our worldwide websites who will join our more than 500,000 active seller accounts, those with orders from our customers in the last 12 months.  

We constantly strive to make the stores more convenient for our customers. One feature that we offer is pre-orders, through which customers can place their orders at their convenience in advance of the product's release. They rely on Amazon.com to deliver their items as soon as they are available.  

The most notable example this quarter was our delivery of Harry Potter 5 pre-orders. I would like to personally thank our retail, operations and customer service teams who worked with our suppliers and shipping partners to deliver on the commitments to customers around the world. Also, as a customer and father, my daughter and I would like to thank you for your great service. Operational highlights of our Harry Potter 5 delivery compared with Harry Potter 4 in July 2000 include the following.  

We delivered 1.4m copies worldwide, compared with over 400,000 three years ago. We shipped to over 175 countries, from Antarctica to Zimbabwe; we shipped to over 175 countries. U.K. distribution centres' peak through-put day was higher than their peak day in Q4 2002. We utilized specially designed boxes in the U.S., which were over two-thirds less expensive than the packaging we used for Harry Potter 4. Our automated U.S. packaging system was eight times more productive than the manual process we used three years ago.  

Our shipping costs were greatly reduced, partly due to our ability to use postal injection for over 50 percent of the books, a capability we didn't have in 2000. We've also offered Harry Potter 5 at an average discount from list price of over 40 percent worldwide since it became available for pre-order in January. On the product price alone, customers saved over $18m off list price in the quarter.  

Customers could elect guaranteed delivery on the Saturday, June 21st release date, at the standard delivery shipping rate. We are pleased we were able to provide Harry Potter 5 to customers worldwide at roughly our overall cost. It was essentially a contribution profit break even event which negatively impacted gross margin and operating margin, although from a long-term investment perspective it was an effective new customer acquisition vehicle with over 250,000 new customer accounts trusting Amazon.com for the first time.  

We continue to relentlessly lower prices to create the best value proposition for our customers. Let me be clear. At Amazon.com, lowering prices worldwide is not an event, it is the way we run our business. Our pricing objective is not to discount a small number of products for a limited period of time, but to offer low prices every day and apply them broadly across our entire product range.  

Recently, for example, in addition to product price savings on Harry Potter 5 and electronics and other general merchandise, we lowered prices on thousands of products last quarter. Free shipping offers around the world again saved customers tens of millions of dollars this quarter, which we consider a marketing investment even though it is captured as part of gross profit, and today we lowered our U.K. free super saver delivery order side to L25 from L39.  

Remember too that we offer 30 percent off books over $15, whereas many book superstores only discount their top sellers. And even on top sellers in our January comparison of product-only prices with a major well known U.S. chain of book superstores, our prices were 23 percent lower than their store prices on their published list of 100 bestsellers for 2002. I encourage you to compare these prices for yourselves with your favourite physical world bookstore and tell your friends, because it takes a long time to educate tens of millions of people about anything, even that they are not spending wisely.  

As we've said before, you certainly may find reasons to shop in the physical world - for instance, if you need something immediately, but please realize you will be paying more. We believe our ability to lower prices and expand selection while simultaneously improving customer experience globally is a unique opportunity and this past quarter offers further evidence that the strategy is working and that customers are starting to realize they will save a significant amount of money and time when they shop at Amazon.com.  

The combination of continuous improvement in customer experience, ever expanding selection, the great value proposition to our customers which includes low prices, great convenience and free shipping; our eagerness to share our prime product detail pages with third parties; and the foundations of our model which leverages technology versus real estate will enable future growth and allow us to generate significant amounts of free cash flow over time.  

I will conclude my portion of today's call with guidance for Q3 and an update to our baseline expectations for the year. Incorporated into Q3 guidance and full year expectations are the order trends that we've seen to date and what we believe today to be appropriately conservative assumptions. However, we also recognize we are lapsing our prior year price reduction, particularly free shipping, and there is a high level of uncertainty surround fluctuations in foreign exchange rates, the global economy, consumer spending and the impact on both of world events. While we are cautiously optimistic, it is not possible to accurately predict demand and therefore our actual results could differ materially from our guidance.  

Also, when we think about growth we are concerned with the long-term growth in free cash flow. That is ultimately how we will measure our success. For the September quarter we expect net sales of between $1.075b and $1.15b, or growth between 26 percent and 35 percent year over year. We expect our consolidated segment operating profit to be between $55m and $70m. For calendar 2003, our expectations are, net sales are expected to be between $4.9b and $5.1b, or to grow between 25 percent and 30 percent. We expect consolidated segment operating profit to be between $300m and $340m and over 150 basis points improvement in operating margin year over year. We expect a reinvestment ratio, or capital expenditures divided by depreciation, to be less than one. This guidance assumes foreign currency rates to stay approximately where they have been recently. We cannot predict fluctuations in the Euro, Pound, Yen or Canadian Dollar.  

Also remember that since last year we have significantly improved our free shipping offers worldwide. For example, in the back half of Q3 2002 we lowered the U.S. free super saver shipping threshold from $49 to $25. Let me also remind everyone that since certain stock awards are subject to variable accounting, which are not cash, charge or gain for any movement in our share price between reporting dates, and we mark our Euro denominated debt to March at the end of each quarter, which results in a non-cash gain or loss for any movement in the Euro between reporting dates.  

We also have exposure to the Euro related to our unhedged interest expense on this euro denominated debt. Therefore, we cannot forecast these items yet they could have a significant impact, either positively or negatively on our results.  

Looking forward for the next several years, we will focus on further improving our customer experience, continually challenging ourselves on whether we are delivering the best possible customer experience. We will be on the leading edge of technology and innovation. We've been investing over $200m a year in technology and content and still think there is a lot more innovation in our next eight years than in the eight years since Amazon.com opened in July of 1995. Our growth in existing countries, and as we expand to additional countries, will continually be driven by increased selection in new and existing categories, including more third party sellers, greater convenience, and lower prices.  

Beyond the customer benefit of all of these, our technology and fixed infrastructure and other operating costs will also continue to scale, declining as a percentage of revenue while growing in absolute dollars.  

We will continue to drive further productivity internally, and lower per unit costs of what we call deflation with our external suppliers. We believe these initiatives, combined with the advantages of our model will lead to high returns on investment capital and sustainable growth and free cash flow.  

Before opening up to questions, let me close with a final, two brief thoughts. First, in addition to the inherent benefits of shopping online, we are creating a unique experience for our global customers. We are determined to offer world-leading customer experiences and the lowest possible prices.  

Finally, customer experience comes first at Amazon.com and we believe that that approach drives the best long term returns for our shareholders. Thanks, and with that, Tim, let's move to questions.  

TIM STONE: Great. Thanks, Tom. Let's move onto the Q&A portion of the call with Jeff and Tom. In the interest of allowing as many people as possible to ask a question, please limit yourself to one question. Operator, if you can remind our listeners how to ask a question, we will proceed.  

OPERATOR: (Operator instructions) Your first question comes from [Jeetil Patel] with Deutsche Bank Securities.  

JEETIL PATEL, ANALYST, DEUTSCHE BANK SECURITIES: Great quarter, guys. A couple of questions. Free shipping continues to pay off in boosting unit volumes for active customers, and it still seems like you are seeing a double digit increase in units per active customer. Do you think that is sustainable? Is that something we should look for in the second half of this year?  

And secondly, can you talk about I guess free shipping in the U.K. is continuing and coming down in terms of the hurdle rate, it seems like you have revved even faster internationally in general relative to the U.S. business. How should we think about the ROI as it relates to free shipping internationally, and particularly in the U.K. and maybe other markets as you do it there, relative to the U.S.  

Finally, I guess, third party development. Can you talk about how it may be different in the international markets versus the U.S. markets? How it is developing, kind of ramping up in general?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Just a broad answer on free shipping. First of all, as we've disclosed before, very expensive, but we think certainly our customers like it and we are seeing some very, very positive results. It certainly takes a lot of time to educate customers both on free shipping and on the price decreases that we've had over time. So again, those things it is difficult to say looking forward how long that will continue, but again we think it really takes a long time to educate customers.  

As far as the U.K., we are certainly very pleased to be able to announce that we are lowering our threshold to L25 today. That is really a result from the success we've had globally. So again, you should expect that it is something that is certainly a significant investment for us but we think it is the right thing to do, and it has helped us to accelerate growth.  

As far as the third party, if you can just clarify the third party question again?  

JEETIL PATEL: Yes, can you talk about how it's developing internationally in Germany and U.K. relative to the U.S. market in the trend's interesting or different relative to the domestic ramp-up that we saw over the past couple years?  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. It's really early to be able to compare the two regions, but we are very pleased with the progress. We certainly have a long way to go, but we're very pleased with the progress we've seen to date globally.  

TIM STONE: Great. Thanks [indiscernible]. Next question, Operator.  

OPERATOR: Your next question is from [Anthony Noto] with Goldman Sachs.  

ANTHONY NOTO, ANALYST, GOLDMAN SACHS: Thank you very much. First question is on international. As I look at the profitability in absolute dollars of the international segment, it looks like you had about $12.6 million in operating profit in the second quarter versus 15.8 in the first. Sequentially your revenue from Q1 to Q2 actually increased $19m. Now four million of that sequentially is from inter-currency benefit from what I can tell. And I just wonder if you could talk about the profitability change internationally, especially since Japan was [inaudible] quarter, net of the currency changes.  

And then secondly, your unit growth continues to accelerate and you benefit from the price reduction and free shipping. And if I go back in time and compare your gross profit growth to your revenue growth on a year-over-year basis, it looks like in the fourth quarter of 2002 was the first time in several quarters, since you started doing marketplace and free shipping and price reductions, that your revenue growth actually grew faster year-over-year than your gross profit growth, which indicates to me that that was the first time that the benefits from the promotional lower pricing strategy actually drove faster unit growth than the reduction in revenue per transaction based on the mix shift. And now we've seen that for three quarters in a row. Do you [inaudible] continue as the benefit in light of the fact of the price promotion and low pricing strategy kicks in and becomes more broadly known because that seems like it's an inflection point that's sustainable now.  

And then lastly on free cash flow -- why can't it be more than $320m this year and what do you plan on using with the cash? Thanks.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. First, to answer your question, Anthony, on international margins, just a little bit of background -- we're very please with the progress we've made in international. This is the first time on a [inaudible] month basis we exceeded a billion and a half on sales on a trailing 12-month basis. Our operating margins on a trailing 12-month basis are approximately three percent or $49m versus a year ago -- it was minus three percent, minus $29m. Again, on a trailing 12-month basis we've made significant progress.  

In the quarter -- again, we've seen substantial growth year-over-year -- operating profit up three percent. We talked about the revenue growth up 81 percent -- adjusted for FX it's up 57 percent. That compares to last year from an operating profit in a standpoint of flat basically. Again, we're very pleased with the progress and our segment operating profit as well.  

When you look sequentially from first quarter to second quarter, you obviously have to take into consideration we had Harry Potter V. We also introduced new shipping offers in the first quarter as well that's impacting that sequentially has it's had in other markets as we've done that. But again, in generally with our international segment, we're very, very pleased.  

In terms of unit growth -- your question on unit growth, if you could just repeat that again or at least a portion of that again, it'd be great.  

ANTHONY NOTO: Yes. Sorry about that. It's a long question. Essentially, as you lowered prices and gave free shipping, you saw a decline in your revenue per transaction. It was very hard to see your real underlying revenue growth, and one way to actually detect that was looking at gross profit growth. And it wasn't until the fourth quarter of 2002 that your revenue growth year-over-year actually grew faster than your gross profit growth after that transition started, which means your unit growth actually started to grow fast enough to off-set the declining revenue per transaction from the mix shift and the type of revenue you reported and it's now stayed that way for three consecutive quarters. And I'm just trying to understand if that's something that's now [inaudible] changed and stabilized and that your unit growth will continue to be faster than the decline in revenue per transaction on the mix shift from the marketplace business relative to the regular retail business.  

TOM SZKUTAK: It's a very good question. It certainly -- there's so many different factors that are driving each of our individual quarters. It's really [inaudible] as you could probably appreciate to pinpoint any specific item, if that makes sense.  

In terms of your question on the free cash flow -- we certainly haven't given guidance for the total year. We're certainly pleased with the performance we've seen, in a trailing 12-month basis, as I've mentioned. It was also helped by Harry Potter, as I talked about. It was also helped by the $20m unusual that I also referred to in the script. Again, I think -- again, we're very, very pleased. We're continually focused on are the inputs that drive pro [inaudible] and costs out and combined with our model, we think that we'll be able to generate significant cash flow over time. But again, you should expect it to be a little bit choppy from quarter to quarter, as it has been. And again, as you can see this quarter, it's also choppy. We're pleased with the performance. It is, again, a little bit choppy.  

TIM STONE: Great. Thanks, Anthony. Operator, next question.  

OPERATOR: Your next question is from [Mary Meeker] with Morgan Stanley.  

MARY MEEKER, ANALYST, MORGAN STANLEY: Thanks. Brian and I just have a couple questions also about unit growth. It looks like the 42 percent unit growth in the June quarter was the faster rate of unit growth you've had since we've been tracking it. I think it was about 39 percent year-to-year in the third quarter of '02. And one of the things that we're trying to figure out -- and this kind of ties in with Anthony's question, is you've given revenue guidance and operating income guidance for calendar '03. Could you give us a sense of what your unit growth assumptions might be and also, there's obviously a correlation with the increase in the third party mix as a percent of total revenue, to give us a sense of unit growth forecasts for '03 and also third-party mix that would be great. I know it's a hard thing to do, but any qualified statements there would be great. Thanks.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Thanks, Mary. We really have not provided in the past unit growth guidance. And it is very difficult to forecast. Our customers will decide also the mix as we go forward. You can see the trends over the last several quarters that [inaudible] that I think are helpful. But as we continue to grow and add new selection each quarter -- and again we're adding new selection each quarter, we're working on a number of new categories right now that we'll be launching between now and the end of the year. Again, all those factors, as well as what our customers want, are going to dictate that. It's extremely difficult to do that.  

MARY MEEKER: Well, Tom, could you maybe give us a sense for the June quarter what the largest needle mover. Could you maybe give us a sense, Tom, or Tim for the June quarter, what the [inaudible] mover was, if you will, in driving up unit growth? Was it apparel? Was it pre-owned stuff? Was it just basic marketplace stuff? Where there [inaudible] that were especially strong? Was it Harry Potter?  

TOM SZKUTAK: We've certainly -- we've disclosed the Harry Potter numbers. Harry Potter was 1.4 million units for the quarter. But beyond that, it was really, Mary, more of the same, more of the same -- more of the things we've been talking about over the last several quarters. It was the lower pricing, free shipping. We continued to add great selection. All those things contributed and really helped drive unit growth. It's really the total focus on customer experience.  

MARY MEEKER: Thanks, guys.  

[indiscernible]  

JEFFREY P. BEZOS, PRESIDENT, CEO AND CHAIRMAN, AMAZON.COM: If we look at what are the things -- knowing everything we know now, one of the things we wish we had done earlier is put in place this testing program that we did on free shipping and figuring out what the right level to do that is. And what you see us doing today in the U.K., for example, is an attempt to get ahead of that curve and do that very rapidly. That certainly continues to be a driver of the unit growth you see, when combined with the very, very sharp pricing that our team has put in place. It's the combination of the free shipping with the low product prices and you can expect to see us continue to work very hard on that. And, of course, it wasn't just the will to do it, which we had to figure out how to do and how to structure it and so on, but it was also the ability to afford it -- to be able to have the cost structure that economically supported this level of free shipping and this level of low prices. But when you can do that, customers respond to it. And that's really what you're seeing in terms of driving the unit growth. You can do the math on Harry Potter V and see that it's a very small percentage of what's going on. We're very fortunate there are no single products which account for a big percentage of our revenues. I think that's a big driver.  

And then there will be other things having to do with the other aspects of customer experience over time that will continue to drive these kind of results we hope. I mean that's what we're trying to do and it's lower prices. It's increased selection. It's things having to do with different tools on the Web sites -- make it easier for people to find what they're looking for. Every single aspect that we know that customers care about we're determined to improve those things [inaudible] year in and year out. And one of the pleasant things in this quarter that we're all happy about is the acceleration in our electronics and general merchandise or the kitchen tools and so on. That category is doing very well. And we think part of what's going on there is -- it takes time to educate customers about new offerings. But you reach -- at a certain point you reach a kind of a critical mass where it starts to build on itself, and whether we're there yet or not for electronics, we won't be able to tell you until afterwards. So we don't really know for sure. But we certainly like the progress that we see in those new categories, too.  

MARY MEEKER: Great. Thanks a lot.  

TIM STONE: Thank you, Mary. Operator, next question. And if you could remind everyone as well to limit your questions to one.  

OPERATOR: Your next question is from [Mark Rowen] with Prudential.  

MARK ROWEN, ANALYST, PRUDENTIAL: Thank you. Could you give us a sense of how much cross benefit you got from Harry Potter? In other words, how many people came to the site to order that book and then ordered other things that were related to that book? And then, if I assume about a million of those 1.4 million were in the U.S., it looks like your U.S. media business grew at about nine percent. Is that about the right number and would you expect single digit growth in that segment for the rest of the year? Thank you.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Mark, to answer your first question on cross shopping -- there's certainly -- we did have attachments to those orders, and we're hoping, obviously, going forward with the new customers or customer accounts that participated that they'll reorder again. Again, we haven't disclosed what those particular numbers are related to cross shopping, but again, it was a -- we're very pleased with the results of Harry Potter V in general.  

In terms of the units, we did release, during the month of June, what the pre-orders were related to Harry Potter V. We haven't released anything since in terms of the split by geography and we're planning to do that on this call. But again, if you take a look at North America in general, we're very pleased with the performance of North American media. It was up 14 percent. Our unit growth was up substantially higher than 14 percent during the quarter. Again, we're very pleased with that performance. We continue to take share from off-line retailers and again, we're pleased with the progress we've made there.  

TIM STONE: Well, good. Thanks very much, Mark. Next question, Operator.  

OPERATOR: Your next question is for -- is from [Safa Rashtchy] with Piper Jaffray.  

SAFA RASHTCHY, ANALYST, PIPER JAFFRAY: Hi, guys. Congratulations on a great quarter. If I can, I'd like to just step back a little bit and just look at the broader e-commerce market and get your thoughts, Jeff, in particular, but also, Tom, on how you see that growth affecting yours. What we have been seeing is suddenly not accelerating growth [inaudible] from some accounts -- possibly decelerating growth and yet your -- increasing growth rate. I guess the conclusion would be your taking market share or expanding in categories. Can you maybe, at the top level, talk about how you see your growth compared to the market? And also, in terms of the operating margin expansion, how much of that 14 percent incremental operating margin that you're seeing can be sustained towards your long-term goal and possibly increasing that goal and how much is third-party contributing to that? Thank you.  

JEFFREY P. BEZOS: Well, our opinion on the kind of the e-commerce landscape, as a whole, is that it is still very, very early days. I still believe very strongly that this is a landscape that is going to create lots of winners. I think there are going to be lots of companies that do very well in e-commerce. I think that we are -- what's driving our results is very, very clear. It is improvements in customer experience -- the things I was speaking of earlier in terms of lower prices, better selection, faster delivery times and so on and so on. You can just go right down the line. But this is -- I still believe that over ten plus years that this will grow to be 10 to 15 percent of retail. And so we have the good fortune, along with other folks who operate in e-commerce, of operating in what is basically a market size, unconstrained opportunity. I mean hopefully, at some point, it would be -- hopefully, at some point, we'll be market size constrained, but that's a long way away because these are big numbers and this is still very, very, very early days.  

TIM STONE: Great. Thanks very much, Satha. Operator, next question please.  

OPERATOR: Your next question is from [Laney Baker] with Smith Barney.  

BILL MORRISON, ANALYST, SMITH BARNEY: Hi. It's actually Bill Morrison for Laney. Congratulations. I've just got a question about your revenue guidance. If I take your third quarter and full year -- kind of the mid-point of your third quarter and full year guidance, I'm getting to an implied revenue growth in the fourth quarter of around 18 percent off of 28 percent this -- in the third quarter -- 36 percent this quarter. Just wondering why you didn't maybe raise your full year guidance. Just seems a little bit light and whether there's a reason for that or something we're missing. Thanks.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Well, we actually did raise our total year guidance and we raised our second half guidance as a result of this call. We're certainly cautiously optimistic for the second half of the year. That being said, we're also overlapping some of the shipping offers from last year. We went to -- in late August of last year, we went from $49.00 down to 25 in Amazon.com. So we had that for the rest of the quarter. Certainly visibility to the end of the year can be difficult based on that. Currency -- certainly, we expect that currency is going to be positive for the second half of the year -- tens of millions of dollars included in guidance for that. But there certainly uncertainty around that as well. Again, while we're cautiously optimistic, we're working on, we think the right things. We think that the guidance is appropriately conservative and right for our business.  

BILL MORRISON: Great. Thanks a lot.  

OPERATOR: Your next question is from [Heath Terry] with Credit Suisse First Boston.  

HEATH TERRY, ANALYST, CREDIT SUISSE FIRST BOSTON: Great. I was wondering if you could just kind of talk generally about the competitive environment and how that's changed as you -- over the last quarter or so -- obviously, the news about AOL maybe -- and I realize it's kind of shady as to what exactly the plan is there. But as you see -- how do you see the competitive environment changing, clearly, especially as you partner with some of the companies that might be competitors down the road.  

JEFFREY P. BEZOS: I think that the -- we have a long-standing practice of not speaking about particular other companies and we'll certainly continue that practice. The fact is that, in this particular arena, the competitive environment has always been an intense one and I think -- I would not forecast a change there.  

HEATH TERRY: Okay. Thanks.  

TIM STONE: Okay. Thanks. Operator, let's make this our last question, please.  

OPERATOR: Okay. Your final question then comes from [Shawn Milne] of [indiscernible].  

SHAWN MILNE, ANALYST: Thanks a lot. Tom, I just wanted to follow up on the operating leverage comment. If you look in the quarter, you talked about 14 percent operating leverage, but you suggested that Harry Potter was a breakeven event on about -- I did the math -- about 25 million in sales. If we backed that out, operating leverage would have been, give or take 15, 16 percent. Your guidance for Q3, if I use the midpoint, is only 14 percent. Is there some incremental spending in Q3 or is that conservatism? Thanks.  

TOM SZKUTAK: Well, certainly as we look at operating leverage, we're trying to balance -- we're continually trying to recruit new software development engineers focused on improving the customer experience. So certainly going forward we expect to be doing that in the second half of the year and beyond. I'm not going to comment specifically what we think operating leverage will do, but, obviously, we had mentioned that we're working on a number of new stores. That certainly will impact the second half operating leverage as we open those new stores. Certainly you should expect that that will be a drag. And so those are some of the key points that you should think about as you look at our second half guidance.  

SHAWN MILNE: Thank you.  

TIM STONE: Real good. Well thank you for joining us on this afternoon's call. As a reminder, a replay will be available on our investor relations Web site at least through the end of the quarter. We look forward to talking to you again next quarter. Thanks for your interest in Amazon.com.  

JEFFREY P. BEZOS: Thank you.  

OPERATOR: This concludes Amazon.com's Second Quarter 2003 Financial Results Conference Call. Thank you for your participation. You may now disconnect.
