   LP
 OPERATOR: Good afternoon, my name is Amy and I will be your conference facilitator. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Amazon.com financial conference call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent background noise. After the speakers remarks there will be a question-and-answer period. If you would like to ask a question during this time press star and the number one on the telephone keypad. If you would like to withdraw, your question, press star and the number 2. Thank you. Now I will turn the conference over to Tim Halladay, VP of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir. 

 TIM HALLADAY, VICE PRESIDENT OF INVESTOR RELATIONS, AMAZON.COM, INC.: Good afternoon and welcome to the Amazon.com first quarter 2003 conference call. Joining me on today's call will be Tom Szkutak, Jeff Bezos, our CEO will be available for the Q&A portion of the call. 

   TD
 Please keep in mind that the following discussion and responses to your questions as of today April 24, 2003 only and will include forward-looking statements. Our actual results may differ materially from those projected. Additional information about factors that could potentially affect Amazon.com financial result is included in today's press release and the Company's filings of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Includes in the Annual Report on the form 10-K for the year ended December 31st, 2002 and all subsequent filings. 

 As you listen to today's call I encourage you to have the press release in front of you, since all financial results and as well as commentaries for the quarter are included and will correspond to much of the discussion that follows. During this call, we will also present certain non-GAAP financial measures in the release which is posted on the Investor Relations website at Amazon.com you will find reconciliations of these measures with GAAP. Pro forma and other non-GAAP results are included for the benefit of the investors. Unless otherwise stated all comparisons used in this call will be against our results from the comparable period of 2002. 

 With that introduction I will turn the call over to Tom. 

 TOM SZKUTAK, CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER, AMAZON.COM, INC.: Thanks Tim. Good afternoon, everyone. This was a great quarter for Amazon.com as our customers took advantage of lower prices and free shipping offers. I would like to talk about four things today. First a few highlights of the quarter, second a execution of our model, third our financial results in greater detail and fourth our outlook for Q2 and the remainder of 2003. 

 First, a few highlights for the quarter. Driven by lower prices in the success of our free shipping offers, revenues reached a non-holiday record of $48 million, representing growth of 28% year over year. Adjusting for the year over year revenue growth for the quarter was 22%. World wide units even faster at 35%, providing meaningful benefit to our bottom line results. Our North American segment revenues grew 13% to $705 million with unit growth of 28%. International segment revenues were $379 million, a 68% year over year increase, on unit growth of 52%. Consolidating segment operating profit, which is consistent with the past measure of pro forma operating profit was $67 million or 6.2% of sales including a $4 million benefit from foreign exchange rate. Pro forma net income which includes interest expense was $40 million, which is 10 per share compared to a loss of a penny a share a year ago. Active customer accounts, those with purchases in the last 12 months sold 33 million, a 26% year over year increase. Third party units, as a percentage of units served, were 19% for the quarter, an increase from 13% one year ago. Free cash flow on a 12 month basis was $123 million, a year over year improvement in excess of $100 million. The combination of common stock outstanding and employee stock based awards decreased 1% year over year. 

 Second, I'd like to spend a minute how Amazon.com is unique relative to other retailers. A concept Jeff discussed recently in his annual letter to shareholders. In many ways, Amazon.com is not a normal store. We have deep selection that is unconstrained by shelf space. We turn our inventory twenty times in a year. We personalize the store for each and every customer. We trade real state for technology, which gets cheaper and more capable every year. We display customer reviews critical of our products. You can make a purchase with a few seconds and one click. We put used products next to new ones, so you can choose. We share our prime real estate product detailed pages with third parties and if they can offer better value, we let them. 

 One of our most exciting differences is poorly understood. People see we are determined to offer leading experience in the low possible prices. Traditional stores face a time tested trade off between offering high touch customer experience on the one hand and the lowest possible prices on the other. How can Amazon.com be trying to do both? The answer is that we transform much of the customer experience such as unmatched selection, extensive product information, personalized recommendations and other new software features into largely a fixed expense. With customer experience cost largely fixed, more like a publishing model than retail, our costs as a percentage of sales can shrink rapidly as we grow our business. More over, customer experience costs remain variable, such as the variable portion of fulfillment costs, improve in our model as we reduce defects. Eliminating defects improves our cost position and leads to better customer experience. 

 We believe our ability to lower cost and simultaneously drive customer service is a big deal and this past quarter offers evidence that the strategy is working. While delivering 35% more units to customers, we delivered our best ever experience. Cycle time, the amount of time taken by our North American fulfillment centers to process an order improved 7% compared to last year. In one of our most important measures of customer satisfaction, contact per order saw a 12% improvement worldwide. 

 Inside existing product categories and countries we worked hard to increase selection. Electronic selection is up over 26% in the U.S. alone over the prior year and we now offer over ten times the selection of typical big box electronic store. Even in U.S. books where we've been working for eight years, we increased selection by 12%, mostly in harder to find and out of print titles. Outside the U.S., selection from U.K., Germany, French and Canadian sites has increased in excess of 50% year over year and of course, we've added new categories. Our accessory store has 500 top clothing brands and earlier this month, we launched Home and Kitchen in the U.K. and Germany. In Q1 we added tens of thousands of third party sellers, that made their products available at Amazon.com. And on this year's American Customer Satisfaction Index, the most authoritative study on customer satisfaction, Amazon.com scored an 88, the highest score ever reported not just online, not just in retailing but the highest score ever recorded in any service industry. While focused on customer experience, we've also lowered prices substantially over the last several years. We have done so broadly across product categories, from books to electronics and we've eliminated shipping fees with year round free super saver shipping with orders over $25. We've also been taking similar actions in every country in which we do business. Our pricing objective is not to discount a small number of books for a limited period of time, but to offer low prices every day and apply them broadly across our entire product range. To illustrate this point, we did a price comparison back in January versus a major well-known chain of book superstores. For purposes of the comparison, we used their published list of 100 best sellers for 2002 and determined that purchasing those books at Amazon.com verses their stores resulted in savings for the customer of 23%. To be sure you may find reasons to shop in the physical world. For instance, if you need something immediately but please realize you'll be paying a premium. If you want to save money and time, you'll do better by shopping at Amazon.com. 

 What does this mean to shareholders? The combination of continuous experience in customer experience, ever expanding selection, the great value proposition to our customers, which includes low prices, great convenience and free shipping, our willingness to share prime real estate with third parties and foundation of our model which leverages technology versus real estate will allow us to generate returns on investment capital and significant amounts of free cash flow over time. 

 Let's move on to the third topic, a detailed look at quarterly results. Net sales this quarter increased 28% while consolidated segment operating expenses increased only 2% year over year. There wasn't any individual group within the company that drove results, instead it was every part of the company. Fulfillment as a percentage of revenue was in the single digits for the first time at a non-holiday quarter at 9.6%, a greater than 100 basis point improvement from a year ago. Marketing costs declined in absolute dollars by 12% while we increased funding to the most efficient marketing channel. Remember also, our biggest expenditure for the year is our investment in free shipping which captures part of gross profit. Technology and content costs decline 10% in absolute dollars year over year. Although we benefited from reduced cost of hardware and tele cost capacity, our engineers are doing a terrific job of innovating and driving efficiencies in development of our website and the software that runs our backend systems. Partially off setting these savings, we have been aggressively continuing to invest in software development engineers to improve our customer experience. G&A was less than 2% of revenue in the quarter, a decline of over 50 basis points. The result was a 2% or $5 million increase in segment operating expenses but a decline as a percentage of revenue of more than 450 basis points. Consolidated segment operating profit improved $43 million to $67 million reaching an operating margin for the quarter of 6.2%. Our net loss for the quarter was $10 million or 3 cents per share compared to a net loss of $23 million or 6 cents per share in the prior year. 

 For the quarter there were three key differences year over year. First, we incurred a stock based compensation charge of $27 million in Q1 2003, primarily due to a $21 million charge for the upward movement of our stock price compared to an $11 million charge in 2002. Second, we had a $22 million net charge in the current quarter, primarily related to the mark to market debt compared to a $6 million benefit in the prior year. Third, we had a $10 million restructuring charge last year with no corresponding charge in the current year. In total these items negatively impacted GAAP results in the current quarter by $49 million compared to $15 million in the prior year. First quarter pro forma net income was $40 million or 10 cents per share compared to a loss of a penny a share a year ago. Free cash flow on a trailing 12 month basis reached $123 million, an improvement of $110 million year over year. When thinking about operating and free cash flow, let me remind you that predicting elements of working capital at a specific point in time can be volatile and subject to many variables including world events, seasonality, the timing of accrued expenses, and discounts offered by vendors in exchange for early payment. You should expect that we may take advantage of offers from vendors when its the right economic trade but overtime fluctuations of working capital will even out. Our primary long-term goal has been and continues to be to drive sustainable and significant amounts of free cash flow. Ultimately we will measure our success by the progress we make toward our objective of generating significant free cash flow. 

 Let me move to asset efficiency. Inventory was $173 million at March 31, 2003 up from $139 million a year ago. Inventory turns were 20 on a trailing 12 month basis, a improvement of 13% year over year. We encourage you to compare this metric to other world class retailers. Our investment success has declined 11 percent from a year ago to $228 million and continues to scale as revenues grew 28% and units grew 35%. This is difficult for a normal retailer to do, but we have the advantage of trading real estate for technology. We ended the quarter with cash and marketable securities of $1.08 million or more than $335 million above a year ago. Today we announced we will use some of this cash in the second quarter to redeem our 10% senior discount notes which are not due until 2008. The redemption price is $270 million which includes a $13 million or 5% premium over the principle amount of the note. The premium will result in a charge to our second quarter GAAP results. This early redemption will have an insignificant impact of Q2 free cash flow but favorable impact on all future years through 2008. 

 I will conclude my portion of today's call with guidance to Q2 and an update to our baseline expectations for 2003. Looking forward over the next several years, we'll continue to have growth driven by increasing selection within existing categories, category and country expansion, the addition of third party sellers and lower prices. Beyond the customer benefit of all these, our technology and fixed infrastructure will also continue to decline as a percentage of revenue. We'll continue to drive further productivity internally at a lower per unit cost or what we call "deflation" with our external suppliers. We believe that growth and cost initiatives that we have in place will lead to sustainable growth in free cash flow. 

 For 2003 incorporated into our Q2 guidance and for your expectations are the order trends we've seen to date in what we believe today to be appropriately conservative assumptions. However, we also recognize there's a high level of uncertainty surrounding the global economy, consumer spending and the impact of world events. While we are cautiously optimistic, it is not possible to accurately predict demand and therefore, actual results could differ materially from our guidance. Also when thinking about growth we are concerned with only one thing, long-term growth and free cash flow. For the June quarter we expect sales to be between $1 billion and $1.05 billion, our growth of between 24-30%. As you would expect this measures foreign currency rates to be approximately where they are today, we cannot predict currency fluctuations going forward. We expect our consolidated segment operating profit to be between $45 million and $60 million. When comparing this with a year ago, please remember that this guidance incorporates $25 free super saver shipping for the entire quarter versus $99 for the majority of the prior year. For calendar year 2003, our baseline expectations are net sales are expected to be $4.7 billion or more to grow over 19%. We expect consolidated segment operating profit to be $275 million or more. 

 Let me remind everyone, since certain stock options are subject to variable accounting, we incur non-cash gains for movement between reporting dates. Also we mark our debt to market at the end of each quarter. The result will be a non-cash gain or loss. Therefore we cannot forecast either of these items, yet they could have a significant impact either positively or negatively on GAAP results. 

 Before opening up to questions, let me close with a final few thoughts. First and for most we have the opportunity to create the unique experience of our customers. We thank our customers for taking advantage of our selection, convenience and low pricing and the experience will only continue to get better. Second, our model is validating itself as we reach the benefit of scale. While we continue to invest in low prices and unit growth, we will work hard both internally, to increase productivity, and externally with our suppliers. Ultimately we will measure our success by the progress we make towards the objective of generating free cash flow. Finally all of us at Amazon.com have the same objective, we are collectively driven to deliver for both our customers and shareholders. We strive to always put the customer experience first, we believe that approach provides the best results for our shareholders. Thanks, and with that Tim, let's move to questions. 

 TIM HALLADAY: Thanks, Tom. With that we'll move on to the Q&A portion of the call with Jeff and Tom. In the interest of allowing as many as possible to ask a question, we ask that you limit yourself to one question. Operator, if you could remind our listeners how to ask their questions, we'll proceed with the call. 

 OPERATOR: At this time if you would like to ask a question, press star then the number 1 on the telephone keypad. We'll pause for just a moment to compile the Q&A roster. Your first question comes from Anthony Noto with Goldman Sachs. 

 ANTHONY NOTO, ANALYST, GOLDMAN SACHS: Thank you and good afternoon. In looking through the detailed analysis of your gross margins, it appears your international gross margin are about 22%, and domestic about 27 if I got that right. I was wondering what drivers do you think could move the international gross margin to 27% from 22 which would have a meaningful impact and how do you see that progressing over time. 

 Secondly you talked about launching new categories, when will we hear about those as we approach the summer time period and preholiday season. And lastly, Tom, just one book keeping thing, you did about $68 million in operating income the first quarter. Midpoint through your second quarter guidance $52 million. Given the seasonality is flat through the third, sort of implies 100 million in fourth, do you plan on spending a lot in the fourth quarter? Thanks. 

 TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. Thanks for the questions. The first question on gross margin, the way we look at it in the international segment, as you can appreciate we had super saver shipping and many free shipping offers in many countries since our existence. As we continue to get scale in those countries, we think we'll get better prices with our suppliers. That will evolve over time. We obviously look at gross margins but we're even more concerned about our operating margins and if you look at our international business, we made considerable progress there. Our operating margins as a percentage of sales last year first quarter were negative 5% and percentage of sales this quarter were plus 4% as a percentage of revenue. We look at gross margins, more concerned with segment operating profit and, again we think we'll see continuous improvement over time. 

 JEFFREY BEZOS, CHAIRMAN, PRESIDENT, CEO, AMAZON.COM, INC.: I'll add to that on the international side, we still do a lot of purchasing through wholesalers and other kinds of distribution. As our volumes in those countries increase, we'll be able to continue to do a lot of volume through distribution but have a larger fraction of our volume be direct purchases and that has a very positive impact on gross margins over the long-term. 

 ANTHONY NOTO: Sounds like the gross margin changes internationally will follow a similar path to the U.S. with direct purchasing and other sort of [INAUDIBLE]. 

 JEFFREY BEZOS: It should follow similar trend, whether it will be the same levels or not in the long-term is still too early to know. They should go in that same direction. And then with respect to new product categories, we will be launching new product categories. I don't want to change our long standing practice of not preannouncing what we're going to be doing or exactly when. So you'll have to stay tuned with us there. We were hard at work on that right now and have been for some time. 

 TOM SZKUTAK: The last question surrounding Q2 and the rest of the year in terms of guidance, a question more on the total year of Q2 incident. 

 ANTHONY NOTO: I'm sorry, you basically guided to $275 million for the year. 

 TOM SZKUTAK: Yeah. 

 ANTHONY NOTO: Back out the first quarter and the implied midpoint in the second quarter and the assumption third quarter is sequentially is similar, that means fourth quarter is going to be flat to a year ago which seems a heck of a lot of upside or you're spending somewhere what we don't know about. 

 TOM SZKUTAK: Yeah, certainly uncertainty as we look out for the rest of the year. Guidance for top line was $4.7 billion in revenue or greater. As well as segment operating profits of $275 million or greater. Again, we think based on what we're seeing to date, our Q2 guidance is appropriate. Again, we think there's uncertainty out there, we're not, you know again, that's why we put the guidance in place. We think it's the right place for us to be. 

 ANTHONY NOTO: Thanks, very much. 

 OPERATOR: Your next question comes from Darryl Smith with J.P. Morgan. 

 DARRYL SMITH, ANALYST, J.P. MORGAN: Good afternoon. Quick question. It seems you have to walk a fine line from the retail business and market place revenues. Given your need to drive values over the distribution network, with what can you do to ensure that marketplace does not cannibalize your traditional retail business and how big of a concern is that for you? 

 JEFFREY BEZOS: What we've found when we've looked at this is that customers who buy in the marketplace offerings actually has a positive impact on new purchases as well. We don't, it's always hard to know for sure, we don't see any reason to be worried about cannibalization. We think what it does, what the market business does is improve significantly the customer experience. And so you get more of the customer wallet share and so on. 

 DARRYL SMITH: Second question is, can you talk about the marketing plans in terms of television, internet and free advertising [ INAUDIBLE ] decreasing year over year? 

 JEFFREY BEZOS: Our best marketing dollars although they're not captured in the marketing line are when we return dollars to customers in the foremost, super saver shipping, aggressive low product prices you see us offering, you saw us start this two years ago, aggressively discounting books 50% or more, 30% off. Very sharp pricing in the electronics store starting a year ago, we are doing more and more of that. Free super saver shipping, the $25 threshold started late August so there have been -- even though they are not capturing the marketing line, we consider that to be very effective use of the dollars. Then we continue to do a lot of very effective marketing in measurable ways online, for example, with our associates program where we buy ad placements from third parties online. 

 DARRYL SMITH: Great. Thanks. 

 TIM HALLADAY: Operator can we take the next question please. 

 OPERATOR: Next question comes from Shawn Milne of Soundview Technology. 

 SHAWN MILNE, ANALYST, SOUNDVIEW TECHNOLOGY: Thanks a lot, and congratulations on a good quarter. Tom, just a couple of quick questions. Can you talk about sequential pattern at all for the quarter? Did you see any impact from the war at the end of March, wouldn't appear so given the good solid guidance but I wonder if you could add color to that and follow up on, if you could talk a little bit about operating productivity and your goals for driving that over the next several quarters. You have exceptional growth in terms of the percent of operating income in the first quarter, how much can you continue to squeeze out of costs, technology costs, et cetera. 

 TOM SZKUTAK: Your first question related to the war, we saw softness in the last weeks in the first quarter and we saw that recover quite nicely in the first few weeks of April and that reflected in the Q2 guidance. As it relates to productivity, you know, it's difficult to talk to absolute numbers going forward. I think the way you should look at it is this. We are spending a lot of time internally on it. We are focused our concepts in two ways. One is how do we make sure we get great internal productivities, doing things more efficiently every day, the second is how do we get better prices or what we call "deflation" with our suppliers. Looking at it in a details level across the business and trying to drive prices down for all the goods and services we buy. 

 JEFFREY BEZOS: I will say that we are already very, very focused on this before Tom arrived here and since Tom got here, we've been able to reaccelerate that effort. I think it's going very, very well. 

 SHAWN MILNE: Great, thank you very much. 

 TIM HALLADAY: Operator, can we take the next question, please? 

 OPERATOR: Next question from Mary Meeker from Morgan Stanley.

 TIM HALLADAY: Mary, before you hang up, I want to make sure we got your questions, it was tough to hear you. The essential question was we had 35% unit growth for three quarters in a row? The second question was quantifying something that was leveraging, a question that we couldn't hear you. 

 MARY MEEKER: The question was could you help us quantify what the benefit might be for better terms one year out. 

 TIM HALLADAY: Terms? 

 MARY MEEKER: Better terms with suppliers.

 JEFFREY BEZOS: We're very positive about our opportunity for growth, and obviously we had great unit growth in the first quarter. That made up of as we mentioned North American was up 28%, international up 52%, we are very positive about our business as it related to growth. The second part, it's probably hard to quantify, yeah. A year out exactly how much progress we'll make. It has a lot to do with how quickly, there's a lot of operational issues involved. As you get to the volume required to make sense to do a portion of your volume directly with manufacturers and publishers as opposed to going through distribution, we're at the volume levels where more and more of that makes sense. We are doing some of it. But it's not something that comes in and kind of step functions, it comes in a little bit at a time. It will be continuous, I guess that's where I would leave it. 

 TOM SZKUTAK: Thanks, Mary. 

 JEFFREY BEZOS: On the growth rates I would add that the things we are doing to drive growth are the right things. So because of that, we are very optimistic. We'll have to wait and see what happens. Customers are responding to the relentless focus of adding selection, continuing lower prices and will be more price reductions this year. We will continue to do that. So increasing selection, reducing prices, increasing reliability, speed of fulfillment, making products easier to find, making the website easier to use, you'll see improvement in every single one of those buckets this year and that is what drives unit growth. 

 TIM HALLADAY: Thanks, Mary. Operator, next question please. 

 OPERATOR: The next question is from Heath Terry of CSFB. 

 HEATH TERRY, ANALYST, CSFB: Looking at the shipping loss of $7 million in the quarter, looks like that was around 2.5% of revenue. How much leverage do you have there to bring that down further? Can we assume that's going to be a relatively stable percentage going forward? 

 TOM SZKUTAK: I think you should look at it is actually the adoption rate of super saver shipping as we've had different offers over the past 18 months, we've had more and more customers are adopting that. We've seen as we look at the last five quarters, every single quarter of that has increased in terms of number of customers liking it. It's difficult for us to predict actually going forward, whether that trend will continue. Obviously we be leaving the super saver shipping offer in place year round. It's difficult for us to estimate that but it's going well and customers like it. 

 JEFFREY BEZOS: It's not going away any time soon, in fact, it's not going away ever. We like it, the customers like it. Its 365 days a year. Please take advantage of it soon. 

 HEATH TERRY: Thank you. 

 TIM HALLADAY: Operator, next question, please. 

 OPERATOR: Next question comes from Jeetil Patel with Deutsche Banc Securities. 

 JEETIL PATEL, ANALYST, DEUTSCHE BANC: A couple of questions, based on the free shipping initiative, you're getting to the point where kind of a number of units you are getting per active customer getting to the point where you are starting to get more frequency. At the same time if you look at contribution for customers, that's turning around as well. Are you starting to see the ROI feedback from free shipping innative from a dollar standpoint and happening at profit line, can you elaborate whether that is happening or not? Second question was as you look at new categories and new markets over the next couple of years, can you give us a sense what the Cap Ex looks like and what is required to get into a new category dollar wise, time wise and a new market, something we could try to model going forward as you launch new markets and categories. 

 TOM SZKUTAK: Right. On super saver shipping, the way I would look at it is this, no question about a change of behavior. Customers like it. The units going out as a percentage of total is increasing in terms of adoption rates. Certainly in first quarter as well as in 2003, you should assume that it's a cost to us. You will not see a full return from that investment in 2003, that's the way we're looking at it. We do expect that over time, we'll get a significant return from investment. The cost in both first quarter and the total year. 

 As far as Cap Ex, the way we are looking at it from a reinvestment ratio, Cap Ex as a percentage of depreciation that will be, our Cap Ex will be less than one when you look at that ratio. In 2004 Jeff challenged the team to do that again. Beyond that it's difficult to forecast. Certainly you won't see the large spikes that you've seen historically just because of the way we've invested in technology and discussions. 

 JEETIL PATEL: Can you talk about what expenses or costs are required to launch a new category? 

 JEFFREY BEZOS: I was going to add that launching a new category is very, very capital inexpensive for us. That is not one of the constraints. The main thing that constrains new category launches is more -- the people bandwidth of organizing the category, building the supply chain for that category, any software developments that has to be done for that and so on. It tends not to be -- these are not heavy lifting capital exercises to get a new category launched, quite the opposite. In fact, we've said before that in terms of even fulfillment centers, that's pretty capital efficient, too. We built our original fulfillment centers on the order of $50 million each and that is, we know a lot more now than we did then on how to do that and we can do that for significantly less. 

 TIM HALLADAY: Thanks Jeetil. Operator, can we take the next question, please. 

 OPERATOR: Next question comes from Jeff Fieler with Bear Stearns. 

 JEFF FIELER, ANALYST, BEAR STEARNS: One of the big changes from this quarter [INAUDIBLE] 20% year over year in Q4, can you give us a breakdown where that is coming from? And also on the from the cash flow line, trailing 12 month free cash flow looks like it's down from Q4 levels and curious what we should read into that. Is that a function of lower account payable days and are the lower account payable days part of discounts for early payments you were talking about, Tom? 

 TOM SZKUTAK: Sure. The first part of that with electronics general merchandise, there's no question we've seen accelerated growth in that segment and both in the U.S. and globally. In the U.S. it's 32% growth year over year. Globally up 37% year over year. We are pleased with the segment. We look at it at a much more detailed level and a skew level as we look at our growth. Again I think that's difficult to communicate to you on this call. 

 In terms of free cash flow. Certainly seasonality in our cash flow. You shouldn't read anything into that. Certainly our payable is down from a year ago. At 44 days versus 45. What we did see with some of the slowdown in the last two weeks of the quarter, that certainly impacted our operating cycle just temporarily for those few weeks. We've seen our orders come back in the first few weeks so it's not, we're not looking at it as a significant trend or anything like that and obviously focused on growing free cash flow over the course of the year and next year. 

 JEFFREY BEZOS: I would only add that if you look at our electronics business, the thing from a customer experience point of view driving that acceleration is compared to a year ago, significantly lower prices as well as very good relative to a year ago instock availability. Those are the two big customer experience changes year over year driving that business. 

 JEFF FIELER: Driving through profitability? 

 JEFFREY BEZOS: Yes, the increased contribution profits in that business need to be aggregated across more units. The key thing in that business is unit growth. 

 JEFF FIELER: Thanks, very much. 

 TIM HALLADAY: Operator, can we make this our last question, please? 

 OPERATOR: Yes, sir. The final question comes from Steve Weinstein of Pacific Crest. 

 STEVE WEINSTEIN, ANALYST, PACIFIC CREST: Thank you. Follow-up to the last question. And, two, looking from a currency neutral basis, significant acceleration on a year over year basis. My guess is we'll start to see that rate slow, the rate of acceleration slow. Can you give us a more detailed outlook? 

 JEFFREY BEZOS: I'll take the first piece of that and then Tom can take the last piece. Electronics and general merchandise business, huge year over year progress and that, our electronics store, for example now does have good availability on what is about ten times the selection you would find in a big box electronic super store. People really are more and more finding what they are looking for and finding when they do price comparisons that we have the lowest price. So price and availability very, very good. Still a tremendous amount of room. Still a lot of selection that can be improved in that business. And we'll keep working on that. 

 Whether you can anticipate that these growth rates will continue forward or not, I wouldn't want to speak to that specifically, we consciously don't give guidance on that level of detail. But that's certainly, we're going to be working hard to make the customer experience better and if the past is a guide to the future, every time we improve the customer experience along one of those critical available, we see unit growth rates increase. 

 TOM SZKUTAK: As far as the international segment, unit growth was up 52% year over year, revenue growth was up 68% year over year. And you're right, we did have favorable impact of exchange to bring that down to 45% year over year. The only thing I would say on that is certainly the last two weeks of the quarter was softer, you know globally for us and including the international segment, that has come back well in the first few weeks of April. Again no question there was some effect but difficult to quantify how much. 

 STEVE WEINSTEIN: Thank you.

 JEFFREY BEZOS: Thank you. 

 OPERATOR: Thank you for participating in today's Amazon.com 2003 financial results conference call. You may now disconnect.

   LP
 OPERATOR: Good afternoon. My name is Tiffany and I'll be your conference facilitator. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Amazon.com Q4 2002 financial results conference call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise. After the speaker's remarks, there will be a question-and-answer period. If you would like to ask a question during this time, simply press star then the number 1 on your telephone key pad. At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Tim Halladay, V.P. Investor Relations. Thank you, Mr. Halladay. You may begin your conference, sir. 

 TIM HALLADAY, VICE PRESIDENT, INVESTOR RELATIONS, AMAZON.COM, INC.: Good afternoon. Welcome to the Amazon.com fourth quarter 2002 conference call. Joining me on today's call are Jeff Bezos, our CEO, and Tom Szkutak, our chief financial officer. 

   TD
 Please keep in mind that the following discussion and responses to your questions reflect management views as of today, January 23rd, 2003 only, and will include forward-look statements. Our actual results may differ materially from those projected. Additional information about factors that could potentially affect Amazon.com's financial results is included in today's press release and the company's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including its annual report on form 10K for the year ended December 31, 2001 and all subsequent filings. 

 As you listen to today's call, I would encourage you to have our press release in front of you, since all of our financial results, as well as commentary on the quarter are included and will correspond to much of the discussion that follows. You will also find a table which reconciles our GAAP results to pro forma results. Pro forma results are included for the benefit of investors, as they have been and continue to be a useful analytical companion to our GAAP results. Unless otherwise stated, all comparisons used in this call will be against our results for the comparable period of 2001. 

 With that introduction, I'll turn the call over to Jeff. 

 JEFF BEZOS, CEO, AMAZON.COM, INC.: Thanks, Tim. Good afternoon, everyone. 

 Before I begin, I would like to take a moment to thank the people that made this Q4 our best ever, starting with our customers around the world who ordered in record numbers. We're extremely grateful. And the big team of people here at Amazon.com who served those customers did a fantastic job. They delivered a record number of units. In stock availability was at record highs, and contacts per order, are most sensitive measure of customer satisfaction, was at record levels. 

 This year was our eighth holiday. And in terms of customer experience, it was clearly our best ever. We've already started working hard to ensure that our ninth holiday is even better yet. 

 A year ago, we outlined our 2002 objectives. First, to add selection by making our platform available to additional sellers. Second, to significantly lower prices for customers. Third, to drive our international business towards profitability. And fourth, to generate positive operating cash flow. 

 I'm pleased to say that the results we report today reflect our success in achieving each of these objectives. A year ago, we had over 100,000 third parties selling on our web site. Today, that number is over half a million, including sellers in the U.K., Germany and Japan. 

 During the fourth quarter, we we launched our Apparel and Accessories store, with over 450 brands that you can purchase in a single shopping cart. Based on the number of units sold in the first 60 days, this is our most successful store launch ever. We've always believed customers would accept a wide range of offerings from us, and the successful launch of apparel is good evidence of that. This is important because it speaks to the size of our ultimate addressable market. 

 A few specific data points: we sold 153,000 shirts, from Polo Ralph Lauren button downs to DKNY blouses; 78,000 jackets, from Old Navy fleece to Polar Tech Windbreakers; 106,000 pairs of pants, from Gap khakis to Guess jeans; 77,000 pairs of shoes, from Nike Air Max to Nine West boots; 46,000 accessories, including handbags, watches, scarfs and so on; and 31,000 pairs of underwear, from Jockey briefs to Hugo Boss boxers. In fact, since we opened the Apparel store, we hoped we might be able to answer the age-old question: boxers or briefs? Unfortunately, the answer remains illusive. The ratio is approximately 1.15 to 1 in favor of briefs, but the results are not yet statistically significant. Please place your own vote with a purchase. 

 Significantly lower prices also drove results this quarter. In the last 18 months, we lowered prices five times, and it's working. We could afford the pricing actions because of our significant improvements in operating efficiency. We saw an acceleration in our revenue growth rate from 13% in 2001 to 26% in 2002, an improvement of $225 million year-over-year in pro forma operating profit and an over $300 million improvement in free cash flow. 

 I'm especially pleased with the impact that lower prices had on our BMV and ETK businesses. We began executing the strategy over 18 months ago, and you can see it in our results as BMV revenue growth rates rebounded from a 1% decline in 2001 to an increase of 11% in 2002, with ETK revenue growth also improving nearly 5 points year over year to 18%. Unit growth in both segments is even faster. 

 We told you that in the new year, we would make a decision on the right threshold for our Super Saver Shipping offer. I'm pleased to tell you that effective today, we've decided to offer everyday, year-round Free Super Saver Shipping and leave the threshold in place at the $25 level. We're also introducing, effective today, Free Super Saver Delivery for orders over 39 pounds at Amazon.co.uk. This represents a significant reduction in total price for our customers across all of our product lines. Even though Super Saver Shipping is expensive for Amazon.com, it is the right investment to make and is in the long-term best interest of our shareholders and our customers. 

 Let me be clear. At this point, when you shop at Amazon.com instead of in the physical world, you are saving a lot of money. Our product prices have always been low ,and now with Free Super Saver Shipping, our end price is even lower. 

 To illustrate this point, we decided to compare our prices to book prices in the physical world, where nine out of ten books are still sold. That's where all of the volume is. For this past weekend, we did a price comparison versus a major well-known chain of book superstores to see how much people could save by shopping at Amazon.com. 

 Specifically, here's what we did. To make the exercise objective, we began with this superstore chain's own published list of its 100 best sellers for 2002. It wasn't a hand-picked list that we created. It was their list, and it featured 45 hard cover titles, 55 paperback titles, ranging across many categories including literature, romance, mystery, nonfiction, children's, self-help and so on. It was a good representation of the kinds of books people buy the most. Then we priced all 100 titles by visiting their superstores in both Seattle and New York City. It took us six hours to find all 100 titles, and we had to go to four different stores to find them. 

 What did we find? First, 99 of the 100 books on their list were available at Amazon.com, ready to ship within 24 hours. Second, at this particular superstore chain, this list of their 100 best selling books for 2002 cost a total of $1,561. At Amazon.com, the same 100 books cost $1,195, for a total savings of $366. In other words, our customers pay 23% less for these 2002 best sellers. For paperbacks on the list, Amazon.com customers saved an average of 17% and for hard customers -- I'm sorry, for hard covers, our customers saved an average of 27%. For 72 of the 100 books, our price was cheaper. On 25 of the books, our price was the same. And on the three titles where their prices were better, our books team has already reduced our prices. In this particular chain's physical world superstores, only 15 of their 100 titles were discounted. They were selling the other 85 at full list price. At Amazon.com, 76 of the 100 were discounted, and 24 were sold at list price. 

 Let me reiterate that this was not a specially contrived list to showcase savings. You'll see similar results for virtually any list you create because Amazon.com's strategy is not to discount a small number of best sellers for a short time, but instead to offer low prices every day that apply broadly across our entire product range. And by the way, the comparisons we just discussed were for our prices on new books. Of course, you would save even more if you used our web site to purchase used books. There may still be reasons to shop in the physical world; for instance, if you need something right now, but you will be paying a premium. We're pleased to report that the word is getting out, and customers are beginning to realize that they're saving money by shopping at Amazon.com. 

 Moving to the final two objectives, our international segment is now almost a $1.2 billion business and grew 77% in 2002. At the same time, we made quicker than anticipated progress towards profitability, as our international segment pro forma operating profit improved $31 million year-over-year to $20 million in Q4. We had similar success in our objective of generating positive operating cash flow for the year. We achieved that; but in addition, we were also able to generate positive free cash flow for the year of $135 million. I'll remind you this number includes $110 million of cash interest expense and $40 million of capital expenditures and excludes proceeds from stock option exercises. 

 Let me conclude with the following point. Our long-term goal remains the same: To generate substantial growing free cash flow on a sustained basis. Our strategy to accomplish that is an obsessive focus on customers, including expanding selection, lowering prices, and doing a great job for our partners. It is that relentless focus on the customer experience that's gotten us this far. and it will take us the rest of the way, too. 

 With that, let me turn it over to Tom. 

 TOM SZKUTAK, CFO, AMAZON.COM, INC.: Thanks, Jeff ,and hello, everyone. It is great to be with you here today. 

 This was a great quarter for me to start here at Amazon.com. First, fueled by lower prices, our positive business trends continued. Revenues reached a record $1.429 billion, representing growth of 28% over the prior year, our fourth consecutive quarter of greater than 20% growth. Adjusting for the favorable impact from foreign exchange rate, overall revenue growth of the quarter was 25%. 

 Full year revenues were $3.93 billion, an increase of 26% year-over-year. Pro forma operating profit was also a record $102 million, or 7.1% of sales, including a $3 million benefit from foreign exchange rates. For 2002, pro forma operating profit reached $180 million, an improvement of $225 million over 2001. Pro forma net income, which includes interest expense, was $75 million or 19 cents per share. Active customer accounts with purchases in the last 12 months totaled 31 million, a 26% year-over-year increase. 

 Unit growth for the year was 34%, continued to outpace revenue growth and provide meaningful benefit to a bottom line result. Third party units as a percentage of North American units served was 30% for the quarter, an increase from 22% one year ago. Worldwide, third party units reached 21% of all units served. Free cash flow for 2002 was $135 million, a year-over-year improvement in excess of $300 million. The combination of common stock outstanding and employee stock base awards decreased 1% year-over-year. 

 Second, our international business continued to exceed our expectations. International segment revenue grew 76% this quarter, with revenue growth exceeding 60% in each of our four international web sites. It is now approaching a $1.2 billion business on a trailing 12 month basis. After reaching break-even last quarter, the international segment was profitable in Q4, with pro forma operating profit of $20 million or over 4% of revenue for the year. The segment approached break even with a loss of approximately $600,000 for the year. Japan, after only two years, is now our fastest subsidiary to reach essentially break-even, with a pro forma operating margin of under 1% for the quarter. 

 Third, our financial progress allows us to continue to invest. We will make $25 Free Super Saver Shipping a year round offer in the U.S. and introduce Free Super Saver Delivery in the U.K. We'll open and promote a number of new stores in 2003, and we'll continue to find ways to offer the best value proposition for our customers through lower prices and selection and unparalleled [indiscernible]. 

 Free shipping and lower prices are expensive and will negatively impact profits and cash flow in the near term. In fact, in 2003, we expected our customers will save in excess of $100 million through our free shipping offers. We believe that this is the right investment and will benefit our shareholders over the long-term. 

 Now, moving to the operating expense portion. Pro forma expense was 8.9% of sales, down over 90 basis points from 9.8% a year ago. In absolute dollars, pro forma expense increased 16 % to $125 million on a sales increase of 28% [indiscernible]. 

 Our improvement was driven by the following: First, unit growth. As we've mentioned many times in the past, our fixed costs will not grow at the same pace as [indiscernible], which results in lower fixed cost per unit. Second, efficiency. Our continued focus on cost improvement and inventory accuracy resulted in significant benefits to customer experience in our financial results. Reliability for holiday orders and worldwide inventory accuracy reached record levels. In stock availability for our top selling items on the U.S. site was a record high of 98%. [Indiscernible], or the amount of time taken by our fulfillment center to process an order improved 17%. In our most sensitive measure of customer satisfaction, contacts per order, we saw a 13% improvement. 

 We made all of this progress while still meeting holiday deadlines. We kept free shipping in place eight days longer than 2001 and standard shipping in place for an additional four days. I would like to remind you that as you forecast our fulfillment costs going forward, that this amount includes credit card interchange fees. On sales third party product, the credit card fee is calculated on the gross sale, not our net revenue share. Therefore, you should expect credit card fees as a percentage of absolute fulfillment costs to increase over time with the success of our third party sellers. 

 Pro forma operating profit was $102 million versus $59 million in the fourth quarter of 2001, an improvement of more than $43 million or 74%. This was our fifth consecutive quarter of operating profit as our operating margin improved 187 basis points year-over-year to 7.1%. 

 Stepping back and looking at the quarter, the operating dynamics that we saw are similar to what we would expect to see over the next few years. We will continue to have growth driven by new categories, international expansion, third party sellers, lower prices and free shipping. Beyond the customer benefit of all of these are technology and fixed infrastructure will also be leveraged. We'll continue to drive further productivity internally and lower cost of what we call deflation with our external suppliers. We believe that our growth and cost initiatives we have in place will lead to sustainable growth and free cash flow. 

 Fourth quarter pro forma net income was $75 million and 19 cents per share compared to 9 cents per share one year ago. For total 2002, our pro forma net income was $66 million or 17 cents per share compared to a loss of $157 million and 43 cents per share in 2001. On a GAAP basis, our net income was $3 million or one cent per share compared to net income of $5 million also 1 cent per share in the prior year. 

 For the quarter, there are four key differences year-over-year in the GAAP results. First, we incurred a stock based competition charge of $36 million in Q4 2002, primarily due to a $31 million charge for the upward movement in our stock price compared to a $2 million charge in 2001. Second, we had a $38 million charge in the current quarter for year base debt compared to a $17 million benefit in the prior year. Third, we had a $5 million restructuring benefit in the fourth quarter 2002, as we terminated the lease for a vacated fulfillment center in Georgia compared to a $5 million charge in the prior year. And fourth, amortization of goodwill, and other intangibles were $1 million in Q4 2002 compared to $38 million in 2001. 

 On a net basis, these four items negatively impacted current quarter GAAP results by $7 million compared to a $27 million charge in the prior year. Although we report the GAAP net income of $3 million, we believe that this positive net income result is not predictive of future results or trends and should not be viewed as material positive event. Our primary focus is on the inputs that drive pro forma operating results in the generation of free cash flow. Free cash flow reached $135 million in 2002, an improvement of over $300 million year-over-year. 

 When thinking about operating free cash flow for 2003 and beyond, let me remind you that predicting the elements of working capital at this point in time can be volatile and subject to many variables including seasonality, the timing of accrued expenses and the discounts offered by vendors. You should expect that we may take advantage of offers from vendors when it is the right economic trade, but over time, fluctuations of working capital will even out and a trend line will develop. It is our intent for free cash flow to be up into the right of the long-term. 

 Let me move to asset efficiency. Inventory was $202 million at December 31, 2002, up from $144 million a year ago. While balancing the benefits of in stock availability with inventory terms of working capital, we took advantage of various buying opportunities from our vendors at year end. Of note, our electronics inventory worldwide represented $32 million or approximately 16% of the total. And in fourth quarter, we turned our U.S. electronics inventory [indiscernible]: Inventory turns were 19 on a current 12-month basis, an improvement of 22% year-over-year. I encourage you to compare this metric to other world-class retailers. Our net investment of fixed assets which was $239 million decreased 12% from a year ago. We ended the quarter with cash and marketable securities of $1.3 billion, more than $300 million above a year ago. 

 I'll conclude my portion of today's call with guidance for Q1 and an update for our base plan expectations for 2003. Incorporated into our Q1 guidance in 2003 expectations are the order trends we've seen to date and what we believe today to be appropriately conservative assumptions. However, we also recognize there's a high level of uncertainty surrounding the global economy, consumer spending, and the impact of both on world events. While we are cautiously optimistic about the coming year, it is it not possible to accurately predict and therefore our actual results could differ from our guidance. Also, when we think about growth, we're only concerned with one thing, long-term growth and free cash flow. 

 For the march quarter, we expect net sales between $1.025 billion and $1.075 billion. As you would expect, this guidance assumes currency, foreign currency rates stay approximately where they are today. We cannot predict fluctuations with foreign currency rates going forward. We expect our pro forma net income to be between $5 million and $20 million, a pro forma earnings share of a penny to 5 cents per share. When comparing this with a year ago, please remember that this guidance incorporates $25 free super saver shipping for the entire quarter versus $99 for a portion of the prior year quarter. 

 For calendar 2003, our baseline expectations are: net sales to grow by over 15% and we expect pro forma net income to be over $115 million or over 27 cents per share. Let me remind everyone since certain stock options are currently subject to variable accounting, we incur enough non-cash charges [indiscernible]. Also, we mark our year to [indiscernible]. The result will be a noncash gain or loss. Therefore, we cannot forecast either of these items yet they could have significant impact either positively or negatively on the GAAP result. 

 Before opening up the questions, let me close with a final few thoughts. First and foremost, I want to thank our customers for visiting us over the holidays and taking advantage of our selection, convenience and pricing. We strive to always put the customer first. We believe that approach drives the market. Second, while we are cautiously optimistic, we're pleased to increase our guidance. Third, our model is validating itself as we reap the benefits of scale. While we continue to invest in low prices in unit growth, we'll work hard both internally to increase productivity and externally with our suppliers. Ultimately, we'll measure our success toward our objective of generating significant free cash flow. Finally, all of us at Amazon.com have the same objective. We're collectively driven to deliver for both our customers and our shareholders. 

 Tim, let's move to questions. 

 TIM HALLADAY: Thanks, Jeff and Tom. With that, we would like to move on to the Q & A portion of the call. In the interest of allowing as many people as possible to ask a question, we ask that you limit yourself to one question. Operator, if you could remind our listeners how to ask a question, we'll proceed with the call. 

 OPERATOR: Certainly. At this time, I would like to remind everyone, if you would like to ask a question, please press star then the number 1 on your telephone key pad. If you are using a speakerphone, please remember to pick up the handset before asking your question. And our first question comes from Anthony Noto. 

 ANTHONY NOTO, ANALYST, GOLDMAN SACHS: Thank you very much. Hi, everyone. First, Jeff, I guess in the interest of all of those out there that are wearing boxers, please put me down for boxers as opposed to briefs. Secondly, as we think about the $25 free shipping, what sort of data points or research can you share with us that indicates that this offer is driving either incremental penetration of new users that you would not have otherwise gotten or incremental purchases from current users that may not have purchased again? And just give us some understanding of those benefits that we should benefit from long-term. They're actually seeing today to support that decision and then secondly, there is a lot of debates surrounding your operating margins and while they were strong in this quarter, as we think out over the next couple of years, you have a long-term goal of double digit operating margins. Where do you think they could be by say 2005 to give us a little bit closer end road map? Thanks. 

 TOM SZKUTAK: To answer your first question, on -- this is Tom, on super saver shipping, we've obviously looked at it a number of different ways. And we're certainly comfortable that we're getting a lift from super saver shipping and we can tell you that our customers like it. In terms of sharing the absolute data, we don't think -- we think it's competitive information and not right to share it with you at this time. So, suffice it to say though, that it is certainly a long-term investment for our business. Our customers saved over $30 million in fourth quarter. They'll save over $100 million in 2003. It is definitely the right thing for our customers and our shareholders during the long-term. In terms of the other question surrounding operating margins, you know, we're giving guidance for 2003. We're not giving guidance for beyond that. But you know, our goal obviously is to improve margins over time. We think we have the right growth formula and the right operating formula to do that. 

 JEFF BEZOS: The only thing I was getting at is that -- we haven't changed our goals -- our long-term goals with respect to operating margins but the caveat we always give with that is that we're ultimately going to do the right thing with respect to maximizing you know, dollar operating profit rather than percentage operating margins. And so you know, if -- ultimately, if there is a conflict between those two things, it will be an easy decision for us to make. 

 ANTHONY NOTO: Ok. Thank you very much. 

 JEFF BEZOS: Thank you, Anthony. 

 TIM HALLADAY: Operator, next question, please. 

 OPERATOR: Our next question is from Heath Terry of Credit Suisse First Boston. 

 HEATH TERRY, ANALYST, CSFB: Great, thanks a lot. Can you talk a little bit about the ETK segment? Earlier, had you talked about the outside possibility of getting that segment to profitability by the end of this year. Do you still think that's -- is that still something that you're looking for? And then if you could also just talk a little bit about the cash flow metrics you're going to be looking at this year. What should we expect for Cap Ex and what do you think the relationship between operating the operating cash flow number you're looking for being positive this year in free cash flow will look like. 

 TOM SZKUTAK: n terms of your first question on ETK, we're very pleased with our progress in ETK. We grew 21% year-over-year and we're going to continue to drive scale in that business. With scale, we think the margins will come. We'll have a lot more leverage once we're able to do that. In terms of cash, we're obviously -- it is a very important measure to us. We're not giving guidance for cash in 2003. But in terms of Cap Ex, I think for your purposes, you can assume that consistent with the last two years, our Cap Ex will be below depreciation and amortization. But again, in the long run, from a cash perspective, we expect to be -- it will be a primary focus and we're going to sustain long-term cash flow over time. 

 HEATH TERRY: Is it the goal of ETK profitable by the end of this year? 

 TIM HALLADAY: Operator, next question, please. 

 OPERATOR: Our next question comes from Safa Rashtchy of U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray. 

 SAFA RASHTCHY, ANALYST, U.S. BANCORP PIPER JAFFRAY: Good afternoon. Congratulations and a good quarter. On the -- international operations, Jeff or Tom, you alluded that Japan is nearly profitable. Do you have a goal for international profitability in 2003? Do you think you can achieve that? And also separately, on the Apparel store which you said has been the most successful launch of any store yet, can you talk about the potential impact of customers who are coming for apparel, who perhaps were not Amazon customers at all. Can you share any data, maybe if not at the future point with us as to what percentage of customers haven't shopped at Amazon before and how do you see the impact of that traffic? Thank you. 

 TOM SZKUTAK: In terms of your first question, regarding international, we're obviously not giving segment guidance on this call. We're pleased -- we're very pleased with the results that our international segment had in 2002. We're expecting great results from our international team again in 2003. But again, we're not giving any specific guidance today. In terms of apparel, you know, we're -- as we had mentioned, earlier, we're extremely pleased with the results to date. It was our most successful launch in the first 60 days that we've had in terms of traffic that that's generated you know, we're not in a position really to disclose that at this time. 

 TIM HALLADAY: Thanks. Operator, can we take the next question, please? 

 OPERATOR: Our next question is from Mary Meeker of Morgan Stanley. 

 MARY MEEKER, ANALYST, MORGAN STANLEY: Thanks. Couple of clarification questions. I think you've typically given out active customers. If you could give us the stat for the fourth quarter there, that would be great. You indicated in your press release that unit growth was 34% year to year for 2002. By our math, that implies that unit growth in the fourth quarter was about 35%. That reasonable? And final question, it certainly appears that you indicated that the apparel launch was successful in the fourth quarter. It appears you're getting good feedback from your apparel partners. Do you think it's conceivable in 2003 that we'll see some of those major apparel partners begin to ramp co-marketing efforts from their end with Amazon.com? Thanks. 

 TOM SZKUTAK: Just to answer your first question on active customer accounts. The active customer account were purchased in the last 12 months were 31 million which is the 26% growth over prior year. 

 MARY MEEKER: Thanks, Tom. 

 TOM SZKUTAK: In terms of units growth, you asked a question about units growth for the fourth quarter. We disclosed total year was up 34%. I think you could assume that, you know, fourth quarter was higher than total year, nominally higher. That's a fair assumption. And then your last question on apparel. 

 JEFF BEZOS: On the apparel, there has already been a small amount of co-marketing. 

 MARY MEEKER: Yep. 

 JEFF BEZOS: And you know, I would expect that to grow over time. How rapidly that will grow, I think we'll have to wait and see. But I think if done correctly, it is in the interest of both parties. 

 MARY MEEKER: Thank you. 

 OPERATOR: Our next question is from Lanny Baker of Salomon Smith Barney. 

 LANNY BAKER, ANALYST, SALOMON SMITH BARNEY: Questions about capital structure, I guess. When do you think the company would potentially need to invest more money in another distribution center? You shut down the lease on one in this quarter but is there a time frame out there where you think you're going to have to put capital in that direction? And then sort of an alternative capital allocation question, is there -- as you start to accumulate now free cash, how do you -- how are you going to prioritize the right-hand side of the balance sheet, taking down the debt versus buying back stock? 

 TOM SZKUTAK: To answer your first question on fulfillment centers, we have no plans to add any additional capacity fulfillment in 2003. Jeff has challenged our team to also do the same thing -- to do the same thing in 2004. I think that remains to be seen at this point. In terms of your last question, on cash and capital structure, you know, it's something that -- thanks for the question. 

 LANNY BAKER: Brand new. 

 TOM SZKUTAK: Up until about a year, 18 months ago, we were getting a lot of other questions about how we were going to repay our debt in 2008, 2009, 2010 but we have time to make the decisions. We'll make those very carefully and keep our investors in mind. But I think at this point talking about how we would do that is probably not appropriate. 

 LANNY BAKER: Thanks. 

 TIM HALLADAY: Thanks, Lanny. Operator, can we take the next question. 

 OPERATOR: Our next question is from Sean Milne from SoundView Tech Group. 

 SEAN MILNE, ANALYST, SOUNDVIEW TECH GROUP: Thank you very much. Tom, just a real quick question on gross margins in the quarter. Obviously impacted by the free shipping. But if you look into the segment breakdown, can you just walk us through the services gross margin? Was that an impact from coupon and you know, the uptake in ETK on a sequential basis. I assume that's a swing around from the wireless. That would be great. Thanks. 

 TOM SZKUTAK: Let me start with gross margins from a total business perspective, first. There are a couple of things that you see that are going on with the gross margins. First, our international segment is obviously growing at a much faster rate than the core. Our international segment, as you know, has a lower gross margin than the core part of our business so that's one. In terms of the services segments, specifically, we're actually just to make a comment on our total services business, we're actually very, very pleased with our total service business. We've added some great partners and many of these service type revenues actually appear in the other segments such as ETK, so, when you think of J and R Electronics, Circuit City, the services are included in the ETK segment. So, just wanted to give you a full picture on services. As at the relates to the services segment when you see the margins going down, that really relates back to some major, older advertising marketing agreements that we had back in 1999 and 2000 that we've talked about in the past that are running off and you know, for the next several quarters, you know, will be available us to. But as you look at the total services business, which includes services in the individual segments, we actually look pretty good. 

 SEAN MILNE: Thank you. 

 TIM HALLADAY: Thanks, Sean. Operator, can we take the next question, please. 

 OPERATOR: Our next question comes from Jeff Fieler of Bear, Stearns. 

 JEFF FIELER, ANALYST, BEAR STEARNS: Good afternoon. Wanted to ask a question on the -- how are you thinking about marketing these days in terms of your actual marketing spend, it was down about $10 million on a year over year basis and wondered if that was an area you were going to prioritize and perhaps grow again in 2003 or if you're looking at it in a broader sense and seeing the losses that you're taking on the shipping side as a form of -- as a form of marketing in putting the two things together as a better way of looking at that. 

 JEFF BEZOS: That is pretty much how we look at it. We look at all of our different types of marketing and broad scale marketing, on-line marketing. There are a bunch of different things we do. And then we have things like free super saver shipping on orders over $25. Lower product prices. If we can make it make sense for the business, that's actually the best form of marketing because we're giving the money directly to our customers. And we prefer to do that whenever possible and so we do look at those two and kind of -- more traditional marketing. We weigh that against things like free super saver shipping. 

 JEFF FIELER: So what do you anticipate doing? 

 JEFF BEZOS: Go ahead, Jeff. 

 JEFF FIELER: Just a follow-up in terms of the core marketing side and where you were with the trials on the TV commercials. 

 JEFF BEZOS: We will -- we'll continue to evaluate our broad scale marketing as we go forward over time and see what we want to do. You know, there are no big revelations to make at this point. 

 JEFF FIELER: Great. Thanks very much. 

 JEFF BEZOS: You're welcome. 

 TIM HALLADAY: Operator, can we make this our last question, please. 

 OPERATOR: Certainly. Our last question comes from Jeetil Patel of Deutsch Banc Securities. 

 JEETIL PATEL, ANALYST, DEUTSCHE BANC SECURITIES: Thanks, hey, guys. Couple of questions. First of all, yeah, you mentioned -- you talked about international expansion and category kind of new categories coming on. Can you talk about international expansion. Would you --do you think that the opportunity lies in Europe or Asia Pacific as you look at it over the next two years? And then secondly, as you look at product category expansion, how extensionible is the Rainier's merchandising and marketing platform from a back end standpoint to go into new categories over the course of this year? And then secondly, eCommerce growth seems to be coming around 20% again for this year. Can you talk about I guess the categories within eCommerce that seem to be growing faster that may be attractive as you look over the course of this year. And the out year as well. 

 JEFF BEZOS: Well, on international expansion, we will, over time, enter additional countries. What kind of schedule we'll do that, whether or not there will be any of that this year, we'll have to wait and see. The countries we're in today represent such a large fraction of eCommerce penetration that we think it makes sense for us and our shareholders to focus on those countries, make sure we're doing a great job there. So, that's one thing. We will open a number of new categories, new stores this year. And in answer to your question, the software that we've developed is quite flexible. And does allow us to do that. In a sort of low cost attractive way. And so under expect us -- you should expect to see that. And then -- Was there one more? Was that it? 

 JEETIL PATEL: If you look at the growth rates of eCommerce, are there categories that seem to be attractive from a growth rate standpoint. 

 JEFF BEZOS: Well, I think apparel is one of those categories, seems to be growing very quickly and so we're glad that we're in that category and with, I think, an outstanding offering, the team that did that did just a fine piece of work. We're continuing to add selection and new brands there. So, that's when we're very happy to be in. As far as future categories, to -- to tip our hand as to where we might be headed next. 

 Thanks, Jeetil. I want to thank everyone for joining us on the call today. A replay of this call will be available on our investor relations web site through the end of the quarter. We look forward to talking to you again next quarter and thanks for your interest in Amazon.com. 

 JEFF BEZOS: Thank you. 

 OPERATOR: Thank you again for participating in this afternoon's conference. You may now disconnect.

 Q3  2002  Amazon .com Earnings Conference Call - Final
