   LP
 OPERATOR, : Good afternoon. My name is Matthew and I will be your conference facilitator. At this time I would like to welcome everyone to the Amazon.com Q3 2002 Financial Results Conference Call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise. After the speakers remarks there will be a question and answer period. If you would like to ask a question during this time simply press star and the number one on your telephone keypad. If you would like to withdraw your question press star and the number two on your telephone keypad. Thank you. I would now like to turn the call over to Tim Halladay, VP Investor Relations. Mr. Halladay you may begin your conference. 

   TD
 TIM HALLADAY, VP INVESTOR RELATIONS , AMAZON.COM: Thank you. Good afternoon and welcome to the Amazon.com third quarter 2002 conference call. Joining me on today's call are Jeff Bezos our CEO and Mark Peek our VP and Chief Accounting Officer. Please keep in mind that the following discussion and responses to your questions are management's view as of today October 24, 2002 only and will include forward looking statements. Our actual results may differ materially than those projected. Additional information about factors that could potentially affect Amazon.com's financial results is included in today's press release and the company's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including its annual report on form 10K for the year ended December 31, 2001 and all subsequent filings. As you listen to today's call I would encourage you to have our press release in front of you since all of our financial results as well as commentary on the quarter are included, and will correspond to much of the discussion that follows. You'll also find a table which reconciles our GAAP results pro forma results -- pro forma results are included for the benefit of investors as they have been and continue to be a useful analytical companion for our GAAP results. Unless otherwise stated all comparisons used in this call will be against our results for the comparable period of 2001. With that introduction I will turn the call over to Jeff. 

 JEFF BEZOS, PRESIDENT AND CEO, AMAZON.COM: Thanks Tim. Good afternoon everyone. Before I begin I want to take a moment to welcome Tom Szkutak our new CFO to Amazon.com. Tom comes to us with 20 years experience in various divisions of GE. Most recently as the CFO of GE Lighting. Tom's been on board since the first of the month and it's great to have him helping us. He'll be formally involved in the call next quarter, and I want to thank Mark for sharing the detailed results with you again this quarter. 

 The excellent results that we report today are the outcome of investments we started making years ago. Investments in category expansion, investments in international expansion, investments in marketplace, investments in operating efficiency and lower prices for customers. I am especially pleased with the impact that our strategy of lowering prices has had on the growth of our business. We began executing this strategy over 15 months ago, and you can see it in our results, as revenues increased 33% over the prior year, and unit growth was at its highest level in two years. 

 All of this growth was achieved organically. Our books, music and video revenue growth rate accelerated to 17%, fueled by the many price reductions we've introduced over the past five quarters. Unit growth in this segment was even higher. Electronics, tools and kitchen had revenue growth of 25% YoverY with unit growth of 39%, as our prices continue to get sharper and our selection continues to expand. Our electronics selection is now more than ten times the selection than a typical big box electronics store. For example, we have over 250 different digital cameras, over 200 different DVD players and over 220 different LCD monitors. All of which are available for purchase today. 

 Our international business continues to grow rapidly. For each of the last four quarters our international segment has experienced revenue growth in excess of 70%, including over 90% growth in the current quarter. This year our international business will surpass $1b dollars, and including exports, represented 36% of overall revenues this quarter. 

 Even with substantial investments in lower prices for customers, we continue to make significant progress on the bottom line. Pro forma net income was basically break even for the quarter, up from a loss of $58m a year ago. And on trailing 12-month basis, we have pro forma net income for the first time of $26m. Most important is the improvement we have seen in our trailing 12-month free cash flow, reaching $120m -- an increase of over $400m YoverY. I'll remind you that this number includes $110m of cash interest expense and $30m of capital expenditures, and excludes proceeds from stock option exercises. 

 The foundation of these results has been and continues to be our relentless focus on the end-to-end customer experience. As we enter our eighth holiday season we expect to be more relevant to more holiday shoppers than ever and provide a customer experience better than ever before. Today, our customers around the world can find approximately 9m book titles in five different languages. Customers can now have a power drill or the latest Rolling Stones CD delivered to their home. They can order a printer from Office Depot, ship a blender to a bride and groom from their Amazon wedding registry, buy a shirt from Target, a Harley Barbie from Toys'R'Us, a down comforter from Marshall Fields or a Sony DVD player from J&R Electronics. And soon we'll begin previewing for customers a brand new store that we've been working on for almost a year. We will invest in the long-term success of this new store through heavy on-site promotions this holiday season. 

 In addition to our expanded selection, availability has also improved significantly. We now have over 4m sq. ft. of fulfillment center capacity around the world, which results in a better customer experience with improved delivery times. This year our last day for standard shipping in time for holiday delivery will be even later than it was last year. Last minute shoppers will be able to order on Amazon and pick up products at Circuit City or Borders stores in their local neighborhoods. In-stock availability this holiday season will be at an all-time high, thanks to better inventory planning and management by our team, and to the new and used product offerings from what are now hundreds of thousands of third-party sellers at Amazon.com -- a number that has increased more than four times just in the last 12 months. In Q3 third-party sellers represented an astonishing 23% of all North American units. The liability both on the web site and in terms of delivery to customers has continued to improve each year as evidenced by the 15% YoverY decrease in customer contacts per order in Q3. Historically, we have shipped well in excess of 99% of holiday orders in time to meet holiday deadlines. This year we'll be working hard to eliminate decimal points and push it as high as possible. Finally, our prices will be the lowest ever this holiday. In 1997, we deeply discounted the New York Times' bestseller list. We still do that. But today customer discounts have expanded to include 30% off of virtually all books over $15. In addition, we've significantly lowered prices on electronics, tools and best selling CDs and DVDs. Not only do you get these low product prices, but you get free super saver shipping on orders over $25 too. If you want a used product you can find even lower prices. As I said many times before, we're committed to lowering prices for customers even though it is expensive for us. The primary driver of the nearly 170 basis points sequential reduction in gross margin from Q2 to Q3, on a $45m increase in revenue, was super saver shipping, which was in place for the $49 hurdle and one month at the $25 hurdle. The long-term rewards of relentlessly lowering price, when and as the company can afford to do so, are enormous as increases in unit volume flow across our fixed cost structure. 

 Today we are announcing that we will leave $25 free super saver shipping in place at least through the holidays. Compare that with last year when we had free shipping for a limited time with a much higher hurdle of $99. After the holidays, we'll consider whether we can make $25 free super saver shipping permanent. Price reductions of this magnitude are only made possible by focusing on productivity in every area of the company. 

 In Q3 our pro forma operating expenses remained flat on a 33% increase in revenue. We drove variable cost productivity largely by eliminating mistakes and errors at their root, which also happens to be a huge driver of convenience and experience for customers. Every year that's gone by since Amazon.com's founding we've done a better and better job of eliminating such errors. In addition to variable cost productivity improvements we believe our business is poised to further demonstrate powerful operating leverage. Looking ahead for the foreseeable future we believe we can hold our fixed costs relatively fixed while driving profitable increases in volume over the base. The result is fixed cost productivity that drops straight to the bottom line and becomes available for further price reductions, other kinds of long-term investments and free cash flow generation. 

 Let me spend a moment discussing marketing and communication in the context of a very large customer base. There's always a lag in the customer's brain between reality and perception. It takes time for mass audience perception to catch up with reality. At Amazon.com we're working hard to teach, and our tens of millions of customers are in the process of learning, two new realities about Amazon.com. The first is that our selection has expanded dramatically beyond books, music and video. The second, is that our new pricing strategy saves customers a tremendous amount of money. We've made excellent progress teaching customers about electronics, tools and kitchen products over the last three years. You can see that in this quarter's 39% ETK unit growth. We're really just getting started teaching customers about the unusually significant price reductions and free shipping we've instituted over the last 15 months. Customers understand clearly that Amazon.com is the easiest, most-convenient, most time-efficient way to shop, and most of them do not yet understand that Amazon is also a way to save a significant amount of hard-earned money. Through consistent, persistent messaging and the passage of time we will get that message through over the years, just as we've made progress with ETK awareness. Through relentlessness and patience, perceptions will match reality, and we are excited about that future. 

 Thank you for your time today. Our goal is substantial, sustained growing free cash flow. That interest is aligned perfectly with working hard to serve customers. I look forward to talking with you again in January after what I expect will be a good holiday season. In the meantime, we look forward to serving you while you shop from the comfort of your home or office. And don't forget, you'll be saving money too. And with that I'll turn it over to Mark. 

 MARK PEEK, VP AND CHIEF ACCOUNTING OFFICER, AMAZON.COM: Thanks Jeff, and hello everyone. This was another great quarter for Amazon.com. First, fueled by our continued drive to lower prices, our positive business trends continued. Revenues reached $851m, representing organic growth of 33% compared to the prior year. An acceleration from 21% growth in the first two quarters of the year. Pro forma operating profit was $27m or 3.2% of sales. For the trailing 12 months pro forma operating profit was $137m or 3.8% of sales. Pro forma net income, which of course includes interest expense, was basically at break even compared to a loss of $58m a year ago. For the first time on a trailing 12-month basis, we have pro forma net income of $26m or $0.07 per share. Free cash flow was $120m on the trailing 12 months. A YoverY improvement of over $400m. The combination of common stock outstanding and employee stock-based awards decreased by 2% from a year ago. Trailing 12-month inventory turns were 19 compared to 15 a year ago. 

 Second, our international business continues to exceed our expectations. International segment revenue grew 90% this quarter --the fourth consecutive quarter of greater than 70% growth, and is nearly a billion dollar business on a trailing 12-month basis. Each of our four international web sites experienced YoverY revenue growth exceeding 60% this quarter. For the first time ever, international segment reached break even, a $29m improvement YoverY. 

 Third, our financial progress is also allowing us to invest for the future. We will continue $25 free super saver shipping at least through the holidays, and conduct an extensive marketing and promotion campaign, which includes the new store launch Jeff mentioned earlier. We'll test the impact of paying higher commissions for Q4 to our over 850,000 associate web sites around the world, and we'll continue to find ways to offer the best value proposition for our customers through lower prices, expanded selection and unparalleled convenience. 

 Each of these investments is expensive and negatively impacts profits in the near term. However, unit growth is critical to driving significant increases in cash flows, and therefore, as we have been doing throughout the year, we are willing to forego some current profits to invest for the long-term benefit of our shareholders. 

 Now I would like to discuss our results in more detail. Third quarter revenue was $851m, up 33% from the prior year. As we told you a year ago we believe sales were depressed $25-35m from the events of September 11 in the 3Q01. Adjusting for last year we estimate overall revenue growth exceeding 25%. On a trailing 12-month basis revenue reached $3.6b, an increase of 21%. Active customers, those purchasing in the last 12 months, totaled 29m, a 25% YoverY increase. Gross profit increased by $54m, or 33%, to $216m. Gross margin was flat with the prior year at 25.4%. Gross margin benefited from marketplace, and improvements of inventory management and procurement, offset by significant price reductions to customers, including the cost of free super saver shipping, and as we discussed last quarter, higher margin advertising arrangements representing a lower percentage of our overall revenue mix. 

 Now I'll turn to the segments. Revenue in book, music and video was $412m, an increase of 17%. Despite significant price reductions and foregone shipping revenue, gross profit for the segment was up 25% while gross margin increased over 165 basis points. Continuing to demonstrate the leverage of our model, segment pro forma operating profits increased 64% YoverY to $43m, while operating margin exceeded 10% of sales for the fourth consecutive quarter. In electronics, tools and kitchen revenue increased 25% to $129m on unit growth of 39%. Gross profit for the segment decreased 2% while gross margin was down approximately 280 basis points to 10%. Early in the quarter, through pricing and rebates, we effectively began giving away wireless handsets to drive volume and increase customer activation commissions from wireless service providers. We've seen tremendous customer acceptance of this price reduction as unit volumes almost tripled over the second quarter. This change in strategy negatively impacted margins in ETK during the quarter by approximately 140 basis points, as we deferred recognition of commission revenue from wireless carriers until the fourth quarter when the customer cancellation period lapses. I might add, cell phones are a great holiday gift especially when they're free. 

 We continue to make progress on the bottom line as ETK segment loss improved 27% to $24m, or 19% of sales compared with 32% a year ago. During the quarter, Target significantly expanded the merchandise they make available at Amazon.com, and J&R Electronics brought their extensive selection into our electronics store. In addition, Office Depot has strengthened our office electronics selection of printers, faxes, computer peripherals and computers. 

 International segment revenue reached $264m, an increase of 90% YoverY. Gross profit was $61m, an improvement of $33m or 116%. As previously mentioned, the international segment broke even for the quarter with pro forma operating profit of approximately $800,000, an improvement of nearly $29m YoverY. Compared with the prior year, the dollar was weaker against foreign currencies, resulting in favorable impacts on international segment revenue of approximately $22m, an operating profit of $1m. Including exports, revenue from customers outside the US represented 36% of the company's sales, up from 29% from a year ago. 

 Services revenue was $47m, flat with the prior year, while gross margin was 55%, down from 59% a year ago. As we've mentioned for several quarters, we expect margins will continue to decline near term as our fixed fee higher margin advertising arrangements, originally struck in 1999, represent a lower percentage of our overall revenue mix. Services segment operating profit was $8m. During the quarter we launched an office supplies store with Office Depot. Target.com re-launched their web site powered by Amazon.com, integrating Marshall Fields and Mervyn's into the site, and taking advantage of the personalization and other features customers have come to enjoy while shopping at Amazon.com. 

 We're also very excited with a number of software tools that we designed in connection with the Target.com launch that allow merchandisers to easily display and edit content on the site. We also recently introduced the Amazon.com branded Platinum Visa with Bank One. By using the card for purchases, customers can now earn reward certificates for redemption at Amazon.com. 

 Now moving to the operating expense portion of the income statement. Fulfillment costs were $90m, or 10.6% of sales, down over 210 basis points from 12.7% a year ago. I'd like to remind you that fulfillment includes credit card interchange fees. On sales of third party products the credit card fee is calculated on the gross sale, not our net revenue share. Marketing was $27m, a decline of 18% from a year earlier, due primarily to reduce spending and less efficient channels and lower rates for traffic generation. Pro forma operating profit was $27m vs. a loss of $27m in the third quarter of 2001, an improvement of more than $54m. This is our fourth consecutive quarter of operating profit as our operating margin improved nearly 750 basis points YoverY to 3%. After interest expense pro forma net income was basically at break even and compares to a loss of $58m a year ago. On a trailing 12-month basis, we had pro forma net income of $26m, or $0.07 per share. 

 On a GAAP basis our net loss for the quarter was $35m, or $0.09 per share. This compares with third quarter 2001 net loss of $170m, or $0.46 per share. During the quarter we incurred a restructuring charge of $37m related to revised sublease income estimates for vacant office and fulfillment space. Ongoing lease payments for vacant space and equipment no longer in use will have a negative impact of over $15m on 2003 free cash flow. As you consider our GAAP results keep in mind that each quarter, we mark our Euro denominated debt-to-market. While this had virtually no impact this quarter, it resulted in a $40m charge in third quarter of a year ago. Also during the quarter, we recognized a benefit of $1m for stock-based compensation primarily as a result of the stock price closing slightly below the stock price at June 30, 2002. Last quarter we told you that we would begin expensing employee stock-based awards by the new year and look at improving the form of stock-based awards with the intent of better aligning the interests of employees and shareholders. We've done that, and beginning with next month's annual grant we will largely move from stock options to restricted stock units as the primary stock based award to our employees. This decision will result in a GAAP charge over the vesting period of the restricted stock unit beginning in 4Q. 

 Our trailing 12-month operating cash flow reached $151m, while free cash flow was $120m on a trailing 12-month basis, an improvement of over $400m. When thinking about operating and free cash flow for the full year 2000, you should consider several factors. Predicting the elements of working capital infra-sites is subject to many variables. The highly seasonal nature of our business during the holiday period amplifies the volatility of our working capital at the end of the December quarter. Thus, forecasting the net change in working capital, particularly accounts payable and accrued expenses, is difficult. Additionally, we expect certain suppliers to offer attractive early payment or other discounts near the end of the year. If taking advantage of these offers gives the best economic trade for the company we would sacrifice cash flow for 4Q to achieve better product pricing. 

 Let me move to asset efficiency. Inventory was $152m at quarter end, as we began our inventory build for the holidays. We expect our in-stock levels this holiday season to be our best ever. Inventory turns were 19 on a trailing 12-month basis, an improvement of 31%. We encourage you to compare this metric to other world-class retailers. Our net investment in fixed assets was $239m, a 17% decrease from a year ago. We ended the quarter with cash and marketable securities of $866m nearly $200m more than a year ago. 

 I'll conclude my portion of today's call with our guidance for 4Q and some baseline expectations for 2003. Incorporated into our 4Q guidance, and 2003 base-line expectations, are the order trends that we have seen to date and what we believe today to be appropriately conservative assumptions. However, we also recognize there is a high level of uncertainty surrounding the global economy, consumer spending and the impact of both of world events. While we are cautiously optimistic about the upcoming holiday season and 2003, it is not possible to accurately predict demand, and therefore, actual results could differ materially from our guidance. Also, when we think about growth we are concerned with only one thing, long-term growth and free cash flow. For the December quarter, we expect net sales of between $1.325-1.425b. We expect our pro forma operating profit to be between $70-95m. When comparing with a year ago, pleas remember that this guidance incorporates $25 free super saver shipping for the entire quarter. For 2003, our baseline expectations are net sales to grow by over 10%, and we expect pro forma operating profit of over $200m. The actual amount we report could be impacted, either positively or negatively, by the long-term investments we choose to make. We cannot provide guidance on our GAAP net income. Let me remind everyone, since certain stock options are currently subject to variable accounting, we incur a charge or gain for any movement in our share price between reporting dates. Also, we mark our Euro denominated debt-to-market at the end of each quarter. The result will either be a non-cash gain or loss. We cannot forecast either of these items yet they could have a significant impact, positively or negatively, on our GAAP results. 

 Before opening it up to questions, let me close with a few final thoughts. First and foremost we are mindful of our customers, and thank them for taking advantage of our selection, convenience and pricing. We strive to always put the customer experience first and we believe that approach drives the best long-term returns to our shareowners. Second, while we are guardedly optimistic, we enter the holiday season with momentum, and we're pleased to be able to increase our guidance. We're again very enthusiastic to serve our customers as we prepare for the holiday season. Third, we are reaping the benefits of scale. While we continue to invest in lower prices and unit growth, we will also measure the progress we make toward our objective of generating significant free cash flow. Finally, all of us at Amazon.com have the same objective -- we are collectively driven to deliver to both our customers and shareowners. Thank you. With that, Tim, let's move to questions. 

 TIM HALLADAY: Great. Thanks Jeff and Mark. With that we'd like to move onto the Q and A portion of the call. In the interest of allowing as many people as possible to ask a question we ask that you limit yourself to one question. Operator, if you could remind our listeners how to ask a question, we'll proceed with the call. 

 OPERATOR: At this time, I would like to remind everyone if you would like to ask a question then please press star then the number one on your telephone keypad. The first question comes from Anthony [Nodo] with Goldman Sachs. 

 ANTHONY NODO, ANALYST, GOLDMAN SACHS: Thank you very much and good afternoon. The company obviously achieved many key important milestones in the quarter. I wanted to look forward and focus on other potential milestones, and as a smaller piece of your business, ETK. As I look at the quarter, I understand the issue with the deferred revenue. I do have one question about where that would occur on the balance sheet. But, more importantly, as we look into 4Q, and I look at your expense level in that business, is it possible that that business breaks even in 4Q based on the YoverY growth rate you're seeing already and then the improvement you'll see in gross margin when you start to recognize that deferred revenue? That's my first question. 

 My second question is, strategically, as you do the different tactics on free shipping, each tactic I can think about either driving frequency or penetration. How do you measure the return on that? The reason that I ask that specifically is that as I look at the June quarter and look at the September quarter you maintained basically the same operating income essentially at a higher revenue base. Did you accelerate your customer growths or your repeat customer growth so that you'll see a return in the future on those free shipping offers because obviously the difference between the two quarters you had about the same operating income on higher revenue. So, how should we think about the return on that free shipping? And does it occur in the future or are you already seeing that in some kind of customer metric? Thank you. 

 JEFF BEZOS: Anthony, this is Jeff. With respect to the ETK segment, and 4Q I assume you mean 4Q of next year, 15 months from now. 

 ANTHONY NODO: Actually, I was referring to this 4Q. Looking at 37... 

 JEFF BEZOS: No. Then it is a very simple question and the answer is no. Was the question could that segment be profitable this 4Q? 

 ANTHONY NODO: Yes. 

 JEFF BEZOS: No. 

 ANTHONY NODO: How should we think about the way the deferred revenue works then? If I was looking at you expense based on your current YoverY growth rate, you know, it looks like it could have been potentially, I guess without this change in the wireless service. 

 MARK PEEK: But, Anthony, the unearned revenue from the wireless business is on the unearned line item in our balance sheet, and 140 basis points to think about as a couple of million dollars of gross profit that will come in next quarter. 

 ANTHONY NODO: OK. Could you give us a perspective of the profitability of that business then in terms of next 4Q? 

 JEFF BEZOS: Well, you're talking about 4Q a year from now. If you look at the fixed costs in that business and its share are allocations and so on, that business needs to grow significantly before it can be profitable. It's possible, let's put it this way, for it be profitable in 4Q a year from now everything has to go right. So, it's possible but everything has to go exactly right. And I certainly wouldn't count on it. And we're not counting on it. 

 And then your second question was about super saver shipping, price reductions in general and how we think about that as an investment. We have a lot of fine grain data about the change in customer behavior with respect to that offer and the other offers we've done, the $49 offer, the $99 offer. And we can see, for example, if you look at order bands, what happens to volume -- how it shifts from orders between $20-25 vs. orders between $25-35. We can look at customers who bought this year and who bought in the same period in the prior year, and see which of those took us up on super saver shipping, which did not, and see what their differences, purchase rates are, how many units they're buying per unit time. We can do a lot of that kind of analysis. We like what we're seeing. We're not ready yet to declare that the $25 hurdle is going to be permanent. We feel good enough about it to declare that we're going to continue it through the holidays. But it is very expensive, and so we're being very deliberate about our decision-making process with respect to that $25 hurdle. We hope to make a final decision on whether or not that can be just a permanent part of our messaging to customers, a permanent part of how we do business, at the end of this year or the beginning of next year, which is in line with our original suggestion that it would take 3-6 months to figure that out. So, we've got a lot of data on that. In any fine grained we don't like to give that data out because we think it is competitively useful. But we certainly know a lot about how customers behave with respect to that kind of offer. The only other thing I would point out is that when you make a change like that, it takes a long time for the knowledge of that whole new price structure to seep into the minds of tens of millions of customers. So, the vast majority of our customers won't even really know, in any real way, about that offer yet. So, it's not changing their behavior. Now what that means is that initially you see more cannibalization than you will over the long term because in the beginning -- people are coming -- they would've bought it anyway, they get to the site and they're like, "Wow! I was going to buy and pay for shipping. I'm going to buy and not pay for shipping. All the better." But that's your opportunity to teach them about this. Then that gives you a chance to dramatically impact their future behavior and your share of their wallet. So, it will literally take years before we see the full benefit of what is a very expensive, but we think worthwhile, investment. 

 TIM HALLADAY: Operator, can we move on to the next question please? 

 OPERATOR: Your next question comes from Mary Meeker with Morgan Stanley. 

 TIM HALLADAY: Are you there? 

 OPERATOR: Speaker your line is open. 

 TIM HALLADAY: Operator maybe we can move on to the next question and if Mary wants to queue back in we'll catch her the next time around. 

 OPERATOR: OK. You're next question is from Jeetil Patel with Deutsche Bank. 

 JEETIL PATEL, ANALYST , DEUTSCHE BANK SECURITIES: Hi, guys. A couple of questions. Obviously, international broke even for the first time ever and it looks like a great number. If I recall, it looks like the US business broke even around the same time last year or, I think, 2Q. And since then you've put up some pretty good leverage in that business up to about 5-6% operating margins pretty quickly. Is it safe to assume that we'll see that type of leverage in the international business over the next several quarters going into 2003? Could it be even greater given the growth profile of the international business? 

 Secondly, it seems like you're getting a lot of data points on the free shipping offer out there. And it seems like the holiday season may be the right time to understand if the consumer base is recalling the free shipping over $25 promotion, and if that's working or not. But are you planning any sort of outbound marketing or advertising campaign to reach out to those customers that obviously know about Amazon quite well but haven't been back since the $25 offer has been out there? 

 JEFF BEZOS: Well, I'll take the second one first. This is Jeff. We are testing a television campaign right now. We've been testing it for many months now -- more than six months. And our plan is to continue testing that until we get statistical significance. We're testing it in just two test markets. And one of the things that that campaign does talk about is super saver shipping. So, it's primarily a convenience-oriented campaign, but it does talk about super saver shipping. So we, the other thing, the other vehicle we have that's obviously a very effective one, is the web site itself with roughly 30m visitors a month coming to the web site. We have lots of opportunities on the web site. As we get smart about how to interact with customers on the web site, in terms of teaching them the things we want them to know And that's our other great vehicle for educating folks about what is genuinely a great deal and a great offer. And we definitely want people to know it. The worst thing is having a great offer and kind of paying for it and not having everyone know about it. So it's definitely in our interest that everyone knows about that. Feel free to put it in your research reports. 

 But I do -- we'll continue to test the broad scale advertising. We're trying to do it very methodically so we actually know whether it's working. We don't want to spend a lot of money on that unless we're pretty sure that it is working. So we'll continue to do the testing. And then on-site is a huge opportunity for us just because we have so much traffic on our web site, and that's obviously been very cost effective for us. 

 MARK PEEK: Yeah, and Jeetil on the international side, certainly with these types of growth rates, we're going to drive a lot of fixed cost leverage. That said, we know that these growth aren't sustainable forever, and that when you're right at break-even, there is a chance that you will go back and forth around that number for some time. But we certainly expect our international business to be profitable in the future. And we also will make investments in the international business because they make sense again with the objective of driving long-term free cash flow growth for one (phonetic). 

 TIM HALLADAY: Thanks, [Jeetil]. Operator can we take the next call please? 

 OPERATOR: The next question comes from Lenny Baker with Salomon Smith Barney. 

 TIM HALLADAY: Lenny are you there? 

 OPERATOR: Lenny's line has been removed. 

 TIM HALLADAY: Great. Can we move on to the next question? 

 OPERATOR: Your next question comes from Mark [Mahenny] from Morgan Stanley. 

 MARY MEEKER, ANALYST, MORGAN STANLEY: Is this the line? Can you hear us? 

 TIM HALLADAY: Mary, we can hear you. 

 MARY MEEKER: Thanks. We have an echo so I apologize for that. I'm sorry we were muted last time. A couple of questions. Could you tell us a little about your expectations are for revenue per customer, trends in the 4Q trend? Do you think you'll see more new customer ads? Or given the education you're trying to do of your customers, do you think you'll see more older customers buying more products, and how we should philosophically think about that for our models? 

 And then the second question, relates to you've really been hawks on efficiency and productivity in the last years. I'd characterize it after being whales. And as you look at the model on a go forward basis do you think you'll see an inflection point for leverage in '03 or '04? And I guess it's the question is pick a year specifically related to volume and growth in third party sales. Thanks. Are you there? 

 JEFF BEZOS: Yeah. We're -- sorry, we're allocating the questions. 

 MARY MEEKER: This is mute vs. mute? Ha ha. 

 JEFF BEZOS: Sorry what was the first question? Well right. In the US we would expect to see new customer, some of both, new customer acquisition and a greater share of wallet of existing customers. That's certainly what we're hoping for. That's what we are -- the things we've been doing are designed to have that happen. Outside the US it will still be some of both, but it should be weighted a little bit more toward new customers, just because we're not as deeply penetrated there and also because we haven't introduced as many new product categories outside the US as we have inside the US. So, but, it should definitely be some of both. 

 MARY MEEKER: Well for the older customers, do you have any targets on how much you would want to see the revenue per customer go up in the 4Q? Because it's a new approach. You have a lot of new product, much better pricing, etc. 

 JEFF BEZOS: Most of our targets are set by product line or by feature set. They're not set by frequency of customer or -- we do segment our customer base. We look at the data that way but we don't set targets that way internally. Mostly because the business owners, the way we have the business organized, the business owners don't own segments of customers, they tend to own categories of products and various features sets. 

 MARK PEEK: And Mary, with respect to our cost structure you mention whale and I'm not sure if you meant the large, fat marine mammal. 

 MARY MEEKER: Just kidding. 

 MARK PEEK: or getting whaled upside the head on our cost structure. But we continue to believe that we will be able to drive productivity on our fixed cost base for the foreseeable future and it will have variable cost productivity going forward. 

 MARY MEEKER: OK. 

 TIM HALLADAY: Thanks, Mary. Operator can we take the next question please? 

 OPERATOR: Your next question comes from Justin [Valdolf] with Merrill Lynch. 

 JUSTIN VALDOLF, ANALYST, MERRILL LYNCH: Much congratulations on a nice quarter. A quick question -- a follow-up question really on free shipping. I'm wondering if you can tell us the information that's typically disclosed in your SEC filings, which is shipping revenues and shipping profits for the quarter. And if you could comment roughly on what first orders were eligible for free shipping, and then what percentage of those eligible orders actually took advantage of the program. 

 And then another question just in terms of the used business, I think it was 23% of North American units for the quarter, up from 20% last quarter. Can you talk about what categories that business is particularly strongest in, and whether or not there are significant opportunities to expand it into the site more broadly? 

 MARK PEEK: Yeah, sure. On shipping revenue for the quarter it was approximately $73m this 3Q vs. $74m a year ago. And our shipping loss for the quarter was $10m, vs. a loss of $2m in 3Q of last year. 

 TIM HALLADAY: For your information, that is in the back of the press release so anybody on the call can go find that at the back of the press release. And remind us of your second question. 

 JUSTIN VALDOLF: Oh, my second one was just about the used business, 23% of units in the quarter. Where do you think that plateaus and where is that strongest today in terms of product category? 

 JEFF BEZOS: Where that will be, kind of what the natural point is, it's 23% of units now, whether over time it should be a higher percentage or a lower percentage or how that's going to shape up, is, I think, very hard to know. And our approach to this has been to set the commission rates in such a way that, more or less, we are indifferent to whether we sell a used unit or a new unit. And then just put them both up there and let the customers decide what fraction of the business is going to be. But we're sort of indifferent to -- we're largely indifferent to the outcome. And, so, I think forecasting that, I wouldn't want to do it. I wouldn't know how to go about doing it. It's very untested and it has -- you'd have to make a lot of assumptions about future consumer behavior that I don't think anybody on this planet really knows, and we're seeing good take up of that, good coverage with listings, good seller velocity, and so on across different categories. Clearly, very strong in books but also very strong in electronics. So we're very happy about that. 

 JUSTIN VALDOLF: And you typically report the penetration from North America. Can you talk about what the used penetration is internationally? 

 JEFF BEZOS: We're very happy with what we've seen. What I can tell you is that if you look at the equivalent period of time, the launches internationally have been even more successful than the launches in the US. So, if you look - if the launches internationally are six months old now, if you look at the six-month point in the US, you see that the international units have made more progress in their first six months than the US did in the equivalent amount of time. These are -- as far as I can remember -- our fastest product launches ever. The business is doing very, very well. We're very excited about it. The international units, the international teams are very excited about it. 

 TIM HALLADAY: Thanks, Justin. Operator, can you make this our last question please? 

 OPERATOR: The next question comes from Derrick Brown with WR Hembrecht. 

 DERRICK BROWN, ANALYST, WR HEMBRECHT: Thanks. I've actually got a follow up question on the used business. In particular, could you maybe help to give a sense for what level, if any, of cannibalization you're seeing in your direct sales from used sales? And also helping us to understand your kind of inventorying strategy around the used market, if you have a difficult time forecasting where that percentage moves in terms of percentage of units? 

 JEFF BEZOS: With respect to your first question, the studies we've done have shown that the people who are purchasing used product from us are actually purchasing even more new product from us subsequent to their used purchases. So it's not at all clear that we're seeing any cannibalization. It's, of course, very difficult to ever know with certainty what's going on there. But the data that we've done looking at customers and their behavior before and after used, is very, very positive in that respect, which is not surprising to me because it basically makes our whole service more valuable. Whenever you do something that customers like, something they appreciate, something that they use, like our marketplace business that reflects well on the entire company, and you just get more share of wallet from those customers. So very, very pleased about that. 

 And the second piece of your question was what again? 

 DERRICK BROWN: Just understanding how demands on the used side may or may not be impacting your inventory strategies for the direct side of your business. 

 JEFF BEZOS: Well. It actually hasn't impacted our -- I would say one of the things that happens is that the used product has been layered in sort of over time enough that all of our computer systems and the people who do the inventory for planning have been able to adjust. But since our business has been growing it really hasn't been an issue, those people have been buying more inventory. 

 DERRICK BROWN: Great. Thank you. 

 JEFF BEZOS: You're welcome. 

 TIM HALLADAY: Thanks, Derrick. With that I want to thank everyone for joining us the call today. As a reminder, a replay of this call will be available on our investor relations web site through the end of the quarter. We look forward to talking with you again next quarter. And thanks for your interest in Amazon.com. Bye for now. 

 JEFF BEZOS: Bye, bye you guys. Thank you.

 Amazon .com  Q2  2002 Financial Results Conference Call - Final
