   LP
 OPERATOR:  Good afternoon and my name Cass (ph) and I will be conference facilitator today. 

 At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Amazon.com Q2 2002 financial results conference call.  All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise.  After the speaker's remarks there will be a question-and-answer period.  If you would like to ask a question during this time, simply press star, then the number one on your telephone keypad.  If you would like to withdraw your question press star, then the number two. 

   TD
 I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Tim Halliday (ph), Director Investor Relations. 

 Thank you.  You may begin your conference. 

 TIM HALLIDAY (ph), DIRECTOR INVESTOR RELATIONS, AMAZON.COM:  Good afternoon and welcome to the Amazon.com second quarter 2002 conference call.  Joining me on today's call are Jeff Bezos, our CEO and Mark Peak (ph), our Vice President and Chief Accounting Officer. 

 Please keep in mind that the following discussion and responses to your questions reflect management's views as of today, July 23rd, 2002 only and will include forward-looking statements.  Our actual results may differ materially from those projected. 

 Additional information about factors that potentially could affect Amazon.com's financial results is included in today's press release and the Company's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission including this Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2001 and all subsequent filings. 

 As you listen to today's call, I would encourage you to have our press release in front of you since all of our financial results, as well as commentary on the quarter, are included and will correspond to much of the discussion that follows.  You will also find a table, which reconciles our GAAP results to pro forma results.  Pro forma results are included for the benefit of investors as they have been and continue to be a useful analytical companion to our GAAP results. Unless otherwise stated, all comparisons used in this call will be against our results for the comparable period of 2001. 

 With that introduction, I'll turn the call over to Jeff. 

 JEFF BEZOS, PRESIDENT AND CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, AMAZON.COM:  Thanks Tim.  Good afternoon everyone. 

 We're very excited about our results this quarter and especially pleased with the outstanding job our books team's doing, posting another quarter of 20 percent year-over-year book unit growth, up from 15 percent growth this past fourth quarter. 

 While the music business has been challenging for everyone, our resurgence in books has been able to temper the impact.  Also, electronics, tools and kitchen revenues reaccelerated with customer experience enhancements such as lower prices and increased selection. 

 Since the beginning of the year, electronic selection expanded 40 percent to over 60,000 items including authorized product from industry leaders such as Sony, Toshiba, Microsoft and Yamaha. 

 Our International business also continues to execute with trailing 12-month revenues reaching 845 million and revenue growth still exceeding 70 percent.  As far as our top line performance has been, you should also be assured to look at the bottom line results where we've made even more progress. 

 With the remainder of my time today, I'd like to talk primarily about two things, our strategy of relentlessly lowering price and the success of our third party business.  Let me talk first about price. The results this quarter are a third consecutive data point that lowering prices is working for us. 

 Let me put this in context, last July after nearly two years spent almost exclusively focused on lowering our cost structure, we reached a point where we could afford to balance growth and cost improvement. At that time we increased the discount on books over $20 to 30 percent off. Then in January, we introduced a year-round free shipping option on orders over $99.  In April, we lowered the threshold for the 30 percent discount to $15 and just a month ago; we introduced a long-term test, which lowers the threshold for free super saver shipping to $49. 

 In addition to the highly visible changes, during the first half of this year we've also been sharpening prices on many items throughout the store particularly in electronics and DVDs. 

 Lowering price for customers along with driving selection and convenience are the pillars of our strategy and it's working.  As evidence, look to the results from each of our last three quarters. As you probably would have expected following our various pricing actions over the last year, our sales growth reaccelerated to 15 percent growth in Q4 and 21 percent growth in the most recent two quarters.  However, what may not have been expected is that our operating margins would increase at such a rapid pace reaching 3.2 percent of sales in Q2 an increase of over 740 basis points year-over-year.  On a trailing 12-month basis, our pro forma operating profit was $82 million or 2.4 percent of sales, an improvement of over $285 million year-over-year. 

 In Q2, even with lower book prices, sharper pricing in many of our non-media stores and free super saver shipping, you saw significantly improved operating results.  Books, music and video operating profit increased 26 percent, reaching a record 12 percent operating margin an increase of nearly 150 basis points from Q1 on seasonally lower sales. 

 Equally impressive, our ETK sales continue to reaccelerate from the eight percent growth in Q1 to 16 percent growth in Q2 while ETK segment losses improved 55 percent.  Customers are continuing to learn that Amazon.com is an excellent choice not only for media but for electronics, tools and kitchen as well. 

 Price reductions are a big deal to customers but can be expensive for Amazon.com in the short-term.  For example, we expect our current test of free super saver shipping with the $49 threshold to have a negative impact on Q3 margins as customers take advantage of lower prices in advance of offsetting incremental demand.  However, over the long-term, the rewards of relentlessly lowering price when and as the company can afford to do so are enormous as increases in unit volume flow across our fixed cost structure.  We make such price reductions possible by focusing on productivity in every area of the company. 

 In Q2 our pro forma operating expenses decreased seven percent on a 321 percent increase in revenue.  Let me give you some examples of how we achieved this.  Pro forma expense was 10.6 percent of sales, an improvement from the prior year of almost 220 basis points.  One of the most important things we've done to improve variable costs productivity also happens to be a huge driver of convenience and experience for customers, eliminating mistakes and errors at their root. 

 Every year that's gone by since Amazon.com's founding, we've done a better and better job of eliminating errors.  This quarter our U.S. fulfillment centers drove a nearly 50 percent reduction in their controllable defects.  Worldwide units shipped per labor hour improved 22 percent year-over-year and worldwide customer service contacts per order declined 30 percent from the prior year primarily because when you do things right the first time customers don't need to contact you. 

 Inventory turns continue to increase and are now 19 on a trailing 12-month basis, an increase of 35 percent year-over-year.  As you would expect, this high number of inventory turns reduces liquidation's and improves capital velocity both of which save us money. 

 We've also seen a substantial improvement in technology expense, which was 7.2 percent of sales in Q2, a decline over a year ago of almost 250 basis points as a result of several factors including moving to a more efficient hardware platform. 

 In addition to our improvements in variable cost productivity, we believe our business is poised to further demonstrate its powerful operating leverage.  Looking ahead for the foreseeable future, we believe we can largely hold our fixed costs fixed while driving profitable increases in volume over the base.  The result is fixed cost productivity that drops straight to the bottom line and becomes available for further price reductions band the best news of all, is that we believe we can continue to drive both fixed and variable productivity for years to come allowing us to continue returning those savings to customers in the form of lower prices. 

 Now, let me move on to our third party business, which includes both our marketplace sellers and our merchant SAT service partners.  About two years ago we started our third party services business with Toys-R-Us.com.  A few months later as part of our single store strategy we first offered customers the opportunity to shop for used products right along side new ones.  Since those first introductions, momentum with third party sellers has taken off as big sellers like Target and Circuit City have added apparel, kitchen, electronics and other selection to our highly trafficked product detail pages. 

 That our customers love the added selection is evidenced by our over 30 million visitors a month and the fact that in Q2 an astonishing 20 percent of U.S. units, representing 35 percent of all U.S. orders were purchased from third party sellers, often from customers that had not previously bought from Amazon.com.  In the last year over 40 percent of the people who made purchases at Amazon.com bought from one of our third party sellers. 

 Also, our marketplace business in Germany and the U.K. is growing approximately twice as fast as the U.S. marketplace business was four months after its launch.  As you would imagine our customers around the world love the increased selection our third party business provides. 

 And before I turn it over to Mark, let me talk about one last topic. We've made the decision to begin expensing stock options and other stock-based awards.  This'll take effect by the beginning of 2003. The best thing about expensing stock options is that it opens the door to more carefully crafted equity incentives.  For example, today in order to avoid expensing stock options under current accounting rules, strike prices must be set at the date of grant. 

 In a volatile stock market employees that start just days apart can have dramatically different strike prices.  A much more rational system of studying the strike price would be to average the price over a 30-day period following the start of employment.  However, any company that would take that more rational approach would be forced to expense the stock options.  This is just one small example.  Our decision to expense stock options also opens the door to thinking about ideas such as restricted stock and indexed options that might better align the incentives of employees with shareholders.  Employee ownership was one of the founding tenets of Amazon.com and without a doubt one of the major reasons Amazon.com has been successful to date is our broad commitment to employee ownership.  That commitment won't change. 

 And with that I'll turn it to Mark. 

 MARK PEAK (ph), VICE PRESIDENT AND CHIEF ACCOUNTING OFFICER, AMAZON.COM:  Thanks Jeff and hello everyone. 

 This was another great quarter for Amazon.com.  First, our positive business trends continued.  Revenue growth exceeded 20 percent for the second consecutive quarter, reaching $806 million.  Pro forma operating profit was $26 million or 3.2 percent of sales.  For the trailing 12 months, pro forma operating profit reached $82 million or 2.4 percent of sales.  Pro forma net loss, which includes interest expense, was $4 million or a penny per share compared with a loss of 16 cents per share a year ago.  Free cash flow was $16 million on a trailing 12-month basis, a year-over-year improvement of $285 million.  Adjusted free cash flow, which is reduced for capital lease payments, was essentially break even on a trailing 12-month basis.  Common stock outstanding was 380 million shares at June 30th, an increase of five percent compared with the prior year with approximately half of the increase related to a $100 million investment by America Online one year ago.  Trailing 12-month inventory turns were 19, an increase of 35 percent. 

 Second, as Jeff discussed, our success continued in our third party business.  Our customers, both buyers and sellers, love the service. 

 Third, the productivity loop works.  Productivity has given us the flexibility to invest in lower prices to customers.  New product offerings like Marketplace and Amazon.ca our Canadian Web site, while continuing improves our financial performance. 

 We are very pleased with the quarter but we recognize there is still much to do.  We must continue to improve the customer experience, continue to drive cost productivity and continue to increase demand by offering a compelling value proposition to our customers. 

 Now I'd like to discuss our results in more detail Q2 performance trends.  Second quarter revenue was $806 million, up 21 percent from the prior year.  Active customers, those purchasing in the last 12 months total 27 million, a 30 percent year-over-year increase.  Gross profit increased by $38 million or 21 percent to $218 million.  Gross margin was up 16 basis points to 27.1 percent exceeding 27 percent for the first time.  Gross margin improved primarily as a result of Marketplace sales, improvements in procurement and transportation related savings and was partially offset by price reductions to customers including the cost of free super saver shipping.  As a result of inbound freight savings and shipment injections, we were able to cover the cost of lost revenue related to our $99 super saver-shipping offer allowing us to migrate to our current $49 offer. 

 Now I'll turn to the segments.  Revenue in the books, music and video segment was $412 million, an increase of six percent.  Books unit growth was 20 percent, offset by the industry trend of slow growth in our music business.  Despite significant price reductions and foregone shipping revenue, gross profit for the segment was up 12 percent while gross margin reached an all-time high of 30 percent. 

 Segment pro forma operating profit was $49 million, up 26 percent year-over-year while operating margin also increased to a record 12 percent of sales.  On a trailing 12-month basis-operating margin for the segment reached 11 percent, a year-over-year increase of over 300 basis points. 

 In June, Virgin Entertainment Group of North America re-launched its U.S. Web site, Virginmega.com as a co-branded book, music and video store powered by our e-commerce platform.  Later this year, Virgin will re-launch their Japanese Web site, which will be powered by Amazon.co.jp. 

 Additionally, we recently launched our Canadian Web site, Amazon.ca. By selecting Assured Logistics, a part of the Canada Post group of companies to handle fulfillment services we were able to launch Amazon.ca in a capital efficient manner.  We are offering access to a growing selection of 1.5 million book, music and video titles in both English and French.  Additionally, our Canadian customers will receive introductory free shipping on orders over 75 Canadian dollars.  Early feedback is positive.  Our Canadian customers love their newfound convenience, selection at low prices and much faster delivery times. 

 ETK, in electronics, tools and kitchen, revenue increased 16 percent to $128 million.  Gross profit for the segment increased 41 percent while gross margin was up over 250 basis points to 14 percent.  The ETK segment loss declined 55 percent to $18 million or 14 percent of sales compared with 37 percent a year ago. 

 During the quarter we became a Sony authorized Internet reseller for digital cameras and camcorders, PDA handhelds, computers and monitors. Additionally, we opened authorized relationships with Microsoft and Toshiba plus Yamaha's home theater product line.  Thus, since December 31st, our electronics selection has increased nearly 40 percent to over 60,000 items. 

 International.  International segment revenue reached $218 million. The third consecutive quarter of 70 percent or better year-over-year increases.  Gross profit was $47 million, an improvement of $18 million or 61 percent.  International segment pro forma operating loss declined 66 percent to $10 million, an improvement of $20 million compared with the prior year.  Although the dollar was weaker against European currency versus the first quarter, on a year-over-year, the impact of exchange rates on our International segment revenue was less than $100,000. 

 While International growth rates must ultimately slow we continue to be optimistic about this segment.  In the U.K. and Germany, we are finding that sellers and customers are as enthusiastic about our Marketplace offering as they are in the United States. 

 Additionally, with new forms of payment, such as cash-on-delivery in Japan and invoicing in Germany we are attracting many new customers. In Japan we surpassed one million active customer accounts during the quarter. 

 Including exports, International revenue represented 34 percent of the company sales, up from 28 percent a year ago. 

 Services.  Service revenue increased $8 million or 22 percent to $47 million while our gross margin was 61 percent, down from 68 percent a year ago.  We expect margins will continue to decline over the year as our fixed fee, higher margin advertising arrangements originally struck in 1999 represent a lower percentage of our overall revenue mix. Segment operating profit was $6 million, a 29 percent increase over the prior year. 

 Last week we started providing shopping functionality for AOL customers.  Over the next several months we will launch Target.com, powered by Amazon.com and expand the selection of Target products at Amazon.com. 

 Now moving to the operating expense portion of the income statement. Fulfillment costs were $86 million or 10.6 percent of sales, down approximately 220 basis points from 12.8 percent a year ago. 

 Marketing was $29 million, a decline of 17 percent from a year earlier due primarily to our move to more efficient means of advertising and reductions in the rates that we are paying for traffic generation. 

 Pro forma operating profit was $26 million versus the loss of $28 million in the second quarter of 2001, an improvement of $54 million. This was our third consecutive quarter of operating profits.  Our operating margin improved 740 basis points to three percent.  Pro forma net loss, which includes interest expense, was $4 million or a penny per share compared with a loss of 16 cents per share a year ago. 

 On a GAAP basis, our net loss for the quarter was $94 million or 25 cents per share.  This compares with a second quarter 2001 net loss of $168 million or 47 cents per share.  As you consider our GAAP results keep in mind that each quarter that we mark our Euro denominated debt-to-market, which resulted in a charge of $71 million in the second quarter.  We also recognized an expense of $23 million for stocks-based compensation primarily as the result of the upward movement in our share price. 

 Cash flow.  Trailing 12-month operating cash flow reached $48 million, an improvement of over $200 million.  While free cash flow was $16 million on a trailing 12-month basis, an improvement of $285 million year-over-year. 

 Let me move to asset efficiency.  Ending inventory of $127 million reached its lowest level since September 1999 while our ability to serve customers with in-stock selection continues to get better. Inventory turns were 29 on a trailing 12-month basis, an improvement of 35 percent.  We encourage you to use this metric to other world-class retailers; it is truly an astonishing achievement. 

 At June 30th, prepaid and other current assets increased approximately $20 million because a credit card service provider unintentionally failed to make a scheduled payment.  Our net investment in fixed assets was $250 million, a 15 percent decrease from a year ago. 

 We ended the quarter with cash and marketable securities of approximately $824 million.  Please note that we received proceeds from employee stock options of $43 million during the quarter.  These proceeds were excluded from our measurement of operating and free cash flows. 

 I'll conclude my portion of today's call with our guidance for Q3 and an update on our guidance for the year.  Incorporated into our Q3 and 2002 guidance are the results that we have seen to date and what we believe, today, to be appropriately conservative assumptions. However, we also recognize that it is not possible to accurately predict demand and therefore our actual results could differ materially from our guidance. 

 Also, when we think about growth, we are concerned with only one thing, long-term growth and free cash flow. 

 Now to the guidance.  For the September quarter we expect net sales of between $780 and $830 million.  We expect our pro forma operating profit to be between $8 million and $17 million.  When comparing to Q2, please remember that our $49 super saver-shipping offer ran for only the last two weeks of the quarter. 

 For the full year, we expect net sales to grow by over 18 percent.  We expect pro forma net income, which means we will cover our interest expense for the year.  We also expect to spend approximately $50 million in cap ex and finally we expect to generate free cash flow for the year. 

 We cannot provide guidance on our GAAP net income.  Let me remind everyone since we expense certain stock options we incur a charge or gain for any movement in our share price between reporting dates.  As Jeff mentioned, we also intend to expense future stock options and other stock-based compensation beginning no later than January 2003. This will impact the accounting for equity awards granted after that time. 

 Also, we mark our Euro denominated debt-to-market at the end of each quarter.  The result will be either a non-cash gain or loss.  We cannot forecast either of these items, yet they could have a significant impact either positively or negatively on our GAAP results. 

 Before opening it up to questions, let me close with a few final thoughts.  First and foremost we are mindful of our customers and thank them for taking advantage of our selection, convenience and pricing.  We strive to always put the customer experience first.  We believe that approach drives the best long-term returns for our shareowners. 

 Second, we enter the back half of 2002 with momentum and we're pleased to be able to increase our guidance for the remainder of the year. 

 Third, we are reaping the benefits of scale.  We will continue to invest in lower prices but we will also measure the progress we make toward our objective of generating significant free cash flow. 

 Finally, all of us at Amazon.com have the same objective.  We are collectively driven to deliver for both our customers and shareowners. Thanks and with that Tim, let's move to questions. 

 TIM HALLIDAY (ph):  Great.  Thanks Jeff and Mark. 

 With that we'd like to move on to the Q&A portion of the call.  In the interest of allowing as many people as possible to ask a question, we ask that you limit yourself to one question. 

 Operator, if you could remind our listeners how to ask a question, we'll proceed with the call. 

 OPERATOR:  At this time, I would like to remind everyone in order to ask a question, please press star, then the number one on your telephone keypad. 

 We'll pause for just a moment to compile the Q&A roster. 

 Your first question comes from Sean Milne (ph) of  Soundview Technologies (ph). 

 SEAN MILNE (ph), SOUNDVIEW TECHNOLOGIES:  Thank you and good afternoon. 

 Jeff, I wondered if you could just talk a little bit more about the used products business, obviously another very big quarter there, clearly trading top line growth for better margin.  What's your expectation for the business in the next couple quarters?  Does it grow as a percent of BMV or do you think we're going to top out at the current level?  Any additional color would be great.  Thank you. 

 JEFF BEZOS:  Well certainly that business, the Marketplace business grew very rapidly this quarter and we expect it to continue to grow. You know, I'd love to see our retail business also growing so fast but in terms of mix that, you know, there's good competition there. 

 So, you know, what we're really driving for is unit growth.  We don't really care whether those units are Marketplace units or whether they are owned inventory units and so we've tried to price those things so that we are, you know, more or less indifferent to which kind of unit get sold and then we just let the Marketplace the way it will. 

 I do expect it to continue and certainly outside the U.S. where those businesses are just getting started, you know, our early experience would indicate that we're going to have the same kind of success there outside the U.S. that we've had inside the U.S. but, you know, we'll have to wait and see for sure but that's certainly what it looks like right now. 

 SEAN MILNE (ph):  Thank you. 

 TIM HALLIDAY (ph):  Thanks Sean (ph), can we take the next question please? 

 OPERATOR:  Your next question comes from Jiteal Bitell (ph) of Deutsche Bank Securities. 

 JITEAL BITELL (ph), DEUTSCHE BANK SECURITIES:  Hey guys, obviously quite a bit of success on the retail side, on the BMV side in particular and the Marketplace side. 

 I guess - have you guys thought about or have you talked about any sort of timing as it relates to the technology platform to open it up to obviously a broad class of sellers that, you know, fit the current categories that you're addressing and outside of - or categories also that you're not addressing from a Marketplace standpoint?  I guess from a technology standpoint, are ready to handle that type of load and you know is there timeframe that you start to look in broadening the overall platform? 

 JEFF BEZOS:  Well we've been - it's a very good question and we've been working now for probably almost three years building the various tools that sellers use on our platform today.  You know we've done a huge amount of build out over the last nine months or so preparing for the Target.com launch, which is coming up and there are on our list of projects to do, still a large number of projects that we'll sort of do what you're talking about.  Sort of upgrade the platform to make it easier for parties of all kinds to sell right along side us on our own detail pages where the 30 million visitors and that's the U.S. number by the way.  The worldwide number is much larger, the monthly visitor number. 

 So the basic answer to your question is we're not there yet.  We're not where we want to be.  We've made huge progress over the last couple of years.  There's a huge amount of progress still to come in terms of upgrading our systems to make it really great for third party sellers. It's working today.  It can be much better.  We know what we have to do and we've got good people working on it. 

 TIM HALLIDAY (ph):  Thanks Jiteal (ph).  Operator can we take the next question, please? 

 OPERATOR:  Your next question comes from Mary Meager (ph) of Morgan Stanley. 

 MARY MEAGER (ph), MORGAN STANLEY:  Thanks, Mark and I just have a couple simple questions. 

 Jeff, could you provide a little more color on unit growth?  You talked about the book business but if you could provide us some color across the difference business lines that would be great and do you have any customer growth objectives you're willing to share with us? Thanks. 

 JEFF BEZOS:  No, the only unit growth figure that we're giving out is for books.  We are - we'll be giving, you know, sort of spot figures from time to time to give people insight into various businesses but we're not intending to make it a regular practice of giving out the unit growth figures on a segment-by-segment or product category-by-product category business. 

 In terms of guidance on customer growth, you know, in a similar vein we certainly would expect customer growth to continue but we're not going to get into the habit either of giving guidance on any of our line items or on customer growth. 

 MARY MEAGER (ph):  OK.  Thanks. 

 TIM HALLIDAY (ph):  Thank you Mary.  Operator can we take the next question, please? 

 OPERATOR:  Your next question comes from Antony Noto (ph) of Goldman Sachs. 

 ANTONY NOTO (ph), GOLDMAN SACHS:  Two questions really. 

 The first is, could you walk through how the customer behavior has changed sort of in three phases when you initially went to the free shipping offer, the before and after period and then when you went to the $49 hurdle rate just recently?  I know it's only been five weeks but did you see a change in penetration growth across those three phases as well as average order size and then, secondly, philosophically, I know that you've debated internally managing both growth and profitability and we've gone through phases of focusing on each and now it's a balance of both.  As I look at the quarter's results you came in above the high end of your revenue expectations, which is the mid-point of the range was like 790 so you're above that.  You had record level gross margins of 27 percent.  You launched the free shipping offer with two weeks left in the quarter, which says you've decided, you know, spend back on growth a little bit. 

 As we look into Q3 and you give guidance of a record growth rate since, you know, fourth quarter of 2000 you're forecasting middle of the range growth of 26 percent, which you haven't done since the fourth quarter of 2000, if you get through the quarter and you're showing strong momentum there, will you continue to spend back on growth to stay within your range or will you try to really drive to the bottom line? Thanks. 

 JEFF BEZOS:  Good questions. 

 The main thing that we've seen with the - you're right to point out it's only been a few weeks with the $49 super saver shipping and we said at the time that we would do that probably for three to six months while we assessed it because one of the things we know about these kinds of offers is that you have to be very cautious about how you interpret the early results.  It takes time for the word to spread, that you can get free shipping when, you know, only have to buy $49 worth of stuff and you can get free shipping.  Takes time for people to learn that and so on and so on. 

 So it is way early to comment on it.  You know early one of the things just to give you some color that we've seen is that it has impacted certain product categories more than others and we've seen that kind of behavior before but we noticed it a little bit more with the $49 super saver shipping test.  So we're studying that behavior trying to figure out what we can learn from it so that it can help us, you know, pick our next steps. 

 In terms of the balance between growth and profitability, what we basically internally we have certain minimum unit growth rates that we're trying to generate and we are, you know, constrained by being able to afford to do so we think one of the most effective ways to hit those unit growth rate targets is by using price as a lever.  So it can be product price or it can be things like super saver shipping but we have, you know, for each of our sort of product categories we have unit growth rates that we think are appropriate and we're trying to, you know, adjust our business to achieve those growth rates and then we have a very hard constraint on the minimum amount of free cash flow that we're willing to accept over time and we balance off those two things against each other.  So that's the way we think about those kinds of decisions. 

 ANTONY NOTO (ph):  So is it fair to say philosophically when you give a revenue guidance range you're basically going to manage to -- you're not manage above the high end of that range unless you're significantly beat the bottom line because you want to basically manage both. 

 JEFF BEZOS:  We don't have -- I think one of the things that your question might assume is that we have sort of very short-term control over the revenue bottom line trade-off and I would not think about our business that way.  So for example, when you sell off through the $49 super saver shipping offer in the last two weeks of the quarter, that was not designed to try and increase revenues in that quarter or anything like that.  That just happened to be the time that we were ready to do that test. 

 And indeed, you know, what we find is that when you reduce price generally it takes time for the elasticity result that you're looking for to creep in to that decision and we've learned something about that price elasticity.  But these things are not fine tuneable in periods of time measured on weeks.  You know it's the kind of thing that we can figure out measured over months and quarters. 

 ANTONY NOTO (ph):  Great.  Thank you very much. 

 JEFF BEZOS:  Thank you. 

 TIM HALLIDAY (ph): Tthank you Antony (ph).  Operator, can we take the next question, please? 

 OPERATOR:  Your next question comes from Market Roland (ph) of Prudential Securities. 

 MARKET ROLAND (ph), PRUDENTIAL SECURITIES:  Thank you. 

 Jeff, you had a full quarter of lowering the book discounts to 30 percent off on books of $15 and above, can you give us a sense of the elasticity there and is there more room to go?  Is there more elasticity if you drop that to say, $10 or all books or is $15 kind of the bottom end of where the elasticity ends and then could you also tie that into the early results you're seeing from the $49 freight hurdle and what that's done to elasticity so far?  Thank you. 

 JEFF BEZOS:  So in response to the first part of that, there certainly would be -- we know enough about now I think we can safely say that, you know, we think there would be elasticity if you were to take that 30 percent off hurdle down to $10 or $5 or zero.  Yes, you would see elasticity there. 

 The problem with doing that is that then you run risk of making those units on sort of a per unit basis unprofitable.  So when you look at the variable cost of handling a unit, it costs us about the same to handle a $7 paperback as it does to handle a $30 hardcover and so obviously when you look at the number of gross profit dollars that you have left over after applying a 30 percent discount you have a lot more gross profit dollars if you're doing that to an expensive item than you do to a very inexpensive item. 

 So it's not so much whether there would be elasticity if we were to take that hurdle down from $15 to $5 that would be there.  I feel very confident about that.  The problem would be that I'm not sure those units would then be profitable and so you'd get a skewed behavior of customers.  They would choose those units.  They would buy more of those units and you might not be making money on them so it's not clear that you want to sell a lot of those units. 

 MARKET ROLAND (ph):  So basically the $15 then is sort of getting towards the bottom end of the range where is if you discounted books lower than that your gross profit dollars might not be higher even though you're gross profit margins would be lower as it has been when you lowered it on $20 books? 

 JEFF BEZOS:  I suspect that $15 is somewhere around the right level. Whether it's exactly the right level or whether it can still come down some, you know, I guess I wouldn't want to comment on that, leave ourselves some flexibility there but certainly I don't think it would ever go down to zero.  I think that would be too far. 

 And then, what was the second part? 

 MARKET ROLAND (ph):  Just early comments on the elasticity of the $49 freight hurdle and also if you could sort of run through the same analysis with that, whether it in fact will give you more gross profit dollars even though a lower margin? 

 JEFF BEZOS:  Well it's still too early to know what kind of offsetting volume we're going to get with the $49.  So we need more.  We're going to continue this experiment and see what we learn over the next, you know, two to five months and but what I can tell you is in just the first few weeks of this quarter and, you know, it's very, very early and so I wouldn't want people to extrapolate from this but we are seeing, you know, we are continuing to see good books unit growth in the first few weeks of this quarter. 

 MARKET ROLAND (ph):  Thank you. 

 JEFF BEZOS:  Thank you. 

 TIM HALLIDAY (ph):  Thanks Mark.  Operator, can we take the next question, please and we'll take two more questions. 

 OPERATOR:  Your next question comes from Justin Baldoff (ph) of Merrill Lynch. 

 JUSTIN BALDOFF (ph), MERRILL LYNCH:  Hi, thanks a lot and congrats on a great quarter. 

 Just a quick question, if you could comment on the competitive environment and if some of the other retailers and e-tailers (ph) have recently lowered - have introduced free shipping programs of their own, I know there's been some quite a bit of press about price wars. Have you been able to gauge any impact from any of those competitive moves? Thanks. 

 JEFF BEZOS:  Well I think the best thing I can tell you there - well first of all a little bit of background, you know, we definitely consider ourselves the leaders in this particular space and we are proactive about setting our own pricing agenda.  So you know, we think we understand elasticity and customer behavior in response to price better than anybody out there.  We've just been doing it a long time. We've been thinking about it a lot.  I think we understand it very well. We have a ton of data from our very large customer base.  We get to see results from experiments much faster than anybody else in a statistically significant way because of that large customer base and high sales.  So we think we know a lot about that.  We're definitely setting those prices the way we think they should be set and then in terms of, you know, have we seen any impact on this, I think the best thing I can share with you is the thing I just said a few seconds ago, which is that in the first few weeks here of this new quarter, even though it is very, very early to be sure, we are very pleased with the continued book unit growth that we've seen. 

 JUSTIN BALDOFF (ph):  Great.  Thanks a lot. 

 JEFF BEZOS:  Thank you. 

 TIM HALLIDAY (ph):  Thanks Justin.  Operator, can we make this our last question, please? 

 OPERATOR:  Yes sir, your final question comes Jeff Feeler (ph) of Bear Stearns. 

 JEFF FEELER (ph), BEAR STEARNS:  Hi.  I guess I'll let Mark answer a question.  It seems like Jeff's been taking most of them. 

 Question for you Mark is, if you have expensed stock options this quarter as you're planning to do beginning in 2003, do you have an estimate of what the impact would be on both the - I guess just the income statement? 

 MARK PEAK (ph):  Jeff I don't and as you know we do expense stock options from the exchange offer that we made in the first quarter of 2001.  As Jeff pointed out, what we're looking at is a number of ways to offer equity instruments be they options or whatever the instrument might be and until we spend a bit more time studying what we'll do in the future it's hard for us to predict what the future impact will be. 

 JEFF BEZOS:  Well except to say that it will be negative. 

 MARK PEAK (ph):  Definitely it will be negative. 

 JEFF FEELER (ph):  All right.  Fair enough. 

 TIM HALLIDAY (ph):  Jeff thanks. 

 With that I want to thank everybody for joining us on the call today. As a reminder, a replay of this call will be available on our investor relations Web site through the end of the quarter.  We look forward to talking to you again next quarter and thanks for your interest in Amazon.com. 

 Bye for now. 

 JEFF BEZOS:  Thank you, you guys. 

 OPERATOR:  This concludes today's Amazon.com Q2 2002 financial results conference call.  You may now disconnect.

 Abstract of  Q2  2002  Amazon .com Earnings Conference Call - Final

   LP
 CORPORATE PARTICIPANTS 

 . Jeff Bezos, Chairman, President, CEO   . Mark Peet (phonetic), VP, Chief Accounting Officer   . Tim Halladay, Dir., Investor Relations 

   TD
 OVERVIEW 

 Company reported revenues of $806m, for a pro forma operating profit of $26m, and a pro forma net loss of $0.01 per share. Expects 3Q02 revenues pf $780-830m and a pro forma operating profit of $8-17m. QA session touched on elasticity of revenues in response to customer incentives. 

 FINANCIAL DATA 

 A. Key Data From Call   1. 3Q02 Revenues Guidance=$780-830m   2. 3Q02 Operating Profit (Pro Forma)=$8-17m   3. 2Q02 Revenues=$806m   4. 2Q02 QoverQ Revenues Growth=21%   5. 2Q02 Trailing Four Quarters Free Cash Flow=$16m   6. 2Q02 2Q02 Net Sales=$806m   7. 2Q02 Operating Profit (pro forma)=$26m   8. 2Q02 Operating Margin=3%   9. 2Q02 Net Loss (Pro Forma)=$4m   10. 2Q02 Net Loss Per Share (Pro Forma)=$0.01   11. 2Q02 Net Loss (GAAP)=$94m   12. 2Q02 Net Loss Per Share (GAAP)=$0.25m   13. 2Q02 Gross Profit=$38m   14. 2Q02 Gross Margin=27.1%   15. Cash and Marketable Securities=$824m 

 PRESENTATION SUMMARY 

 A. Operational Review (JB)   1. Excited about 2Q02 results.   2. Saw book unit growth of 20% YoverY growth, up from 15% in past      four quarters.   3. Music sales challenging as for everyone, but books helped offset      this.   4. Saw improvements in electronics, tools and kitchen (ETK)      revenues. Electronics selection expanded 40% YoverY. 5. International business continues to execute with trailing 12 month revenues of $845m and revenue growth exceeding 70%.   6. Topline improvements good, bottom line even better.   7. Third consecutive data point in which lowering prices is working      for company.   8. Last July, after nearly two years focusing exclusively on cost structure, decided company could afford to balance growth and      cost improvement.   9. Increased discount on books over $20 to 30%. In January,      introduced year round free shipping option on orders over $99.      In April, lowered threshhold for 30% discount to $15. A month ago, introduced long-term test lowering threshhold for free super-saver shipping to $49.   10. Also sharpened prices in 1H02, particularly electronics and      DVDs.   11. Lowering price, driving selection and convenience are pillars      of strategy.   12. In last three quarters, sales growth accelerated as expected      from pricing actions. But operating margins also improved at a      rapid pace, reaching 3.2% of sales in 2Q02, an increase of over      740 basis points YoverY.   13. On trailing 12-month basis, pro forma operating profit was      $82m, 2.4% of sales, improvement of over $285m YoverY. 14. Even with lower book prices, sharpened pricing in many stores and free super-saver shipping, saw significantly improved      operating results.   15. Books, music and video (BMV) operating profit increased 26% to      12% operating margin, an increase of 150 basis points from 1Q02      on seasonally lower sales.   16. ETK sales continued to re-accelerate from 8% growth in 1Q02 to      16% in 2Q02. ETK segment losses improved 55%.   17. Customers see company as choice for media and also ETK.   18. Price reductions good tool for customers, but can be expensive      for company in short-term. Expect super-saver shipping initiative to have negative effect on 3Q02 margins.   19. See rewards of relentlessly lowering price, when it is      affordable to company, to be enormous as volume increases flow      across fixed cost structure. Productivity focus aids this      strategy.   20. 2Q02 pro forma operating expense decreased 7% on a 21% increase      in revenues.   21. Pro forma expense was 10.6% of sales, 220 basis points better      than prior year.   22. Improved variable cost productivity while driving convenience      for customers by eliminating mistakes and errors. Saw 50%      reduction in controllable defects. Worldwide units shipped per      labor hour improved 22% YoverY and customer service contacts per      order declined 30%.   23. Inventory turns increased to 19 on trailing 12-month basis, up      35% YoverY.   24. High number of turns reduces liquidations and improves capital      velocity.   25. Significant improvement in technology expense, 7.2% of sales in 2Q02, decline of 250 basis points from prior year period, driven      by several factors including move to more efficient hardware platform.   26. Improvements in variable cost productivity gives opportunity to      show operating leverage. In foreseeable future, believe company      can hold fixed costs while driving profitable volume increases      across base.   27. Result is fixed cost profitability that drops to the bottom      line and becomes available for further price reductions.   28. Believe can drive fixed and variable productivity for years to      come.   29. Third party business includes Marketplace and merchant      partners.   30. Two years ago, launched third party business with toysrus.com.      As part of single-store strategy, then offered customers      opportunity to shop for used products alongside new ones.   31. Momentum of third party sellers has since taken off with third      party sellers like Target and Circuit City, adding apparel,      electronics and other selections to product detail pages.   32. Success of initiative shown by company's 30m Web site visitors      a month. In 2Q02, 20% of US units, representing 35% of all US      orders, were purchased through third party sellers. Many of      these were customers who had not previously bought from company.   33. Over 40% of people purchasing from company bought from third      party sellers.   34. Marketplace business in Germany and UK growing twice as fast as      US Marketplace business four months after its launch.   35. Made decision to begin expensing stock options and other      stock-based award starting in FY03.   36. Opens door to more carefully crafted equity incentives.   37. For example, today strike prices must be set on date of grant.      In volatile stock market, employees  starting just days apart      can have dramatically different strike prices. More rational      system would set strike price at average price over 30-day      period from start of employment. But approach would require      expensing of stock options.   38. Expensing opens door to thinking about ideas such as restricted      stock and indexed options that might better align employees' and shareholders' interests.   39. Employee ownership is a founding tenet of company and major      reason for its success. Commitment will not change. 

 B. Operational Review By Segment (MP)   1. Revenues growth for 2Q02 exceeded 20% for second consecutive      quarter, reaching $806m.   2. Pro forma operating profit was $26m, 3.2% of sales, in 2Q02. For trailing 12-months, operating profit was $82m or 2.4% of sales.   3. Pro forma net loss, including interest expense, was $4m or $0.01      per share in 2Q02, vs. loss of $0.16 per share in 2Q01.   4. Free cash flow was $16m on a trailing 12-month basis, up $285m      YoverY.   5. Adjusted free cash flow, which is reduced for capital lease payments, was essentially breakeven on trailing 12-month basis.   6. Common stock outstanding was 380m shares on 6/30/2002,  up 5%      from prior year. Half of increase was result of $100m investment      by AOL about one year ago.   7. Trailing 12-month inventory turns were 19, an increase of 35%.   8. Third party business a success.   9. Productivity loop works, giving flexibility to lower prices and      invest in new product offerings like Marketplace and amazon.ca,      our Canadian website, while continuing to improve financial      performance.   10. Recognize there is still much to do.   11. Will seek improvements to customer experience, drive cost      productivity and increase demand with compelling value      proposition.   12. 2Q02 revenues were $806m, up 21% from prior year.   13. Active customers, those purchasing in the last 12 months,      totalled 27m, up 30% YoverY.   14. Gross profit increased $38m, or 21%, to $218m.   15. Gross margin was 27.1%, up 16 basis points. Improvements      primarily result of Marketplace sales, procurement improvements      and transportation-related savings, partially offset by      super-saver shipping and other price reductions.   16. As result of inbound freight savings and shipment injections,      covered cost of lost revenues from $99 super-saver shipping      offer, allowing migration to current $49 level.   17. Revenues in books, music and video grew 6% to $412m.   18. Books unit growth was 20%, offset by industry trend of slow      growth in music business.   19. Despite significant price reduction and lost shipping revenues,      gross profit rose 12% while gross margin reached 30%, an all-time high.   20. Pro forma operating profit in segment was $49m, up 26% YoverY,      while operating margins increased to record 12% of sales.   21. On trailing 12-month basis, operating margins for the segment      reached 11%, up 300 basis points YoverY.   22. In June, VirginMega.com launched as co-brand with BMV store      powered by company platform. Later this year, Virgin will      relaunch Japan Web site, powered by amazon.co.jp.   23. Launched Canadian Web site, amazon.ca. Partnered with Canadian      company on fulfillment services, launched in capital efficient      manner. Canadian customers will receive shipping incentives.   24. ETK revenues were up 16% to $128m. 25. Gross profit for segment was up 41%, gross margin rose over 240 basis points to 14%.   26. ETK segment loss declined 55% to $18m or 14% of sales, vs 37% a      year ago.   27. During quarter, became Sony reseller for cameras, camcorders,      handhelds, computers and monitors. Opened electronics      relationships with Yamaha, Toshiba and Microsoft.   28. Selection has increased 40% to more than 60,000 items since      12/31/01.   29. International segment revenues reached $218m, third consecutive      quarter of 70% or better YoverY increases.   30. Gross profit was $47m, up $18m or 61%.   31. International pro forma operating loss declined 66% to $10m, an      improvement of $20m vs. prior year.   32. YoverY impact of exchange rates on international segment      revenues was less than $100,000.   33. Optimistic about segment.   34. Sellers and customers enthusiastic about Marketplace offerings      in UK and Germany.   35. Delivery options such as cash on delivery in Japan and      invoicing in Germany attracting new customers.   36. In Japan, surpassed 1m active customer accounts in quarter.   37. Including exports, international revenues represented 34% of      company sales, up from 28% a year ago.   38. Services revenues increased $8m, or 22%, to $47m   39. Gross margin in segment was 61%, down from 68% a year ago.      Expect continued decline in margins over the year as fixed fee      advertising from 1999 represent lower percentage of overall      revenue mix.   40. Operating profit in segment was $6m, up 29% from prior year.   41. Started providing shopping functionality for AOL customers  as      of last week.   42. Will launch target.com, powered by amazon.com, in next several months and expand selection of Target products at company's Web site. 

 C. Financial Review (MP)   1. Fulfillment costs were $86m, 10.6% of sales, down 220 basis      points from 12.8% a year ago.   2. Marketing was $29m, a decline of 17% due mainly to more      efficient advertising and reductions in rates paid for traffic      generation.   3. Pro forma operating profit was $26m vs. a loss of $28m in 2Q01,      a $54m improvement.   4. 2Q02 was third consecutive quarter of operating profit.   5. Operating margin improved 740 basis points to 3%.   6. Pro forma net loss, including interest expense, was $4m, or      $0.01 per share, compared to loss of $0.16 per share in 2Q01.   7. GAAP net loss was $94m, or $0.25 per share, compared to 2Q01      loss of $168m or $0.47 per share.   8. Consider in GAAP results, each quarter company marks      euro-denominated debt to market, which resulted in a charge of      $71m in 2Q02. Also took $23m expense for stock-based compensation, due to upward movement in share price.   9. Cash flow was $48m on trailing 12-month basis, up more than      $200m, while free cash flow was $16m on trailing 12-month basis,      up $285m YoverY. 10. Asset efficiency: Ending inventory of $127m was lowest since 1999, while ability to serve customers with in-stock selection continues to improve.   11. Inventory turns were 19 on trailing 12-month basis, compares      favorably to other retailers.   12. On June 20, prepaid and other current assets increased about      $20m because a credit card service provider unintentionally      failed to make a scheduled payment.   13. Net investment in fixed assets was $220m, down 15% from year      ago.   14. Ended quarter with cash and marketable securities of about      $824m.   15. Had $43m in proceeds from employee stock options which were      excluded from operating and free cash flow calculation. 

 D. Guidance (MP)   1. 3Q02 guidance based on conservative assumptions.   2. It is not possible to accurately predict demand. Results could      differ materially.   3. Focus remains on long-term growth in free cash flow.   4. Expect 3Q02 net sales of $780-830m.   5. Expect 3Q02 pro forma operating profit between $8m and $17m.   6. Remember for 2Q02 comparison purposes that $49 super-saving shipping ran only last two weeks of quarter.   7. Expect net sales to grow 18% for FY02.   8. Expect to have pro forma net income, cover interest expense.   9. Expect $50m in cap ex spending.   10. Expect to generate free cash flow for the year.   11. Cannot provide guidance on GAAP net income. Option-based      compensation results in charge for any movement of stock price      in between reporting dates.   12. Intend to expense stock options and other stock compensation no later than January 2003. Will impact accounting for equity      awards granted after that time.   13. Company marks euro-denominated debt to market each quarter,      result is either non-cash gain or loss.   14. Cannot forecast these items, but they could have significant      impact positively or negatively on operating results.   15. Will continue to strive to put customer experience first.   16. Enter 2H02 with momentum, and pleased to have increased      guidance for balance of FY02.   17. Reaping benefits of scale.   18. Objective of company is to deliver for both customers and      shareowners. 

 QUESTION AND ANSWER SUMMARY 

 Q1. (Sean (phonetic) Millney (phonetic), Soundview Technologies)  Your used products business had a big quarter, trading topline for  margin improvements. Will it grow as percentage of BMV in the next  couple quarters or top out at this level? 

 A. (Jeff Bezos)  That business grew very rapidly this quarter. We'd love to see  retail grow that fast. We're driving for unit growth and we don't  really care if it's Marketplace or owned inventory. It's priced so  that we are indifferent to that. I do expect it to continue. Outside  the US, our early experience indicates same kind of success is happening there. 

 Q2. (Jitel (phonetic) Patel, DeustcheBank Securities)  Have you thought about the timing of opening the technology platform  to a broad class of sellers? From a technology standpoint, are you  ready to handle that? Is there a time frame for that? 

 A. (Jeff Bezos)  We've been working now for almost three years building the various  tools sellers use on our platform. We did a huge buildout for  target.com launch over the last nine months or so. On our list of  projects to do, there are many that will do what you're talking  about, upgrade the platform for parties of all kinds to sell, alongside the detail  pages where the 30m visitors come. And that's just the US number, the worldwide number is much larger. We're not there yet. We've made huge progress over the last couple years. There's still huge progress to come. It works today, it can be  better. We know what we have to do and we have great people working  on it. 

 Q3. (Mary Meeker, Morgan Stanley)  Color on unit growth across business lines? Do you have any customer  growth objectives? 

 A. (Jeff Bezos)  We only give unit growth for books. We don't want to make a practice  of giving out unit growth figures elsewhere. On cost growth, we  expect it to grow. We also expect customer growth to continue. We  also aren't giving guidance on line items like customer growth. 

 Q4. (Anthony Notto (phonetic), Goldman Sachs)  Can you walk through customer behavior in three phases, the intital  shipping offer, before and after, and then moving to the $49 hurdle  rate? Penetration growth and order size? 

 A. (Jeff Bezos)  We're only a few weeks into the super-saver program. We need three  to six months to assess the results. We have to be cautious about  early results. We know these kinds of offers take time for word to  spread. It is way early to comment. For color, we see it has  impacted certain categories more than others. We're studying that as  we consider next steps. 

 Q5. (Anthony Notto (phonetic), Goldman Sachs)  Philosophically you've debated growth vs. profitability, now  balancing both. In 2Q02, you came in above high end of revenues  expectations with record gross margins, then at quarter-end launched  a free shipping initiative that says you want to spend back on  growth. In 3Q02 you're forecasting a record growth rate, highest  since 4Q00. Will you continue to spend back on growth? 

 A. (Jeff Bezos)  Internally we have certain minimum unit growth rates we want to  generate. We are constrained by being able to afford to do so. One  of the most effective ways to hit unit growth targets is by using  price as a lever, whether in product or shipping. For each product  category, we have unit growth rate targets and we adjust our business to meet those rates. We have a hard constraint on the  minimum free cash flow we will accept over time and we balance  those. 

 Q6. (Anthony Notto (phonetic), Goldman Sachs)  So it it fair to say philosophically, in your revenues guidance  range, you're not going to manage above that range? 

 A. (Jeff Bezos)  Your question seems to suggest we have very short-term control over  revenues to bottom line tradeoff. I would not think about our  business that way. So we do the $49 super saver offer in the last  two weeks, that was not designed to increase revenues in the  quarter. It just happened to be the time to do it. It generally takes time for elasticity result to creep into the price decision. These aren't fine-tunable, not measured in weeks, but in months and quarters. 

 Q7. (Marcus (phonetic) Rowland (phonetic), Prudential Securities)  You had a full quarter of lowering book discounts to 30% off books  $15 and above. Do you have a sense of the elasticity? Is there more  room to go? Is $15 the bottom end of elasticity, or can you go to,  say, $10? How does that apply to the super-saver shipping? 

 A. (Jeff Bezos)  There is certainly elasticity if you took that to $10 or $5 or zero,  you would see elasticity there. The problem is you run the risk of  making those units unprofitable on a per unit basis. It costs the  same to handle a $7 paperback as a $30 hardback. There are more  gross profit dollars on an expensive item. The elasticity would be  there but it would not be profitable. Customers would buy more and you're not making money. 

 Q8. (Anthony Notto (phonetic), Goldman Sachs)  So that's getting to the bottom end of the range in terms of gross  profits and margins? 

 A. (Jeff Bezos)  I suspect $15 is around the right level. Whether it can come down  some, I wouldn't want to comment on that right now. Zero is too far. 

 Q9. (Anthony Notto (phonetic), Goldman Sachs)  And on the elasticity of the $49 freight hurdle? 

 A. (Jeff Bezos)  Too early to know what kind of offsetting volume we will get. We  will continue experiment, see what we learn in next two to five  months. In the first few weeks of the quarter, it's very early, but  we are continuing to see good books unit growth. 

 Q10. (Justin (phonetic) (indiscernible), Merrill Lynch)  Can you comment on the competitive environment, other e-tailers and  retailers? Can you gauge the impact of any competitive moves? 

 A. (Jeff Bezos)  We definitely consider ourselves leaders in this space. We're  proactive about our pricing agenda, better than anyone out there. We  understand it very well and get results much faster than anybody  else. We think we know a lot about setting prices where we think  they should be set. In the first few weeks of new quarter, though  early, we are pleased with continued book unit growth. 

 Q11. (Jeff Feeler, Bear Stearns)  If you had expensed stock options this quarter, do you know what the  impact would have been? 

 A. (Mark Peet (phonetic))  No. We do expense options from the exchange offer we made in 1Q01.  We're looking at different ways to offer equity instruments. We  can't estimate the impact. 

 Q12. (Jeff Feeler, Bear Stearns)  If you had expensed stock options this quarter, do you know what the  impact would have been? 

 A. (Jeff Bezos)  Except to say it will be negative. 

 Q13. (Jeff Feeler, Bear Stearns)  If you had expensed stock options this quarter, do you know what the  impact would have been? 

 A. (Mark Peet (phonetic))  Definitely, it will be negative. 

   NS
